text:
Wow - an overwhelming selection of products.
They are coming out for an estimate and I will update after that time.

So far, I am liking it!

We come to this Joann's when we can't get what we need at Michael's or AC Moore - and, as you'd expect, this store is more fabric-focused so we were able to get the adhesive and embellishments my 13 year old needed for a project.

No issues.

Better cookies!!!  Try the Chinese "Jewish Deli" cookies.
Very good cakes - but priced a bit high.  Need 48 hours notice for large cakes.

A good place to know about for sure!

Our 7 year old is a crafting wiz - albeit I am inept at such things.  We visited Jo-Ann on a surprisingly busy Sunday evening.  4 people working in the IMMENSE store (understaffed) but still, friendly and efficient service.  Amber (??) who was running the show, cutting fabric, re-stocking bolts and cashiering was great.

They honored all 3 of our 50% off (single item) coupons.
We got alot of needed fabric, notions, needles and supplies.

LOVE IT.

I love TJ's and this location is no exception.
The parking lot is always packed if you come Monday - Friday over lunch though.

Excellent products especially frozen foods.

This is the location in the Pennsport Shopping Plaza - right next to SuperFresh.  I actually have had great luck in here - and especially during the semi-annual sale events.  Candles for $5.00, old packaging designs for body wah & lotion for $2 or $3.

The sales associates greeted me and were friendly and helpful.

Sometimes the store is very crowded and other times absolutely dead.  I like to shop when it's not crowded - so I like that.

Glad to have one that's not in a mall. (Especially since the one on 17 & Walnut closed).

Most choices were really great (avoid the chickenparm - awful.) like my crab-stuffed ravioli, over broccoli rabe.  St. Louis Ribs were fall-off-the bone tender.

There is a slight "SYSCO" pre-fab element to the food - but for the most part we love a nice weekend lunch here.  Burgers (patty melts, southwest style) are a solid choice.  Upgrading to Sweet potato fries is a good idea!

I jokingly call this place Oh So Mediocre - but really it is pretty good.  The Korean lady who runs the place is very, very nice and always asks about my daughter.  The hot & cold food bar is fairly clean with a wide variety of choices, some of which are actually healthy.  (Be careful - many of the hot foods are loaded with oil/fat).

If you really want something good here, though - skip the "pig bar" and head to the back for a fresh grilled turkey burger.  You'll have to be prepared to wait several long minutes - but it is worth it.  Cheap and tasty - not at all dry.  I got my T-burger with Ketchup, tomato and lettuce.  3.75.

What a deal.
Oh So Good.

Now that I am working in this area, I must confess that I am frequenting Qdoba far too often - however the Craft 2 menu allows me to eat one, save one - and thus not consume the requisite 750 cal minimum.  (Beans plus rice plus any meat choice = about 660 alone).

Also the "new" whole wheat tortilla is 270 cals (not 330).
Additionally, they introduced a slightly spicy brown rice (a few calories less per serving than the white) in February 2013.  I don;t like it though, so I still get the bad-for-you-white rice.

Still, a cheap, calorie-bomb on the go.
Oh - and I have to give a shout-out to Antoine - the cute (nearly looks like L'il Wayne!) cashier who is super cool and friendly.

My husband had a minor surgical procedure at Rothman's Surgi-Center on the 4th Floor and he was well cared for - but there was a long wait (we arrived at 8 AM and he was prepped right away but not seen by the doctor until close to 11:30 AM.  Eek.)

We got outta there just after 1 PM.

Follow-up care and administrative staff seemed good also.
So far so good - I was a Commerce Bank client and now bank at TD Bank by default.  Jury's still out as I discovered an erroneous charge and need to have it investigated.

There are some great little gems tucked away in this part of town.
The Clay Studio, The Wood Turning Studio - there's a bunch of artsy studios, a few BYOs scattered about and yes, tha Park-o-minium and other parking facilities.

Easy walk to Old(e) City - let's not start THAT debate again,  (Whether or not Old City has an "e" on the end of Old.  What ehvs.

Anyhow, I like this area just fine.
Thought this was outta biz?  Is it back?
3-4 stars rating for EVENTS & Ballrooms (we did not stay at the hotel).  The space is lovely and events are well planned and well run here.  And the location is sooooo convenient.

Great cappuccino and other espresso based drinks.  Plus good salads, hummus and snack-y foods.

Free wifi and comfy, homey seating.  Cute barristas (male & female) and well poured shots of eeeeeeeeeee.

Comfortable homey environment.  Beats the hell outta fourbucks.

I'm a fan!

Needed Urgent Care (ER/ true emergency) for our 11 year old and had 5 star treatment from all staff, however we arrived on a Monday night at 6:10 PM and although triaged right away were not seen until around 9:20 PM by a resident.  (over 3 hours waiting and waiting.)

Once seen treatment, diagnosis and medications arrived quickly.
Mikey (female) the respiratory therapist was truly exceptional and a wonderful care giver.
Laura, patient liasion, was terfic and the Doctor - Dr. M. W. Attia is terrific.

I hope we don;t need to come back but if we ever do, we'll be coming to Dupont!

Beautiful facility.

A nice surprice on Walnut Street - a deli with some healthier choices, like fresh cut veggies (carrot, celery, cucumber, green and yellow bell peppers and a few grape tomatoes) with dip for $3.19.

Sandwiches, coffee and grocery items, too.

Wow - I coulda sworn i reviewed Susanna Foo a looooong time ago, but I guess not.  Anyhow - went there again (3rd time) last night and sat putside - which I usually never do.  It was a surprising lovely evening.  I had been here twice before for lunch - which was good but maybe only 3 or 4 stars.  

Last nite's meal solidified the 4 stars.  Service was wonderful and attentive (maybe because they are slow in the summer??).  We stated with virgin Golden Pineapple Mojitos which were truly delish.  FRESH pineapple juice and mint - perfectly balanced.

My dining companion was a close friend from out of town who walked by and wanted to go here.  She is very health conscious and ordered the salmon in a light (not too salty) black bean sauce over a crsip tender bed of TERRIFIC baby bok choi.  It was accompanied by a Cocunt "polenta" that was so silken it tased and felt like coconut flan.  Almost dessert like.

I had a started of an Ahi Tuna Sampler (which I have ordered before and I just love it.).  At $17 it is small and expensive - but the quality of the tuna tartare and the fabulous accompaniments make it somehow worth every delicious teeny morsel.

Instead of an entree I had the COMPOSED  $12 salad with golden beets, candied Walnuts, sliced yellow tomatoes, microgreens in a delectable, sweet but not cloying , light vinagrette.  The salad came with 5 small goat-cheese wontons - that looked like over-stuffed tortellni.

I ate 3 and gave 2 to my partner.  They really didn't do much for me.  The goat cheese inside was almost like a bleu?  Goat gorgonzola maybe?  Too strong.

But the salad and all the other compnents was terrific.

If you think Foo is past her prime or somehow not "all that" anymore - I urge you to give it another try.  At dinner.  (It was way better than the 2 lunches I had previously.)

I had a basic (el cheapo) oil change over my lunch break.  I was told it would take 45 minutes (there were a few cars ahead of mine) but it actually took about 70 minutes.

Guys were friendly and seemed knowledgeable.  Not too pushy about upgrades.

I got a $10 off coupon from the jiffylube website so after taxes and discount I paid around $40.00.

Yes, it's expensive.
No, you can;t do your "regular" shopping here but it is terrific for taking kids.

We came for the "No Kid Hungry" cupcake event (for $3 kids could decorate a chocolate or vanilla cupcake) and the kids (both age 9) loved it.

My daughter loves to shop the bulk candy department and there are some unique holiday gift ideas here also.  Look into their cosmetics (Pacifica for CHEAP!) and chocolate bar sections.

No, it's not cheap - but there are some unique items here that I can't get at Whole Foods (aka Whole Paycheck) nor Trader Joe's.

I confess, I am a Sephora and Ulta shopper - I price compare on ebay, also and it pains mne to pay retail after spending YEARS in the spa industry.  Meanwhile, I stock up on Tweezerman, NARS, Lorac, MUFE (Makeup Forever) and other staples at this Center City location.

The ever-changing line up of staff (usually young overly-made up MUAs) is friendly and usually pretty knowledgable about makeup.  Skin care?  Not as much.

Meanwhile, I love Sephora - and have since its creation.
It continues to evolve.

Needed mass quantities of Guac, Pico 'n Chips for a picnic stat.
Qdoba to the rescue - for $21 and change we had plenty for all.

Upon my teen daughter's pleading request, I caved and picked up 2 take out items at the now-dreaded Qdoba in Springfield.

What'd'ya know?  Everything was fresh and great again.  It helped that there was a new (at least new to my eyes) manager and that we cam at 11:50 AM on a Thursday before the lunch hordes had descended.

Steak burrito and Steak burrito bowl (both with Guac) were both great.

I truly hope the "badness" of the past is in the past.
Management and team makes all the difference.  The female team lead (front counter) is friendly and good!  Give her a raise!

I have been to this Starbucks many times - right across the stress from CVS - and close to my former job.  No issues - very busy during morning rush (as is expected).

Good service and consistent beverage quality.

$5 coffees.  Whoo-hoo!

Now that I work right near this Target, I can't help but run in from time to time for household goods, frozen entrees for lunch on the cheap and of course, a latte from Starbucks.

Lunch hour can get busy - but if you go at 10 - 11 AM (sure, my boss will love that!) it's ded in there.

Weekends?  Another story.  Parking lot is big but gets full and a bit of a cluster getting in and out.

Bonus:  I can stop at Petsmart, too.  And Trader Joes' is walking distance.

Lots of shopping in a compact area.

The desserts OTHER than ice cream are so yummy here.  The gargantuan slices of pecan or apple pie (topped with yummy ice cream, if you wish) are so great.

The sandwiches and soups are good too - but defintiely save room for dessert.  That is what  this place is famous for.  In the old days we'd get cream of broccoli soup here - so good - so rich and a slice of warm pecan pie with ice cream on top.

Mmmn mmmn!
Had another lunch here with the 'rents and this time service was great and we had cappucinos (very good ones) along with the soup & salad.

This corner gas station has been many types or gas station over the 35 years I have known it.  It was a Shell, a BP and even a Sunoco for a while.  Now, it's LukOIl and prices are great.  Usually well below the local average price.

I really love Angela - the owner of the new Wings to Go on the Corner of Vine & 15th.

So, I ordered a bunch of party platters (boneless wings & buffalo shrimp) for a party I had.  Everything was piping hot, fresh and perfect.

I really want people to support this much needed busines on an otherwise "dead" block.  Need wings?  Catfish?  Shrimp?  Corndogs?  Come here to get them.

This is the same as the "Falafel Cart" reviews - same guy on 20 & Market.
Line down the block.

You get what you get - and it's usually good - but I like Mama's better,
Meanwhile, people LOVE this cart.

This remains our go-to Rita's and the young teen staff is friendly and polite - in the summer (evenings) the lines can get longer.  We enjoy an occasional custard or "wooder" ice treat here.

Tip:  Ask for the kiddie size to save calories and money.

Benches and tables to sit at outdoors.

This place is a strong 4 stars - maybe even 5 (but it's just not the same tier as a Nobu).  It's homey vibe and decidedly 2-3 star service (not bad - but weird service - a bit inattentive and spacey - hard to get a check - hard to ask questions) knock me down to a solid 4 stars.

Bright, homey decor and even the bathrooms feel clean and light.  Owner is very nice and has gorgeous eyes.  (Waiter was pretty hot, too.)

My good (lacto-ovo-vegetarian) friend and I had a delicious lunch there today.  I have 2 yummy glasses of the Lemonada (1/2 mint iced tea mixed with 1/2 lemonade - the PERFECT summer refresher.  My friend had Greek Coffee - made the traditional way.

For our lunch he had Shouksouka (delicious) - great for a breakfast or brunch, too.  Very rich and filling.  I had the Kanella platter and for $12 it was the perfect way to sample alot of offerings.  For me the best part were the Dolmades (stuffed grape leaves).  Now, I realize that everybody and everybody's grandma makes 'em dirrefently and Kanella's are distinctively sweet with currants and luscious Pine Nuts.  The falafel, Zucchinni fritter and yogurt were all good too.  The only thing I could not eat was the spicy tomato salad (next time I will order it made mild - if they can do that).  It was soooooo peppery with a "harrissa-like" taste to it.

Baklava was served with syrupy orange slices and was chock-full-o-nuts.  Very good for $3.50!

We plan to return.  But - please - beef uf your staff and service.

I have been taking classes at Fuel House (I buy packs of ten classes for $80) for 2 months now and I have lost over 5 lbs.  I am seriously considering the Unlimited Monthly membership.

There are a few classes that are NOT Zumba - like "Boot Camp" and Tabata (a high intensity interval training 30 minute workout).  There are also a few "easier" classes - which I like since my fitness level is low.

If you are a serious athlete - this is probably not the place for you, but if you are a middle-aged suburban mom with pounds to lose - come on by!!!  It's perfect for me.

I am a huge proponent of food co-ops, locavores, slow foodism, sustainable agriculture and the like - so I was thrilled to visit the medium-sized - very crowded Weaver's Way.

We have very few of these types of food coops in Philly - but when I lived in NYC there were many - in Brooklyn and Manhattan - where you could both shop and participate as a member.

Even though it's not flawless - there is a big space issue - I am so happy to have them here and I will continue to buy my brown eggs, brown rice, and brown bread here when I am in the nabe!

Oh - and they sell locally farmed Christmas trees and greens during the holiday season.

Go Weaver's!!!

A great place to get a salad, pizza or (rich and tasty) pasta for lunch.  Kinda pricey - but the portions (of pasta anyhow) are big.  I can eat half for lunch and the rest later. (dinner!!!)

I have been there now a bunch of times - many for lunch (and it is usually hoppin') and another time for a quick dinner. (They close at 7 PM.)

Both times I had pasta dishes - but my husband had pizza (he said it was good but not great.) and a friend had a salad that he LOVED.

I really enjoyed my fresh fettuccine dish and a was able to substitute marinara for the usual rich cream sauce.

The cashier was freiendly even though she was slammed with customers, and my order was processed relatively quickly.

I'll return.

We had a pleasant first-time shopping experience.  I may adjust the rating once we know the area better and have tried ALL the local big-chain grocers - but for now the prices at Giant were fine, butcher and produce areas were above average, customer service (we got a Giant Card) was good and we found what we needed.

Much nicer than the crappy SuperFresh we are used to from Center City.

I returned to Kanella last night with a good friend and we had a lovely evening.  We shared everything.

We started with the Horiatiki Salad - chopped tomatoes, cucumber, radishes, red onions, parsley and a PERFECTLY light olive oil vinaigrette that literally "sang" in the mouth.  Just the right amount of salt & pepper - fresh, balanced, crisp and light for summer.

We them shared the Boureka (Phyllo pastry stuffed with savory cheese) topped with a drizzle of sweet, floral honey.  The sweet 'n savory combo was perfectly showcased by the beet salad (fresh, red beet chunks and herbs) along side.  It was like dessert for an app.  Swwet and luscious.

Thing just got better & better.

John, our server brought the main entree ($28) a Whole Dorrado fileted tableside (albeit a bit clumsily).  Wrapped in Grapeleaves, drizzled with a fruity Olive Oil and lemon, it was cooked perfectly and we each ate every last bit.  (My friend did discover a few scales on her fish - but I did not.)

Equally wonderful was the side of steaming-hot kale, tomato and onion.  That is just my kinda food!

We shared a dessert sampler (Small $8, Large would have been $12) which came with nutty, crispy baklava, a honey-drenched semolina cake (reminiscent of my Aunt's honey cake).  Both great.  It also came with a shortbread stuffed with a date paste - not so great.

But most facinating perhaps, was the center piece on the dessert plate - a whole blanched fig that we still can't quite figure out how it was prepared.  But, boy was it tasty.  I love fresh figs.

I wish they would add a fresh fig plate or a fruit plate of some sort to the summer desserts.

We brought our own Prosecco, beer & cider and had a lovely summer evening meal.

SUPER!  A hair's bredth away from 5 stars - but certain aspects of service and prep are still 4 star.

Kanella is a place to try - and re-visit.  They are on the move - and it's all delish!

Tbar is a fun place, especially for a tea lover like me.
Now that the Tea place on Sansom is gone (It's now the Chutney Company) and Remedy is kinda small, I go here alot more.

I love the Jasmine Green and a good First Flush Darjeeling, when they have it.

Not a fan of Roibos or Chais but they have those, too.

Bring your nook or kindle and stay a while for a cup or a pot of the GOOD stuff.

Nice iced whites in the summer, too.

LOVE IT!

Every summer my little daughter (who's now 5) and I "play tourist".  Even though we live in Philly - we had never tried the duck boats - and she really wanted to.

We reserved for a Wednesday tour at 4 PM.  It lasted lust over 70 minutes and was GREAT fun.  Our Captain (Crash) was funny and the tour woulda been great for a tourist or someone unfamiliar with Philly.

There were tourists from Brazil, Arizona, Iowa and Florida on our boat.
And since it was not packed we each got our own seat.

Yes, it's pricey, kitschy, touristy and those quackers can me MOST irritating - but if you have little kids this is a fun way to show them the city.

That said - my kid also loved the Double-Decker bus tour.

OK, so Jones Group (As in Jones NY) who owns 9West, Enzo Angolini and many other brands, decided to rip out the 9 West in Liberty Place and replace it with "Shoe Woo" - the new concept that allows a variety of Jones brands to live together all in one store.

Decor is cutesy and brand new - with a few rotating turntables that showcase lots of mid-priced platform heels, seasonal boots and others.

My 6 year old thinks it's paradise.  Boy do they start early!

Sale shoes range from $30 - $100 - not bad if you can find your size in a sale style you like.

Yum, artery clogging, yum.  
Fried Chicken.
Mac and Cheeeeese.

The decor is straight outta the designer's "retro" wish list.  
I can see Marsha Brady.

Great for some nap inducing corporate catering, too.

I'll write more later and elaborate.

This is a nice store - though a bit cramped.  It is not as good as Penzey's though - I bought granulated garlic at both and Penzey's was fresher and cheaper.

The salt-free lemon pepper blend from Spice corner looks promising and the service was excellent.  Nice staff working there.  Glad to see them in business.

This is a BEAUTIFUL pet store - but it is also pricey.  I guess we are helping them pay the rent in pricey Glen Eagle Square?  Right near the Whole Foods - so for me it is convenient - but I can get the Eukeneuba my rescue-mutt likes for much cheaper in Newtown Square at Delchester feed.

For toys and gifts?  this place is great!
Plus they help adopt out cats and kittens.

There is also a clean-looking grooming salon in the back but you pay them to wash your own dog.  (It's like a self-service car wash for dogs.)  I don't see the point in this unless you have a big and very messy dog?  I bathe my mutt at home, so I will not use this service.  I'd rather pay for someone else to take care of the entire bathing process, or else save $$ and do it at home myself.

Nice selection of treats, too.

Absolutely delicious and perfectly cooked burgers that are not too big.  A little more expensive than 5 guys - but much better.

A great place for a haute-fast-food burger fix.

I got mine "Classic" with Cheddar.

No fries, no shake for me.  The burger was just enuf.

I wandered in, as I am new to the area, and ordered take-out (a lunch special - came to 9.95 plus tax).  Next time I will call ahead or maybe dine in.  Took 11 minutes to get the food (was told 15 - so that was great!).

Chicken pad thai was a tad greasy but good and a large portion.  Standard American-Thai loaded with sugar, which I happen to like from time to time.

Tulip dumplings were good but unremarkable.
Thankfully they were steamed and not deep-fried.

I would definitely come back for lunch, but this is still not the greatest Thai food.  Pensylvania - even the great city of Philadelphia still has yet to find me a good thai place.  

The one in Bala is OK (Chang Mai?), and the one in University used to be good.
The Little Thai Market in Reading terminal Market is the best I have gotten.
The 2 pseudo-Thai places in Media both suck.  Sorry, but they do.

So for Suburban Thai?  Thai Orchid is looking like my new place.
The 2 ladies serving were lovely and courteous.
Super easy parking (and you can head to Giant afterward to shop.)

Next time I will do my litmus test of Tom Kha.
See you in about a week!

Big Target with groceries and all "the usual" Target-y stuff.
No issues.

Parking lot, although enormous, is packed on weekend.

Surburbia-typical.

Tara, the manager, is a sweetie and we ordered alot of customized wedding gifts from Papyrus - and Tara took our orderes.  We also get Thank-you notes and birthday cards there.  Papyrus has upscale cards, stationary and gifts.  The store is small - but still navigable.

Although I wound up getting my wedding invitations done at Details (who rock - by the way.) I would certainly shop here (we did - but found a similar design for a bit less money at Details.) for custom wedding and party invitations.

When you shop around - come here - they will have what you need.

OMG!  A bar where you can smoke (and smoke, and smoke).  And they have a cigarette machine ($9 a pack).  A real honest-to-goodness cigarette machine.

And super friendly bartenders (like Mark on Wednesday nights) and patrons.

Classic rock on the "juke box".

Cheap-ass drinks served in plastic cups.

Fun, smoke-filled, drunken debauchery.
A real working-man's bar!

Well, it's 6 years later and Tokyo Sushi is still here and seems to be larger than I remember it.  I picked up a 3 roll combo from the pre-made case at $12 which have 4 pieces each of tuna (fine), salmon (fine) and Yellowtail (surprisingly very good) with scallions - all in brown rice and rather large pieces.

I am pleased and Shall return now that I am back in this area again.

Seems more like a "real" sushi place now and less like "supermarket" sushi.

Next time I will order some nigiri to order.

My only complaint?  $7 - $9.5 for a sinlge handroll (They call theirs a demaki vs. temaki)???
Way too high.  

All in all very pleased and will return - and soon!

Chaotic to shop here - but good values on crafting, art and school supplies.  We come here and Michael's and depending on what 'specials' or coupons are offered you can really do well here.  Back to school time (Late August/Early Sept) is madness.

Holiday season is pretty busy, too.

Not always a "floor" person when you need one - but generally we can wander around and find what we need,

Glad they exist.

While we still prefer Fellini's in downtown Media (not sure if they are the same owner or not - but the menus are very similar) we had a good experience - especially with Jessica, our helpful, friendly server.

Fellini's offers solid Italian (and lots of pasta) dishes.  Salads and Antipasto are also good here.

Crowded as heck on weekends - we squeaked in at 6:45 PM on a Saturday and somehow lucked out - there was a line to get in minutes later.

Love the Chicken with Eggplant in Aurora sauce (rich and fattening - but so tasty.)
Decaf cappuccino for dessert was spot-on!

As said before - BYOB - can get noisy from drunk and happy customers.
Carbo-load!

You're kidding?  I am so sorry to hear about the bad reviews below.  We rented a HUGE pole tent, tables, chairs and LARGE fans for a summer anniversary party for my parent's surprise 40th anniversary in 2006.

We dealt with Mary Beth Brilman (and also got quotes from 2-3 other vendors).  They did a site visit to make sure the tent ewould work, delivered and picked up the items exactly as ordered.

It's a shame that laura and april had botched events.  Mine was smooth as silk.
Closed - now another restaurant on the same site - new name, new menu,

I had a very pleasant 4 star experience an Nooddi - but it is really a 3 star kinda place (needs a makeover!).  But - I happened to get there before 6 PM and got the early dinner special which is a great value.

A cup of Tom Kha soup. 2 steamed crab dumplings (delish!) and a generous portion of Chicken or Tofu Pad-See-Yu.

Loved every bite.
And my wallet thanked me.

Great service - place was empty on a Thursday at 5:40 PM.

No, it's not the best Thai ever - but it'll do and I will be back - and likely soon.
Adorable gifts and toys for children - especially young girls.  Cute stuff - but pricey.  We love it there.

3.5 - 4 stars - a very nice Acme as Acme's go.
I run in here on occaision for fried chicken (or grilled) - when it is fresh, and milk and other things.

Convenient location - and I can stop at Gentile's before or afterward.

We really enjoyed our 3-4 visits to Ly Michael's.  We've had lunches and dinners there.  The thai-inspried dishes are really tasty as are the Chinese choices. The Duck Dumplings (Appetizer) are so yummy.  We also loved our (medium rare) lamb chop entree.

Even our 4 year old (who then was 2 or 3 liked the food.  Service was great - because the place was nearly empty every time we were there.  I hope they get enough business to survive.

A welcome choice near the convention center.
Oh - great specialty martnini's too.  The cheesecake martini tasted almost like the real thing.  (Just boozier.)

My 8 year old just LOVES it here - from musical instruments to jewelry to hand bags, everything is giftable and comes from a fair-trade community.

It's great fun - but a bit pricey - and nothing here is a neccesity - but if you gotta buy gifts, at least here they are unique and helping another community.

We love it!

I returned to Jay's tonight - and this time I put them to the test.  I ordered the sushi/sashimi "pick 3" - and had Salmon sashimi (very good), Yellowtail nigiri (Good - but not orgasmic) and Ikura.

I am VERY picky about Ikura (- it has to be "poppin' fresh) and this was very, very fresh and good. BUT - I get the feeling not too many people order it.

I also reprised the fair Eggplant Lady (appetixer) and she deserves a starring role.  Jay accomodated me with very light on the sauce (both in the shrimp mixture and on top) and 2 lusciously crispy eggplant slices.

It was raining so the place was not crowded, but the delivery was HOPPIN'. (Yes, they deliver, thank goodness!)

Also Jay showed me several goreous salt-molds he makes to serve on the sushi platters.  (Kinda like ice sculpture - but made with molded salt.)

Martin was there, too.

Nice guys at the bar.

I can't wait to take my 5 year old and husband here.  They will love it.

Oh - and did I mention the pick 3 sahimi/sushi was $8.50?  What a deal - the items I ordered would have cost $15 a la carte!

Food is great - atmosphere is ZERO - you are eating in an open kitchen of a Mexican grocery store. 

The people working here are so kind and the tacos al pastor are authentic and delcious.  The sopes are good but heavy for me - so next time tacos!

Delicious Guacamole and home made Horchata and Jamaica (Sweet!).

I am thrilled to have found this place - and they are gonna need more tables.
It is packed at lunch time.

Delicious!

Menta's Sunoco is where I've been getting gas these days - as it is right on my way to the Elwyn train station.  Friendly service - full serve and self (full includes a window wash).

I'll be back.

A brand-spanking new Ulta at Ellis Preserve (a Whole foods will soon be there, too.).  Super clean and well organized and only about 6 weeks open.

I was able to pick up some holiday-packaged gift sets (Like Lorac alter-ego lip glosses) for a good value.  Also you can get gift cards.  There is a small skin care spa area and a hair care/hair salon.

This area will be clogged with holiday traffic soon for sure!

I had to stop in and see what all the fuss was about - and the folks at Ryan's are very nice.  The service was easily 5 star - but the day I came there was only frozen Italian entrees - nothing fresh or hot.  (I wanna come back for the Veal Scallopine).

From a cold cuts perspective it's more like 4 stars. - A great selection of hoagie makings - Hatfield Liverwurst (our pug liked that) and Milk, Sodas, Eggs and Butter.

I want to return and support this local business.

I vacillate between 3 & 4 stars.
Butchers/Delis of this kind are a dying breed, which saddens me.  The world needs more places like this.

Low prices - call in advance for a custom freezer-pack.

I have now had lunch here twice (both times I had fresh delicious salads) and I am a fan.  Good service, clean comfortable booths and tables, and a large bar.

French onion soup was a tad too salty for my taste and pasta dishes (at lunch) are close to $20 so I will pass on those - but for salads and burgers (my dad had an amazingly good patty melt) we will be back again and again.

I returned to Slainte today for a business lunch with about 10-12 collegues - and I have to say my opinion has improved.  For "bar food" my lunch was surprisingly fresh and wonderful.

Our server was lovely, friendly, courteous and very efficient.  (Having my firm pick up the tab never hurts!)

I ordered the grilled salmon salad ($12.99) and they added extra cucumbers upon my request,  The fish was delicious and grilled to perfection - not to overdone nor dry.

The apps we shared included the aforementioned greasy-heavy-cheesesteak springrolls - that the guys seemed to love (I am not a big fan, I guess) and very tasty Chicken Quesadillas.  Plus a generous Hummus plate.

Good job, Slainte!  A welcome addition to this nabe!

P.S.  My colleagues ordered the French Onion and "Loaded Baked Potato" soups and both looked excellent.

I am reviewing the Le Scala offshoot in the COMCAST center.  I have been there now twice - once for lunch (and it was hoppin') and another time for a quick dinner. (They close at 7 or 8 PM.)

Both times I had pasta dishes - but my husband had pizza (he said it was good but not great.) and a friend had a salad that he LOVED.

I really enjoyed my fresh fettuccine dish and a was able to substitute marinara for the usual rich cream sauce.

The cashier was freiendly even though she was slammed with customers, and my order was processed relatively quickly both times.

I'll return.

McCall is a smaller, private golf club - primarily used by PECO employees and clients.  they have a large "ball room" that can accomodate over 100 (maybe over 150??) for a seated affair.

We had a huge business meeting here that included a catered breakfast and lunch - both were very good.  Service is friendly.

Locker rooms are "old school" in feel and the look is a bit dated.

It's an old-school country club feel that is not too snooty.
The small cafe/grill is nice for breakfast or lunch as well.

OK, the hot Aussie bartender is still there (Big plus.) but a few things have changed.  3 of us had dinner at Xochitl on sunday night.
We were made to wait until about 7:20 (at the crowded bar) for our 7 PM reservation.  Not a huge deal, since I was intent on ordering Dona Florindas.

Well, they changed the way they make them and now they use apricot infused tequila instead of pineapple infused tquila - but hot bartender made me one old school.  TERRIFIC.

The 3 of us each ordered the Sunday Special - 3 courses plus Guac for the table for $35.00.  It was a ton of food - and a good value.

The table-side guac was top of the line, as usual.  So delicious.  Once we ate it and had our apps (I had a fresh and sublime shrimp cocktail with jicama and mango) we were too full for the entrees.  I enjoyed my skirt steak with unique "Avocado fries".  My friend special ordered a mixed grill and did not like it.  I felt bad for her.

Meanwhile, DH had the pork and enjoyed it.  I never eat pork, but it looked well prepared.

Since I was so full - I ate about 3 bites (yummy, tender, succulent bites) of the steak and had it boxed to go.  We still had dessert coming and I was jonsin' for churros.  Well, they came out burnt.  Such a shame - as we had eaten them twice before.  DH had the chocolate cake which was rich and delectable and came with a Cajeta ice cream.

All 3 of us had the Mexican Hot chocolate - and I like Xochitl's version even  better than the Aztec one at the Naked Chocolate Cafe.  (Nakeds is too spicey for me.)

So it wasn't quite the 5 star experience that we had on the 2 prior visits - but it was still very, very good.  It just kinda feels like (maybe its the economy, maybe it's just a factor of restaurant age) service and food quality are slipping a little.

Don't get sloppy, Xochitl.  We're counting on you for a 5 star visit when we return.

And I will return (not sure about my friend though.).

Without Whole Foods and Trader Joe's I'd be sunk.
So, Whole Foods - I am be-whole-den to you.

High prices and all - what choice do I have?  My child must have chemical-free, persticide-free, herbicide-free non Genetically Modified organisms on which to feed.

And so I present - An Ode to WHOLE FOODS:

That meat case is impressive!  As are the baked desserts.  The juice bar is a saviour - and sushi never hurts!

O, Whole Foods - how I love thee - though parking really sucks.
A least they'll validate the lot and save me a few bux.

OK - It's realy a 3 star place but our food and service were so nice on a frigid January night that I will round up to 4 stars.

The place is, indeed, a "hut" - you have to walk around outside to get to the bathrooms and the decor is sparse - but Nikita - our server/cashier - saved the day with her congenial manner.

To top it off my friend and I both loved our huge platters of Oxtail Stews in a rich brown saucewith plantains (not dry - very nice) and rice - fragrant with allspice and studded with beans.

A $5 (ouch) side of roti bread was the perfect accompaniment.

I loved my meal - and will return.

Believe it or not we had an excellent time at cracker barrel  with our party of 5.on a not-to-busy Friday night (5-7 minute wait for a table).  The little one loved her food (fried shrimp) and she and my MIL shopped in the gift shop and bought "Mad Libs" and an old-style box of Cracker Jack.  (The little one had never had cracker jack before and wondered about the prize.)

After a carb and fat loaded meal (not good for the diet at all) we relxzed on rocking chairs out front (for sale) and played checkers.

The staff especially Judi (trainer) in the gift shop and Justin or server were all terrific.

Is this my favorite place?  No way.  But it beats Denny's or Perkins any day and you can get pancakes for dinner!

COnveniently located in RTM, this is a great place to grab inexpensive cut flowers.  The staff is friendly and very helpful.

Note:  The also give a discount to PHS (Pennsylvania Horticulture Society) members and often run deals during the flower show.

This is our go-to Rita's - for it's spacious parking lot, clean picnic tables and benches, and sweet teen-aged girls running to show.

Our 8 year old and I both get kiddie sized (ASK)  water ice or custards - and the kiddie portion is PLENTY in my opinion.  I love the coffee custard but is is GONE (forever??) now - so I get chocolate or swirl.

DD often gets lemon, blue raspberry or swedish fish flavored "wooder" ice.

The blendini is fun, too.
And now they have sundaes (unlimited toppings like hot fudge, "jimmies"/Sprinkles, whipped cream and a cherry).  ASK for the kiddie size - it's cheaper, smaller and just as satisfying.

Indulgent and a diet breaker for sure - but a summertime must in PA!

After not coming to the Aston diner in years, our party of 6 had a very nice lunch (specials are a good value and come with soup and dessert) for under $70.  Service by "Barb" was great and we enjoyed the food.

Burgers, grilled cheese, Chicken Caesar salad, Cobb Salad with shrimp (instead of chicken) [$14.95] with mammoth portions (took some home).

Glad things have improved.
We'll return,

Tacos al Pastor - I dream of you...

They are slowly improving the dining area - but still needs work.
meanwhile, for $2.50 a pop I get tacos al pastor - the REAL DEAL and a luscious side of guac (also $2.50).

Pico de gallo here is fresh - but super spicy with jalapeno chunks and raw onion - so bring breath mints.

Horchata is also great.

LOVE IT HERE.  Please open one in Media/Aston!!!

We needed an oil change - stat  - and poor planning had us arrive at Pep Boys 40 minutes before closing.

They took us right away and had us in and out for $26.95 plus tax.

No issues.

Oh - and Klaus (manger from the Wilmington location) is now up here and is very knowledgeable about parts.
It's under (slightly) new management (meaning the boss has changed but most of the front counter ladies are the same) and is still a good place for a quick take-out lunch.

It's big - it's (relatively) new, it's fairly clean.

Pretty nice as major stadium venues go.

As always, wish there were more ladies bathrooms (and cleaner) and healthier food choices.

I had a lovely first-ever experience at Fresh Market.
All 4 staffers I spoke with were friendly and helpful.

They carry Stonewall Kitchen Jams and Sauces - so I snagged a $7 jar of swanky peach jam.  I love stonewall - and if I buy it here I don't have to pay shipping.

They also had HINT water on sale for $1 a bottle - so I got 8 bottles.
I also picked up 3 bottles of Australian Water infused with flower essences.  I am a Bach Flower Essences Practitioner so I am curious to see what it tastes like (should just taste like plain water) and if it works.  

They also carry Vosges chocolate bars and other high end goodies.
Produce looked great - albeit pricey and meat case looked good but I doubt I wll buy any.

I liked it here alot and will be back.
It's a little pricey - but it's closer to my house than Whole Paycheck (aka Whole Foods).

Gorgeous - but it's a shame that there are just so many homeless around - and dogs pee in it.

Meanwhile, it's a treasure - and now that PHS (PA Horticultural Society) is re-planting the elm trees (they died), it will be even more special.

A Philadelphia landmark.

We bought our 2007 Hyundai Sonata from Fred Beans.  Over the years my family and my husband's family have each bought many different cars - new and pre-owned - of different makes from Fred Beans.

Between them and Foster & Kardane (and we were friendly with the Kardane clan back in the '80's) they pretty much OWN the D-town automotive scene.

Competitive prices and salespeople who don't make you feel like a target.

Good repair work, too.

I'm a fan.

I returned to Jay's a few weeks ago - and this time I put them to the test.  I ordered the sushi/sashimi "pick 3" - and had Salmon sashimi (very good), Yellowtail nigiri (Good - but not orgasmic) and Ikura.

I am VERY picky about Ikura (- it has to be "poppin' fresh) and this was very, very fresh and good. BUT - I get the feeling not too many people order it.

I also reprised the fair Eggplant Lady (appetixer) and she deserves a starring role.  Jay accomodated me with very light on the sauce (both in the shrimp mixture and on top) and 2 lusciously crispy eggplant slices.

It was raining so the place was not crowded, but the delivery was HOPPIN'. (Yes, they deliver, thank goodness!)

Also Jay showed me several goreous salt-molds he makes to serve on the sushi platters.  (Kinda like ice sculpture - but made with molded salt.)

Martin was there, too.

Nice guys at the bar.

I can't wait to take my 5 year old and husband here.  They will love it.

Oh - and did I mention the pick 3 sahimi/sushi was $8.50?  What a deal - the items I ordered would have cost $15 a la carte!

Pho, summer rolls, iced coffee, vermicelli, broken rice plates, all the staples in a quick-service format. Mid-priced and great for lunch. Come right when they open at 11:30 to beat the lunch rush.

New digs with a clean restroom. For now.
Old-school (read:  no gas station) Wawa with everything you need.

My faith has been restored in Bistro St. Tropez - or maybe it just tastes better when somebody else is paying?? 

We attended a corporate luncheon (small group - 7 people) here and had great, attentive service - and best yet - much improved food.

Although they do now charge ($3.00) for the delicious hot rolls and pesto, the salade Hache (a chopped salad with chicken and shrimp - a tad over cooked) was fresh and tasty.  The classic Soupe a'l'oignon was rich in flavor, not too salty and had crisp crouton on top.  Mmmn!

The desserts were best of all (and I have NEVER had room for dessert here before, but somehow today I managed it) - ice-cream filled profiteroles and a chocolate mousse cake were shared by all.

Two leaves & a bud tea capped off a hearty lunch.  How we all need a nap, now!
Off to the conference room...

Mandarin Garden has been here For Eh Ver!  And the good food (not the needs-a-makeover decor) is why.  Consistently good "classic" Chinese American mid-priced food.

A local landmark - and right near the train.

Went here today for cake & ice cream with my 4 year old and we had a grand time with great service (sometimes service here is flaky but today it was not).

She had birthday cake ice cream, and adored it.

We split a GI-NORMOUS slice of chocolate layer cake - or shall I say we split 1/2 of the slice and took the other half home - it was THAT huge - and for $4.75 a slice it should be.  Not only was it huge, the loist rich cocoa-rich cake had a delicious chocolate buttercream icing that was finger lickin' good.

A great snack on a sweet summer day.

My faith has been restored.
Stopped in solo tonight out of sheer craving for sushi.

I sat, alone, at the bar and chatted with Alan, Don (sp??) and my lovely server Amanda.  FANTASTIC service - and very good, fresh fish.

I am more of a purist and do not care for gloppy sauces - but the Tuna Tartare (with a bit of chopped mango, avocado and fried shallots mixed in) was perfect.  Fresh tuna - chopped - not minced.

The plate was garnished with at least 4 sauces though.  (All delicious - miso, cilantro oil, mayo, red wine reduction)

3 pieces of yellowtail sashimi (one order) and one temaki (hand roll) and I was stuffed.

I shall return - happily, now!
This is a big Target with everything you need.  They even have a small Starbucks up front.
A generous co-worker bought a huge Mocha cake with rich, delicious buttercream frosting on it and we each had a slice.  HEAVENLY.

Absolutely wonderful and a real lesson for our 8 year old about "how the other half lives".  The show, fairgrounds, food (tea sandwiches an crustless white bread) and staff or volunteers are wonderful and the horses are magnificent.

We enjoyed the carriage event and seeing ladies in crazy hats.

Love these guys!  The name-sake ravioli is delicious and affordable - usually frozen and many varietys.  Great tortellini, too - meat or cheese (I love the meat).  Take it home and cook it up!


The real deal - straight from sou-philly.  Oh - and they support the Mummers - so go to P&S!

MGK is pretty much all I listen to - with occaional tune-ins to MMR & YSP.  DiBella does the AM show and I love Andre Gardner and Breakfast with the Beatles.

It seems like MGK now is like YSP or MMR were in the late '80's.
Classic rock at its comforting best - plus they have "Get the Led Out" at 7 PM and Jones for the Stones.

All good stuff.

The beauty uber-store.  I really miss the flagship location in New York (it closed) but tnow there are Sephora's popping up all over.  Believe it or not, Sephora has really streamlined their brand selections over the years.  They used to carry TOO MANY brands.  Now it's just about right.

Since I am in the beauty bix and hate paying retail - I usually browse and try products here - but buy elsewhere.  However, I will say that in a pinch I run here for things I really need now - like Caudalie, MUFE (Make Up For Ever) and Ojon Hair Care.

This is like the grocery store for me.  Can't survive without it.

I think you mean Dimitri's.

See my other review on this small, cash-only Greek staple with terrific baba ganoush.

The food tastes fine - and the cafeteria style of "design your own" burritos, tacos and quesadillas is catching on fast -but don't be fooled.  It's still fast food - and it is super-duper HIGH in calories.  A typical burrito has 1100 - 1600 calories.  (Naked will reduce it by 330 - as the PLAIN TORTILLA is 330 whopping calories alone.)

That said - I do enjoy the Naked Chicked Burrito, no cheese, small (70 cal) taco-sized torilla on the side.

It's just too hard for me to "hold the guac" and save 220 calories.  That guac - for fast food guac tastes muy bien to me.

By the way - I think Jack-in-the-box owns Qdoba - I know Chipotle is owned by McDonalds.

FAST FOOD - people.
Eat under a health advisory.

5 stars for the food!  What a fabulous find in a Girard Ave. location.
We enjoyed our dinner here very much!

I had a Pineapple Strawberry Daiquiri (BYO Booze) and some amazingly good ceviche - shrimp and tillapia.

My husband's chicken enpanadas were so good, too (I got a bite!).

For entrees he had a tender and flavorful shredded pork with super-fresh corn tortilla black refried beans and rice. He liked it alot.  I really loved the Eggplant Tower - a great vegetarian (NOT VEGAN - it's overloaded with 2 kinds of cheese) choice served over white rice and a home-made tomato & onion sauce.

Desserts are very well done here, too at $6-$6.50 each we tried the banana crepes and cheesecake bunuelos.

Delicioso! We can't wait to come back (The crab & shrimp enchiladas and Carne Azada are calling to me.)! They also do weekend brunch - which sounds marvelous.

Service by our sweet cambodian server (He's a doll!) was attentive and great.

And a big thanks to Eversave (the groupon knock-off) without whom I never would have tried this place.

A super-great find!

A must-see tourist (and local) attraction - but not for small kids - way too boring.
You can get through the Museum itself in 2-3 hours, if you take a tour of Wyeth's studio ($8 extra charge) allow another 75 minutes.

Cute cafe inside but no cpecialty coffee drinks - just coffee, tea and very good food.  (Shrimp & Grits and Kombucha were both available.  Interesting.

An older crowd, for sure.

Barb-Lin Carpets has been a core Doyltestown business for years 7 years.  They offer all sorts of flooring options - not just carpet - and will install it, too.

A good local source for carpetting and floors.

A great place for a quick lunch with a multitude of choices.  The "small" salad is HUGe - and you get to choose your own ingredients.

The have hot pasta and baked potatoes, a few hot entrees and sides each day, subs, hoagies, soups, chili and great sandwiches and wraps.

And the catering a great and cost effective.  Try the STRAWBERRY SHORTCAKE.  (mmn, mnn!)

Also a great spot for breakfast - they do oatmeal well.

Stopped in for dessert & coffee at the lovely bar - and service by Brittany was first-rate.  We shared the molten vanilla cake (like a chocolate lava cake but vanilla and caramel) $11 of pure bliss and a luscious cappucino.

The perfect way to enjoy the view of the city at sunset.

Oh, the fat & calories...

...Delightful

I called the Brookhaven PetSmart to see what their hours were (for grooming as well as for the store) and the phone rang and rang and rang - no answer.

Finally, somebody answered and I was able to schedule an early (8 AM) nail trim for my mutt.  Griffon (the groomer), Rob (store manager) and Ellen (who opened the door  - as I was literally the first person there that day) were all terrific.

Now that the Springfield PetSmart (one of 2 in Springfield) closed, we'll be coming here for grooming, food, treats, supplements and whatever else our pooch might need.

Still, nothing can compare to the prices at DelChester Feed up in Newtown Square.

PetSmart is kinda like "Giant Food" for us.  We have to go, so it is nice to have a new (opened late 2017), clean, reliable PetSmart nearby.

Thank you Griffon.

Fun to take the bridge by train - can get crowded by car.  you can see the river and the Camden Riversharks stadium.

Nice.
My kid loves it!  Free entertainment just blocks from our house.  Nice at Xmas, too.

Upgrading my review - the staff here are lovely and we attending a competition here (The annual "Challenge Cup" and it was so smoothly run and wonderful.

For a single surface and old (1938) facility, it's still a great rink.

Ate here one day at about 2 Pm for a late lunch out of sheer desparation with DH and 9 year old kiddo.  Kiddo bitched and moaned at first b/c she wanted Subway.

She wound up very happy with her basic chicken & cheese quesadilla - no pico.
She also liked the guacamole. And demolished the side of black beans.  (Who knew - kiddo eats beans?)

DH & I each had "the usual" naked burritos (burrito bowls) loaded with beans, rice, meat and toppings.

A calorie binge - but worth it.
We got in and out and back on track.

OK, first let me make it perfectly clear that I don't DO truck food, but today I was absolutely STARVING and this cart (Near Drexel/Hahneman) on the North East corner of 15 & Race - which usually has a huge line every day - was nearby.

So for $3.50 I took a leap of faith and got beef w/ broccoli (no sauce) over brown (aka fried) rice.

It's good.

Really!

I might even come here again.

Friends don't let friends spend fourbucks on Charbucks!
That said, I occaisionally splurge on a $3.00 iced latte served up by Brie (sp??) at the Passero's in Suburban station. Or a lovely Cafe au Lait for $2.45 in the afternoon.

The roasted-bitter espresso they use still has a good flavor and the service far supasses that of Charbucks.

Passero's is some of the best coffee in the city (that and La Colombe) - so I will be back.

Budget permitting. Love it here!

I don't get to come here very often any more - but when I do I try to come when the place is DEAD EMPTY - like today - a random Thursday at 2 PM.  Dead.

As a result?  Fan-tabulous service from Stefan (from Serbia) and the lovely bartender (Jamie?  James?).  Seriously - great, great service.

The food - as always - is solid but mabe just a few tweaks could up the game even more.  I especially enjoyed the crab salad (made for the burger of the month - but I asked for a side of it and they were so kind to oblige me).

Jose, baby, you done good!

I love it here when I get here at 11 AM and the lunch rush has not hit yet.
Today I ordered by phone and waltzed in and out with my Green Lemonade (a must), Sweet potato fries and a veggie burger.

So hip.

So city.

So veg.

So cheap?  (Not so much - $15.64 for those 3 items)

LOVE IT!

Want the Fifth star?  Get a BATHROOM, please.

We attended a corporate party at the DuPont country club and it was great.  The club itself seems as though it has been around for-eh-ver.  Old school ballroom decor.  Nice restooms, dancefloors, place for a band, terraces.

Good for weddings, parties and large events.

Food was surprisingly good - pasta station, carving station, crepe & dessert waffles with BIG fresh berries.  Also a sushi bar brought in by Okura in Hokessin.

Good stuff!

Never disappointed at VW - especiallyy when I split a burger with a friend (the kitchen will gladly cut it in half) so I can indulge in a 1/2 order of lobster mac & cheese.  Decadence!


No room for anthing else - except for a $14 shot of whiskey.

Mmmmn Mmmmn good!

We came here for the 3rd consecutive year to place our balloon order for our little one's birthday bash.  They were out of some of the Mylar designs we wanted. 

Also the costumes for kids were NOT cheap - ours cost $24.95 - which isn't awful - but Target had similar cheesy costume for cheaper.  Masquerade definitely has way better selection of sizes and types of costumes though.

Asusual in October it is a PACKED madhouse.  We got there at 10:20 - they open at 10 - but drove by at about 9:50 AM and there were people waiting to get inside.  Wow!

Bought a second Hyundai Sonata from FB (A 2012, we also have a 2006).
Got about $500 in "credits" for buying a second time (whoopie!).
So far, so good - we've had the car about three minutes.

MUCH better experience this time - very friendly service and almost NO LINE - but it was 4 PM on a HOT (100 degree) Summer Saturday.

My 11 year old got a TRENTA aka "vat" of green iced tea.

We needed this!

I love Trader Joe's at holiday times for inexpensive food-oriented gifts or for throwing a party (great frozen treats and hors d'oeuvres ), I also buy a few frozen lunch meals here like the Shells with Brie and Asparagus and the "Reduced Guilt" Mac 'n Cheese.

That said, I can't give TJ's 5 stars because I can not get ALL of my grocery shopping needs met here.  Yeah, yeah, you can get bread, milk and eggs and WAY overpriced meat here - but I can't do that.

I shop at TJ's for "fun food", Whole foods for "organic" food and Giant for "normal middle class" food.

Glad we live in the USA and have options.

Wow - such awful reviews for this place.  Sure it's sky-high prices - but you are paying for the convenience factor.  Decent produce, frozen foods, dairy, meat and prepared foods.

I go here for emergency purchases, certainly not to do my everyday shopping.

GLad they exist.  Grocery stores are few & far between in Center City.

Took el Kiddo (who is now 9) back to Comacst for the Christmas 2013 show - and it was very nice this year.  Some parts were the same as in prior year's and at least one segment seemed new.

The show is once per hour (sit on the floor unless you are lucky enough to snag a bench) and lasts about 18 minutes.

Free and fun for kids and families.

Excellent lunch-time fare - but man, oh, man the crowds at 12:45 are just CRAZY.
Meanwhile our order came quickly and the gals up front and hard working gals and guys in the back really know how to WORK IT.

Excellent Customer service.
Great Food. - I have the Udon Salad and a Green Lemonade.

I'll be back - and SOON!  (But next time at 11:30 or 11:45 - I can't deal with the crowds.

A nice, relatively new and very clean Qdoba with amazingly no line at 12:15 on a Monday.
I zipped in and out with my taco salad bowl.

Good stuff - no issues.

3 ladies running the front counter were pleasant and delivered great customer service.

I will be back - and likely soon.

Ditto and Tritto wehat they already said!  I usually get the (enormous) platter.
You get what you get and you don't get upset!

Mama's Falafel is good, too.  (Right down the street.)

A lovely old-school, well-run condo with modest-to-high monthly fees - and a pool in the summertime.  Garage parking is available for an extra charge - but there is plenty of free parking in the lot out front.

There are 3 buildings and you can walk to "downtown" Old Jenkintown and to SEPTA - but I'd  get lazy and drive.

Still some of the best coffee in the city - and still a line (that moved pretty quickly) every morning in Suburban Station.

Pricey but so much better than Dunkin or Charbucks.

The Café au Lait and Lattes (the will used your favorite type of cows or nut milk) are so delicious.  Like dessert in a cup for breakfast (and I don't even get any flavored syrups - just a plain latte or au lait is so creamy and sweet.)

Yum!!!!

CHOP is a godsend - and we just HAPPEN to live in Philly.  They have the BEST doctors in the UNIVERSE who are specifically trained in rare illnesses and conditions of children.

I pray we don't have to go here often - but we already have had one harrowing experience which involved taking our daughter (then 4) to the CHOP ER after she fell from a shopping cart in Superfresh.  She was bleeding from her nose - but did not hit her head.

WE were seen in triage within 3 minutes and then waiting about 10 minutes to be put into an ER room.  Then the real waiting began.  The Nurse saw us right away - but we had to wait 40 minutes to see the doctor.  By then the bleeding had stopped and she was pronounced OK - and she was acting her "normal" self again.

Meanwhile we REALLY had to wait for the billing information to be processed.  That was a drag because now it was after 10 PM   (we arrived at 7:30 or so initially) and our tuckered out 4 yo just wanted to go home.  (and so did we.) 

And they spelled her name wrong - more waiting to correct that.

So 5 stars for great doctors and state-of-the art facilities (the give you a pager prior to triage) and 2-3 for lousy administrative skills.

I agree (as I usually do) with Alice L.  This is pretty much what we did growing up as kids.  The park is great in Spring & Summer - but at Xmas t is a historical treat.  

Great park!

This is a review for corporate/banquet events and not for staying at the hotel.
I attended a 150 - 200 person conference here ate it was very well run and the food, service and facilities were far better than similar hotels at similar price points.

The dinner was just OK (salmon was kinda dry) but the buffet lunch was actually GOOD.  I have eaten many corporate "rubber chicken" dinners - and the Crowne Plazaz K of P handled our group very well.

No issues with audio/visual, A/C temperature was good (not too hot, not too cold).

I would definitely consider holding a future event here.

I love the larder for bulk foods and gift baskets.  Back in the late '80's and '90's they were the only game in town.  They have teas, coffees, spices, grains and candies.  It's alot of fun to poke around - though nowadays you can get alot of these items more cheaply on line or at Wegmans (There WAS NO WEGMANS back in the day).

The ladies who originially opened it (they've been around a looooong time) I think no longer own it.  But the gals working there are always pleasant and helpful.

If you are in D-town and need a gift basket of food items or just want some yummy treats for yourself, check out the Larder for sure!

I have past by this stripmall bar a bazillion times but never wanted to go in. Last night my friend who is a Delco native, dragged me in there for her old high school reunion.

The bar was PACKED with middle-aged ex-Sun Valley graduates.  Renee, the lovely and gorgeous hostess, sat us at a table. 

At 9 PM a live duo began jamming out 70's and 80's covers.  They were pretty good, too.

Best of all, we even got Mary, our overworked server, to smile.  She brought us some surprisingly delicious food including a Mammoth-sized wedge salad. 

I literally ate a head of lettuce.

Lettuce and vodka. 
I was a happy camper.

So pleasantly surprised by this neighborhood jawn with solid food, drinks, live music and terrific service.

We love you, Mary!

We stopped in (had a 6:15 reservation) as a party pf 5 for Opera Night (a $4 charge PER PERSON so be aware) on a crisp autumnal Monday.  Not too crowded (the Monday night and $4 charge helped with that I am certain!) and the service was just fine.  Note:  Please tell people when they call on Mondays about the $4 charge.  We had no idea until we saw it on the menu.

We heard 3 arias by Heidi and one included a very talented tenor - can't remember his name.

Caprese salad makes a good app for 2 or 3 to share - delicious fresh mozzarella balls and a mound of lettuce (lettuce??) and fresh basil in the center.

Entrees included an uber-rich gnocchi Gorgonzola, spaghetti carbonara, ravioli marinara, chicken parm (for the 9 year old - and she loved it) and my dish - Shrimp Scampi.  Delicious and HUGE - nearly everyone took something home.

No room for dessert - but other people's looked great.

We love Fellini's and are so happy that they are now open for LUNCH on weekends - so maybe, just maybe, we can take our parents there next time.

Since then we have been back for weekend lunch a few times and it is very good (Try the Linguine alla Vongole).  The only complaint?  My 9 year old does not like their hot chocolate.  Says it is bitter.  However, I love their cappucinos!

This is one of the best CVS's I go to.  Love that Extra Care card with it's Extra Bucks.  Also if you have a prescription at any CVS you can re-fill it at any other CVS.

This Doylestown branch (near the train station) is clean and well run with friendly staff.  
I'll be back!
So grateful to have these guys on our street - mulch, gardening supplies, rakes, hardware.  NEEDED!!!  Also propane for our grill.  Definitely check them out.

If you liked Vic's in the OLD Days (when Vic & his wife first opened) you'll like Jay's.  Jay (and Martin) worked with Vic for a while.  Many of the crazy (and a bit over-sauced - get your sauce on the side - problem solved), calorie-laden specialty rolls are just like Vic's but sub lobster for crab and have different names.

My first visit (a few minutes ago) I ordered 2 things - tuna dumplings (divine) - and the eggplant lady.

Both are apps. - but that was just perfect for little ole me.

The $7.50 order of 2 hand-flattened tuna pouches came bursting with a slightly sweet, slightly spicy mixture of lobster (real) and crab (fake) salad with masago and avocado.  Creamy, fattening, non-traditional goodness.

The $4.25 eggplant lady (I will re-order this for sure) had 2crispy-thin tempura slices of purple japanese eggplant.  The eggplant was luscious, crisp slice was topped with chopped shrimp and (fake) crab salad (more avocado, masago, kewpie - like my hips needed THAT!), topped with sliver-sliced avo and eel sauce.

(Next time - no sauce.)

This is NOT a place to get traditional nigiri.  (The tamago is frozen, and there's no way that Inari is home made)  It is a place for "fun-food" rolls as a treat.  Purists won't like it, but Phat-Philly types should LOVE it here.

The service was Excellent - but Jay is new and eager to please.  I anticipate visiting againsoon - and I'd bet money on it that the 6-seat sushi bar (and tables for about 14 more - It's bigger than Vic's - andthey actually serve you your drinks) will be MUCH more crowded.

So in summary:  Sushi-newbie?  Great place for you.  Fresh-fish, sashimi purist?  Probably not.

For me - there is a time and place for everything.  Tonight was my time for the 2 month old Jay's.

I sure hope the quality doesn't deteriorate in 6 months.

A surprisingly GOOD experience with Dorjee (our Teppan chef) and our server.
Excellent Sunday-lunchtime service for our table of 10, celebrating a birthday.

The lunch menu is a good value - the "Lunch Boat" - I chose salmon - a teeny piece of salmon - comes with sashimi, edamame, tempura (all in small portions - perfect) and soup/salad.

My daughter (age 12) devoured the tuna tataki app. and a plate of nigiri.

We enjoyed the food and service, while watching the onion volcano.
Nostalgic.

A hair's bredth away from 5 stars - the food, deluxe cocktails and service are 5 star - the cramped, crowded digs and icky single bathroom make it down to 4.

We stopped in for drinks and were not at all disappointed.
Wonderful bartenders who explained every exotic sounding thing we asked about.  Great selection of draught beers and ales (even a cider on tap).

Love it!

GET THE BURGER!

Wow - nobody's yelped Poor Richards yet?  
This branch is the "new location" - the original location is on State Street right in the middle of Doylestown.

For 35-40 plus years Poor Richards has been a Doylestown staple.

Poor Richards is a unique shop.  Is it a gift shop?  An antique shop?  A craft lovers place?  A furniture store?  It's abit of all of these things.

A great place for tourists and locals alike to poke around and make discoveries. Great decorative items for home and hearth - and often you'll find the perfect gift here, too.

A strong 4 stars for Village Whiskey from me!
A good friend and fellow yelper squeaked into the bar at around 8:45 PM on a snowy Tuesday.  There just happened to be 2 great seats waiting for us.  (I don't know if this place is worth a long wait)

Service from Sasha was excellent and she is so friendly and helpful.
We started off with an order of fried pickles and shared the DELICIOUS pickled artichokes.  (These are the best thing I tasted that night and worth a re-order)

My companion had a delectable veggie burger topped with a fried egg (Wowza!) and guacamole.  The lady next to us had a beef burger topped with an egg as well and they sure know how to fry an egg here!
(Incidentally the couple next to us also shared the duckfat fries topped with shortribs and cheese sauce - looked so heavy - like a heart attach on a plate.  I bet it ROCKED!

Anyhow, we continued with an order of "tater tots' that were so rrefined they'd put Ore-Ida to shame.

And an order of pickled golden and red beets that I wound up barely touching and had packed up to go.

The best thing to me?  The delicious lemon oil-scented whipped ricotta that accompaied the pickled dishes.  Also a tasty tapenade and fresh, thin slices of baguette.  Nice!

I will definitely come back here.

What a cute (albeit small) "retro" feeling place.

Even with the mixed reviews I had been wanting to try Spasso for over a year.
Last night - a slow-as-heck Monday night was the night to do it.

While this may be a truly 3 star place, I am giving them a 4 for the excellent service we got (along with $4 cape-codders) at the bar.  The caprese salad was not the best - it was served with iceberg lettuce (who does that??) and was swimming in low-grade olive oil. For $5 on happy hour it was fine.  Normally it's $8.50 and I would not order it again. (Which is a shame because I love a good caprese.)
Bartender was cute and very personable also.

Dinner was better - we were seated right away (dining room was only about 1/4 full) and our (young, pretty) server was perfectly fine.

Food was actually great - veal with spinach and crab-meat served with al dente fettuccine.  Large portion so I took 1/2 home.  My friend had veal parm - which looked average.  (Veal was deep fried underneath the sauce and cheese. Chocolate mousse cake was OK for dessert but the cappuccino was Excellent.

I can certainly understand why some don't like it here as there are many unprofessional chinks in the Spasso armor.  The dining room below the chair rail MUST be re-painted.  It is a deep brown color and everywhere a chair has bumped there is a white chip out of the paint (looks bad).  Also the female servers and hostesses tend to collect in a gaggle at the hostess stand or by the kitchen and chat (they were bored and it was slow ) - or out back for a smoke.

Not truly a 4 star place - morel like 3, 3.5 but we had a great night and I am feeling generous.

I'll be back for happy hour for sure.

I shop at the Wilmington TJ's when I am working near there.  
The parking lot gets crazy around lunchtime on weekdays - but other than that the lines are never ridiculously long and the staff is great.  So friendly.

They have lots of cool "fun" foods at TJ's.

I rarely ever get to the Comcast Center anymore - so today a friend and I met at 11:40 AM - just in time to beat the lunch rush and the long lines.

La Scala made her vegetable sandwich on focaccia (huge and fresh) to order, as did they my chicken florentine - no cheese.  HUGE portions. - Worth the 12-15 minute wait for the cooked-to-order hot meals.

$10 a pop after tax - but big enough for lunch and dinner!

Our office uses Crocodile Catering (and a few other companies) because that are reliable (never late - which is key here) and have "safe" choices.  Salads are fresh and sandwiches are plentiful.  We usually get a cold breakfast (bagel platter and cut fruit bowl or a Sandwich/Wrap platter with salads for lunch.

I have not tried any of their hot food options.

A solid option for business/corporate catering.

GORGEOUS.

Shi-Shi.

Pricey.

That about sums up floribunda.  They will do large or small event floral design.  Fresh or silks arrangements.  They do great things for rich people who need home decor.  The ladies who run the show are nice.

The do have a parking lot but it gets full quickly.

Check them out.

Another wonderful (and huge portion sized) meal - this time for lunch on a Sunday at Fellinis.  The Shrimp Scampi, Veal Parm, Caprese Salad, Chicken Scarp and Linguine with Crabmeat (in a red sauce) were all terrific.

Great service, and re-done restrooms!

Love it here.

5 stars for our service today from Lallo.
Also the new dinining room is great.

Some of the BEST cappucino we have ever had.

The only thing preventing 5 stars?  Too loud!  Crazy-loud - even at lunch time.  (The ceilings maybe?)

Thank G-d for CHOP - the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia - one of the finest Children's Hospitals in the nation.

Yes, mistakes are made, no hospital is perfect - but when our (then) 4 year old fell out of a shopping cart and nearly broke her nose their emergency and triage teams were speedy, accurate and so caring.

The only bad part?  The administration - we waited over an hour for them to get our insurance info - with a very tired 4 year old.  We just wanted to leave.  This could have been handled better.

But the care we received?  Top-Notch!

Pina's Pizza has 2 or 3 locations around Doylestown, but this location in Chalfont is where my family are regulars. So much so that Anna Maria set out Diet Cokes for my parents before the car was even parked.

She knows us all by name.
So the service is always 5 star.

The food is good - solid Pizzeria staples and cheese-steaks.  Deliciously garlicky garlic knots (with chucks of garlic - you will need to brush after wards!) and fresh salads.  The cheese on the caprese is fresh and wonderful.  

Portions are generous.

We love it here and return over and over.

Plus - Anna Maria gives us mini canolli for dessert.
Wow!

Fellini's Media is a BYO located in an historic building - the site of an old Cigar Shop.  The place is PACKED especially on weekends - we showed up (no reservation) on a Saturday night at 7:45 PM and lucked out.

The placed was a cacophony (sp?) inside, but we managed to snag one of the 2 outdoor tables on a September night that was not hot and not cold.

FAB!

Rose and Chris (and about 3 other server/bussers) were terrific - and man, were they workin' it.  Our bread, butter, ice water and bruschetta arrived right away.

Soon after, our HUGE, moderately priced entrees - Chicken Contadina for the husband, Penne Sophia Loren for me.  (Took half home - so nice, I'll eat it twice.)

A great spot for sure, in Media.

5 Star service from Vera (hostess) and our amazing and attentive server, Kaitlyn.  Wow - we were seated outside on a hot, sticky, humid Father's Day and Kaitlyn was just on point!

Our party of 6 truly enjoyed the sweet potato fries and fried brussels sprouts (sans bacon) which we all shared and wolfed down.

For entrees we enjoyed a variety of burgers (brioche buns), flatbread, "power bowl" and a "healthy" salmon on pita called "The Edinburgh".  I would totally come back here.

Great place for families at lunch and a different, noisier crowd at night.

Chicken Caesar salad and Matzoh Ball Soup (sans balls) were both great and delivered to my door by a caring friend.

I would definitely try them again.

2 words are all you need to know:

Strawberry. Shortcake.

End of story.
Has been serving up law firm cakes for years.  Decades even.

Yes, please!

Stopped in on a whim for a quick bite and boy am I ever glad!  They have alot of great Korean food (bi-bim bap with tofu is a winner!) as well as sandwiches and salads.

The owner/lady/cashier is a doll.

Love it here.

Had not been to Fellini's in a few years - yes years.
Went with a group of 5 ladies about a month ago and again tonight.
We sat in Juana's section both times - and Juana is a terrific server.

The food can vary from a 3 to a 5 depending on what you choose.

The burrata appetizer (special) and caprese (on the main menu) are always safe and delicious lower-carb choices.

The pastas are terrific but alas, I can't do the carbs any more.

Solid "classic" Italian-American dishes.

There's a very special place in my heart for the crummy ole 'WYCK.  First of all - they served me drinks when I was about 15/16 years old - but that was many years ago - I won't say HOW many.  So a star for the underage mem'ries.

It's also the place I had my first ever Rob Roy.

You can get all the old school cocktails here - and beers on tap and in bottles.  The food is surprisingly good and safe.  They used to serve a tasty cheese ravioli - but that was a long time ago - not sure if they still do.

But man, that Rob Roy - what was I thinking????
A beautiful symbol of Philadelphia's growing Chinatown community.

I have never eaten in the restaurant, but this review is for the EXCELLENT job done by Karen and her team.  They catered a dessert corporate event for my company and everything was beautifully presented and delicious.

The desserts included moist two-bite cupcakes in chocolate, vanilla and (was that) carrot with a coconut frosting.  Decorations were so cute.  Lemon squares, brownies and a gorgeous key lime tart.

Along with lemonade and iced tea (I, of course, made an Arnold Palmer) it was just right for our event.

Brava!

I now have NO excuse to not come and eat at Curds & Whey.

The Cookery Ware Shop has been a Peddler's Village shop for years & years.  The service is GREAT and they have EVERYTHING you could possibly want. 

Better than Williams Sonoma - family owned, great selection.

Con?  Tourist pricing - but again - no worse than Williams Sonoma which has high retails prices.

I got a crepe pan here 3 years ago and used it until it literally died.

Great little gadgets, too.  Fun for the home cook.  For the professional chef?  Not so much (it pains us to pay retail).

Just like the Haru mini-chain in NYC.  Over-priced and over-hyped.  Nice maki and fresh fish with a good selection - but NOT a Holy Grail by any means.

The ceviche appetizer, King Crab dumplings and Yellowtail hand rolls are always tasty.

Still, I love Shiroi Hana best for its un-pretentious feel and super-fresh fish.

OMG this target is so clean and new.  It even has a small starbucks and a Pizza hut in the front.  Compared to the Target on Columbus BLVD this one it pretty ritzy.  I found what I needed so I can't say that I agree with @robyn h.

I use Megabus when I can't get onto Bolt Bus.
They are both good, cheap options to get to NYC fast from Philly.
A much needed upscale version of wawa - with sandwiches and convenience foods, plus beverages and yogurt.  Sorely needed so I am thankful it's here.

The Porch - the newly constructed slab of fresh sidewalk and tables & chairs - provides FREE miniature golf all during July 2012.
Concerts at lunchtime.
A new Farmers Market on Wednesdays (11 AM - 2 PM thru beginning of October) complete with Mom Pops (YUM - read that review next!).

Check them out - and let's help get 30th Street re-re-revitalized.

M. Butterfly was the first "real" sushi bar to open in D-town.  Now sub-lplanted by Ooka and other competitors, they are definitely on the high end for price and quality.  The sushi here is just plain better than Ooka - but you PAY (dearly) for the organic wild slamon (we did a taste test and ordered nigiri in the "regular" sake and the "organic" and there were distinct differences in color, flavor and mouth-feel.).

They also SOMETIMES have "real" wasabi root - ground fresh.
For $5.00 an order (which they didn't tell us when they asked me if I wanted fresh wasabi (which of course I said "yes".).  The $5.00 was a little shock to us when we got the bill.  But not nearly as shocking as the total.

WOW.

I was getting better, cheaper stuff in NYC.

Ah well - they are doing their best.  Very good fish and good meals - just bring money - you'll need it.

This review is for Mexican Post Express (the one in the bottom of the Comacast Center).  I am so happy they now have a Mexican option in the Comcast Center.  

While I am not a huge fan of the sit-down branches of Mexican Post (we have often been to the Cherry street location, which is near our home.), the Express offers a less expensive option and is great for lunch.

They also participated in the Yelp Spring Festival and had muy delicioso Spinach Flauta.  I hope they'll add it to their every day menu.  (But somehow I doubt that.)

So, muchas gracias to Mexican Post Express for offering the hungry lunch crowd a quick and tasty burrito, taco or enchilada.

3 or 4 stars from me for Coffee Beanery inside the Concord Mall.  The lady attending the counter on a quiet weekday morning at 10 AM was personable and we had good service.

I have an Iced 1/2 caff latte and my friend had an iced (regular) coffee.

No issues.

Therapist - 5 star, experience at the spa - about 3.
The waiting room at 9:45 AM on a summer Saturday was like a zoo - with 9 people waiting for their 10 AM appointments,

Over crowded and not relaxing at all.
They don't even give you a robe & slippers - it's basically a waiting room - not a spa lounge at all.

However, all was forgotten once I entered the treatment room (nice) and had a great aromatherapy massage. $80 (Tips must be in cash - not on credit card so know that before you go.)

I will be back.

We had a perfectly fine experience at the Springfield Mall outpost of Tar-jay.
DD got some "littlest pet shop" toys, I got an OXO vegetable peeler and DH browsed for Nintendo DS games.

All in all - mid-length lines (not short but not disasterous) a decently clean rest room and predictable target merch made for a decent experience.

We shop Target - here and otherwise.

We had a wonderful event here for 32 (yes, 32) people with a set menu and everything was great.  Eduardo and a team of about 4 servers/bussers were expedient and muy friendly.

The Salmon Manchamanteles ("messy Mole") was terrific.  Vegetarian Enchiladas and Skillet tacos looked great, too.

Sides of rice with pepitas and black beans with cotija were brought to the tables for all to share.

Dessert of tres leches cake or flan was simple.

Prices run higher here - but it's a yuppie/affluent area.
Can get VERY loud.
Mike (Mark?) the red headed bar tender was patient and wonderful.

You can even take your kids here.  For real!
