Stopped in for lunch and would up ordering the eggs Florentine - and they were PERECT.  So satisfying on a cold wintery day.  It was very busy (They do a big lunch business).

A go-to lunch spot or for "breakfast all day".

Old-school décor.  Pay up front.

This is a review of the Panda Express in Granite Run mall.
And maybe 4 stars is a bit much - but they were definitely more than 3 on the evening we went.

We are NOT fast food people, - and usually fast food Chinese is very low on my list.
But DD loves the Orange Chicken (yes, it's fried) and Honey Walnut Shrimp (also fried - and shrimp dishes cost extra at PE) so we went here. Steamed veggies on the side (instead of lo mein - that they call chow mein - or fried rice).

Clean, friendly staff - brought us our kids meals - free refills on fountain drinks.

They even have their own restroom (cleaner than the one in the mall).

We'll be back! (But not too often - it's not so good for our diets.)

We have been Zoo members for 2 years now - as we have a 3.5 year old.
For members, the zoo is a great deal.  The free parking alone is a great bonus.  We also don't feel pressured to see the entire zoo in one day, as now we can visit whenever we wish.

The Zoo also has a "treee house" just for members - but it is not airconditioned and gets very hot..

Also they do not sell milk - only sodas - so if you are nutrition (and cost) conscious - pack drinks and snacks for your family.  It is shameful that there are not more healthy choices for kids to eat here.

I am not a big Indian Food lover - but I do love the breads.
That said, a group of 4 coworkers (including me) went for lunch here and indulged in the $8.95 lunch buffet.

Everything was fresh (We arrived right after 12 noon) and not too picked over.
I enjoyed the Chicken Tikka Masala (very mild and basic), rice, Saag Panir and fresh naan.  Galub Jamun for dessert is always a treat - and Chinnar's is good.

We also ordered a freshly cooked (off the menu) order of Aloo Paratha (Bred with potatos) and that was terrific.

I prefer to order freshly cooked meals over the buffet - but for $8.95 you can't beat the selection and value.

Next time if we come for dinner I want to try a lamb dish.
And yes, we'll be back - likely soon.

We have lived in the Packard Motor Car building (a Reinhold property) for over 4 years.  We enjoy the convenience of the location and many of the ammenities the building provides.

The property is generally well-maintained and well managed.

We do have a FEW gripes - the most significant being the energy-wasting drier that is very, very old and will not be replaced.

Other than that, we love our gorgeous apartment (many units have been recently renovated and look great) and enjoy living here.

UPDATE:   We moved out after 6 years when we bought a house in the 'burbs.

So pleased with the service and beverages (hot coffee drinks, iced lattes and smoothies).

They also have free (but very slow internet) computers to use.

The (male) owner is very kind to us and my 9 year old loves the hot cocoa in winter and pina coloda smoothies.

Oh, this is a conflicted 4 star review - and brace yourself - it may be a long one.  My husband and a close (vegetarian) friend of ours finally took the plunge and went to Chifa for dinner on Halloween night.

Decor is 5 star - and gorgeous.  Everything from the restroom to the blue & white tiles on the walls, and tons of flickering votive candles at night.

I do have to say that the service was EXCELLENT - from the hostess and our server, Melissa, right down to the ceviche chef.  Everyone was friendly and accomodating to our various requests and questions.

From reading these reviews, I am sure by now you know that Chifa serves small plates (perfect for sharing) and that some are smaller than others.  You may also have read about the hot, cheesey bread balls served with a spicy guava butter.  They are, indeed, AWESOME and I scarfed down 2 of them without even realizing it.

We started our meal with a round of delicious - if overpriced ($12 a pop) - cocktails.  The guys had glorified Shandies - Ginger liqueur, fresh lime juice and beer.  I had a virgin Pineapple Ginger concoction that was made w/ REAL, fresh golden pineapple.  It was so tasty & refreshing.

Then came the famous buns.  The BBQ tofu bun (we subbed tofu for pork belly) was so terrific - possibly the best bite of the night.  The tofu was crisp and blissfully glazed in a hoisin BBQ sauce.  A dash of spicy mayo on the white steamed bun.  Yum.  The Pork belly was (likely sous-vided - they have gone sous-vide CRAZY here.) very fatty - but hey - it's pork BELLY.  Belly as alot of fat, right?  Well, I preferred the tofu.

Anyhow - we progress onward - out came the egg mcmuffins - no really, I can't remember the name, but they were corn arepas topped with Oxtail, a PERFETLY done egg (a bit runny but not slimy), crisp bacon and (here's where Chifa loses major points) tons of gloppy peppery sauce.  Thankfully, and thanks to YELP, I knew to order my food with "sauce on the side" or "Light on the sauce" - and this was my mantra for the evening.

My veggie friend had the Chinese Broccoli, and as others have said, it was way too oily.  Literally swimming in a sesame oil sauce.    He also had a vegetarian version of the Chaufa rice.  I tasted a bite and it was complex and delicious - if a little heavy on the (surprise) salt.

Yes, folks, it's true.  Chifa has potential to be a real, true 5 star joint, but they are too heavy handed with the salt, oily, sauces and seasonings.  The ingredients they use are top-quality and need to be able to "sing" for themselves.  I am not saying to under season them, just please don't OVER season them.

Next came the (much, much anticipated) Lobster noodles.  I knew to ask for this "light on the sauce" and it was still swimming in a rich, creamy, slightly red-peppery sauce.  Succulent and buttery-sweet hunks of lobster and fresh, green peas.  The noodles were perfectly cooked.  I would totally order this again (and the tofu buns, man they rocked).  But next time I'd go even LIGHTER on the sauce - I can't imagine how over-sauced it would have been had I not asked for light sauce.  

Ok.  Whatever.  You get the point.

Anyhow - we're not done (Oh, and by now I CANCELLED our order of $38 wagyu steak - as I knew I'd be too full to eat it.) - Out came the curried goat (get it  for one - it's more than enough).  This is a unique dish - and not my fave - but hubby liked it.  Served with freshly sliced bananas and more of those light fluffy buns along side.  Plus a weird crispy lentil cake.

And next came the (yes, they are greasy) scallion pancakes.  Not the best I've ever had - but the cauliflower sauce (yes, really) was super tasty.

Oh - and Chifa is really weird about "coursing out" the meals - the served us a single bowl of broccolli after the buns and before anything else.  If we return, I will try to tell them what we want first (Like, the Waygu!!!)

By now we are all pretty stuffed, but we just had to have some Chai tea and Banana-Pumpkin funnel cake (too greasy for me - but somehow, I ate it!  Ha!).  The banana ice cream quenelle along side it was home made and PERFECT.   The odd honey-anise tuile?  Not so hot.  Thankfully, once again, I asked for the strange spicy peanut sauce ON THE SIDE.

Garces must be commended for his creative menu, but I fear there is just a little TOO MUCH going on in each dish.  Too much salt, too much sauce, too much fat, etc.

Also they sure are getting full usage out of their brand new sous-vide machine.  Nearly all the meats are sous-vided (and yes, they are tender to a fault) - but what about some good ole pan-searing?

OK, I am a spoiled, jaded, ex-Manhattan brat - but I really did enjoy our 2.5 hour meal here and WOULD return - especially now that I know what to get and what NOT to get.

Chifa, you are sooooo close to 5 star - but some of the dishes were really 2-3 star.  (Brocolli, Scallion pancakes, Desserts need work.)

We'll drop in for buns 'n beer

Great customer service from Dontae and my food was ready in a flash - even during a busy Thursday lunch rush.  Line moves quickly.  Tables get crowded, so I carried out.

Excellent choice in fast food if you stick to grilled nuggets and super food side.

For $15.95 we purchased an ice cream pie (fed our crowd of 7 easily with a few slices left over) - graham cracker crust, cheesecake flavored ice cream and garnished with whipped topping (likely cool-whip-type) and pecans.  Much more popular for Thanksgiving than pumpkin pie.

Delicious.  In fact - we liked it so well we ordered it again for Christmas Eve dinner/dessert.

Great job on the ice cream pies, ladies!
Our 4 year old (who has been coming since she was 2) loves it here. What chilkd wouldn't?  There is so miuch for kids to do here.  It's great! We are members.

I'm sorry - but I LOVE the flower show - and have been 6 years in a row.
Some years are far better than others.  A few tricks?  Never go on a weekend - take a 1/2 day off from work and go Tuesday or Wednesday after 1 PM.

Bring bottled water with you so you don't have to buy it there (convention center prices) - you can even pack a lunch.

Buy roses (and irises etc.) from the Marketplace ($6 - $7 a dozen is a steal). and bring a shopping bag with you.  Great bargains on gardening tools, too.  (PHS members get a 10% discount at MOST - not all - stalls).

Go!  It's worht it - and if you become a PHS member your tickets are included in the membership price.  (Makes it really worth it).

We held a conference here - including a breakfast buffet and lunch buffet.
Service was good - a little "slow on the draw" in some areas but every request we made was eventually addressed.

Main "room" felt a little "barn like" with a high ceiling and thus hard to keep adequately cool (without being freezing).  Alternated from too hot to too cold when the A/C cycled on and off.

Had over 200 people in attendance.

Food was tasty and hot items were hot (and cold items kept chilled).

No water glasses on tables (you had to pour your own).

Not 5 star by any means - but a strong 3.5 stars.

Located inside the bank - you can get a luscious latte, a hot white chocolate mocha, salted caramel cocoa and other caloric coffee treat as well as muffins and bagels.
They also have a limited amount of salads/sandwiches and soups for a quick lunch.

My tall (small) iced latte was not too expensive ($1.90 with tax) and our 8 year old enjoyed her cocoa with whipped cream and tiny chocolate chips on top.

Female barrista was friendly and fun.

Great service and a clean restroom.
We'll be back - and soon!
This is a very nice, well run, clean Chipotle.  My Chicken Burrito Bowl was a bit too spicy for some reason today - but otherwise - it's just the way I like it.

Cafe Riviera provides a lunch buffet of hot items (with cold pasta or green salad along side) for our corporate cafe once a week and man, is it ever delicious.

The meatballs, Italian sausage (with peppers and onions) and Chicken Cacciatore are classics and so well executed -even for a mass buffet.

So pleased - and now I wanna go to the restaurant!

A very solid 4 stars.
We dined last night as part of a large (11 people) private group with a set menu.

Mr. Pete at the bar is a love, and kept the Prosecco & Chambord flowing.
He also made virgin "bikini cocktails" for my 7 year old.  

Michael is terrifc and got the little one some non-truffled fries and chicken fingers - which she (of course) enjoyed.

For the grownups, crispy artichokes were punchy with lemon - delish - but the plain arugula bed they lay on was boring and bitter.

Entrees were much better with a luscious campanele pasta with a rich mushroom sauce.  The chicken, served with tasty brussels sprouts (I'm a fan!) was delighfully presented.  Our friends had the fish which also looked great.

We could not stay for the dessert course - but we will be back - and hopefully soon.

This would bve a great place for a party or private event.
Fantastic waitstaff (Dennis, you rock!).
Accomodating, friendly and fun.

This is the new outpost of NCC in the Duane Morris Building on 18th Street.  It is more spacious than the Walnut Street Branch and has the same basic menu of items.  (Yum-my!)

It is much larger than the 13th Street store and can accomodate private parties upstairs.  They also have a bakery onsite and thus have a few more varieties of cupcakes and baked desserts available.

The new NCC also has elaborate tea party set ups complete with gorgeous china teapots and cups/saucers for sipping tea (Harney & Sons) or that awesome sipping chocolate.  (A little goes a long way.)

Oh, my hips!!!

This review is specifically for the terrific makeover I received at the MAC counter by Cynthia.  She is a bit older, experienced makeup artist and made me look FAB.

I like many of MAC's products and the $55.00 minimum purchase to have your look done is really no biggie - once you pick out a few items.  I spent more like $100.  (Ssssh - don't tell my husband.)

Anyhow - give Cynthia a try at MAC - she knows what she's doing and is not pushy at all.  I really enjoyed meeting her.

Went for lunch again with a coworker.
Chicken Tikka Masala is excellent.

Freshly-baked Naan (even on the buffet - you can get a fresh basket of naan included).

A lovely selection.
Price is now $9.95 for lunch - we must have goten a special or something last time it was $8.95.

Not a big deal. - for $10 you can eat yourself silly.

I am not a big Panera girl - but I have eaten in quite a few of them.  Went here for lunch when it was crowded but not crazy (when it's crazy I won't go.)

Monday - Friday ferom 12 - 1:30 the joint is packed with pharmaceutical folks wolfing down their salads, soups and sandwiches.

I got a 1/2 size salad (plenty) and a cup of delicious lemon chicken orzo soup.
I wish they offered that one more.

Salad was on romaine and it was boring but fine.
Soup was very good.
Came out for about $10.

A good quick-fix for lunch.

I was having a challah emergency (and they only bake real Challah on Fridays - appropriately enough) but I got 2 braided Briche rolls that looked like little round mini-challahs and it worked out fine.

Thank goodness they were there!

I have also had the odd croissant and breakfast treat here - very good stuff - especially their almond croissant.  Soooooo flaky & buttery and good.
OK, I give 'em another star.  I took my 4 year old there for the $5.00 Tower Tour (15 minutes to go up, look around and come back down).  She WUVED it!

A colleague of mine prdered a huge cookie and brownie tray from Panera for an office event and the cookies (HUGE - and about 450 calories a piece) were delicious.

The Chocolate Chipper and Double Chocolate with Walnuts (and white confection pieces) were snapped up in minutes.

I did not try the brownies but they looked great and also disappeared.

Quick and easy - plus they have a drive through. (The morning coffee rush is a bit hectic).  I usually get an iced coffee (I walk in) during the summer.
They have everything a basic DD has - coffee, donuts, sandwiches and cold drinks.

No issues from me - but I do not come here a whole lot.

Really good food and great Iced Coffee - pus decent service (but it was really hot in there this last time we went for lunch.

The Chicken over broken rice (or banh) is great and the Chinese broccoli  in garlic sauce was crispy and tender and cooked to perfection.

And you can get flaming rum drinks, too - though we never do.

Love Vietnam for a quick comforting meal.

Should be called the "DiBruno's: market - although there are several other shops.  A Capital Teas, Tabouli, an Asian Place and a great Flower shop.

Only 2 places selling fresh produce.

1 fish market.

Clean and fun to visit.
Bring money.  Parking can be tough.

Fantastic Food - including Kabobs and Gyros and a terrific lunch special for $7.95.  Very small place and super casual.

Quick, friendly service and delectable sides like Cauliflower & Sabzi!

Yum!!!!

I come here whenever I have a 10 or 15% off coupon that I get in the mail.  If you buy stuff on sale here you can get some nice "gap-ish" quality kids clothes for a decent price.  (Better yet - shop at a Children's place outlet and use those same coupons.)

My daughter who is now 4 wears a size 5 or 6 here.  I think the label sizes run small because at 10 months old she wore and 18 mos. or even a 2T.

The sizes go from 0-3 mos. up to 14-16 - but I can not imagine that any "cool tweens" over 11 who dain to shop here.  It's a KIDS store.

Also when they have end-of-season sales you can get some good deals.

The saleslady here (one of them) was especially nice and event the bored-out-of-her-mind security guard helped me find what I was looking for.

I like to shop here.

When I moved to Philly after spending 10 years in New York City (1 year in Brooklyn) the diners here were a let-down.  Meanwhile, I am so happy to find the Oregon (I prefer it to the "classic" Melrose).  They have great old-school waitresses full of spunk and bite.

The food is terrific and the Italian Dinners (Chicken Francese, Cacciatore, etc.) are enormous and restaurant quality.)  What a deal.

Salads are fresh and crisp as is the attitude of the patrons.

LOVE this place with or without my 4 year old in tow.
Viva the Oregon Diner.

We came at the end of the day (around 4 PM) on Sunday so the shelves were fairly barren - but my 11 year old and I shared a HUGE Mexican cookie/cake and a churro (delicious).

Lady helping spoke little English but had a bright smile.
Inexpensive.

Wish they offered a place to sit and eat,  (Philter - a cafe is next door).

Very welcome treats!
CASH ONLY.

At last - I am a Tony Luke's virgin no longer.  And what a way to go.  It was a gorgeous day in November for philly and DH & I went to Tony Luke's but the line was so long that we decided to go acrosss the street to the sports bar.  Afetr a round of fried goodnees - DH had the cheese fries and I had some really outstanding O-rings - we were on to our main attraction.

DH had a cheese steak with Provolone and it was terrific.
I enjoyed a garlicky plate of Veal Scallopini that was kickin' in old school.  This was THE $#!T - for real.  Mushrooms, green peppers, onions and tender veal (wish there had been a bit more of that) in a garlicky, olive-oily sauce that reminded me of how my Nonna woulda done it.

Um.  If I'd had an Italian Nonna.

Can't wait to go back and try the Chicken Sandwich with Spinach.

I am sold on Tony Luke's.

My ex boyfriend LOVED this tiny gem of a tobacconist.  He is/was a cigar afficianado and this place had some rare cigar that he had been seeking.

I like a puff or 2 in good measure - but am no "knower" of all things cigar - but this was a nice, friendly little shop right in the center of D-Town (wedged in between the Fountain House (aka Starbucks) and Buck County Coffee.

Cigars & Coffee.

Who would have thunk it?

The 4 stars is for the burger - I did not try any other items (Fries, mayo or shakes).
I got soggy sweet potato fries at L'il Dans - FAIL.  (But that's another review.)

The burger itself was on the rare side - and I had the special with a fried egg (perfectly done - a bit runny but not raw) and cheddare cheese (subbed for swiss), lettuce tomato and scallion mayo.

Perfection!   (And a calorie bomb.)

Can't wait to visit again - but not for at least 4 weeks.

$9 for just the burger.  (That can really add up if you get a $3 soda or $4 fries)

4.5 stars.  We love it here and are members.  Our 4 year old adores the "Big Dig" exhibit and everyone (even bug-phobic me) likes the butterfly area.  (Wear light weight clothing - it's hot and very humid in there.)

This year the Academy had a free Members night for the members and it was great fun!  Membership pays for itself if you visit more than 3 times.

Bring food/snacks - the Cafe has a limited selection - but better than some.
Pizza was dried out & nasty - but they did have yogurt, frui8t and other healthier options.

Went here last night for Lexi's big bash and it was such fun.  We had a choice of 3 beers, a white wine, a Merlot or 2 cocktails.

I had 2 of the Mojitos and they were very sweet and easy to drink.  (I'm sure Sprite was in the mix).  They also had a Sake Sangria which was Orange-Juice colored and full of fresh fruit.  I did not have it but Anjali did, and she seemed to like it.

They also served plates of thinly-sliced crsipy sweet potato chips (yum) with a supposedly-truffled, truffle sour crea.  It was tasty - but I detected little to no truffle - I was like dipping in pure sour cream.  OK - but just OK.  (Fat City!)

A few people ordered some small plates of food and everything looked nice, but I did not try any.

Pearl (now AKOYA) has re-vamped its look to be more of a club/bar and less of a fine dining place.

Many of the menu items remain, but the menu is more streamlined and focuses on muchies with an Asian flair.

Not bad.  

Oh - and the bartender was a hottie and VERY attentive to all of us.  (He was workin' it.)

This review is for RAW - inside Boyd's.

Raw - the sushi & sake lunge from 12 & Sansom - opened a 2nd branch inside Boyd's Department store on the mezzanine level.

I just had lunch there today and for $13 it very well may be the only thing I can afford at Boyds!

Delicious yellowtail bento box was a steal at $13.00 and came with yummy salad, miso soup, rice, gyoza, 2 bacon-wrapped shrimp and FABULOUS tuna tartare.

I'll be bag.

And maybe I'll snag that Ferragamo dress or $3000 cashmere knit top I spotted today.  Or those fabulous Black & Gold D & G Stilletos.

I have to give B&N a BIG positive shout-out for supporting my child's school.  once or twice per school year we have a B&N day.  Teachers can make a wishlist of books they need and parents can purchase them.

Also any purchases we make that day - using a code - a portion goes to help the school.

It's a great program so I am really thankful to B&N for this.
Even our purchases at the Starbucks Cafe (most of them anyway) count!  Excellent.

Such a cute place for gifts - at the holidays it gets crowded - but Quincy's is great shopping all year-round.

I love to support stores like this - owner-operated local non-chain businesses.

Full of nostalgia and charm. And hostess gifts.

Ate at Azie on Main in Villanova (It's around the back of the shopping center next to the STAPLES) as part of a large group - 27 people - in a semi-private room.

We had a set menu which was very good - but I have a feeling the "regular" menu is even better.

Good options for pescetarians.

Nice service.  Gorgeous decor.

Will be back soon.

It's mall sushi - and believe it or not - it's safe and decent.
My 5 year old loves the "free examples" (that's what she calls free samples) of the Cali roll.

Last time we got her a whole order of California rolls and asked the guy to cut them into 8 instead of 6 pieces (which he kindly did) and she ate them ALL.

Note:  I have never had any Nigiri here (I'm too scared/food-snobby) but for a cooked maki - no problema!

I happen to really like L'Occitane's Shea butter based products and the Verbena fragrance line, so I was/am pleased that the Walnut Street boutique is near my office.

At holiday time they have some good deals - although I was able to snag the hand cream trio CHEAPER at Sephora down the block - slightly different packaging - same great products inside.

Staff are friendly & helpful.

We had a positive experience with the service department.  I called about 2 weeks ago when our dryer broke (no heat) and Tina - who answered the phone explained a few things to me about dryers (no, we did not have a clogged vent or tubing) and then their policy.

It costs 79 for the guy to come out and if there is a fixable problem they apply the 79 to the labor (99 minimum charge) and parts.

It would up costing $169.60 to fix our broken heater (coil was busted) and he had one right on his truck. I wrote a check but could have also used a credit card.

The only complaint?  I was told 9 AM - 1 PM and they came at 12:45 PM (still technically on time, but I waited almost 4 hours).  I wish they could have 2 hour windows - or more repair techs.  Our guy (Rob??) was getting sick and working his a$$ off.

Tina was a doll.

I will call again if we ever need to - but I pray we won't need to often.

Lately, my office crew has wanted to go to Panera so i have now been to this one quite a few times and have my "pick 2" order down to a science.

I am starting to actually like it here now - I always ask for an apple instead of the bread that comes with the meal.
If I get a beverage I blow about $12 (close to $13) so I try to just get water.
Otherwise my choices are about $10 - $11.

I like to stare at the baked goods in the case but I never get any.

Awesome selection of PRICEY gear and sections dedicated to yoga, pilates.  (Which I love.)  Also children's wear (limited selection).

They have a free yoga class on Sunday, too.  So neat.

Plus there are big photographs of local fitness professionals (Pilates Teacher, Karen Pecarsky among them).

I'd give it 5 stars - as it's a gorgeous store, but the prices are just Soooooo high.  But if you just have to have that custom $45 yoga mat - go for it.

It's very fun to browse here, I just wish i could afford to do more buying.

Having lived in Doylestown from 1977 until 1988 and visiting often ever since (family still ives there) I have seen the hospital grow, grow, GROW into the large complex it is today.

The emergency room is well managed, and the "regular" hospital is run by a caring trained staff.  Great doctors, nurses, P.T.s, the works.

So glad they are building a new parking facility.  They need it!

I was sooooo pleasantly surprised by our group of 5's dinner (yes - try it for dinner - less crowded than the lunch rush) at a huge table (that can seat 7 or 8) in the D-town Panera (fairly new location).

While prices are a bit high for "cafe style" fast food - the soups and breads are tasty (if not caloric) and our 8 year old loved the $11 Shrimp Sandwich. Plus - somebody's gotta wash the real nowls and flatware they serve on (This is not a Saladworks!).

Some items took a long time to come out - but were worth the wait.

We'll be back for sure.

Duck Deli (so named for the original location in Duck, NC) is a great find for BBQ in Bucks County.  The owner, Chris, is terrific and the Duck Deli catered a "Backyard BBQ Bash" I threw for my husband's surprise 30th birthday in 2007.

The mac 'n cheese, pulled Pork, Beef Brisket and smoked BBQ chicken are terrific. For a lighter idea - get a caesar or house salad topped with 6 grilled shrimp.  (Big ones!)

The iced tea and lemonade freely flow into big ball-jar mugs.

My 3 year old daughter loves it - but always asks if they serve Duck.

No Duck is served at Duck Deli, but we love it just the same.

Between OK and Iovine's the RTM has your produce needs more than adequately met.
I usually check Iovine's first and then head to Ok's for whatever did not appeal over there.

They also have good prices on bananas.
Some of the discounted bagged produce you must use it right away (use it or lose it).

Cute place.  I hope they make it.
Expensive coffee drinks - along the lines of Starbucks or Burlap and Bean.

Easy to get out (or in but not in (or out) since they are right on 252 and if there is traffic getting in (or out) is bad if you need to make that dreaded "left turn".

Good customer service and I love to support local businesses.

I'm a Chipotle fan from back in my Manhattan days - so I was glad to see one open in Warrington.  While I must admit to liking Qdoba a tad more - Chipotle is my go-to place for a Burrito Bol (Naked Burrito) with Chicken, Black Beans and Guacamole.

It's fast and cheap - but watch those calories - I never get cheese and rarely get sour cream so I can justify that guac!

This bracnh of Chipotle is in a stand-alone building (did it used to be the Pizza Hut - I forget).  It has a cool-gray ambience - a bit industrial looking.  We usally get take out, though so we don't really care.

On the Sunday afternoon when we last visited, the place was loaded with families with young children.

No issues for me - but I usually just use the ATM here.  The teller experience is not one I love, so I tend to avoid going inside unless I have to.  That said - my kid participates in TD bank's summer reading program (They give kids $10 for reading 10 books over the summer) and they are so nice to her.

After watching numerous cups of iced tea, "fairy tea" (a red herbal and berry tisane) and sweets come out of Zen Den, we just had to try it for ourselves.

The clean, new, wood-floored decor complete with comfy seating will be a huge hit - as I'm sure will be the La Colombe coffee.

We though the Lemonade was just "OK" and the sweet tea urn was surrounded by fruit flies which kinda skeeved me out.  So we opted to mix the Lemonade with a bit of the unsweetened black tea and a few ounces of the orangey iced green tea.

Meanwhile, the brownie was just OK - a weird (soft - almost confection-like, fudge?) spreadable consistency.  More like a candy or fudge than a brownie.

Odd.

We'll be back - but won't rush back.

Wonderfully spacious and clean ladies room!
Beats the hack outta Charbucks.
Good service from the cute young highschool "boys" behind the counter.

Went to a private event at Boyd's last night for Philadelphia Collection 20101 (Philly's version of Fashion Week).

The theme was Bella Italia and they had great food from several vendors including DiBruno Bros., Yogorino, Le Castagne and more.
Plus a DJ, live opera singers and models who posed as mannequins wear prada and gucci etc.

They had a Vespa and a Maseratti parkes out front.

It was a blast!  And my 5 year old came too (despite aghast looks from salefolk) and tried on a fabulous pair of purple & black velour Prada shoes. (And some $1300 Manolo's - she's a gal after my own heart.)

I swear I'm gonna buy them for her the minute her feet are big enough.

Too Cute.

For cheap Chinese - this place is great.  Inexpensive, relatively clean and safe.
The lunch specials are usually what we get - as it is near out office.

Also try the steamed dumplings (Get the watercress kind - they seem to be home made.).

Service can get slow - as they are usually under staffed (1 waitress and the mam-san Owner/Manager) during a busy lunch time can be a bit harried.

The used to give out free ice cream - but that is over now.  (They made it past the 6 month mark.)

Did I mention the prices are sooooooo low?
It ain't Susanna Foo - but for 6.99 for Shrimp & Broccoli with brown rice (not too gloppy either) I'll be back!

Oh - and they WILL deliver.

I used to work at the Mercer Museum - as a summer day camp counselor and arts & crafts supervisor MANY, many years ago.  I don't know if they run a kids sumer program here any mroe - but the one they used to have was great.

Anyhow, the Moravian Pottery & Tile works was built of  steel reinforced concrete by Henry Chapman Mercer to erve as his workshop and still produces lots of gorgeous tiles to this day..

Kids and Adults can both learn from Mercer - either here or at his home, Fontill next door.

You can also get married on the grounds and it's a great place to have a picnic in the summer or fall.

Once again my (now) 9 year old and I made the annual pilgrimage to Macy's, the Holiday Light Show and Chritmas Village (Dicken's).

She loves it - BUT - now the show is every 2 hours.
It's mayhem.

They need to go back to every hour or 30 minutes.

Also - to have your picture taken with Santa is free - but the photos start at $16.99 (plus tax).  OUCH!

Excellent food and service from Mike at the bar and Paul our server.
The Salmon Manchmanteles never disappoints me.
Echiladas Mixtos were tasty, too - as were the shrimp tacos (app) and Flauta (app).
Do not miss the Watermelon Margarita.  ($5 off at happy hour).

Hot churros and Tres Leche Cake were delicious.

Love it here.

They catered an event for me with cold salads (mozzarella balls, pasta etc.) Very good food and decent prices.  Will use again.  I should clarify - they made the food - but I had to come pick it all up.

Still - a great option.

While I would never buy a dog here (and you can adopt cats here for free.), I am upgrading Monster Pets fish & aquatic department.  We bought a 50-cent feeder fish (goldfish) for our kid - and with proper care and advice, she is thriving in a cute 2.5 gallon take with a few decorative plants.

It's been almost a month - and I hope this little fishie will have a long and healthy life. We go great advice here on first-time goldfish ownership.

Oh - and we buy oodles of Eukeneuba dog frood and Greenie Pill pockets here for our pug.

This is our local Bruster's and it is open YEAR ROUND - though much more crowded in summer.  The gals runnin' the show are friendly and kind to our 9 year old who LOVES the orange & vanilla parfaits (5 scoops of ice cream/sherbet is an obscene amount so she eaits it in 2-3 sittings.)

We like it just fine.
Have been back several times now.

Still a solid, inexpensive choice for classic chinese - take out or dine in.
For $7.50 - $9.50 you can get a filling lunch special (small charge for brown rice).

I ask for whatever I get to be "light on the sauce" and It's always saucy anyway.
I enjoy the Chinese Eggplant with tofu or chicken and sometimes I ask them to add string beans or broccolli for $1 extra.

FAST service.
LOW Prices.
A solid lunch-time pick.

Super yummy ORTGANIC chocolate treats - and adorable packaging.  Those cute little ladybugs are awesome party favors or gifts.  You can get them alot more places, too, nowadays like RTM and farmer's markets as well as online.

Love the little bumble bees, too.

Yes, they are expensive (but check out other high-end cholatiers - and they are within range) but you get what you pay for here.  GREAT packaging and deliciousness inside.  (The raspberry filling is my fave - I am not a mint lover.)

Keep up the good work J&K's!

Browsed for $200 - $300 Michael Kors Watches which my kid wants.
Did not purchase (yet) but the saleslady was very nice and humored us while my kid tried on a myriad of fake rose-gold-toned watches.

4 stars for the drinks and 3 for the food at the bar (we sat at the bar for the 4 - 6 PM Happy Hour) with Jet.  He made us a delicious hot toddy and Irish coffee on a cold day.

Apps are pricey - even on the happy hour menu.
$10 shrimp cocktail came with 6 large, deliciously seasoned shrimp and a vodka cocktail sauce.  Very good.

Can't wait to return.
Menu is small but lots of good choices.

I have been to a few corporate events & seminars here - and also eaten at Keating's River Grill (separate review on yelp).

Most recently I attended a meeting on the 2nd floor in a large ballroom.

AV and amenities were just fin and the open bar and appetizers afterward were surprisingly good.  Vegetable crudite (including blanched broccoli - not raw - nice touch), Cheese and crackers,  EXCELLENT mini crab cakes with remoulade (real crab - very little filler - YUM) and deep-fried dumplings (deep fried is noy my fave).

Bartenders and servers were so friendly and pleasant.

I would consider having an event here - maybe even a wedding if you are into a "ballroom" style wedding.

Great views of the river.

Humanely raised, chemical free produce, eggs and meats (lamb, pork and poultry).
Available at the Media Farmers Market on Thursdays (and Bryn Mawr on Saturdays).

Love the $4/doz. Brown eggs and $9/lb bacon.
Got another lb of bacon in September, too.

LAMB!!!!

Will consider getting a 4 pack of duck breasts next time and definitely a T-giving bird!

LOVE THEM!

Credit Cards for orders over $25.

A close female friend and I dined at Stella tonight.
The weather was sublime and we sat inside - but right by the LARGE open floor to ceiling windows - so we had the best of both worlds - inside and al fresco.

We BOTH ordered a plate of the special app - a gloriously fresh mozzarella and heirloom tomato (yellow, orange, red, brown and purple) salad.  It was lightly and PERFECTLY dressed with a basil infused oil and a sweet balsamic (decent quality - not the cheap stuff, but not the 17 year old either).  It sang on the palate.

I am hankeing to try the meatball and risotto app - next time.   (And there WILL be a next time.)

Next we split a pizza.  Let me preface this by saying that I am not (shocking, I know) a pizza lover.  I am a pasta lover, but never really "get off" on pizza.  

Stella's pizza is very, very good.  (My friend says it's better than Osteria - but the pie she had as Osteria was burnt.)  Thin crust - but not ridiculously thin.  (I dislike "pizza on a cracker")  Thin in the middle and medium rise (with some puffiness) on the edges.  We had #11 - Spinach.  It was a white pie with a healthy hit of garlic, toasted pine nuts (Oh, yeah, baby!!), the ideal amount of fresh, bright green, sauteed spinach, and a few heavy handed spinkles (globs?) of a sundried tomato/oil puree.  Definitely tasty - and worth a try for those of you who like spinach.

One negative?  No substitutions on pie.  They make 'em how they make 'em.

One positive?  GREAT service by our your server (can not remember her name - but she was really nice and attentive.)

Another thing... only gelatos for dessert.  We skipped dessert here and opted to get some home-made cakes at "More than Just Ice Cream".  But I bet their gelato is good.  (However, Capogiro is not too far, ya know...)

Anyhow - Starr strikes again with a good (and not overly decorated - thank goodnees) spot.

Note to the hard-working pie men (and gals):  Please keep the pies crispy on the bottom - nobody likes a soggy pie.

JOB WELL DONE.

Oh - another thing - we really wish you'd take reservations.  Thankfully at 5:30 on a May Sunday we (2 people) did not need one and were seated quickly.  Hooray!

Real-deal authentico Mexican "bodega style" - no atmosphere, tiny space and a bit "grubby" but man, the food is good.  Squash blossom quesadillas and very solid tacos al pastor.  Real Horchata, too.

Lovely service. Inexpensive.

Can't wait to return.

Our group of 4 came here for lunch at 11:45 on what turned into an insanely busy Driday lunch rush.  You gotta come early or the waits are long.

We shared 20 wings (double fried, K-style spricy and soy) and each got entrees.

Note - way to much food.  Next time just the entrees or fewer wings.

The food was great - the Gal-bi (beef) costs $4 extra but for me it is worth it.

We like Giwa too, but Koreana is a winner in my book.
I shall return.

Wanted to go to Yia across the street but it was a Monday and they were closed.  So a friend and I went to Desert Rose - and this time the food was much better than I remembered from a few years back.

I had a Chicken Shwarma platter and they gladly substituted cucumber slices for the pita bread.  The cucumber/tomato salad here is terrific and always fresh.

Moroccan Tomato soup was a tad too acidic but the pine nuts were a delicious addition. 

Fresh mint tea afterward is always refreshing.

Pleasant service.

Wow - it kinda boggles the mind just how many beers, ales, ciders, lagers, stouts etc. there are.  Gotta love America for dat!  

Staff is eclectic and helpful (and mostly male) with a small bar in the back to imbibe and sample while you shop.  (Bring ID - they card EVERYONE).

If you are a beer lover you will enjoy this place.

I am giving this place a good review for the nostalgia factor.
Years and years (and years) ago my childhood best friend and I - who are still best friends to this day went to the "Grange Fair" every year.

And what fun it was in those days.

Rides, games and flea-markety stuff to buy (or not) and junky food.

When you are 10 or 12 - it's great fun.

Returned to Paramour - this time for Happy Hour with a picky, disgruntled colleague,  (Not Paramour's fault).  Giselle, the lovely hostess and the nice young male bartender (forgot his name) tried to smooth things over but he (my colleague) was NOT having it. He did not like the "house" wine and when he ordered a different wine, complained that the pour was too little.  

Le sigh...

Meanwhile my Vodka & Soda was 1/2 price (for happy hour) and the deviled eggs here are terrific.  I know, who get's jazzed over deviled eggs?  Well I do, at Paramour.  I get all 3 peppadew or 2 peppadew and a bacon.  LOVE Paramours deviled eggs.

Wow.

My apologies to the lovely staff for my grumpy colleague.
I won't be bringing him again!

Yum! Scaramuzza'a frozen pasta - available at local deli's and even at Acme.
Love it! Competitively priced and cooks up straight from the frozen state.

I have gotten the Linguini, Fettucini and Manicotti.

Good stuff!

A coworker took me here for dinner and I was fully expecting good sushi (and I was not disappointed) but what really made me smile was the incredible Galbi/Kalbi!  Wow - complete with 5 panchan (potatoes, bean sprouts, kimchi, broccoli and cucumber salad).  

Some of the best Korean I have had in a long while.

The spicy crunchy tuna rolls are delicious here and they have a FULL BAR.
Lovely lady (owner??) served us.

Can't wait to return.
Jazz once a month!

I am astounded at how good the food was here for a late lunch.
The hostess, however, had a very sour disposition - perhaps tempered by thescreaming throngs of 6 year olds assembled for a noisy birthday party.  We asked to sit elsewhere.  This displeased her all the more.

But the 2 star hostess was quickly forgotten when sunny Stephanie arrived to take our drink orders.  The food came quickly and was delicious - everything from the (somewhat high priced) kids meal for the kiddo, to DH's sandwich to MIL's mushroom pizza.

I had a 1/2 order ("small plate" of pasta wit chicken, broccoli andlemon pesto.  
It was great.  Honestly!

I can't believe I now like it here.
Wow.

Wow - much better than King of Tandoor.  We had a very inexpensive ($8-$9) lunch today at Saffron.  What a pleasant place.  The saffron colored decor with black accents, the delicious Chicken Tikka Masala, the Mango Lassi - everything was great.

2 very nice tag-team male servers.  They even made me a poori (not on the menu) and my friend had a scrumptious garlic naan.

Fresh and wonderful!  Can't wait to try it at dinner time.

They have renovated and it is super clean, freshly painted (even the restrooms are clean and fresh) and just a GREAT place to either have a party (kids or adults bowling/birthday party) or rent a lane and bowl for a couple of hours.

Very nice!
Yay!  D-town got a Primo's!  I like the Nonna's veggie (as a wrap) or the Milno.  The fresh mozzarella is so good on the sandwiches here.  LOVE PRIMO'S.

I am absolutely astounded at how good the food was here for a late lunch with our party of 7.

The hostess, however, had an unfriendly disposition - perhaps tempered by thescreaming throngs of 6 year olds assembled for a noisy birthday party.  We asked to sit elsewhere.  This displeased her all the more.

But the 2 star hostess was quickly forgotten when our sunny female server arrived to take our drink orders.  The food came quickly and was delicious - everything from the (somewhat high priced) kids meal for the kiddo, to DH's sandwich to MIL's mushroom pizza. They also have a full bar - so I had a (well) vodka and cranberry juice.

I had a 1/2 order ("small plate") of pasta with shrimp and a few chunks of lobster in a scampi-esque sauce.  
It was great.  Honestly! (I asked for it light on the sauce so it was not swimming in oil.  YAY!)

I can't believe I now like it here.
A chain.
Who knew that would be possible?

A solid place for take-out - does not seem to be as popular for dine in. Pizza, Garlic knots, Focaccia (fresh) and Salads (big!) were all solid and did not disappoint.

Friendly service.

Restroom was moderately scary.  Needs to be cleaned more often.

They also have a soda fountain like the ones at Wawa where you can make any flavor drink you can imagine.

Good pizza and a huge variety of slices or (better yet) get a whole pie baked fresh.

My colleague brought in cookies and muffins to share with the team from Pure Bread and the Red Velvet/chocolate chip muffin (or, shall I say unfrosted cupcake) was terrific! I had half - but now I want another half!

I am sufficiently sugared-up for the day.

Still love getting the occasional item from Canter Hill at the Media Farmer's market - they are there every Thursday.

Got a 4-pack of frozen duck breasts ($14 per pound - sometimes on sale for $12 per pound).
I only wish they were individually frozen so I could cook one or two at a time.

Great people producing humanely raised meats and poultry.

LOVE!

I have driven past Maria's many times but finally stopped inside and am I ever glad that I did!

The butter cake, strawberry shortcakes (we got a mini size for $4.25 in the refrigerated case) and cookies are all delicious.  The service from the 2 young ladies was great, too.

I would definitely order a birthday or wedding cake from here if I were local to this area.

Yes, it's more expensive than Acme - but way better quality.
So good.

Love Maria's!

We are now coming here about every 3 months so that I can have my shakshuka fix. That and the beef short ribs and silky-smooth hummus are faves. The tomato soup with Manchego cheese shaved over the top is worth a try, too, if you like tomato soup. 

Don't miss the fresh mint tea, too.
Great service the last few times.

Very happy now!

For better or for worse, Philly is MY city.  (No, it is not the 6th Borough of New York City).

The restaurant scene is strong and getting better all the time.
Shopping districts are improving.
Yes, there is still a huge problem with poverty and street crime.

We have come a long way and we will continue to get better.

I think it says alot that downtown Media now has 2 bubble tea joints and soon will have 2 dim sum spots.  Meanwhile, Kung Fu Tea is brand new (about a month old) and spacious and clean with a ton of sugar-laden tea and coffee/tea and slush and bubble-tea choices.

They also offer rice balls and crepes (Did not try yet).

Speedy service (they call your number so hang on to your recepit), so sit in a booth or on a comfy couch and play a game of Jenga or Uno.

Then, sip and enjoy.

A great spot!
Boba Tiki needs to watch out.

Great for take out.
Fabulous Gyro sandwiches, platters, kebabbs and afghan delights including fried cauliflower and (oily but good) eggplant.  Spinach is great, too.

Love it here!

Quaker City was my old law firm's go-to company.  We had a voucher system (so that the firm would pay for the cabs) and it worked very well.

Independently I will sometimes call Quaker City when I can't get a car from Philadelphia Coach.

Some of the cars are very nice and well maintained - others less so - and one smelled awful.  It's on a car by car basis - as are most of the cab companies in Philly.

My list of companies I use (and the order I call them:):

1.  Philadelphia Coach (215) 744-7777
2.  Quaker City
3.  Olde City Taxi

Peri at Night Kitchen bakery did our (gorgeous) 3 tiered wedding cake in 2008.  It was beautiful to look at and 2 of the 3 tiers were delicious.  The top tier was white cake with Lemon curd and it was slightly dry, but the middle tier (carrot cake no raisins) and bottom tier (Moist deep chocolate cake with chocolate mousse) were both scrumptious.

The cakes here are made with love and attention to detail.  I recommend them highly.

My husband and I had a "date night" here on a fairly slow Saturday night.
Everything was smooth and easy from the web-based lane reservation process to the clean lanes, to the slick bottoms of the rental shoes.

We bowled 3 games each and had a great time.

Can't wait to take our 8 year old here.
No, it's not a chi-chi North Bowl - but this is old school bowling in a clean (even the ladies room was clean!) well-lit environment.

And there is a snack bar - and arcade area.

FUN TIMES!

Got a simple take out order of Chicken with Broccoli (light sauce), brown rice, steamed pork dumplings (so tasty) and classic Moo Shu Pork.   Everything was terrific.

Very impressed as my expectations were low - I usually don't like Chinese - too greasy and many have "gloppy" sauces.  This did not.  

Wow.

I will be back - and maybe dine in next time so I can try their Peking Duck - if a place does Moo Shu well (good pancakes, hoi sin) they MIGHT just do the duck well.

THANK YOU!

I agree with Dave H.  Bucks County is sorely lacking in the Thai Department.  (And how I loves me a good Thai meal - especially that Tom Kha Gai!)

Meanwhile - Siam Cuisine does a very nice job in holding me over for West Coast Thai.  Prices are moderate, service is good and food is tatsy (if predictable.).  Even had a nice DUCK breast dish a while back.

My parent's are old-school and to them Italian is adventurous - so I can't get them to go there too much - but I did manage to get them to go with me once years ago and I my mom liked the Chicken Basil Curry.

I will definitely be back.

@Christopher - they had a Belgian called Delirium Tremmens tonight.
Interesting brews for sure here. (8.5% alc.)

I had avoided coming here for years.
Really.
Years.

I had such bad experiences with the Uno (then called Pizzeria Uno) in the early '90's that I just never wanted to deal.

So tongiht our party of 7 dined for aboout $100 - very reasonable (But few of us ordered alcohol - and no apps, no desserts).  My 6 year old loves it here and - get this - gobbled up all of the steamed broccoli.  The side order of steamed broc is $2.99 and worth every penny.  I got one for me and one for her (along with our pasta dishes.  Wow.

My faith has been restored in Uno - and Steven our young server was very friendly and had a great attitude - and the hostess Lori (sp??) addressed me by name - twice.

Oh - and ironically nobody ordered pizza.  And we all enjoyed or pastas, burgers and chicken dishes.
Great for kids and families.


Such a pleasant surprise.

Had a great and moderately priced (no longer cheap!) large lunch here (we took a bunch home).  Great service and tasty basic diner food.  Excellent soup.

I love diners!

Huge menu - eat breakfast whenever you like.
Nicer than the Melrose (IMO).  Food at Oregon Diner is a little bit better (also MHO).
this is our go-to Wawa WITH Gas - and it is always busy but you can get in & out fast.  no issues.

This place - as many, many others have said is a hidden gem with really, truly good and inexpensive Mexican food.  The Huaracche (I got mine with Al Pastor) was $7.50 and enormous.

Home-made horchata and a variety of aqua fresca.

Plus you can shop for REAL Mexican goods and groceries.

Our server Jeanette (sp??) was a doll.

Can't wait to return.
It almost makes Norristown bearable.

My 11 year old will occasionally want to come here - and they are open all year -round (but of course, busier in summer).  Prices are a little high - but ice cream, parfaits and other treats are very good and service is just swell.

One day a week (Thursday? I forget) there is a deal if you BYOB (Bring Your Own Banana) for a cheaper banana split.  I thought this was a scream - but we have never done it.

Imagine... BYO Banana!!!

Cracks me up.

Also if your small child is under a certain height they get a free kiddie cone.

I used to eat at the Full Moon many moons ago - so boy was I glad to find that it's still Egg-cellent after all these many moons!

Yesterday my huband, 6 year old and 2 cousins met for a noon-time brunch at the Full Moon (they also serve dinner - once a month on the Full Moon).  I had a decadent crab, tomato & spinach topped eggs benedict - one of the best I've ever eaten.

Service was great - the place is small and they don't take reservations - so come early or be prepared for a bit of a wait.  (We lucked out and were seated right away.)

Nice waitstaff, great food in a moon-decored casual atmosphere.

Now, if only I could explain to my 6 year old not to moon people.

Much improved!  (That renovation period was the pits)
A new clean food court with decent sushi, crepes, DQ/Orange Julius, A&W Rootbeer (aka fried food nightmare) and Taco Hell.

My littel one loves Build-a-Bear workshop, and I usually can find what I need at Kitchen Kapers.  (Love it!)

There is also a Maggiano's, a Seasons 52, Bahama Breeze (meh!) and a BIG crate & Barrell in the parking lot of the mall.

And - NORDSTROMS!

A full service Wawa with clean restrooms and a gas station.  Can get crowded but service is always quick and friendly with all the staples that every Wawa has.

I come here about 4-6 times per year.

Sabrina's - you have redeemed yourself.  (or maybe I've just figured out when to come and what to order??)

I dined solo (and was greeted and served promptly and properly) tonight and enjoyed a 1/2 sandwich, soup and salad ($1.00 extra for salad instead of fries).  The plate also had a home-made slaw of cabbage, carrot and sweetened, dried cranberries.  A nice plate!

Also enjoyed my (you betcha!) Arnold Palmer.

Iskra was a doll and I am now much more optimistic about Sabrina's.
When they get it right, they really get it right (and when they screw up - the screw up bigtime.)

Here's my take - DO NOT GO at brunch/breakfast time.

Come here for dinner.
And try the stuffed (dessert posing as breakfast) french toast.

Every time I am dragged to Uno I am amazed that it is as good as it is.  My dad and I came here during COVID (masks on) and sat in the empty bar area and a bar-booth.

We both had burgers.  BIG (8 oz) juicy, perfectly cooked and topped with whatever you wish (I had Cheddar, tomato and lettuce).

I was able to get steamed broccoli instead of fries.  Yay!

Honestly?
It was really good.  For a chain.

The key is NOT getting pizza, I think.

This is a review of the spa area only - not the medical stuff and not the hair salon area.
The locker rooms needed attention - showers were lined with little pieces of soap from other guests.  (Eew) And there was NO conditioner (I came at about 6 PM).
Used robes and slippers littered the restroom area.

That aside - my actual massage was a REAL lomi lomi by Vicki who is a gifted healer.
I had only had one Lomi Lomi ever before and that was on Maui years and years ago.  Vicki's came close.

For $130 - not sure I would do this, but for the special price of $99 (plus a dear friend got me a gift card) - I was all-in.

The brine room is way overhyped- basically it's a lounge with annoying and ever-changing LED colored lights.  The salt crystals are nice.

They also have a real Rassul (mud) room and a Steamed Hay treatment (not my thing).

For an everyday massage - I would not waste the money here - it is soooooo expensive, but for aspecial treat - or a party with friends (that Brine room can seat 6 people easily) it's fine.

They also throw in a complimentary foot soak (lavender or peppermint in a copper bowl of water.  Whoo-hoo!

This place is a little gimmicky - but if the therapists are good (which they seem to be) - I'll go with it.

Overhyped, overpriced and gimmicky - but deep down - a good spa.
And if you get a chance for a lomi lomi (Vicki is the only practitioner who does 'em) or a Lotus - try it out.

P.S.  You MUST tip in cash - so bring plenty.

It's more like 3.5 stars - but I am giving them four to be generous.  The dark, slightly in need of a make-over Morracan digs are a great place to crash on a cusion or low couch with a crowd on a Friday or Saturday night when the hot mint tea flows, the belly dancers shake their thang and the hookah comes out of retirement.

My 3 year old was enthralled by the belly dancer.

Food is a set meal - with just about the best Bastilla (rabbit or chicken) around for miles.  Lamb was tender and flavorful.

Not a holy grail - but for Bucks County - where else ya gonna go for the "real deal" Moroccan cuisine?

Plus - they are family owned and have been around for gotta be well over 20 years.

A nice place to see a flick.  Fairly clean and quiet.
No problems here.

I had a lovely solo dining experience at El Rey on a scorching hot Wednesday Night.  My servers Justin and Isaiah were both terrific and very knowledgeable about food and the menu items.

Since I dined alone I had only one item from the menu (and I can't wait to return to try more).  I had the short rib torta and it was BIG (Huge, and messy - definitely NOT a date night food.), but more importantly it was Excellente!

The braised beef shortrib was tender, yet charred (they do this at the end for presentation) and tasted so flavorful and succulent with just the right amout of fat to taste great but not too fatty.

The sauce - made of guajillo (sp??) peppers and tomato, really tasted like tomato sauce to me - but what do I know?  The best part?  A FRESH - I mean uber-fresh - baked roll - almost like a mexican "fat" baquette with a crunchy crust and a white, airy inside.  (Yes, I know trop carbs, but who cares when the Bread is shipped in from Parc!!!)

They even re-did the back bar as a swanky faux speak-easy.

Yes, it's pricey - but I bet if you order the right things you can have a 4 star night easily at El Rey.

Oh - and even though the place is blaringly-loud - it's still less noisy than Distrito - but I gotta say - Distrito's food still ROCKS my world.

I shall return.  Next time with friends!

Came here for a license renewal (photo required - so could not do online) and luckily I picked a good time as it was not too crowded and I only had to wait for a few minutes.  

No issues - which is great to report.

Way better than the DMV in Center City or worse - NYC where I used to live.

My family & I have been eating at Chambers for years (a big shout out to Matt and the gals!), but it is rare that we venture over to "the other side" as we are not big drinkers.

We did, however dine on the other side when we went for Mother's Day Brunch at Chambers.  The enter place (both sides) were packed and the food was terrific.

TOS offers a fully stocked bar and a lively scene - especially on Friday or Saturday nights.

We sure do love Chambers, and Matt & the gang are the BEST!

Finally we a got a chance to eat inside the restaurant and the food is every bit as terrific inside as it was on those balmy summer nights.

We started with the super-fresh (just made) $8 guacamole and chips.  (Plus their 4 house made salsas.  Our 10 year old loves the salsa Roja and I like the Chipotle one.

El kiddo had the surf & turf fajitas which she loved and I had a special - small steak and chicken enchilada.  Husband had pork ribs al pastor (delish!).

Kudos to Greg (who was not there that night) Nina and Sidney (Sydney?) for terrific friendly service - even with problem with their POS.

We love you!

I like Jos. A. Bank when they are having sales (which is nearly always).
Ran in here quickly to buy my man some duds.

Excellent service.

Makes for good gifts.

Update:  I bought a bunch of stuff here in February 2015 for a Valentine's gift for my husband.  I needed to return 2 items and they accepted them back (unopened with receipt) with no issues.  Easy Peasy!  GREAT SERVICE.

The next best thing to a trip to Cape Cod - I tried the Taste of Maine which is a 1/2 roll each of shrimp, lobster and crab for $20 - including a drink (I got a pellegrino) and a bag of Cape Cod chips (I got BBQ and saved them for later).

Good sized rolls and the crab one was really excellent. I also loved the lobster one.
Not too much mayo and the roll was toasted and lightly buttered (a classic split-top) just as it should be.

Can't wait to go back. (I went at 11:40 right before the line started to form.  Smart move!

This restaurant rivals any fine dining place you'd expect on NYC's Upper East side.  Small space, crammed with tables, deafeningly loud and pricey.

The food, however is very well prepared and they use top-quality ingredients.  The signature app. - thinly sliced smoked salmon wrapped around a panko-crusted poached egg topped with a razor-thin crispy potato "chip", microgreens in a tangy vanaigrette and a bitt of maldon salt.  WOW.  (And for $14 it better be!).

DH had the pork belly with came with a delicious jus and a golden raisin puree (which on paper grosses me out - but actually tasted ok.) and topped with a quarter-sized "slice" of mustard gelee (eew. sorry - gelee is also not a big hit for me.)

DH also had the trout entree which was perfection on a plate - sided with creamy pureed cauliflower.  I opted for foie gras app in lieu of an entree - which made me feel like I needed gall bladder surgery.  Wow - so fattening - I literally only ate half. (It was a scoop of foie with a "liquid center" of cherries.)  The brioche toast to spread it on was heavenly as well.

After all that fat we just couldn't handle dessert - but the table behind us had fresh begneits which looked amazing.

We brought our own wine and the bill was still nearly $100 (and I had 2 apps - no entree).  Wow that's kinda steep for a BYO.

Service was top-notch - especially Jackie our server who catered to our every whim.

A few things make it so I just can't give them 5 stars - namely the price for what you get.

They have Manhattan prices in Coshohocken. Imagine!
Meanwhile the place was packed, and the decor and service are great - if you can handle the crowded digs and the noise.

I would definitely go back, but I would not RUSH back.  
It is worth ONE trip out from Center City to see if you like it.
After that - judge for yourself.

Oh - and they cater - but man am I scared to imagine that bill.
Just got back from a lovely Sunday 2 hour session of blueberry and peach picking.  From March - December there is something to do that's great at Linvilla.

Just stopped in for a quick bowl of vermicelli with spring rolls and sliced beef.
On a cold night - this place (still in dire need of a makeover) serves a great, warming meal for under $10.

Love it here!

Truly Delightful prepared and Packaged foods.
Not so much delightfulness?  The place could use a good cleaning and the parking situation is a bit crazy.  (I wound up at the McDonald's nearby - no spots in the back nor the front.)

wish they had fresh produce too.

Stocked up on some of the BEST stuffed grape-leaves i have EVER had.  plus eggplant salad (a little oily) and delicious meat pies and bakalava.

Don't miss the Lahmahjoon!!!!

LOVE THIS and wishing them many more years of success.

Dining Under the Stars (Wednesday night in the summer) can be a big ole mess - super crowded, long waits for a table, long waits to order, long waits to get food.

Surprisingly - this was NOT the case and we. lucked. out.  Greg and his amazing team at Dos Gringos honored our 6:45 PM reservation (all 3 people in our party were present) and sat us right when we arrived at 6:30 PM (WOW!).

The wait staff was uber-busy so we waiting a while - but not very long for menus, chops/salsa (so good) and that fabulous $10 guac.  Yup.  Guacamole is $10 here.  But we love it.

Vegetable enchiladas and surf & turf fajitas are family faves.

We keep coming back (even after Hildago opened - which we also enjoy).
See you next time!

I have been taking my (now) almost 11 year old pug hear for about 2-3 years (after I moved back from NYC).  Even though we live in Philly now and commute up to DAMC to take him - it is worth it.  We have seen Drs. Benson (GREAT) and Gray (OK - not as nice as Benson, but still a good vet.)  

Saturday appointments are limited and the placed gets mobbed - so be timely and call in advance to help us all out.

The administation of the practice is OK - but not superb (I got spoiled by my FABulous - and fabulously expensive - vet in NYC).  They are very willing to ship meds and supllies to me in Philly which is a huge help.

All is all, I recommend them - but I did get spoiled while in NYC - where my precious puggy was treated for the first 8 years of his life.

Another excellent night at Dos Gringos with 5 star servce from Nina, Billie, Jess & of course, Greg.  

Our 9 year old devoured the "surf & turf" fajita platter.

Such a cute store - and a great place to pamper your pooch.  I have an 11 year old male pug and he is just a love.  I get his "treaties" here.  (Glucosamine/Chondroitin to help with his arthritis.

Expensive - but nice, top-quality merchandise.

Woof!  You have my bark of approval!

I had great fun browsing amongst the All-Clad, raclette Machine, Fondue Sets, Lemon Misters and Ice Cube Molds at Kitchen Kapers.

 When buyng kitchen gear I prefer multi-taskers to items used for only one limited purpose - but Kitchen Kapers has items I never knew I needed!

Great for gifts and barware, too.  Friendly and knowledageble staff.

Fun to browse.  The $400 Breville toaster oven was a hoot.  I will stick with my $79 job from tar-jay.

We went here for brunch and it was surprisingly AWESOME.
Having eaten lunch several time s and having drinks at the Continental Midtown over the years - I was iffy about coming here - but we needed FOOD and it called to us.

I had an eggs Florentine (egges Benedict with spinach instead of meat.) and my husband got the Breakfast quesadilla.

Both were good and brunch was served with a melon mint sorbetto as a palate cleanser.

Decor is Starr-ized and funky (although someone told me that Starr is not involved with the Continental on Market - only the Continental midtown - not sure if this is true.)  Olive themed light fixtures and olive drab restrooms with gorgeous stainless steel light fixtures on the mirror.

Servers were young, good-looking and surprisingly attentive.

The only disappointment wis the potatoe casserole.  It was just their regular deep-fried potato slices with cheese, peepers & onions melted over the top.  It really shoulda said "cheese fries".

Prices weren't too bad.  Brunch for 2 - no alcohol was $25!
(But I missed having a Champagne-o-rama - my Continental Fave.)

Drink menu is THE SAME as the Cont. midtown.

We may actually come back here!

The juice bar gets 5 stars - the procude 4.  Sook Hee, the owner is a doll and offers a myriad of fresh fruit, veggies and gourmet snack items.  The juice bar which has FRESH wheatgrass juice is a godsend for me.  This is the real deal - and I will support them.  We needs a REAL JUICE BAR (Basic 4 in RTM is ok, but this is even better.)

Years ago I would have given Herb's 5 stars.  I remember shopping in their original location on the corner of Main & Wets Streets.  Now they are just a few doors down Main where the old Fagin & Fagin grocery store (now THAT's a blast from the past) used to be.

Herb's is a D-town instituion and a great go-to spot for crafters who don't feel like driving out to AC Moore or Michaels.  They have all sorts of crating supplies, balsa wood, glue, floral arranging supllies, DIY kits - you name it.

When I was 8-11 this place was like wonderland.

Glad they're still around.

Let me make it clear that I am reviweing the restaurant in the BAR AREA at the Sofitel - but it is the same menu and same kitchen as Chez Colette.

Service here has always been great for us - we come for lunch and I usually get the Salmon over butternut squash risotto - which is a rich, delicious meal.

My friend usually will get a burger that is served with an enormous cone of thinly cut greasy fries.  (Yes - they are a little BKish.)

But the food was not crap when we went.  It was really good - and I had freshly squeezed OJ.

Eat in the bar - for the comfy couches and big tables and people watching.  The main restaurant (which I have never sat in) is usually dead empty.

Delicious coffee drinks and a plethora of syrups (Butterscotch latte anyone?) if you are into diabetes in a cup.

Funky-eclectic male baristas.  

Decent prices and a fun-in-the-sunny window seating area.

Love.

Kingyo has summer appetizer specials for $3.00

Yes - that's right $3.00 - for sizling AgeTofu with mushrooms (enoki & shitake)  or 4 crispy Ebi (Shrimp) shumai.

Kingyo is rapidly becoming my go-to spot for a sushi fix when I am in that area.  Ben and Yama are very nice to me and to my 5 year old - who loves the steamed shumai.

Try the Tuna Citrus salad - served in a whole orange - or the spicy tuna tartar.  I also like the tuna tataki over a bed of fresh greens - very diet-friendly.

I have had all kinds of maki and te-maki here - very fresh - and the best of all?  Home-made tamago (none of that frozen garbage.).

Yes it costs a bit more than Vic's or Jay's - but the preparations are more classic and pure.  I like that from time to time.

Kingyo is much friendlier to me than Genji ever was.  Hooray!
Dinner for 2 last night with one cocktail ($9) was $70 including tax 'n tip.

Greg and his staff treat our party of 3 like royalty during our "Dining Under The Stars"  (aka chaos out in the heat).  Possibly "Duning out in the Mist" due to the light rain and heavy cloud cover.  Still, the place was hoppin' and the food was poppin'.

Our 9 year old get a chicken quesadilla and rice & beans which she loved.  She also plowed through the guacamole abd the mild red salsa.

I love the specia that night - Crab (real lump crabmeat) and goat cheese enchiladas.  The pale green avo-jalapeno crema was terrific over top of it.  Rich and decadent.

So close to 5 stars - why not?  Hubby did not care for the braised beef enchiladas - he said the shortribs last time were better.  I did not try his dish but it looked flippin' fantasstic to me.

Love this place - and love to Greg and his hard working staff (front and back)!

Now they have all 4 ramen options in a vegetarian broth with great veggies!
Also for Summer 2013 there is a great cold ramen salad ($11.00).
HOORAY FOR VEG-Friendly options.

I love it here - but it is sooooo salty - but today the lady said if I tell her they can make them less salty.

This time I got the Vegetarian Miso (regular size is plenty big for me - but they also have a large size) and a side of tender Toriniku Pork (I like it better than the Cha su).  I skip the egg and extra noodles (no need for me - but if you like poached eggs they offer it as an add-on.)

So happy they are here!
This is one place where I like takeout better than eat in - as they pack the broth and noodles/goodies separately and I love that!!!
And they accept LevelUp.
A great place for birdwatching, and of course, wildflower tours for adults and kids.  This is a great treasure in Bucks County.  GORGEOUS.  Must go here.

We loved coming to (there are more than one) all the Lamberti's over the years.  My best friend (of MANY years) and her late father loved it here so much that she had her (small, informal, hippy-filled) wedding here.

The chicken marsala and salmon were excellent, and the family style penne marinara and spinach made it a great evening.

The roasted peppers and mozzarella are sooooo good here.

It is a very casual place - not what I would pick for a wedding - but maybe for a rehearsal dinner or shower.

Convenient location on the corner of Rittenhouse Square with 3 ATMs.  I just wish that ALL of the TD ATMs could do ALL of the functions.  (Like deposiuts, purchase stamps).

They are often out of stamps.

Before, when TD was Commerce you could do every function from every ATM.  This new system is NOT GOOD.

Just got back from the CHAOS that is Linvilla during halloween season.
We enjoyed a fabulous hayride and bonfire - complete with long sticks and marshmallows for toasting and small cups of home-pressed Linvilla apple cider.

I also bought (naughty me) a half-dozen apple cider donuts which were still warm and disappeared quickly.  YUM!

It would be 5 stas but for the commercialism that is rampant and grows larger every year (they have 2 enormous parking areas and they are both always packed.)

Want to really enjoy Linvilla - come when it's not Hallowwen and get the same great treats, seasonal rpdocue and less people/kids/lines/chaos.

Great products.
Fair prices.
Weird hit or miss service at this location.  I disapgree with eric f. and I BET he gets treated well because he's a guy.

Anyhow - I stock up on my lip balm #1 and get the heck out.

I finally took the plunge and accompanied a close friend of mine to BP last night.  She had been there oodles of times - but it was my first.

I had the most amazing Salade Lyonnaise and home-made cavatelli.
Her fish (Brnazino) had bones in it which accounts for knocking a star off.

Service was terrific - attentive yet unassuming.  Decor is fab.
A great selection of wines - although we did not partake.

We really enjoyed our evening capped off by a delectable plate of assorted cookies (that pattissiere knows what they are doing!) and fresh brewed Jasmine Green tea that was fragrant and wonderful.

I can't wait to go back.

Still don't accept credit cards - but they do have take out - that is well packed (broth and goodies in separate bowls). I also love the little piece of nori that comes when you get Shoyu.  You can also add bean sprouts and/or bok choy for a small upcharge.

I tried the Shio this time - and liked it better than the Shoyu.  Both are salt-laden, though. And I also enjoy the Miso - but that may be from the drizzle of black garlic "nom nom" sauce on top.

Next time will try the (limited time offer) Pork Cheeks or the Soft-Shell crab buns!  (pricey stuff - but I bet it's great.)

The bad part?  With all the extra goodies (no need for extra noodles in my opinion, unless you are a big eater and famished) I usually spend about $10 on ramen.  YIKES.

My (then) 10 year old took 8 classes (2 packages of 4 classes each) before she decided that Archery was not "her thing" but in the mean time, GG and her daughter were great instructors and she got to be pretty good and indoor and outdoor target shooting.  My kid even joins JOAD for a bit.

Grounds are beautiful.

I liked our experience here.

Had a much better experience - this time for dinner - and the grilled beef summer rolls ($6.50) were so tasty and fresh.  Pho was average - but worked.  Broken rice platters are a good value. Friendly service and a fun experience.

When they said "small plates" they weren't kidding.
Lilliputian is the word my friend used to describe our $2.00 cups of tea and $5 cappuccino.

Deleicious food - but so small.
Sushi rolls are "normal" size - and the $5 spicy tuna roll at happy hour (Usually $9) is a good deal - but you have to sit at the bar or in the bar area.

Mike from Detroit was our cheerful server/bartender and he was terrific.

I enjoyed the Louella roll (Lots of yellowtail) most of all - but the tuna nachos - had 5 (five) nachos on the plate.

Really?  For $10 there wer five pieces?  That's$2 per chip.

Seriously???

I would never bring my husband here or any "big eater".
No way.

This is a menu comprised of apps and you can very easily leave here feeling hungry with a much lighter wallet.

I am NOT a fan of chains - and truly not a fan of Outback (in fact, I stay away from most of the steaks there), but today our party of 5 - including my parents who LOVE Outback had a great Sunday lunch.

Part of what made it so great was that the place was EMPTY at 12 noon on a Sunday.
Thus, we had attentive service and no waiting to be seated.

Bliss.

I enjoyed a 1/2 rack (4) of ribs and my 7 year old ate 2 of them.  Plus a kids meal of "mac-a-roo" - and steamed broccoli.  The kid ate like a champ.

Do I love the food here?  Not really.  Is it 5 stars?  No way.
But we got a decent 4 star meal out of a 3 star place.
Good for kids (mine at least.)

Go at an off-peak time for this formula-cooking meat fest.

P.S.  - for $5 they serve up an enormous and very good key lime pie on a graham cracker crust.

Came back one more time - and this time there was a special exhibit on Sugar and Candy Making (how ships brough the sugar to America) by the Berley Brothers (Shane Confectionery/Franklin Fountain).

My kid - who by then was 8 -now she's 9 - loved it and she really likes this museum.
Don't miss the ship-building shop where they will cheerfully answer your questions and the master craftsmen will stop their work to talk to you.  What great (and talented) guys!

We also thoroughly hit up the gift shop on this trip and there are lots of over-priced toys and knick knacks that appeal to kids so beware if you have children - they will want one of everything.\

A fun museum - and if they keep roating the exhibits we'll be back for a 3rd go.

P.S.  The tattooing exhibit is lots of fun as well.

Here again but this time had EXCELLENT service from an u-named male employee who showed us where to get everything we needed.

No problems this visit.

A great and majestic venue for hosting a corporate event or large party - easily accomodates 300 for cocktails/stations.  You must use their caterers, though - decent food and excellent, friendly servers.

Coat room available.
Spacious.
Ammenities.

Consider this for your next event!
closed!!!!!

I attended a large (260 mostly women) function all day today at the Meadowland's Country Club.  While valet parking is (and was) available, we parked in the large lot and walked over.

The building outside is stone and beautiful as are the (golf coursey) grounds.

The facilities are very lovely although a bit dated looking.  For instance, I would not have my wedding here but a Bar/Bat Mitvah or corporate function would be fine.  It's just not "slick" enough (in my humble opinion) for a wedding.

The food and service were very good.  While continental breakfast and lunch were both provided, breakfast was not big deal  (Literally juices, coffe & danish - that was IT.)

Buffet style lunch service was tasty and nicely presented.  The eggs florentine (served for 260) was a bit cold, but tasted wonderful.  Homemade tune & egg salads were tasty and the green salad bar had numerous tasty toppings.  All fresh.  All great.

A giant fresh fruit display walong with delectable (and some still warm) homemade cookies and (not warm) brownies.

A nice place to host an affair.

Also - Membership is reduced from $1500 to $1000 due to the recession (a house membership does NOT include pool access, and you have to spend $125 a month on food from Dec - Mar).

Since we live in Center City I doubt we would ever join here - but I sure would consider having an event here - if they'd let a non member do that.

Called for an inquiry - and plan to use them to re-key our new home in Media.  Woody was very helpful and informative.  A service call is $85 plus the cost of whatever you are having done.

They have 24 hour emergency service, too.

Odd service (from hostesses - not server - she was great) and excellent "fresh" food for a pricey but delicious lunch.  Crab Cake Wedge salad was terrific as was a simple side of roasted red beets with sliced almonds.  Sweet & Crunchy and so easy to scarf down.

A fizzy glass of sparkling raspberry lemonade was refreshing and light.

Love it here.  Wish I could afford to come more often.

Try the Toriniku (pork cheek) special - or get a side order of it.
If you are a pork fan this is BETTER than the pork belly.  Still fatty, yes, but very tender.  Super flavorful.

All the broth here is very salty to me, but still a tasty winter treat.
Tip:  add Bok Choy and Bean Sprouts!

Very clean, well-run Starbucks.  Parking lot around back.
No issues.
I can usually find some decent pants and socks at NY&Co.  Good prices and they usually send e coupons in th email.  The one in K of P is nicer, as i loathe the Gallery.

Not sure if this is the SAME produce cart neat Penn's dental School - but if it is - I love it.  Used to get fruits and veggies here all the time when I went to Penn.

Tip:  you MUST wash everything well.
