They always have apples, bananas and organges, but very often they have more exotic fruits like mangoes and fresh berries - at GREAT prices.  Select carefully, weash thoroughly and ENJOY!
A nice flower shop - right in New Hope.  They have done a few items for our family over the years, but we usually used Doylestown Florists - because they were closer.
One of the only places in D-town to get a car washed.  Has changed names and owners a few times.  Not bad.  Not awesome either.  It's fine by me!

Took my 7 year old to Golosa as part of Dining with Friends - her school's program.  We are so glad Golosa participated.  The red velvet cake and hot 56% chocolate with "shaken cream" on top were divine.  

DD loved the red velvet cake so much we got a slice to go for tomorrow.
She also got a blood orange chocolate (truffle?) for $2.00.

We also tasted 4 different cookies ($4.00) and we liked the corn meal and cocoa sable the best.

An elegant, pricey, caloric, indulgence.
Worth it!

Love it here.

Cash only.

We still go here - and my kid is now a teenager.  She got braces here (invisalign Teen), retainer afterward and gets cleanings twice a year (assuming no cavities.).

We love Ashley (hygiene) and Dr. Alex.  Linda and Maryellen (??) at the front desk are great, too.

However - we can't give them five stars because their hours are sooooo limited.  No Friday afternoons.  One Saturday per month.  No late evenings - maybe one day per week they might stay past 6.

For a working parent, it is not convenient.  But now that ortho is over, we can make it work for 2 cleanings per year.

Super happy with Dr. Alex (pediatric) and Linda (Pediatric office Manager).
Also I go to RTD for adult dental cleanings downstairs.  Dr. Liberman (sp??) is great, too.

Our only complaint?  very limited (sometime none) Satruday or evening hours.  Kids need appointments after 3 PM and after 6 PM many days.

It is very hard to get my kid the coveted 5 PM cleaning and I book it months in advance.  (And then, life happens.)

Wish they had more weekend and evening hours.  (Maybe open at noon one day a week and work until 8 PM?) Yes, staff hates that - but patients love it!

Love it here.
Great staff and everything you need for a party or cocktail hour at home.
Frozen hors d'ouvres, Cheeses like Chevre, Cheddar and Stilton, Crackers, Fresh OJ, Pomegranate seeds to garnish.

WONDERFUL.

I had been taking Amtrak (way expensive) every 2 weeks up and back to NYC, but now that my dad told me about Bolt bus - ihave used it twice.  The first time was awesome - but the second time our 8:30 AM bus did not arrive until 9 AM -needless to say we arrived about 35 minutes late to NY.

Like others below - how the heck to they make money?  For me and 2 other to go up and back to NYC was under $60.00.  The tickets ranged from $7 to $13 one way.  I did not get the $1 fare yet.

Also - there is a 50 cent surcharge for each transaction - so kep that in mind when you book.

I am kinda hoping this stays a secret because the busses are getting more & more crowded each time we go.

I also agree that the seats are very stiff and not comfy - but the busses are new and CLEAN (not like Chinatown hell, I mean, bus).  I did not use the wifi - but others did.  There are plenty of outlets (pugs) and also sometimes they'll play a movie.

MUCH cheaper than Amtrak.  During the winter (icy roads) I may be forced back to Amtrak.

DSW is usually a good place for us to find shoes (Women's Men's and shoes for my enormous 11 year old who wears a ladies size 10).  

This location was no exeption - we scored big with 2 pairs of ladies size 10 heels - one open toed and one strappy sandal.

No issues here - and be sure to check out the clearance area all the way in the back corner - you never know!

This is my go-to Tar-jay and it is nicer than the one in Philly (on Colombus Blvd) for sure.  I can get vaious and sundry supplies, kids stuff and household goods.

The bad part?  I a always seem to drop no less than $80 and usually over $100 every time I come here - which is about every other weekend.

They have a (slow as molasses) starbucks on the lower level and restroom on both levels.

Burlap and Bean is a nice alternative to that "other" ubiquitous coffee chain.  Prices are a bit high and the coffee is a bit too bitter for me - but my kid just LOVES it here and eats the waffles.  Plus on Wednesday nights they do an "open mic" - and some crazy old folks were singing the last time we came in.

A homey-vibe - very chill and laid back.  Do not come here during the morning rush and expect to be in and out quickly.  People here take there time.

If you want quick - head to Charbucks or Dunkin (feh).  If you want to relax with a beverage and a snack - this is the spot.

Wish they stayed open later on Saturdays - they close at 3 PM.

Two words.

Tomato Pie.

All you need to know.

Being in the spa biz it PAINS me to pay retail - but for certain items that I must have NOW (and can't or won't wait for shipping online or ebay) I get at Douglas.

They even carry Bond fragrances.  (Love 'em.)  Also my 3 year old is a girly-girl and runs straight to the CHanel display to play with lipstick whenever we are there.  She adores Coco Pink.

I nicknamed this place Bun Cali - because i much prefer to get the bun here - tho the Pho is good, too.

My little daughter likes the Sugar Cane shrimp.

CHEAP, fast and a good Viet-fix when you need one.
Decor is very basic and could use a clean-up.

How do they do it?  And they've been doin' it for years?

The country place serves good down-home/bar type food and is sooooooo cheap.  Great drinks - and yes, sometimes the crowd is bikers and other times "church ;adies" so you never know what you're gonna get.

I miss it.  I live in Philly now and am too far away to go to COuntry Place - but I have fond memories.

I really, really needed a new manual can opener (we rarely open cans except maybe for our dog) and did not want an el-cheapo from Acme or Giant, so off I trekked to KK.

They had about 7 varieties from $13 - $25.  I settled on a $17.99 (about 19 with tax) model that is alot like my trusted (AS SEEN ON TV) "Safe-T-Can" that crimps the edges.  

I was also tempted by a $60 nonstick pan, but I resisted.

Love to shop for kitchen gear.
Love to cook.

Very nice store.

We went to this "rustic sports bar" on a lovely summer day with family - not realizing that it is a chain.  The food was surprisingly good - Potstickers (though frozen, very tasty) and Cobb Salad (nice FRESH romaine) among them.

The outdoor seating is fun - but we opted ti sit indoors in the a/c.

Service by Sarah our server was great and friendly.

If we are in Medford lakes again we would return for lunch - but I bet dinner and happy hour are crowded and noisy.  Lunch is nice & quiet.

Better update the address - Foster's has not been on Union Street for YEARS - they moved to the shopping Plaza where Kmart is (and there used to be a SuperFresh there until 2009) on 611 near 313.

Anyhow, Fosters is our go-to place for balloons and party supplies, as well as all sorts of toys and bikes for kids.  They are NOT cheap.  It is NOT Toys-R-Hell, and the service is great and you pay for that.

I love Fosters - a Doylestown institution for many, many years.

And they have helped me make my kid's 1st & 2nd birthday parties so special (the dollar store in the same shopping plaza has cheaper balloons, but they don't last as long and they'renot open on Sundays.)

I trust that Foster's will get my balloon order right - and I am thankful for that!

Still taking my elderly pug here - after all these years.
Place is mobbed on Saturdays - but they are always friendly (staff and reception) and willing to taker th $100 - $200 I routinely drop every time I walk thru the door.

Excellent vet care - and we will continue to schlep our dog here from Philly until he they day he dies.

The salads (especially in summer) and ceviches here are amazinglt fresh and flavorful.

I really ejoy it here, especially earlier in the evening before it gets too noisy and corwded.

LOVE the food at El Rey.

A fun place to browse for (and sometimes buy) costume jewelry and accessories.  My 9 year old can't get enough of the place.  Tables are coordinated by color family which is fun.

They also carry a limited selection of clothing and shoes -but the JEWELRY and hair accessories make this akin to a grown-up's Claire's.

Sparkly & Fun and not too hard on the wallet.
Great for proms, weddings, color coordinating an outfit, interview stuff.

It's all FAKE (Costume) but it's all FUN!

So far we are very pleased with the Pediatric part of this practice (downstairs).
We are sending our 8 year old here for cleanings and some restorative work.

Will report fully when the work has been done.

Bad news?  No more Saturday Appointments.

5 star service for the bar staff (Matt and Allyssa) and our fabulous, attentive server, Valarie.  The atmosphere and vibe were perfect on a busy Friday evening.

Cocktails for Happy Hour (4 - 6:30 PM) are a great value at $8.  For $13.25 - not so much.  I had a Cucumber Gin/White Cranberry concoction and it was refreshing and enjoyable.

The food was just OK.
The highlight for me were the $4.75 brussels sprouts - I got them sans bacon and they were perfectly roasted and wonderful.  

The salad I chose was where things fell short.  I ordered the heirloom tomato and mozzarella salad (a dish I have had at many places, prepared in many different ways).  The "herb crust" on the mozz just ruined it.  (And I could tell is was good, quality mozz underneath.)  Also the tomatoes.  The small, mulit-colored tomoatoes were fine - but the thickly sliced green tomato (the "meat" of the dish") was over ripe and mushy.

Ick.

My friend got (what I was thinking of getting and should have gotten) the veggie sampler for $15.50.  Next time (if it is still available) I will get that.  The black bean taco and roasted tofu looked great.

So 3 star food and 5 star service/decor equals about 4 stars.
Pretty darned good for a chain.

Bill Haney who runs A & B Cleaning and Dana (and his team) have been cleaning our home for 2 months and so far, so good.
They bring their own equipment (vacuum cleaner and all supplies) and charge a very reasonable rate.

We are lucky to have found them!

Update: It's 2014 and we still use A & B cleaners. Very pleased!

I have never been to John's restaurant, Pizza & Pasta - but they are a godsend to those of us who work at the Amtrak Mechanical Yard.  John brings us goodies like spinach &  ricotta pizza, salads and penne with chicken & broccolli 3 days a week.

The crispy chicken salad with hard boiled egg and Ken's Honey Mustard Dressing was great!  Lettuce (albeit iceberg) was crispy, fresh and rust-free.

Pasta dishes are a little too heavy on the garlic and oil for my tastes  - even when I ask for them "light" on the sauce.

I also tried a cheesesteak roll (Pizza dough wrapped around cheesesteak meat and American cheese).

If you call in your order in advance, they will make you whatever you like.  The other day I had a REAL Veal Parm with spaghetti and delicious (garlicky) garlic bread plus a can of soda for $8.50!!!

Today I had eggplant parm platter (no cheese) and it was PERFECTION - John had just gotten cases of farm-fresh eggplants.

We really appreciate having a nice hot meal nearby!  And they bring it right to our workplace!
Thanks to Pizza & Pasta for their efficient catering.  I can't wait to try more items.  They bring the food right to our door!  God bless 'em!

4-5 stars for sure.  I am a huge proponent of greenmarkets and farmers markets and headhouse is no exception.  LOVE IT!  We got some terrific summer fruits here last summer and I can't wait to come bacak agin in May & June to snag some fresh berries.

Oh - and the fresh tomatoes in season are SLAMMIN'!
Bring some cash.

No issues with this outpost of Giant on Route 3 right near 352. Got a few snacks at about 8 pm on a Saturday night and there were no crowds and no lines.

I bet it wasn't like that a few hours earlier, though.

Our family is a big Dos Gringos fan, but they really need to figure out a few things.
We had a large group (12 people) and they could not seat us all together.  We made due a few feet apart.

Also the new male server is a little abrasive.  It's "his way or the highway".  I kinda miss the nice ladies at lunch time - but I guess they no longer work the dinner shift.

Also - do NOT come here for Dining Under the Stars (aka Chaos out in the Heat).  Service is way, way slow - and we know they are doing their best - but it's not working.  Demand is too high for supply.

Ran out of chips, ran out of mild salsa (made more).  

In the mean time, the pitchers of Mango and Lemon/Lime margarita mix are terrific and after a few shots of tequila none of us cared.

Food was excellent - Chicken Enchiladas, Veggie Enchiladas, Fish Tacos and of course the AMAZING surf & turf fajitas.

One more small gripe:  We were changed a $2.95 sharing charge, but the platter was not split for us.  Basically we were charged for the server to give us 2 bread plates.  Wha?????  I don't mind paying a small sharing charge if it means the platter will, indeed, be split to share.  Ours wasn't.

Sorry to come off harshly - we still love you guys - but there are some areas for improvement.

Lunch?  Come here.
Dinner (not on a Wednesday)?  Come here.
Catering?  Come here.
Large Group?  Don't come here.
Dining out in the Chaos?  Do NOT come here.

Yvonne - who usually works evenings at the main register - is a lovely lady.
Both she and another sales associate helped me in the cosmetics department.

Even though i usually shop at the Walgreen's in Aston, I come to Paoli from time to time as it is on my way home from work.

The cosmetics lady was very helpful and I was able to get a name-brand gel manicure kit (including LED lamp) for $30 with coupons and deals.

Very pleased.

Just got 7 knives sharpened at the Media Farmer's Market (it's on Sunday mornings now from 9 AM - 1 PM) by Rich.

He did a great job however because he was so busy my knives (4th order in the line) that I dropped off at 11:15 AM were not finished until about 1:20 PM.  Since the market closes at 1, poor Rich was stuck there for who knows how long finishing up everybody's knife orders.

Tip:  Neil's only comes to Media on the last Sunday of each month, so get there EARLY.  The also sharpen garden tools and axes, scissors, too!

We need this valuable service.

Summer after summer, means softball games and post-game Gallucio's for Pizza (still greasy), Wings (The BBQ ones are great) and Beer.

Very attentive service - especially for a bar.

Wonderful to sit out back and chill.
They treat our 7 year old well, too - and bring her fettucine with butter.

Wish it were a little more affordable because my now 13 year old LOVES to buy accessories and loves the shopping experience here.  Like "Claire's for grown ups"?  Maybe?

OK, maybe not.

But the separated by color displays are just. so. attractive to a tween or teen.
Sparkly stuff.

Fun.

A great place to dispose of disposable income.
Avoid if you don't have that!

What would we do on a rainy day without IKEA?  Our 4 year old can play here and eat a cheap lunch.  We don't really buy much furniture here.  I feel glad to have graduated from the post-collegiate disposable furniture era of my life, but we do come here.  Often.  At least monthly - to entertain our kid.

Last time we bought a cute "Fishie" bath mat for 4.99.

Oh and as of 10/1/08 - no more plastic bags - so bring your own! (Or buy one for 55 cents.)

Now that's we are local-yokels, Linvilla is all the more pleasant.
We now live about 5 minutes away - so we go during off times - like March (when all the veggies are 50% 0ff) and get our fresh apple cider donuts (skip the pies - they are not made there - but they are BAKED there), and feed the chickens, goats and an ostrich or two.

Great playground for my 7 year old.
We might even have her birthday party here.

It is madness in October, though.
Just madness.

Well, my husband & I finally tried this place - we've driven by a bunch of times but never went.  And we would consider returning (although Shiroi Hana is more convenient for us - and lately I've been really into Vic's.)

The place was nearly empty at 5:30 on a Friday.  The hostess asked if we had a reservation and we told her that we did not.  She made a negative face so I asked her if that was a problem (The place was empty except for one male couple lingering - and they were there before we got there AND after we left.).  She said no and seated us.

I stopped by the sushi bar to bow to the chef and take a peek at the fish.  Looked good.  Chef recommended the Red Snapper and O-Toro.  

We started with an order ($3.00) of Pork Wasabi Shumai.  - 2 large shumai.  Tasty and very wasabi-ish.

My husband ordered a bowl of udon (very tasty dashi broth) a spicy tuna roll which he loved, and a negi-hamachi roll which was just OK.

I got a special roll (Jay roll?) with rice "pops" on it - good but I did not care for the spicye-level of the tuna filling.  It was too hot for me.  (And I had asked for it mild.)  I bet if you are a spicy lover you'd like the rolls here.

Tuna was fresh - but not the yellowtail.  Also my $6.00 piece of O-Toro was gristley and GROSS.  What a shame.  Toro should be a mouth-gasm and this was not.

The best sushi I got was the Inari stuffed with chopped tuna (spicy tuna - this time WAS made mild) and garnished with chunks of avocado and a few pine nuts.  The pine nuts really made it so special.  I would DEFINITELY get that again.

For dessert we had the green-tea icecrem filled mochi which was very good.

Oh - and they do NOT make their own tamago - it's frozen - so we did not order any.

I used to come here when it was Genji - and frankly due to the economy (I am in brokeville these days) and a slightly icy experience when I last visited Genji (over a year ago) I was reticent to try Kin Gyo.

Well, boy am I ever glad I stopped in tonight for a solo sushi bar dinner.
Yama, the chef/owner was accomodating and cordial.  I savored a delectable negi-hamachi hand roll, a salmon lover's roll (very good but a bit steep at $13.50), a succulent solitary piece of (of all things) foie gras nigiri (Yum and fat-city), 2 HOUSE_MAD tamago sashimi (excellent).

The only negative?  The ikura sushi piece was not quite as "poppin' fresh" as i would have liked.

Meanwhile - Yama makes his OWN inari (what a rarity that can be in the sushi world).  And at $7.00 a pop, I think I will wait till next time to try the Chu-toro (which I actually prefer to the fattier and pricier O-toro).

My faith has been restored.  I disagree with Victoria - the fish was all fresh (save for the ikura which was fresh but not "peak").  Service was very nice,and i can't wait to return.

Dinner for one (just me - no beverages) was $45 including tip.

This place is GREAT for lunch.  Thai, Cheesesteaks, fresh veggies, deli, sushi.

We had very tasty (and spicy) Thai from Jeenwong yesterday.  Nice!

Can't wait to return.

I attended a breakfast meeting for 24 people (although only 19 showed up) with a sumptuous salad bar buffet (complete with 1/2 sour pickles and egg, tuna & chicken salads - all of which tasted great).

They also had egg omelettes to order - I had an egg white LEO (Lox, Eggs & Onions) wioth choppoed tomatoes added.

The chef, Bill and all the staff (butlered juices and coffee servers) were so kind and lovely.

Wonderful food & service.
A great place to host events large or small.

A large location complete with cat, dog, fish and small mammal supplies.
They also have doggie training classes. Maria - our instructor - is great.  She owns a huge rottweiler and knows how dogs behave.
A good source for spices and dried herbs.  Not as much fun as Penzey's - but good prices on most things.

The ladies in here are always so kind to me - and my 8 year old if she's ever with me.
They always ask me about her if I go in without her to get her monthly treat.

I get the "free piece" - you can get 1 free piece of chocolate from the case each month - not including certain large items and no chocolate-dipped fruit.  My little one loves the Chocolate Lava Cake and Red Velvet Cake truffles. One summer they had a pineapple truffle and she went crazy for that one, too.

She also likes the dipped berries - but those are not free.

Thanks, Godiva - for making my 8 year old spin around in circles for 20 -30 minutes on her sugar/chocolate-induced high.

I have been coming here/working here/living near here since the late 70's so my how PV has grown.  Now there is a festival just about every weekend in the summertime - and the place is crawling with displaced NYers.

But, it is still charming and you MUST go here at least twice in your life - once during the Strawberry ot Teddy Bear Festival and once on a MID WEEK day in the morning - when it's dead as a doornail and you can actually shop in peace.

Don't miss Penn's Purchase nearby and Granpa Hicks, Total Animal, and Accents & Images Gallery.

Beats the heck outta Starbucks.  Plus it's a local institution - IF you can find a table on a busy summer day.  Nice big cones of ice cream and lots of coffee to drink in store or purchase (whole bean or ground) for take home.

In the '80's and '90's (yeah - I'm dating myself again) I even knew some of the kids who worked there.  these kids now prob'ly have kids of their own.

A cute spot - and great after a movie at "The County".

Ellen - the lunch-time bartender (who also served our lovely lunch) is terrific and has been here for years.

I enjoyed the new "spa" menu - and had the $21 3 course lunch - a delightful tomato soup with ginger and lime, a small portion of artic char (like salmon) over beans and oven roasted tomatoes (super juicy and cooked perfectly) and a lo-cal mokha meringue with fruit compote.  (OK - not awesome).

A pleasure to dine in the BAR AREA.  Nice and quiet.

Oh no!  They are closed?  I hear the Franklin Fountain people bought them.
I hope they re-open soon.  They were great last spring for Easter Bunnies!

I love trader joes - and this one is smack dab in the middle of down-town Media.  (With parking - yay!)

Same stuff as at my beloved Phillybranch - but pomegranate seeds were $4.99 in Media - just $3.99 in Center City.  Odd.

Great frozen meals, too.

LOVE!!!!

A friend and I finally got a chance to try Nom Nom (the name kills me!), and it made me lament for the five dollar bowls of ramen from Larme Dosanko back in NYC "back in the day".

Wow for ramen this is pricey stuff.  $8.00 for the regular bowl (I got Shoyu, friend got Kari).  We both got the poached egg (I was "meh" about it - will skip it next time) and extra noodles (WOW!  Should not have done it - but got to take some home.)
The extra noodles are $1.85 ish and worth it.

We also shared an order of pork buns which rival those at Chifa.  VERY good!  Wish they'd do a non-pork bun (Tofu??).

Oh - and they NOW OFFER TAKE OUT.

PLEASE start taking credit cards!!!

PLEASE!!!!

The frozen custard is quite good.  I am not a water ice eater - but I love the custard at Rita's.  News flash! Their "Gelatti" is NOT Gelatto.  It is a bastardization combo of water ice and custard.  Whatever.  It tastes good.

Bring on the coffee flavored frozen custard, please.

Note:  I have never stayed here - this review is based on the great job Sofitel did catering our Corporate Holiday party in 2006.

Gorgeous ballrooms, great services, fantastic food.  (We had stations - multiple stattions - with delicious food.)

Even getting a cab home was organized and well executed.  GREAT JOB SOFITEL.

Review of bar food by Chez Colette at Sofitel:

Let me make it clear that I am reviweing the restaurant in the BAR AREA at the Sofitel - but it is the same menu and same kitchen as Chez Colette.

Service here has always been great for us - we come for lunch and I usually get the Salmon over butternut squash risotto - which is a rich, delicious meal.

My friend usually will get a burger that is served with an enormous cone of thinly cut greasy fries.  (Yes - they are a little BKish.)

The food was really good - and I had freshly squeezed OJ.

Eat in the bar - for the comfy couches and big tables and people watching.  The main restaurant (which I have never sat in) is usually dead empty.

We went to tequila's last night for Tres de Mayo (instead of dealing with the Cinco de Mayo crowds).  Margaritas were not nearly as heavenly as in the past.  Too sweet and "lemonadey" this time.  Oh well.

Meanwhile, the food was good - but not 5 star.  My dish (at least to me) was the best - a special of Langostino, split and grilled and sauced with a yummy tequila, garlic and pepper sauce.  Flavorful - but not too hot & spicey.

Tequila's makes one of the BEST Caesar salads EVER,  It can run heavy on the dressing, so i always ask for it lightly dressed and last night's was up to par and delicious.

Our female server (her name escapes me) was lovely and attentive.

The BEST 5 star part of the meal was the Tres Leche cake (which the 3 of us split - we were stuffed).

The worst - which made me downgrade from 5 to 4 stars - was the queso fundito.  Just tooo heavy and greasy.  A big crock of melted cheese.  (I didn't order it - I never would have in a million years.)

Bring back the FRESH lime margaritas and I'll quickly re-up you to 5 stars.  Tequila's is a great restaurant.  I recommend it to out of town guests often.

Oh - and please start taking reservations.  (Right now they'll only reserve for parties of 6 or more.)

What a welcome green space in Center City.
Fitler square has a cute little fountain, shady trees and lots of cute coffee bars and places to explore nearby.

Love this area.
Took my 6 year old here last night and we sat on the high-stools and blissfully munched on Sicilian and veggie slices.  GREAT oizza and very friendly service.  LOVE IT!

I have used A & B cleaning services for over 4 years now and they are terrific.  We have had some specific re-training issues that needed to be addressed about 3 year sin when our original team of 2 ladies switched but now we are back on track and everything is "Spic and Span".

I love working with Bill and the team and A & B cleaners. We trust them in our home.

We have visited the Pig Placement Network's booth at A-Day at Delaware Valley College for 2 years in a row and can't wait to attend the annual PiggyPalooza benefit at Ross Mill Farm this June 22.

Ross Mill Farm (outside of D-town in Rushland, PA) serves as an educational facility, foster care and sanctuary for pet potbellied pigs.  

The pigs are so smart, friendly and cute.  Our 8 year old fell in love instantly.

We are big fans of the valuable work they do here - and making sure that ignorant people don't adopt pigs only to give them up after a few months.

An excellent resource.

A friend of mine got us 2 free passes otherwise, I quite honestly never woulda thunk to come here.

Today I took my 6 year old daughter here and we arrived at 3 PM (They close at 5).  We will definitely come back one more time - soon - to see the rest.

We straight away headed to the submarine (creepy & cramped) and ship that are docked nearby.  This took about 35 minutes.

Then we started in on the exhibits - and did not get all the way through.  We spent a long time in the boat shop.  I had no idea they actually build, replicate and restore boats for museums all over the east coast.  While we were there, one of the head builders stopped sanding long enough to tell us about a design they are working on for the Seaport Museum at Mystic, CT.  Neat-o!!!

The lights were dimmed at 4:45 - so we headed to the gift shop.  Whew - narrowly escaped that one.

We'll be back soon.  I enjoyed this a heck of alot more than I thought I would - on the surface it seems like a real snooze fest.  But with the 6 year old in tow - it was much better.

Oh and it was great to come on a random Monday in April than say - July 4th when tourist central swoops in.

Conveniently located right in Center City - but pricey and a limited selection on items my 8 year old artiste actually uses.  Great in a pinch - and get the student card for a discount (which makes it worth it).

We shop here, Pearl (now closed), Uterecht, AC Moore, Michaels, JoAnnes Fabrics and lots of other places for crafting supplies, canvas, paints and brushes.

We even get the kiddo her own French Easel (but not from here!) - so she can apply to Studio Incamminati when she's ready.

Had a memorable meal with top-notch service from Ella at Casta Diva tonight.
My good friend and I both had the beet salad to start (so delicious and fresh).  She had the salmon with crispy skin and red wine sauce.  (A generous piece - or "portion")  I enjoyed the salmon tartare stuffed cannaloni app as an entree.

La Colombe coffee and our own BYO wines sealed the deal.

A great night with stellar food.

The only downer?  Cash only.  Wish I'd known that before we went.

Love KK and this branch is friendlier than the Paoli location.
Picked up some Republic of Tea.

Parking sucks - meters are broken.

LOVE.

I went here with 2 girlfriends.  We all split 1 salad (so yummy) 1 appetizer and 1 pasta entree (which was huge) and bought dessert.

Honestly - it was more than enough.  The home-made stuffed pastas are very good.  They also offer "couchlike" outdoor seating (which we did not choose - we sat inside).

They also make pizzas - which we did not order - but they all looked delicious.

We'll be baaaack!

All vegetables (not fruit) are 50% off from Jan 1 - March 31 every year!!!
It is a terrific deal and we now buy 95% of our veggies at Linvilla (includes tomatoes which technically are not a veggie).

Love the winter veggie sale!

Also in 2016 apples (many varieties) are 69 cent per lb!  Stock up!!!!!

It was a cold rainy November night when I stumbled into Pho Cali - and believe it or not I actually ordered Pho!  I ordered the "rare steak" pho for $6.50 - and it was great - but the steak (very thinly sliced and tender) was not rare.  I guess the steaming hot broth cooked it through by the time it got to me.

The Pho came with a plate of traditional garnishes - fresh white bean sprouts, slices of green jalapeno, fresh lime,

Delicious!  And for $6.50

Digs could use a makeover.

FABULOUS FIND - i can't believe I never came here before.
Nick, the owner - is a sweetie and he has 2 cute dogs and a cuter 2 year old.

To top it off in amongst the vintage vinyl and new-er CDs he found me a rare 4 disk set of the Complete Bob Marley (with and after the Wailers).  I snapped that right up.

Can't wait to come back.  Bravo!!!

Not bad for a chain.  My 3 year old daughter likes to watch the "pizza man" make pizza - so she, of course, loves it here.

It's better than Olive Garden - but not as good as Bensi's - in the "Scheme of mock-Italian chains".  It is also less noisy in atmosphere and decor than the obnoxious Buca di Beppo.

I'd go here if it was nearby - but would NOT go out of my way to eat here.
At least it's not too expensive.

Hesrchel's meets with my approval:

Dr. Browns?  Check
Extra lean corned beef?  Check
REAL Rye bread?  Check

Service with a smile?  Double check.  What nice young men.

If I gotta have a jewish deli style corned beef sandwich - I come here!
Save me a Diet Dr. Brown's cream soda!
It's fine.  Decent coffee and tea drinks, a reasonably clean restroom, and plenty of seating to work for a while or just relax.  Great location near the "Gayborhood" and Jefferson.

5 stars for food and value - 2 or 3 for decor.
When I moved here from NYC about 3 years ago - one of my favorite restaurants in NYC - Afghani or otherwise was Pamir.

So 2 or 3 New Years Eve's ago we went to Kabul - and what'd'ya know?  The owner is the cousin of the man who owned Pamir (which, alas, has since closed in NYC.).

The menus are nearly identical and oh, how I love the fried pumpkin turnovers (Buranee Kadu).  In fact, anything with pumpkin is a yummy choice here.  The service is good - very friendly but they can seem aloof - so if you WANT more water/sauce/napkins - you need to be pro-active (some may see this as a bad thing.).

It was also a great place to have an un-crowded experience.  The place is rarely crowded.  (Possibly because it is a bit old and grungy looking.)  Don't let the crummy decor dissueade you - TRY THE FOOD - terrifc Chalau (stews) and Pallaus (Pilafs/Rice dishes).

I love Afghan food and I love the food at Kabul.
And it is a GREAT value for very little money.

Maybe they'll re-decorate some day?  (Not likely.  *sigh*)

Stopped into El Rey this time during happy hour - and man, WHAT A DEAL.  I got 2 of the $1 tacos - one chicken and one fish (the fish taco was perfect!!!  Cabbage, lime-cilantro-crema and fresh fish).

I also had a $4 house margarita.

If you are around early in the evening and need a tasty snack - you can't beat the $1 tacos at El Rey!  They are small - but 2 or 3 or 4 of them together are plenty.

Good service, too.  I am still lovin' it here!

Went here for a very nice linner (that's half way between lunch and dinner) at about 4 PM on a rainy Sunday.

Since the lunch specials end at 3 PM, we ordered off the regular menu.  DH had a spokie pizza which he enjoyed and I got the dinner portion (enormous - took 2/3 of it home!) of chicken picatta, no capers.

Very good.
Quite good for a chain.
Really.

Excellent service as well (the place was dead from it being 4 PM on a rainy Sunday).

Delivery one night - our first time ever and it won;t be the last - but - we have never set foot in the place.  I suspect takeout is their forte.  Mei Fun is delish - and not greasy.  Spare ribs are a saucy greasy mess.  Dumplings are old-school doughy with pork  - el kiddo loved them, grown ups less so.

So far we just might convert from Da Shin to Jing Fong.  We miss old owners of Da Shin.

If you live in Philly or are visiting you HAVE to visit the liberty bell.  But once is probably enough.  To me this is the "new" liberty bell site - as I visited it in a different place as a kid.  This "new" site is much nicer and allows for better line/crowd control.

This review is for the Doylestown Starbucks in the historic Fountain House - that for years & years was a bank.

As you may know - if you read my reviews - I am not a big Fourbucks (aka Charbucks) fan, but this location - smack-dab in the middle of town - is a keeper.  The multiple room layout makes for a good spot to cozy up with a (burnt tasting overpirced)  coffee drink.

My little daughter likes the iced green tea lemonade.

A nice location with decent service for a Starbucks.  About as good as a Starbucks can get.  (Oh and boy, can it get crowded with yuppies!).

On a very hot Thursday Evening at 5:45 PM, 30 women decended on Modo Mio.
 
Sicilian fare was on the family style menu, and once we were seated, freshly sliced bread (two types) and caponata (eggplant, onions and pine nuts in olive oil) was brought to us.  Monsu is BYOB, so we brought many bottles of wine - red, white and otherwise.

Appetizers were brought by our terrific wait staff, including mussels in a spicy tomato, oregano and white wine broth. Next, came octopus (Polpo) salad with green olives and crunchy wild fennel.  Piping hot, crispy "arrancia" - Sicilian Rice Balls, quickly disappeared. They were filled with luscious saffron rice, gooey mozzarella cheese and savory mushrooms. For the vegetarians of the group a crisp bruschetta with a bright green fava and mint puree appeared, topped with a variety of heirloom tomatoes. The balsamic drizzled on the plate was finger-lickin' good!

Next, we were treated to several pasta primi (first courses). Plates of pillowy-soft ricotta gnocchi were sauced in a bright lemony-tomato cream, studded with chunks of sweet crabmeat.  A spicy (some thought too spicy) rigatoni with tuna as well as house-made taglietelle with a variety of roasted mushrooms and baby artichokes were quickly devoured. 

Believe it or not - there was more!!  Next plates of Bisteck - a fried beef steak topped with fried egg, prosciutto and provolone in a savory sauce arrived.  A bit too salty for my taste, but certainly enjoyable. They run heavy on the salt here - so keep that in mind and if your are sensitive to sodium TELL THEM before you order.

For the non-meat eaters, there was Mackerel served over faro salad with roasted red peppers and (more) fennel.  Next came heaping bowls of fall-off-the-bone-tender pork osso bucco (folks ate all of it including the marrow).  An innovative accompaniment to the osso bucco were sweet chestnut pancakes.  Really super!

Our vegetarian friends enjoyed a smokey, freshly baked eggplant parmesan.  Delightful!

Finally, small dessert trays were passed among the tables.  A sweet vanilla panna cotta was topped with a rich strawberry/balsamic mix.  Gooey, rich, flourless chocolate "brownie" cake was enrobed in a thick salted caramel sauce.  A lemon bar, drizzled with raspberry sauce was topped with crunchy coconut shreds.  (By now many of us were too full to eat dessert - but somehow we managed!)

Kudos to Marguerite and Tyree - two of the 5 or 6 servers who helped our lively group.  They kept the water glasses filled and the plates cleared efficiently.  Such outstanding service!

5 star service - and nearly 5 star food - a few dishes were found by some to be overly salted or spicy - but in a group of 30 tastes can vary widely.

I can't wait to go back - and I will surely try the new Delco spot.

We've stopped in this Whole Foods numerous times on our way from Philly to Bucks.  We love Whole Foods (aka whole paycheck) and this one is no exception.

Great baked goods, cheeses, olives, meats, and especially produce.

Fun to shop here - and you can get some great ingredients.

Good pre-packaged sushi, too.
Yummy prepared foods.

OK, I am upgrading them to 4 stars now.
My husband, daughter & I have come here many times now after every softball game (win or lose).

DD is 5 and she loves the (greasy - blot it off with napkins first) pizza.
I love the fettucine - perfectly cooked - aldente but somehow light tasting.

We also play the electronic bowling game in the corner of the bar.

Yes, the place is a bit "divey" but they sometimes have live music - and the back patio can be very nice if it's not too hot 'n humid at night.

The 4th star is now added for nostalgia.  We are making memories.

BYO Tequila and be sure to have some of the FABulous guac.
The steak and meat dishes are pricey - but delicious.
Twice we had the Carne Asada and it was perfectly cooked.

The sauce is very rich, though.

Also try the delcious Beet & Goat cheese salad.  All the goodies are hidden under a mound of micro-green goodness.  2 juicy, fried plantain chunks accompanied the plate.

This upsacel Neuvo-Latino/Mex is a BYO and they make the margarita mix for you.  NO CREDIT CARDS and kinda snooty service.  Tables are small and closely spaced.  

Our waiter was cute - but rushesd us along and we felt it.

Went to A-Day (Agriculture Day) again this year.
Our little one is now 8 years old and still loves A-Day (although she has now declared that she si too old for pony ride because she "is in 4H and knows how to ride a horse by herself".

Still had a blast drinking a chocolate milshake and jumping on the bouncy-type rides for kids. Note - $10 to park in the field - so we walked.

Mom & Dad browsed the boutiques and stands, including Vik's Picks - for a jar of delicious home-made pickled beets.

Only ONE person selling local honey this year and it was cost prohibitive.  Bring back the bees!!!!

Als of note - over 4 different booths about dogs, dog rescue and pet adoption.  Including the Pig Placement Network (also at A Day last year with their "kiss a pig" donation fundraiser) which finds homes for pet potbelly pigs.  My kid fell in LOVE with those cute 8 week old oinkers.

Sheep shearing, Bovine and Equine exhibits and frisbee catching rescue dogs.
Gorgeous weather helped.

WHAT FUN!

OMG.

Shrimp Scampi over Linguini - came with 6 big shrimp, just the right amount (but alot) of garlic & oil - not too oily/buttery.

Carby BLISS in a foil pan.

I love ya, John!

3.5 stars, really, but I feel generous and we had fun last night so I am giving the Limelight in Doylestown 4 stars.

The four of us stopped into the limelight - which is basically a piano bar & restaurant.  The food is Italian influenced American and all of us had veal dishes.

The iceberg lettuce salads were blah and overly dressed in a vinegary-balsamic vinaigrette.  This was made up for by the delicious Veal (or chicken) Irene - with crabmeat and pencil-thin asparagus.  
My mom had a veal picatta which she enjoyed.  DH had veal parm whic he said tasted freezer burnt.

We intend to return again to give them another shot (service was good, by the way - friendly and attentive without being pushy) but if things don't go well that'll be it.

Seems like it'd be a fun bar to go hang out in, though.  Happy Hour (4-6 PM Mon - Thurs) offers $2 beers and $5 house wine.

Cutesy-diner-cum-coffee-shop.  We went on a Friday night and I had the panko-crusted mahi-mahi (Fish o' the day) and DH had the "blue plate" special.

Food was above-average and surprisingly good.
Service (by cute high-school/college guys) was friendly and the under-age eye candy made me feel slightly strange.

Ask about the "Lucky Buns" for dessert.

Alas, my buns are far too large on their own - so no "Lucky Buns" for me.
I'll  stick to the mahi-mahi with lovely brown & wild rice and veggies.  (FRESH green & wax beans and baby carrots.)

YUM!

We made a reservation that afternoon for "dining Under the Stars"  (aka chaos Out in the Heat) and were pleasantly surprised by only a 15 minute wait (others waited up to 25 minutes) for our table for 3.

Greg - one of the owners - treated us so very well - as did all the servers and bussers - especially Sarah.  

Our 8 year old enjoyed the guacamole, rice & beans and chicken quesadilla kids meal.

The best bite of the night?  My husbands app - a shortrib quesedilla made with queso fresco and diced pear and onion.  Scrumptious!

I enjoyed my shortrib entree - and DH had enchiladas.  Very filling - we took some home.

No issues here at all - and much better food than the Cantina on State.  We can' wait to come back on a non-Wednesday - I bet it's even better!

Many thanks to all at Dos Gringos - they were workin' it - for a lovely evening.

My little 4 year old adored Linvilla (Lynn-ville) because there are animals here and our "home orchard" (Solebury Orchard - which ROCKS by the way) does not have animals.

This is a great place for a class field trip -especially around Halloween with the Hayrides and pumpkin & Apple picking and cider making.  A great place.

Fantastic take-out food last weekend from Chin's.
Note:  Now they are CLOSED MONDAYS.

Try the chicken and broccoli and Shrimp with snow peas.
10 ingredient (House special) fried rice is NOT greasy and full of goodies.
Meaty. big spare-ribs and classic (doughy but tasty) steamed meat dumplings.

The only game in D-town!

I usually stop at this Wawa - on a busy stretch of Baltimore Pike - for gas.  That said, it is easy to get in and out here as long as you are "going that way".  I do not usually get food/coffee here.

Convenient for gas.

Much nicer than the Springfield location, but also we came on a weekday at 4:30 pm, so there was no line at the cutting table.  Definitely use the coupons and offers, as it really helps.

Lovely young lady at the front counter and a knowledgeable lady running the cutting table.

A great experience. 

Clean restroom, too.

American may run on Dunkin, but Dunkin' does not run me!
In the mean time - every once in a great while I get a hankerin' for a DD Iced Coffee - so if I am in Suburban station I go to this location.

Service is VERY quick and efficient (they have multiple lines) - even during the insane morning coffee rush.

I never get donuts - and very rarely food items (I actually kinda like the toast sandwiches there - but at 500 - 800 calories for BREAKFAST there is just no way!!), but I love the iced coffee - especially in the summertime.

This update and higher 4 star rating is for the IMPRESSIVE catered feast we had at my office today.  The lady who delivered it, set up the sterno, poured the raspberry (unsweetened) iced tea and catered to our every whim was terrific.

Large pans of spaghetti, meatballs, chicken parm, ravioli in a creamy-blushish-basilish sauce, 2 kinds of salad, 2 desserts.

WOW.

FOOD COMA.

And - it was all hot and very tasty.  Maggiano's - you have redeemed yourself.

Attention yuppy-families - the Froyo craze has come to the 'burbs!  (Media, PA)
Service - 5 stars.  Yogurt and toppings - 4.

My 8 year old and her friend (also 8) stopped in with me for fro-yo and while the place was packed to the point of ridiculousness on Wednesday night (Dining Under the Stars aka "Chaos out in the Heat") it was peaceful and empty at 7PM on Thursday.

Do not come on Wednesdays in the summer.
Come another night and oh - what a treat for the kiddies (and grown-ups who dig the froyo).

5 machines produce 10 flavors - that night 4 were non fat.
The original tart - my litmus test for truly good froyo remains untried - but I did sample the coffee (non fat but who can tell?) and kiddo had Mango, peanut butter and one other (who can remember??).  The other kid had marshmallow and cookies 'n cream.

Toppings abound including the usual suspects, fresh berries, COLD whipped cream and a canister of HOT fudge.  3 Ghiradelli sauces include White chocolate, dark chocolate and caramel.

Pricey stuff when the kids get wild - we spent close to $12 for the 3 of us (And all I had was a "bowl o' whip").

Brand-spankin' new (opened about a month ago) includings a spotless restroom (YAY!) and cute hand painted Trompe-l'œil murals in progress.

Owner is "Mike" from Little Anthony's and allegedly an upstairs party-room (for pizza and froyo birthday bliss) is planned.

A welcome addition to State Street, Media.

WELL DONE!!!!! Please don't let it slip in 6 or 12 or 18 months.

A solid choice in this part of Media - and very convenient to Rt 1.
Full bar - and pricey but good cocktails and many beers.
A vast take out and catering section.

Don't miss their signature pistachio crusted chicken tender - especially if they have just made a fresh batch.  They really are delicious.

Salads are good too.

Wow - I remember when this used to be Tilly's.
What an improvement.

Great spot for a diner-style breakfast or a basic lunch sandwich.
I usually go for breakfast.

You can get home fries or a hash brown pattie.

Decent hot coffee, too.
Not super expensive.

A good choice.

My source for specialty food products - especially the fabulous selection of balsamic vinegar, a good cheese counter and swanky (pricey) prepared foods that taste as great as they look.

A small coffee is $1.99 - so not too bad.
Fresh OJ for $2.99 in the AM with a carb-laden pastry?  (Try the flaky cinnamon stick - like dessert for breakfast).
Catering, too!

Lines can get long but the move quickly.

Thank goodness we have Di Bruno's.

We had a luncheon here in one of the private banquet rooms for about 30 people.  The food and service were bith excellent.  Green salad, rolls and butter, a basic penne marinara pasta course followed by a choice of 2 entrees. Crab cake or Chicken Marsala.  Both were delicious.   Super creamy (was it homemade?) Vanilla ice cream fir dessert. Sounds like no big whoop,  but it was soooooo rich tasting. I put some in my coffee. Very good coffee, too.

Rob (server) and the young lady at the door were very kind.

I would definitely come here for dinner or plan a special event here. Plus they have their own parking lot.

Great!

Billie Jo is one of my favorite estheticians EVER and I, in fact, followed her here from another spa.  This place is so swanky - very nice.  A great relaxation room and a well thought out floor plan.  

A facial here can run $149 and up (ouch) but it is wonderful to have Billie Jo work on you.
They also offer a whole menu of med-spa services including laser treatments (hair removal, collagen rejeuvenation, etc.), fillers (Botox, Restylane, Juvaderm) and SculpSure (not Cool Sculpt - the other one.).  Packages run in the THOUSANDS so bring money.

Love it so far - but man, I guess I am in the wrong demographic.
A teen facial (18 & under) is $99.  Lucky kids!

The staff here is friendly and wonderful - and although I can't do 100% of my "regular" grocery shopping here, I do come by a few times each month for "fun foods" and frozen treats.

They have some great lunch options, too, like salads, pomegranate arils and meats in the refrigerated case.

Unique products and tasty foods that are quick to prepare.
Also a good source of holiday gifts for the food lover in your life.

I am attempting to review the Kohl's department store on route 611 in Warrington.  (Next door to Home Goods & in a strip mall.)

I hope this is the same place.

In any case, kohl's is the home of "disposable clothing" and also a good place to get inexpensive housewares and gift items.  The quality is much better than Kmart or WalMart - and some may argue that the clothing is nicer than arget - to me the quality and price points are about the same.

The nice thing I like about Kohl's is the incredilble deal I get on baby/kids clothes and shoes.   scored fabulous sneakers for my daughter at a fraction of retail price.

DFor myself - I am not a huge fan - but i have slowly started buying a few shirts & sweaters here due to my new budgetary restrictions on shopping.  Kohl's has been great also for my husband who bought some semi-precious jewelry (10 K gold and Topaz) for him mother (my mother in law) for Mother's day.  It was a bargain for sure. 

I would not purchase "fine" jewelry here - but when them have sales - they realloffer deep discounts ant the jewelry department is always worth a look!

Well, now that Hong Kong Jack's is dead and gone - Chin's is THE only game in town for Classic Chinese-American.  (There are 2 small take out joints that keep changinbg hands down 611 toward Warrington).

Chin's offers perfectly safe Cantonese and a few Szechuan dishes - and all the classics you'd expect.  Service is fast (especially if you call in a take out order and then drive over to pick it up) and friendly.

Our only gripe?  They don't open until 2 PM on Sundays - so lunch on a Sunday is out.

OK, so this review is for the sales portion - we have yet to take delivery on our newly-purchased leather sofa.  Price was right, sale rep Alan was terrific and Reggie at the check-out was efficient.

Will update review once the couch arrives in about a month.  Hopefully not 4 months (some furniture stores have a 12 to 16 week wait time).

So far, so good.  Go during a sale!

I stick with the salads here, although a coworker gets the stir fry and likes it.  The Cobb Salad (I make a few changes to it using the touch screen ordering sustem) is a bit steep ($12 when I get through with it.) but the portion is immense and I can eat some at 3 or 4 PM if I get hungry again that day.  It will not keep well the next day.

The staff is underpaid and disinterested which I fear will cause long term service issues.  The 2 guys at the wok - working very hard - were clearly ticked off about something.  Then, the oven started to smoke.

Crispy-drama at lunch.

Came here many years ago to get a (cold) six pack.
A nice selection of wines, liquors and beer by the case or six-pack.

Young guys running the counter.
No issues.

OMG, Dunkin' has taking over the universe - including Suburban Station with multiple outposts.

That said I never eat donuts, but I do occasionally succumb to temptation and get a hot or ice latte as is seasonally appropriate.

Passero's in Suburban has far superior coffee and food but is also more money - natch.

It is still cheaper that Charbucks (FiveBucks?) and they have oodles of flavors/syrups (I pass on those.)

For a "regular" cuppa joe - Dunkin or Wawa are my go-to's.
Thanks for being here when we need you, Dunkin. You are taking over the WORLD.

Fantastic Thai - the same stuff as the now-closed Thai Chef in Philly.
Tom Kha (Coconut) soup is divine and not too thick and not too watery.
DUCK Pad Thai was a bit sweet but the noodles and duck were both perfectly cooked.

(MEAT of choice) - we opted for pork - in Thai Basil sauce was very mildly spicy (tolerable for even a light-weight).  Delish.

Casual, friendly service.

This Starbucks has a drive thru which is great - however there is nearly always a significant line.  Also if you come after 11 or 12 noon they are sold out of many "breakfast" type items so keep that in mind. 

No real issues.  Keep in mind I have never set foot inside this particular store - but I have used the drive thru 3 or 4 times.  Convenient for me when I am heading North on 202.

What?!?  Nobody yelped DVC yet?  Wow.

Where do I start?  Delaware Valley College is part of the backbone of the Doylestown/New Britain area.  In the 1800 it was started as a "Farm School" later re-named as an agricultural school, and it still overs terrific program in farming, equine and bovine studies, horticultre and floricultre.

Each year "A-Day" (Agriculture Day) is where the Aggies can flaunt their stuff. Everything from campus-grown produce to honey is displayed.
As kids we could not WAIT for A Day each year.

The school now focuses on teaching and educatioon certificate and degree programs.  Its a good school.  (Not Ivy League, of course - but a good, solid college.)

For retired citizens (my Mom included) there are numerous non-credit courses and programs.  Foreign Languages, Art, Music and lots to choose from.

If you live near DVC, try to take advantage of all it has to over the community.  It is a great local resource.  (High school kids - you may be able to borrow books from the DVC library.)

We purchased our living room couch from R & F about 2-3 years ago after seeing it advertised on sale (and after shopping at nearby LazyBoy, Ethan Allen and other mid priced chain furniture stores.)

Furniture is expensive, and quality is not what it once was, but I am happy to say that our couch (which was delivered as promised and on time a few days after we ordered it - hooray!) is standing up to the major abuse our elderly pug and young child are giving it.

I just called the store today to see about replacement seat cushions.  I am hoping to get a favorable reply.

Customer service has been excellent.  (And for a cheap $600 couch - that says alot.)

This is not FINE nor designer furniture - but for day to day, middle class, family living - R&F is working for us.

Di Bruno's is kinda like the Philly version of Citarella or Agata & Valentna in NYC.  It's a gourmet & specialty food market with a vast catering arm and now an upstairs lunch-only weatery.  It also has a cafe/espresso bar with a small selection of artesenal gelato.

The pastries are good - but pricey.

The cheese counter is a good place to investigate a world of cheeses.  (I, of course, hjave been forever spoiled by Murray's in NYC -but this is a good Philly alternative.)

They also carry sushi, spreads, and pricey prepared dishes.
Fresh produce is a plus - but the selection is limited.

I contacted Pitruco about hosting a private event.  They were responsive and wonderful.  While my budget won't support it right now ($750 minimum for about 50 people at $15 per person), I will definitely consider them for future events. (The event I am having is for about 20-25 people only.)

If you are having a big graduation party or family reunion, it'd be so cool to have the Pitruco truck roll up and crank out fresh pies for your guests.

A gal's gotta dream...
Maybe some day Pitruco will come rolling up to MY driveway.

As a community resource for non-credit courses it seems just fine.
I have never enrolled here in a degree program but many of my colleagues' kids attend here and some adult learners also.

The vast parking lots are STILL not enough parking (Imagine??).

There is a small café/coffee bar in the main building that serves a decent latte.

So far, I am still exploring all that DCCC has to offer.

Came here during the Covid19 crisis looking for paper products and they had some!!!  Alice at the front counter was cheerful and friendly amidst all the chaos.

This CVS is well managed, clean and well-run.

Great!

Stopped here on an early Saturday morning, with "mixed precipitation"  to use the restrooms and grab a Starbucks.  There was NO LINE at Starbucks - wow!  Usually there is a huge one.

Very pleasantly surprised with the Starbucks.

Bathrooms need a touch up - a few toilets had urine in them - unflushed.  Ick.

Cold Hiyashi Ramen (regular with Cha su or Vegetarian) is a summertime treat.
I get mine with the sauce/dressing on the side.

Blissful carbo-loading.

I got there at 11:45 just before the lunch rush hit and got in and out with my take out bag.  Sweet!

3 or 4 stars depending on what you get.  Yes, you can eat there but there is zero atmosphere - so we get it as take-out.  My vegan kid likes the vegetable lo mein (no egg).

A little greasy, inexpensive - reminds us of the take out Chinese we used to get in Brooklyn.

No frills, no issues.

Is it the most amazing food ever?  Heck no, but it is cheap, fast and tasty and once in a while we will come here.  Counter-man/Manager is always kind to us - never had a problem with service.

Hornberger's delivered a lovely two-tiered mini wedding cake to our office for a wedding shower.  The buttercream icing and sugar flowers over a tasty (dense) vanilla (pound?) cake was delicious and gorgeous.

Easily fed 20 people (4 inch round over a 6 or 8 inch??).

Had a great take-out meal from Chin's on Monther's Day (did not want to deal with crowds at restaurants).  Beef and brocolli, chicken with cashew nuts, spare ribs, one egg roll (for my old-school relatives), pepper steak, house-special fried rice (really good) and chicken lo mein.

All were hot and fresh (They open at 2 on Sundays) and better than last time.

Tip:  ask for "light on the sauce" to mitigate the grease factor.

3.5 stars - I will be gracious and round up to 3.
Creed's is reminiscent of a by-gone era.  (Seafood Shanty?  Conti's Cross Keys Inn?)  It definitely has an old-school vibe in décor, service and food.

The food itself was actually excellent. We went for lunch and it was around $45 including tax and tip for 2 (no booze, no desserts).
I had a shrimp cobb salad and the ingredients were all super fresh and tasty.  
My friend had a very nice looking (but small) crab cake over spinach.

Service was attentive and fine - but this is NOT a place to go if you are in a rush.
Leisurely.  Sedate.  Safe.  (No nouveau cuisne here, no fusion)  A good place to take your parents - or rather have them take YOU.  Bring money!

Other than the extremely cramped seating (this place is hoppin' at lunch time), our party of 4 enjoyed our food very much.  I had the Burmese Crunch salad with tofu and it was delicious. 2 of my friends had it with grilled chicken.  A 4th colleague had the curry with large grilled shrimp which looked amazing.

We'll be back for sure.  I would like to try the wings. 

Much improved over the Chinese place that used to occupy this spot.

Nice flowers for my birthday via internet ordering.
They misdelivered me the wrong arrangement but quickly fixed the issue.

Lovely selection of fresh flowers in a classic glass vase.

Easy in and out here on most days - compared to other PennDOT locations.
License renewals, testing, permits, etc.

Located inside the Booth's Corners Farmers Market (Hours are limited to Fridays and Saturdays except during holidays and special events when there could be more hours).  Grecian Delights is an inexpensive and absolutely DELICIOUS counter-style restaurant.  Nikki - our server - was terrific and the gyros, grilled chicken, salad, tzatziki and especially that Avgolemono soup were all Yia-Yia approved.

I can't wait to dine here again - or get a $20 gyro special (with a big salad and baklava) to go for a quick dinner for 2.

I LOVE IT.

Super yum!!!

There used to be 2 KC's but I think the one on 11th Street has closed.
Thank goodness the 10th Street location still purveys oodles of freshly baked breads, cakes and sugar-y confections.

The fried donuts and buns are so good - and when you get them while they're hot - Oh what a treat.

I vote each election at the nearby Chinatown fire department - so I pass buy KC's on my way to work after I vote.  I always get a croissant (Chinese style) or a sponge cake "cone" wrapped in paper.

It is decadent to munch away on such a treat while riding the SEPTA bus west on Market.

And all for under $1.50!!!!

Sign me up!

For $11.95 the lunch special - includes drink and choice of Tom Yum soup, Dumplings, Egg Roll (fried) or Fresh Spring Roll (Summer Roll - not fried) is a very nice meal.

I have tried the Bun (Rice Vermicelli also, Masuman Curry (very good) and Tofu with Eggplant.

A little greasy and sweet - but solid Viet/Thai especially for out here.
The Philly area's Thai choices are lacking.  This place is Vietnamese with a few Thai dishes also.

So far I have come 3 times for lunch - and that is after visiting Thai Orchid nearby twice.  This place - for me anyway - is better.

Much better to come here in the winter for some warm comfort food.
I tried the chicken salad with green apples - very good but just a tad too mayonaise-y for my picky palate.  Next time I'll go back to the 1/4 chicken platter.

The counter gal who has been there from the start is amazing.  She is bright and friendly and works her tail off!

Friends all had 1/4 chicken meals - some had light, some had dark - all enjoyed.  Mac 'n cheese, corn muffins, kale chips, beet salad, collard greens and mashed sweet potatoes were enjoyed by all.

LOVE IT HERE.

(Boston Market for Yuppies?)

Too costly but a nice facility with great classes (like Zumba, Water Aerobics and Karate). Excellent pools and swimming instruction.

9 year old found the summer camp way too boring so we don't go any more.

Soooo cheap and very good cakes and sponge cones.  My daughter loves it here.  They also have numerous flavors of bubble tea.

We have come here 3 times now for the delcious cream cake, shrimp dumplings (fried and greasy - but pretty tasty, too.) and superb egg custard tarts.

2 tiny tables to sit at - so get it to go if you can.  DD & I tend to sit and people watch.  She just LOVES it here and the nice ladies behind the counter love her.

Very reasonble prices, too.  They treat my blue-eyed, sandy haired 4 year old like a rock star.  She's give it 6 stars!

Big shout out to Tina who treated my 7 year old so very well!
My little one loves the chicken here (the two of us get the $12 1/2 chicken meal which is way more than we can eat.  The corn mini-muffins were a huge hit with DD.  I love the Kale Chips (DD not as much.).  Plus they now serve Reed's Ginger Brew.  I love this place more and more - and when I want roast chicken - this is where I come.

Today (a Wednesday) was my first go at the East Norriton Salad Works.
Since the mad rush was over on Tuesday (Every Tuesday all "standard" salads are $6.99), there was hardly any line on a Wednesday.

I got a "pick 2" combo - 1/2 an avocado BLT and a 1/2 salad.
Everything was fine and even the lettuce mix was fresh.

No issues so far.
I will be back - but NOT on a Tuesday.  It's worth 2 extra dollars to NOT wait in that line.
I may experiment with online pick-up ordering.  But I fear the Tuesday crowds.

I am actually reviewing the new InnerVision at 1700 Sansom.
I assume it's the same owners - but not sure.

Anyhow, even though I elected to pruchase my glasses elsewhere - I really liked the selection of fine frames and the GREAT customer service I received from Micha.  The frames are gorgeous - and of course pricey.

I would recommend looking here - but I have to say I found 1 place I liked better - and I wound up purchasing there.

I am very thankful to Kennedy Food Garden for being there over the years.
Rebecca at the front counter and the deli guys are friendly and service oriented.

The shrimp salad is still a fave as well as the kasha and potato knishes.

I can get milk, juice and sliced fruits and veggies here in a pinch.

They are my winter savior!

It's not bad - I think the same people run it as ran my old cafeteria at JP Morgan (not Aramark - but some other big conglomerate food service thing).

They have a salad bar, a "Jazzman's Coffee" bar, a pizza station, grill (with greasy burgers and junk food), a hot entree (today it was fried fish), and several grab 'n go foods like salads, SUSHI (from Bumblefish - not bad!) and parfaits.

It a pinch - it's great as I live nearby.  Open from 6:30 AM - 7 Pm but by 6 PM the pickin's get slim - it's better for lunch.

Finally tried the pricey 1906 restaurant and had 5 star service (and 4 star fare) on the lovely outdoor deck.

Salmon was tender ($26 for lunch!!!!) and Burger ($18!!!) on a Brioche bun with sauteed mushrooms and onions was very good also.

Super pricey (even with 10% off for members) but a fun and special experience.
Great for Mother's Day (come a different day and celebrate your mom) or a proposal dinner.

Friendly staff convinced me to buy the $5 per year club card to get lower prices - a decent investment if you shop there as often as I do.

Professionals (bring your license) get an even better deal.

Combs, brushes, flat irons and nail supplies.  Skin care selection is limited.

Everything tastes better on somebody else's dime...

Meanwhile I attended a "heavy app" holiday party at JG last night.
Nathan - who took care of our raucous party of 22, kept the drinks flowing and I tried the FABULOUS Butterscotch (supposed to have a bit of bourbon in there??) Latte.

Dessert in a cup.

Beef sliders were cooked very rare - which I did not mind, but others complained. Charcuterie and cheeses (and heavenly fig jam) were artfuly displayed and delicious to eat.  Mini crab cakes (puffs) were fried and fattening.  Flatbread with mushrooms, truffle oil and fried ege was a BIG hit.

Try the beers here, too!

My faith has been restored.  Although I still don;t like paying $30 - $0 for lunch - I just might come here again pretty soon.  Gotta get me another of those $6 calorie-bomb lattes.

Had a much better time now that my little one is 6.5.
She was too freaked out by the Spies & Saboteurs Exhibit (there is a KKK part that she found very disturbing)

But she LOVED the 17 minute show in the Kimmel Theater (Freedom Rising) and the "carpet game" for kids on the top floor.

We became members through Groupon, so from now through next June we'll be living there.

They had 1 of the 2 obscure items I needed (wish they carried both).  Helpful staff - friendly service.  No issues here.

Please stock "blue denim" doggie diapers.  My elderly pug needs then (we currently can only get the at MonsterPets in South Philly).

Even though I much prefer to shop at the Giant in Aston (or Whole Foods in Glen Mills when time and budget permits), I stopped in here and customer service was so, so, so much better than at Giant.

I bought a jar of jam for my dad and it turned out not to be the right kind.
They took it back 5 days later (unopened, of course) with no receipt. This is a rare occurrence and I was hoping they would not give me any problems.

I am very pleased.

Nearly 5 stars - what a great place to sit and have a drink (try the house made ginger ale - so perfectly refreshing) or a franglo-pub lunch.  The house burger is quite good and comes with frites AND a nice green salad.

A good place to meet a client, conduct an interview or just hang out.

I really love Harvest - but during peak times the acoustics are LOUD!!!!!
Our server Ian was terrific and explained the menu and dishes well.  My husband enjoyed the shortrib entree.  Potstickers ($10 - ouch!) were fried and IMO over cooked.

I enjoyed the quinoa salad - and a small was plenty for me ($6) and loved the shrimp (2 large deliciously seasoned shrimp) crabmeat cocktail served over gazpacho and a thick slice of yellow tomato.

Love it here - and can't wait to come back.
A little pricey but great for a date or a family meal.

This is such a cutesy place to shop for everything your pooch would ever need.  My daughter loves to browse in here, too.

I have a sweet 12 year old male puggy - and they are so nice to us.  Great advice on pet care, too.
Very bondage oriented but a good selection of toys and adult enhancement items in a no-pressure environment.  Fun to browse.

A nice place to hang out and eat/drink/shop.  They've done a nice job with it.  I wonder though, if you live in one of those big, new buildings, does the noise level in the summer (especially on Saturday nights) preclude a quiet family life??

Just sayin'...

Visited 3 times in the summer of 2016 -Liberty Bell, NMAJH, Constitution Center, City Tavern and many local restaurants, cafes and shops.

I am proud and glad to live in the Greater Philadelphia area.

I get my cheapie manicures and polish changes here because they are clean and quick.  I am not feeling secure enough to get a pedicure here though as I am a complete hygiene snob and a pedi-connoisseur.  I used to go to Mint Julip for pedis - but my favorite vernisseur left.  I guess it's back to Salon Royale Court for pedi's from now on.

Meanwhile - need a quick eyebrow wax or a mani (or $6.00 polish change?)

Hurry.

Pick-color!

4.5 stars - just a hair shy of 5.

I just attended a private luncheon event at the Union League in the McMichael room.  The service was "White Glove" and so attentive and wonderful.  Food was good - with a great salad that contained dried cranberries, toasted oine nuts & crumbled bleu.

Also a stand-out were the individually plated pecan pies.  YUM-O!

The entrees, however were just "OK" my fish stuffed with crabmeat bechamel was a tad dry and OVERLY salty.  I can't speak to the other entree choice - roast pork - as I don't "do pig".  But it looked nice.

Great presentation and a great, historic space with lots of portraits to look at - one of George W. was being hung with great care the day I was there.

You can also (try to) have your wedding here - but you really "gotta know someone" to get on the list.

Oh - and there IS an enforced dress code - so don't be the bopob that I was and show up wearing sheakers.  (I KNEW I shoulda hauld my shoes along..)

They snuck me in thru the back.

I came here alone for lunch on a dead-to-the-world August Thursday at about 12:15 PM.

Place was nearly empty and thus, I had attentive and Stellar service from a lovely young lady (I forgot her name).

Good music on in the background (we had just lost Aretha Franklin today so lots of 50's and 60's tunes, including the Queen of Soul and BB King).

But even better was the $9.79 2 meat combo for lunch.  Wow!  I'm gonna need a nap at my desk fter that feast of ribs (2 - but very tender and delicious) and 1/4 chicken dark. 

Those corn muffins taste like cake.

$2.99 for a diet soda seems way high though...
In any case, Famous Dave's is a chain so you know what you are getting when you go. Decent 'cue in a chain-y environment.

Wow - I can't believe it took me this long to yelp the Constitution Center.  This really is a must-stop place for visitors & tourists as well as residents.  The exhibits are historically accurate and a bit of fun - although kinda dull for the very young (our 4 year old would rather run the halls).

The performance is not a great for young kids - too boring - but we, as parents, enjoyed it.   (And the respite of sitting down for a few!!)

Solid!  A great new choice for lunch ($7 for dark, $8 for white 1/4 with 2 sides).

My BFF and I got a 1/2 chicken and 2 sides for $11.50 - 2 sides were plenty for us to share.  We chose the cornbread mini-muffins (so good) and mac 'n cheese (my friend loved it, I wasn't wowed.)

Meanwhile the chicken is the star of the show.  Not too salty, yet nicely seasoned and perfected rotisseried.

It was very warm in there - even with the A/C running.  (All those rotisseries)/

Decent service, too.

Jamie sums it up - this is the Adult version of Plato's Closet.
I found some cheap and cute (new with tags on) items but nothing that fit well.
I will be back to try again. 

Excellent service from Nyra (nyla?) from NYC.

Valentine's Day weekend and service by Laura was wonderful even if we could only get a 5 PM or 8:30 PM res.  We opted for 5 PM and there was still a huge crowd.

Appetizer sampler ($20) was great as well as Duck App. The kiddo devoured it.
Sashimi was MUCH fresher and better this time including the ($27) Blue Fin lover's plate and a few pieces of toro ($8 a pop) and Ikura ($4.50).

No room for dessert but we left happy.

Dear Nail Salon,

I confess! Today I cheated on you, my usual nail salon, with Noble Nails.
Kim is an excellent technician and gave me a straightforward, basic manicure with the new OPI Nail Envy Color Formula.  I am anxious to see how many days wear I can get out of it.

My hands were is dire need of cuticle care, and Kim is a true professional.
The salon is clean and well run.

If I lived near here, I would DEFINITELY be back.
$10 mani, $22 gel and $22 pedis.  (They also have $30 hot stone spa pedis.  YAY!!!!!)

They also carry CND - including my beloved Vinyluxx. I can get 6-8 days out of a Vinyluxx Mani!

Loving it here so far.

This is a review of the Macy's located in the Cheryy Hill mall.  We had a fun day of shopping noth at Nordstrom and here at Macy's.  My friend got 2 amazing pair of shoes at great prices.

The sales are worth checking out.

Many thanks to the Acme on Baltimore Pike in Media for supporting our girl scout troops and graciously allowing them to seel Girl Scout cookies at their stores.

We are so grateful for this!
A good choice for local produce in season - strawberries, preserves and tomatoes in the summertime.

Took our 2012 Hyundai herefor annual inspection and a few minor repairs.
Had a 9:30 AM appointment and arrived early - 9:15.  Inspection was done (including oil change) in about 1 hour while I waited.  Took another 90 minutes for repair work.

Killed the whole morning - but at least not the entire day.
TV in waiting area with coffee and a water cooler.

Thankful we got out in about 3 hours.

Our 10 year old LOVES this store and we come in all the time now.
Gonna ask for gift cards for her next birthday.  Check out the selection of nightlights of all things.

Wonderful things.

OK, now that my 3 year old is nearly 7 - this place is a wee bit more appropriate.  (Incidentally she had her 6th birthday party and will have her 7th also at North Bowl).  Meanwhile - we popped in for a quick game (she bowled - I watched - our poor server, Dennis (bless his heart) served us 2 glasses of water).  $11.00 for 1 game ($5.95) plus show rental.

Sheesh.  Glad I didn;t order a cocktail.

Meanwhile - the BASE price for a kis party here is now $25 a head.

The music was very loud - but they turned it down for us.
Lanes are clean and seating is comfortable.

Very "clubby" - just as it was when we came here years ago.

The 7 year old loves it! (But - she did say that she likes North Bowl better - and so do I for many reasons.)

It sure ain't the crappy old bowling alley that I grew up with!

Did they re-model?
Something seems better about this beer-stocked deli - snacks, sandwiches and all the usual suspects.

A wide selection of cold drinks.

Good location - and hours.

No issues from me.

Yup.  This is the place.  This place is worthy of my 600th review on yelp!!!  It has the sentimental factor (CHeck) - we ate here right after meeting with the Judge who would marry us.

It has the location factor (Philly burbs).

It has - most importantly -great Mexican food and free Margarita's in a strip mall.  You gotta love that loosely interpreted liquor law.  Go, Pennsylvania!

In any case we thoroughly enjoyed (and JUSt - I mean just barely - beat the dinner crowd by getting there at 5:25 PM on a weekday. ) our home-made salsa fresca, chips and terrific guac.

I had chicken in a mole sauce - but it was different some how - and really special.  My (then) fiance had lamb - which her really enjoyed.

Not cheap - but so worth it.

What a surprise and a pleasant one. By the time we left the place was PACKED - and i bet they will continue to pack 'em in.

By the way - free or not - the Margarita's were very good, indeed.

Woo Jung (Brother is Woo, Sister is Jung) is a Korean owned Japanese place (with Hwe Dup Bap on the menu!) in a strip mall in East Norriton.  I was honestly scared to even try it but I am so glad I did.  The staff is wonderful and my experience was terrific as a single diner on a dead-empty Friday lunch.

I ordered the $16.95 lunch special which came with 6 pieces of sashimi (all were excellent - included seared/sauced Chu-Toro!  Score!!!!!!) and 3 nigiri (Tuna, Salmon and a white fish - not sure which - not yellowtail).  The accompanying spicy tuna roll was delicious as well.

Miso soup had a slight sweetness of Mirin.
Very nice.

I can't wait to return!!

BYO - and a little pricey for lunch but worth it for a special treat.
Now, maybe they'll add some galbi to the menu???

Thank you, Jung!!!!!

The food is excellent but Soooooo pricey.  The cafe next door is a better value - and similar food choices.  But what really makes this place special are the sweeping views of Longwood gardens.  

I love it there!

Top-quality, good looking breakable gift items.  Lamps, baubles, shiny stuff and GOREOUS, gorgeous gifties.

It's been around forever and I love it.

OK - I take back some of what I said.
After a year has passed - I returned to Tierra Mia today and found a few things have changed.  The icy-cold receptionist is gone (YAY) and I was treated very well during my visit today.

I started with a $58 pedicure with the coconut oil & fresh coconut shavings as the exfoliant.  It was done by Karina herself and was FANTASTIC.  I hope the polish will wear well - as my feet feel FAB-U-LOUS.  Again - I reiterate the pedicure chair she bought has sounds therapy - ask for the headphones - that vibrates in time to relaxing music.  It is a reall cool, wonderful pedicure chair.

I would pay money just to come and sit in it for a while.

After my pedi - which took about 60 minutes, I got the seasonal cucumber mani.  It was $28 and used pure shea butter, sea salt and cruished cucumbers (they put it in a food processor).

Very cooling and wonderful for summer.

Justin - Karina's fiance was there - and he is a very nice guy and runs things well.

It's a beautiful (pricey) spa.  I am fearful the polish will yellow or chip. (I told them about my previous experience with yellowing - and they said NO SUNSCREEN or bug spray.  Turns out I had, indeed, applied sunscreen after my services a year ago - MY BAD!)

I still wish we could bring our own polish - and I kinda thing it's ridiculous that for the MONEY we are paying (I dropped $100 even today including tip) we can't use our OPI or CND products for fear of destrying her air quality.  That still seems a bit wrong, but anyway - If I can get a decent wear out of her products (all water based polishes), I will come back again.

Definitely for pedis - not sure if I can justify a $28 mani every week - or even every 2.

Tierra Mia - you are a beatiful, unique place.  I am sure you will be very successful.
El kiddo is now 11 and still loves coming here.  Expensive but fun.
