Yay to Rebecca Michaels for expanding the Flying Monkey empire.  The new space is small, but so cute - and the color scheme continues the theme.  You can get all the goodies you know and love from the Reading Terminal location here in the gayborhood.

Go, monkey, go!

I can not believe how clean, new, slick, friendly and pleasant my experience was at the new (actually 5 mos. old) Panda Express, fast-food Chinese in the Comcast Center.

Normally I can not stand sloppy, gloppy, steam-table, mall Chinese - so boy was I shocked when the food not only looked great (albeit lots of the choices and all of the shrimp choices are fried) but tasted good, too.

Trepidatious bynature I ordered only a small a la carte (1/2 pint) box of Honey Walnut Shrimp (Fried + Mayonnaise + Sugar = health BOMB) and instantly recalled the bygone era of late 1980's Chinese-American fare.

The Manager, Jay,  was very accomodating and said that now - for large orders (and within a few blocks) they will deliver and the offer party trays and catering.  The even have a deal they will do with schools for fundraising.

The wheels are turning...  Perhaps a Panda Feast (for $30 you get 3 large entress and 2 large sides - enough for 4 (easily) to 7 (tiny eaters) people.  A big pan entree $36 - $48 if you pick shrimp feeds about 8 people.

They also have a small catering package for $96 that easily feeds 16.

I am planning a prty soon and will update my review with the results - but so far I am shockingly pleased with Panda Express.

Still Excellent after all these years.  A gal-pal and I shared the potato latke app with our lunch today - what BLISS.  3 petite, crisp, flavorful (not too greasy) pancakes topped with lightly salted smoked salmon, applsauce and dill creme fraiche.  WOW.

My Kale salad was over-the-top delicious and lightly dressed with the perfect amount of lemon/oregano vinaigrette (You could taste juice and zest) with parmesan slivers and sweet, glorious butternut squash chunks.  I got a small for $7 - but next time I may just get the large ($10).  Good, good, good stuff.

Very nice server, too.

GO TO MATYSON.  So rockin' good.

This place is more of a shop and less of a tea bar - for a tea bar see Remedy down the street and around the corner - but STEAP has a great selection of fine and rare loose leafs.

I like both Remedy and Steap - but I prefer to buy tea here and drink tea at Remedy.

The Iced Peach White I tried over the summer was terrific.  No sweetener needed.  It was naturally fruity and sweet with a clean finish.

YUM!

Oh - and teas and tea-gear from STEAP make for cute gifts.

An American classic and a Philadelphia GAYborhood staple.  Help save Giovanni's!  This place is a needed gem and a beacon for free-speaking, free-thinking Americans, gay or not.

Love it here!

A solid 4 stars (the Beet Salad was 5 star for me) with swanky decor, clean restrooms, great service from Tim and a healthy wine list.  (A few more sparklers by the glass would be nice.

I loved the beet salad app (Got a small for $5) served with pickled SWEET cippolini onions and served atop a small amount of tasty goat cheese cream (not too goaty).  I also enjoyed the mushroom papardelle - loaded with asparagus, garlic slices and of course - lots of 'shrooms.

My partner's food came out cold - but they promptly heated it up.
His sweet potato mash was far to nutmegy for me - but the side of mac 'n cheese ($5) was terrific.  Bison meatloaf was $22 and served with baby carrots and broccolini (a bit salty).

Not 5 stars - but very close - a lovely lunch was $66 without booze and without dessert - so that is a bit pricey.  (My cappucino was $6 - OUCH.

I agree with Caroline AND Emily.  We take our little girl here and she LOVES it - especially all the animals.

They have activities in every season - even winter time.
Xmas trees, Halloween Hay rides, Strawberry picking in spring.

Love it!

And yes - we make her wash her hands after petting the goats and before eating ice cream (or apple turnovers!!!)

Aliitle touristy and a few items in the market have HIGH prices - but hey - the loval produce is terrific.  We love it here.

Had dinner at the sushi bar on a busy Saturday night (no reservation so no tables available - but plenty of sushi bar spots early on).  Excellent service by our server and expediter as well as the 2 "junior level" sushi chefs.

DH ordered edamame and chicken teri (yeah, I know) which he enjoyed.
I had a small (which was huge - I can't imagine how enormous the large must be) Tom Kha which is one of my faves.  I have had Tom Kha at many places and the Tom Kha hear was overly sweet and thick with too much coconut milk and lacked the lemongrass and complexityy that a good Tom Kha should have.  That said - it was tasty but bland.  not exciting at all. Would not reorder it here unless I am having an intense Tom Kha Craving.

The Blue Fin lovers platter was deliciously fresh - and the complimentary veggie naruto roll was crisp and refreshing.

Since aside from Temaki in Media, this is the best sushi we have found (Yes, we've tried Margaret Kuo's and Azie)  we shall return.  And next time we'll make a reservation!

Oh - and the prices are on the high side.
Love coming here to bird-watch and walk around on a nice spring or summer day with el kiddo.  Free - and fun and can e educational.  Good for biking, too.

Free internet access and (as I happen to be an ING account holder) access to your banking.

Plus if you wear orange (like that EVER happens??) on certain days your coffee is free.

Kitschy come-ons and cool swag to be had here as well.

I really enjoy banking with ING Direct and the coffe shop is a nice addition.

But they need to clean those bathrooms more often - or else they'll be downgraded to 3 or even 2 stars.  They get GROSS!!!

My daughter enjoys the "square pizza" slices here (She refers to Sicilian as "square pizza") but even she at the astute age of 8 commented, "It's good - but not as good as Brooklyn".

Sums it up perfectly.

Smart kid.  Like her Momma.

Surrisingly good food located in the bowels of Suburban Station.
Breakfast wraps are made to order and fresh - $3.50 each.

Friendly cashier lady and cooks.

Matyson used to stand for Matt y Sonia - but, alas, the original owners have fled the coop.  However, the place is still run by a member of the family and for a BYOB - this place ROCKS.  I have been there for both lunch (many times) and dinner - just a few.

The $45 prix fixe is a deal - IF you like what they are serving.  Most times I pick and choose - and let me just say that you can not go wrong with the fish.  For lunch a delicious trout sandwich on fresh black bread with watercress for just $11 is terrific.  I have also tried the lobster pop-overs.  A warm, buttery pop-over (man I could eat about 4 of them plain) with large pieces of lobstermeat surrounded in a DECADENT (read: just a bit too much cream, for me) newburg style sauce with fresh chopped tomtato and presh green peas.

They also love morel mushrooms.

Dishes are complex without being "snooty" or "over the top".
Desserts are great, too.

LOVE Mat-y-son - even under the new regime.

I am giving this a high mark based on the ONE birthday party we attended there today as a guest.  The 2 staff members who worked with the 15 kids (aged 2 - 6 - mostly 5 year olds) were lovely especially Sun.  They supervised 60 minutes of Gym activities (including the Air Track - a big inflatable trampoline-type thing that the kids just LOVED).  The parties are based on 15 kids and cost $300 ($320 for non-members) plus $35 extra for the air track.  Cake is NOT included, but all the paper goods, balloons and everything else is all done for you.

I have been to lots of kids parties recently, and this place was well run and a good active place to have a party for a 4, 5, 6 or even 7 year old.

I can not comment on their gymnastics or dance classes.

I called Triple A when I had a slow-leak flat and they dispensed Dan from Jamison;s towing.  Dan is terrific - he was patient and explained everything well.

He also inflated all 4 tires and I was able to get on my way.

Thank goodness for triple A and Jamison's was just fine, in my opinion.  I did not require any major repairs.

We had a terrific time here on opening day (3/27/09) and had makeovers at the jam-packed Chanel counter in the jam-packed cosmetics department.  Scored some great new eyeshadows and Glossimer.

We ogled the David Yurman counter and tried on some fancy shoes.

I adore Nordie's and am so glad there is now one nearby.

There are now so many Doggie Styles around it  feels chainish.  Anyhow - this cutesy dog boutique (this is for the one on 20 & Walnut - they are all a little sifferent) has doggie gifts and treat, plus cute gear and clothing for big dogs or small.

About a year ago, my child attended a classmate's 6th birthday party here.
The party was well run and the kids (over 20 of them) had a blast.
Parents provide their own cake and refreshments, Bounce U lets the kids play (free-play and organized activities) on their equipment.

Not my idea of a good time, but kids sure do love it.

No atmosphere - but pretty decent grub - 3.5 stars really, but I feel generous and will give them 4.  The atmosphere is about a 2.

I love the Kasha Knishes here - warmed up they taste almost like the ones I'd get out in Brooklyn.  They also make a good shrimp salad and it's always fresh.  They have a high turnover in the deli case - which keeps the cold cuts fresh.

Very nice people working there, too.

Oh - and it's very inexpensive to eat here - or pick up some groceries and take out foods if you don't feel like cooking.

I am glad they exist - higher prices and all (for groceries) because the convience factor is a big plus - especially in inclement weather.

Without Kennedy and Whole Foods - we'd be sunk.

A gorgeous arrangement arrived for me today from Carl Alanand so far - WOW.  The Flowers were amazingly fresh and the spring flowers lasted 4 days, roses are still goung strong at 6 days.  (Tulips & Freesia wilt quickly.)

A 6 inch glass bubble bowl filled with 6 white roses, 3 pink ranunculus, 3 pink tulips, 3 light purple freesia, green hypericum berries (fill), pink wax flower (filler), and Salal leaves. (Or maybe it's ruscus?)
 
Perfect for a spring pick me up.

I love my best girl friend (who sent me this "just because").  She rocks!!!!
And Carl Alan did a very elegant job on this arrangement.

I am not a fan of Darden/Chain restaurants and my expectations were quite low when a friend suggested we meet for dinner at Bahama Breeze near the King of Prussia Mall.

I arrived a bit early and sat at the bar and had a very nice (classic) mojito.
There is a huge selection of overly sweet and fruity drinks - so a "regular" mojito seemed like a good pick for me.  

My friend arrived and the super-friendly hostess took us to our table.
To start we shared the crab/shrimp stack - very good and fresh tasting.

So many items on the menu are fried or otherwise dietary disasters.

For an entrée I chose (and enjoyed) the grilled salmon with a mango glaze and pineapple salsa.  It was cooked to my liking and not at all dry.  It came with (untrimmed!!!! ick..) haricot vert and sweet plantains.  

I wound up taking about 1/3 of it home - and my kid devoured it instantly.

No room for dessert  - so we paid and left.

I would come back here - but it's not my favorite place.
Meanwhile, for my first time EVER at a BB - it was pretty darned good.
Great service - which surprised me.

Needed an oil change and had a $10 off coupon (so I paid about $40 instead of about $50.
Tried to upsell me on EVERYTHING - filters, fluids etc.  I will do that part myself.

Good news?  Got in and out in 12 minutes.  No lie.

Came again for my regular oil change, also sprang for the $25 tire rotation.  had a $10 off coupon which helped.  Very friendly guys and explained things well.  Again, they try to upsell with EVERY customer - it's just the Jiffy Lube way.

So far I am having a good experience here and I will be back again in 5-6 months.

Comfortable chairs in waiting room.
TV and good tunes on the background music (Classic Rock).

I could write a novel about all the great things we have experienced because of Joe Gunn, Chef Adan and the entire staff at Jose Pistola's.

My 8 year old competed in the 2013 MANNA Guac-Off - where Chef Adan's tuna and sambal topped guac took 1st place (my kid came in 5th - which is not too shabby!).

Since then, Chef Adan and Joe have been so gracious to our family and we finally got a chance to experience a veritable feast of Mexican wonders (some with an Asian twist) with 5 star service all the way.

We truly enjoyed the Scallop tiradito, Classic Guac (and the mango pomegranate one), Freshly muddled pear mojitos, anything with that Korean Rib in it (I had a quesadilla), Lobster Tacos ($18 for two) and HUGE burritos.  (My husband loved the short-rib one.)
Choco-Flan and Churros completed the meal - but we were so full we could barely touch them. (Some how we managed (wink-wink).)

The kiddo loved her black bean and BACON (she asked for it special and they made it for her) quesadilla.  Fan-frikkin-tastic!

Can't wait to return.  We were treated like royalty.

We can't thank you enough!!!

Nook graciously supported my kids old day care and donated 24 mini cupcakes.
I won them - and used them for my child's first grade class.  They were the perfect size and came in chocolate and vanilla.  Cute sprinkles on top, too.

Will definitely come back for more cupcakes and to try the coffee drinks.

Excellent, friendly service.

We are thankful for their support and yummy treats,

Came for Christmas Eve with the fam and the place was packed with families and people of all ages.  Excellent service and much higher quality sushi - but TINY portions.  Appetizer was $15 and barely 3 bites.

Meanwhile we loved all that we ordered, especially the salmon tartare.

A great "special occaision" place.

What a cute place with unique and fun (some functional!) gifts.
Between this and 10,000 Villages your holiday shopping or baby-shower needs are all but met!

Great, friendly owners.
Yes - a bit pricey but unique and mom 'n pop are worth more to me.

Support your local businesses before the world is one big chain store!

The cafe(I have not shelled out the $$ for the pricey 1906 restaurant yet) is great food.
Yes, it's expensive - but the kids meals (mac n cheese) are huge - get one for yourself if you like the options.

We love Longwood and have been members for 2 years now (10% off for members - still expensive!).

I have had several good experiences ordering gifts for friends and also centerpieces for my own events from the Broomall location as well as the Center City branch (separately owned).

The chocolate dipperd berries (added to any arrangement) are great.  Big and thickly coated with chocolate.

My 7 year old loved her Valentin's Day arrangement - and it was eaten within hours.

Good service and delivered on time.

We still love this place - and it is a great resource for adoption, too.  They get such sweet and friendly dogs.

Love the staff, products and care they all display toward our canine friends.

I am feeling super happy and generous - so I am giving Panini's and our lovely server Breah and the other nice ladies who poured water and served our Mother's Day party of 4 this afternoon.  It may only be a 3 star place - but we had a 4 star experience (with 5 star weather for dining al fresco).

The inside of the restaurant is being renovated (and it sorely needs it) and we had a lovely table reserve outside.  (Luckily no car exhaust fumes and no weirdness - plus the aforementioned PERFECT balmy, non-humid, sunny spring day made for a perfect 2 PM reservation.

My 6 year old chowed down on the (boring coled) bread basket right away and ate about a third of her ENOURMOUS (same size as the grown ups) $7.50 kids meal of spaghetti with marinara sauce.

My mom had an antipasta salad which was chock-full of goodies including fresh mozz., marinated artichoke hearts and marinated mushrooms (I ate her 'shrooms - and found then a tad too vinegary for my liking), but my mom loved it.

Dad had liguine al vongole (white) with small tender clams (in shell) and strangely enough - very LIGHT on the garlic.  (usualy liguini with clam sauce is garlic city - but not here.)  He ate every bite and the sauce was perfectly clammy and olive-oil without being a puddle of oil.  NICE!

I loved every bite of my Fettucini with Eggplant (the little one has decide now that she's tried Spaghetti, Liguine and Fettucine all at one meal that she likes fettucine now - so she at a few twirls of mine).  The pastas were all perfectly cooked.  Al dente.  not mushy, not undercooked either.  YUM.

Too full for dessert.  Not super expensive.

I sure hope the renovate soon.  (They are in progress.)
Surprisingly good service.

VERY pleased and will return (We dined pre-Arden Theater.).

This is OUR National park and we must treasure and enjoy it.
Great for singles, couples, families, kids, seniors - everyone can find something to learn about and/or enjoy here.

Wow!  Famous Dave's opened mini-branch in Center City - and they have lunches for $7.99 - $8.99!

The management was so accomodating to us today - and the staff was friendly - especially Jennifer who greeted us at the door. I hope the high service level continues (they are still new and trying hard - so please don't stop trying!)

Our orders were filled quickly & correctly and the BBQ chicken, ribs, corn muffins & sides were delicious - and just like at the "big" restaurant  (chain) in South Philly.

I am so glad to have them in the neighborhood.  Oh - and they have a $19.99 per person (10 people minimum) holiday party special - includes drink, tax & tip!

Can't wait to take my little one here to see Wilbur!!!!!
And maybe ONE day I will try the deep-fried bread pudding with pecan dipping sauce.  (Or dare I even metion the deep-fried oreos?)

Oh, my thighs!

I have always liked browsing in Beans - but since I am in "the industry" and it PAINS me to pay retail - I usually don;t do a whole lot of buying.

However - (especially with a Sephora right across the street and a block over) - I am glad to see them open.

I picked up some Essie polishes (the also have Lippman collection - at full retail) Teraxx Shapoos from Italy and lots of neat things.

They offer hair services in the small salon area in the back, but I have never had anything done here - yet - I just might.

Welcome to the nabe, Beans!  I am so glad you are here!

Oh and the staffers I met (one blonde young woman and a man - older) were both VERY helpful and knew their products!

MUCH nicer (for me) than the vibe I get at Blue Mercury.

A full line of CHI blowdriers and tourmaline charged flat irons.  GOOD STUFF to be had.

The menu has changed a bit and now Korean BBQ is offered, however since we were getting take out we stuck to the basics.  The Beet salad was just wonderful as was the Salmon Ceviche ($11).  Fried rice ($4) was fresh and tasty - basic stuff.  The best part was the Kikku Nigiri platter - very fresh tuna, salmon, yellowtail and a spicy (not super spicy - just right) tuna roll.  ($16)

This was my 4th or 5th visit to Harvest over the years and I still like it.  It's a bit steep on the prices for the amount of food but every plate is under 500 calories (unless noted otherwise) so you get the right amount of food.

I had the summer menu for lunch with a delicious Tuna tartar and a Crab/Shrimp cocktail.  All the seafood was fresh tasting and nicely plated and garnished. My friend had a cedar-planked salmon which looked terrific.  Salads here are always fresh.

A $6 cappuccino (ouch) was my dessert.

Very lovely place for a corporate lunch or a date night or girl's night out.

I am assuming this is the four-bucks inside the Target in Glen Mills.
Went there today for a large order for a group and they were pleasant, helpful & quick.

No issues and so glad they are there.

A decent sushi spot. The lunch menu is very affordable.
I had a Hamachi Lovers lunch with Miso Soup and an order of Ikura (good) and Tamago (Frozen.).

In general, fish seems OK, but lots of frozen product.  Welcome to suburban sushi!

Philadelphia Ladies?  This is the place.  Pefrect for Bridal and wedding needs.  Of course, the main attraction is the selection of dresses.

But this ain't no David's bridal.  (And also, it ain't Kleinfelds)  Be prepared to pay for the level personalized service.

I did NOT purchase my gown here - but I did get a fabulous lead on a seamstress, Teresa - who is just wonderful.

My parents LOVE it here.  It is not a good place for kids, though.  They have a delicious tomato & fresh mozzarella salad - and of course, there's always the BEER.  (They actually brew a substantial amount of it here.)

Dad likes the sandwiches.

It's a nice choice in the midst of the Peddler's Village tourist-trap eats.
I prefer this to the Cock 'n Balls any day.

We took my kid's Girl Scout troop here to have lunch and tour the public areas.  (Would have been 5 stars if we were able to actually tour the facilities).

The food is GREAT.  Sushi, Salads, Hot and Cold foods.  Great soups.

The girls had a good time watching the Koi in the Koi pond, too.

We just moved to the area and joined the Y so our 7 year old can attend the summer camp this summer.  So far we are very pleased and can't wait to use the pools (Kiddo will love the water slide) and sign up for Karate classes.

So far our kid is enjoying the specialty camps.
Costly - but we need it!

This is my go-to diner in Media and I enjoy the home made pierogies (even for breakfast!) and grilled shrimp salad very much.

Other items can be hit & miss.
They also have some unique specials like the shortrib-stuffed ravioli.

Service is friendly and great - they are nearly empty on weekdays for dinner time but JAMMED for breakfast on weekends.

Standard diner fare with a few unique home-made touches.

Oh my goodness - my how you've grown.  Knobs 'n Knockers has been in Peddlers Village a might long time - and has changed locations and expanded enormously from when i remember first going there in the late eighties.  They used to only sell decorative hardware - and that is still the main business - but now with the HUGE influx of NYers and the general yuppification of the whole area - the business is BOOMING and morphing into all sorts of home exterior decor.  (And where else can you drop such serious cash on a DOOR KNOCKER.)  They are like works of art.

Maybe one day when my windfall arrives I, too, will be able to outfit my home and cabinetry with swanky-yet-functional baubles from K 'n K.

Keep on Keepin' on!!!!

Your basic pet shop - right in the Genaurdi's (Now Weis') shopping plaza.
We go here to get Eukeneuba Senoir dry dog food for our pug if we ever run out while we're in D-town.  Thank God they have it!

They also have many toys and treats for dogs (and cats, too.)

Nice teenaged staff running the joint.
Update - 2014:  Have they closed????

We are loyal customers of the Viso's in Aston and were delighted to stop in today for a cream puff (just ok) and FRESH chocolate dipped strawberries (Perfection).

Love the "cone"ollis and cannolli also.
Oh - and the Black Tie Shortcake.

YUM.

If you are a licensed esthetician you can get even LOWER prices.
Otherwise, yes, it is worth it to buy the $5 membership - they give you a free gift worth more than $5 when you renew and the discount is worth it.  (Membership Discount is not as good as Esthetician Discount).

Meanwhile, at this location (smaller but not tiny) the manager is NUTS.
Really nice to customers and just awful to her staff.

I go in about once a month to get hair care and nail care supplies.
I do not get skin care stuff here. (Maybe cotton rounds or sponges.)
Oh - and the "Sally Girl" brand of make-up is cheap and junkie - but my 12 year old love it and for experimentation it's fine.  (99 cent eye shadow singles.)

I nned to let you know how great my goat cheese & beet salad lunch was here today and that you need to RUN OVER here this week to try the "Phillies Victory" Chef's tasting menu.  They have a home-made Butterscotch Krimpet.

I am not kidding.  Go this week or you'll miss out.

Wow - so much cheaper than the MonsterPets I frequent in Philly.  Big wide aisles STOCKED with doggie & kittie gear - and the fish supplies were cheaper too, and more plentiful.  And in DE - no tax (gotta love that).

Kinda felt like a supermarket - except that a few people had their dogs with them.

We'll be back.

We had good customer service from Keith when my husband and I stopped in to test drive the 2012 sonata (and alkso drove a few pre-owned vehicles).

Ultimately we bought elsewhere (got a better price) but we will be coming here for service.  Hope they are kind to us!

Solid!!  Went here again (a few more times since my last update).  Tina is gone - but there are at least 3 fine young gents manning the counter - and the service is still great.

Had a 1/4 chicken dark platter with beet salad (so good!) and corn muffins (love 'em).

They have a new chicken salad now - so I may try it.

Consistently good, tasty, inexpensive lunch staples.

LOVE YOU!

A decent format and good tunes from the old days.
We'll listen to 104.5 when 102.9 or 94.1 are on commercial.
A lovely and historic park and greenspace.  Beautiful river and lush foliage in autumn.
It's getting better & better.

This now our pet-supply store of choice.
They carry Eukeneuba small-breed senior (which we sometimes could not find) and greenies pill-pockets (we have an OLD, old pug).

Get the petsmart card for sporadic discounts.

They also offer grooming and obedience training, though we have never used these services.

It gets me to Joisey when I need to use it.
Relatively timely, inexpensive, fast and (somewhat) safe.

Needs help with the cleaniliness of stations and train cars.

Still lovin' it here - a little pricey ($60 for lunch for 2 sans alcohol/dessert) but so fresh tasting.
Try the Swordfish with crab on top if they still have it.

Summer salads are loaded with heirloom tomatoes that actually taste like ripe, sweet tomatoes.  A lovely selection of ($3) mighty leaf teas.

A great place for date night or dinner with the fam.

Very happy.

The food tastes fine - and the cafeteria style of "design your own" burritos, tacos and quesadillas is catching on fast -but don't be fooled.  It's still fast food - and it is super-duper HIGH in calories.  A typical burrito has 1100 - 1600 calories.  (Naked will reduce it by 330 - as the PLAIN TORTILLA is 330 whopping calories alone.)

That said - I do enjoy the Naked Chicked Burrito, no cheese, small (70 cal) taco-sized torilla on the side.

It's just too hard for me to "hold the guac" and save 220 calories.  That guac - for fast food guac tastes muy bien to me.

By the way - I think Jack-in-the-box owns Qdoba - I know Chipotle is owned by McDonalds.

FAST FOOD - people.
Eat under a health advisory.

Years ago (and I mean many) ETL was THE only place around for any type of Mexican food.  They were much needed and much consumed by my crowd back in the day.

Nowadays, to be fair, there's alot moore competition - but Chicken Tacos and Quesadilla's at ETL ESPECIALLy after a night of New Hope drinking are always a welcome taste of home for me.

Bring on the guacamole - hold the jalapenos (OK, I'm a wimp) - and I am where I need to be.

Recently changed owners and slowly making improvements.
They still have the BEST La Colombe coffee beverages including lattes, cappuccino, mocha and breve.

Gelato, pastries and a few sandwich options.

Love it here.

I am THIS CLOSE to giving Ursula's 5 stars.  I went back again for a bacial (Back facial) with Elina - who is a STAR esthetician.

I can't say enough good things about how well she treated the skin on my back.

WOWZA!!!

If you get a chance to try Ursula's "Pause" spa - you MUST try it.

Stopped in Around 9 PM on a random Tuesday night and got a Gyro to go and it was terrific.  Honestly, great.

Will come back to try more items.
Good service too - since the place was dead-empty.

OK, now that I have been going here for a while (Please, Jeff Prall - my old instructor - don't be mad if you are reading this but they are cheaper than you and I am broke right now) I can give it a true solid 4 stars.  Why not 5?  The space is just too small for all the equipment they have crammed in there.  And the studio for mat classes, while adequate for 5 or fewer students (which is usually the case) is way too packed for the 10 people max they will except.

I also wish you could get a package of 5 Privates or 5 Semi-Privates instead of 10.  Even with a price break $700 is just too much to shell out at once - for me anyway.

Karen Pecarsky, the owner, runs a good business and has good client service skills.  Her instructors, especially Danielle and Lucia (Lucia's Tower classes will kick your a$$) are terrific.  The online reservation system is a little problematic, but so far I have purchased 2 packages from here.  (Thanks for giving my friend her free mat class for refering me!)

I will buy another package, barring no unfortunate occurences.

So far I am liking it here.  Alot.  Wish Jeff Prall taught here.  He is my favorite Philly Pilates instructor.

Oh - and did I mention that I am so glad to find a Power Pilates (brand) studiio?  That's the kind I took from Allisa Stein and Susan Moran when I lived in NYC.  To me Power Pilates is a strong, solid modaility.

Lucia, girl - in my mind you are the mini-Romana.  You keep going with your training.  You rock!  (5 stars to you!)

We have been here 3 times now - the first was the best and was for a friends birthday party and her (rich) parents got the top-of-the-line $23 per kid package so the kids could basically do anything they wanted.

Mama on her own is a bit more, shall we say, frugal, so we usually get the middle-of-the-road pass which includes $5.00 on a refillable card for games.

Our 8 year old LOVES it here and it is much nicer than the crap-ola purgatory that is Chuck-E-Cheese (especially the nasty Chuck E. we were stuck with on Columbus Blvd.). She especially loves the "rock wall".

The games are often $1.00 or $2.00 per play (ouch) so watch your money!

Weonly have one kid, but I could easily see how a family with 2 or 3 (or more) kids would NOT want to come here.

Fun?  Yes.
Better if someone else is paying?  Yes!

I thought the food here was surprisingly good for the quick-service and the fact that there is a full bar.

I had 1 brisket taco (very good - could have used more veggies - it was simple - Pico & Beef).  Also tried a Chicken Enchilada with a sinfully rich lemon cream sauce (not very authentic for Mexican - but tasty and fattening nonetheless.).

Decent fresh-made guac & lots of chips.

Lunch was under $11. Not bad.

We had a lovely 30-35 minute "medium" horse drawn carriage ride with Cynthia (a Philly native and a tough broad!) and her horse "Rex" a tall, handsome, well-trained draft horse.

My little one and I thoroughly enjoyed the good weather (perfect day - not too hot, not cold, no rain) and quiet streets in Society Hill.

I am hopeful that the horses are well fed and kept better than those AWFUL stables we drive by on 13th Street.  I am concerned for all those carriage horses being out in the heat and little fresh water around.

This is a really good place - a bit pricier than I'd like - but worth it.  BIG margarita's and a good selection of entrees.  And yes, as said below, it is nice that they use MANCHEGO cheese and not some generic American alternative.

This is as close as you can get to authentic Mex in Bucks County.

Urbanfront is a decent sized Pilates studio CRAMMED with state-of the art equipment (4 reformers, 2 or 3 Towers, a few chairs and a Cadillac).  There is also a large room for mat classes that about 12 people can be in for a class.

The owner, Karen, is a Certified Power Pilates partner - which is good news for me, as I study this method of Pilates.

There are 2 changing rooms and 2 restrooms in the hall near the studio.

Fees are competitive.  Private, Duo, Semi Private and Group classes are all offered.

I came here for a mat class and returned for a private session with Theresa which was excellent.

I plan to return again as I purchased a small introductory package of Private sessions and mat classes which was a good value.

We attended a corporate dinner/dance event in the Christina Ballroom.
This venue is easy to get to for us and free parking is great, however the event was a bit "sterile" and "cookie cutter" for me and there is no way I would have a wedding here.

Trade show?  Perfect.  Wedding?  Not so much.

Meanwhile the staff was wonderful especially servers Nicole and Latavia.  (Not sure if they came from the venue or from a catering company.)

This venue is a great asset for the Wilmington area and I hope they will keep it well maintained (bathrooms were spacious and clean - hooray!).

Please support business in Wilmington, DE - they need your support.

Iron Hill redeemed themselves tonight with truly stellar service from Bob and Ashley who gave my 8 year old an impromptu brewery tour in the middle of a Sunday Night dinner service.

French onion soup was SPLENDID and not a bit too salty.  Wonderful and worth the close to $7.  Nacho platters are huge but one suggestion - cheese is needed throughout - not just on the top layer of chips (The end is naked chips)..  DD loved the pasta carbonara with shrimp added ($4 more) and had her sauce on the side so she could decide if she liked it or not.  She did.

A real winner tonight.

We'll be back again.

The Pineville Tavern has changed hands several time over the past 35 years.  In its current incarnation (apparently since 1989 - dayamn I am shoing my age), the food is much improved and it is more of a "real" restaurant - or perhaps a "Gastropub" than a bar.

You can still get sandwiches and burgers and brews, but now you get get real meals as well.

Sit in the back and it feels less like a bar (the bar's out front.)

Update: Oh - and no, I had no idea when I wrote this review that Pineville tavern was gonna be on Diners, Drive-ins and Dives tomorrow night!  ACK!  I bet they'll get real busy!

My 13 year old is a lover of (Honeydew) Bubble tea and has tried it at a bunch of places.

Boba Tiki (cute little thatched hut motif) in Media is super convenient for us but not the best Bubble tea - but "very good" nonetheless - per el kiddo.

$5.10 for a large.

Very, very hot inside due to the refrigerators and freezers.

This is a review for one of the many Nina's waffles & ice cream trucks.  Our company paid for the truck to come out to our facility in Plymouth Meeting, PA for about 2 hours on a hot summer afternoon.

Each employee had a choice of a waffle and/or ice cream or a waffle cone with ice cream.  Many toppings were available.  I chose the waffle (fresh, hot, liege style) with home-made espresso crunch ice cream and a drizzle of chocolate ganache.

The man who made them (fresh - to order) was lovely as well.

WONDERFUL and indulgent treat.

A great idea for a corporate event or large party - rent the waffle truck!

The bakeries in Bucks County have not been that great, but Crossroads is surprisingly good - anbd busy as a beehive on Saturday mornings.

My daughter's itty-bitty (.95 cents) chocolate cupcake was the perfect size of deliciousness and I enjoyed a flaky buttery croissant.

I was very impressed with what we tried and would definitely come back again.

We had a lovely 30-35 minute "medium" horse drawn carriage ride with Cynthia (a Philly native and a tough broad!) and her horse "Rex" a tall, handsome, well-trained draft horse.

My little one and I thoroughly enjoyed the good weather (perfect day - not too hot, not cold, no rain) and qiet streets in Society Hill.

I am hopeful that the horses are well fed and kept better than those AWFUL stables we drive by on 13th Street.

Went to Ben & Irv's during Covid (sat inside - everyone wore a mask when no seated) and Michelle, our server, was beyond wonderful.

Half Sour Pickles are always a good thing.
Classic Deli food with HUGE sandwiches (and prices to match).

Sadly, not as good as some other places - the chopped liver was just OK and the kreplach soup was good but not amazing (next time, Matzoh ball - a better choice).

Plus:  You can order your take out while you eat so it will be ready when you are ready to leave.

Excellent service and good but not orgasmic food.

7 Stones is the perfect blend of hippie and hipster.
Iced La Colombe Coffee, Sandwiches, Salads and a friendly (cute) young barista.

A lovely place for a REAL cuppa.

Back in the early '90's this place was truly innovative - and it still has many, admirable programs and activities.  We nicknamed the White Dog the "Adjective cafe".

A simple dish of corn frittersmight be labeled as:

"Warm fresh sweet corn and roasted red pepper fritters"

The entire menu was so loaded with adjectives that it was hard to find was the noun was!

Anyhow - the food was/is, indeed, very good and many of the ingredients are local or at least regional and organic whenever possible.  I really admire the work that White Dog has done and the viable business they have built.

Go, dog, go!

Nice, small, independently run pharmacy - which I always love to see.
Picked up a few sundries here. A bit pricey - but so convenient.  And it's NOT a CVS!  

HA!

Glad to have you in the nabe!

Where would we be without Uber and Lyft?
I check both and see which will get to me quicker out in the 'burbs.

Sometimes it's not about $$ for me but time.
Time is money.  LOL.
I wish more reliable Lyft drivers were in my area (Media, PA).
One of my friends is a Lyft driver but she is in "Souffily".

Anyhow - so far only good experiences.

A beautiful, gilded Catholic church but absolutely nowhere to park. Celebrated a funeral mass here and parking in this neighborhood is chaos.

Singer had a beautiful voice and the organ is amazing. 

Roman catholicism in all its old school glory.

Hallelujah. Lord, hear our prayer.

We had a far better experience at the Ardmore location of NYAJ than we ever did at the Glen Mills one.

First of all the layout, crowd and vibe are a bit different.
We arrived in stages - 7 women in total - and our delightful, albeit overworked server, Melvin, came right away with bread and "dipping oil".

Since we arrived in time for happy hour (must order by 7 PM) we were treated to $5 Sangria, Margarita or Pineapple Pain Killers.  The Sangria, to me, was the tastiest of the 3.  

$6 apps included sliders in 3 varieties (any combination you choose), cheeseburger, mini crab cake (great) or buffalo chicken.  We also tied the waffle fries and lettuce wraps (from the regular menu) and carrot cake for dessert.

We had a great time socializing and listening to the (loud) 80's and 90's background music. 

Shout out to MELVIN for top-tier service.

A good place for take out - they do have a room with card tables & chairs next door for eat-in, but the decor just screams - take out.

 An old-school staff of pizza makers crammed into the busy kitchen turns out terrific FRESHly baked pies.  The cheese, pepperoni/sausage and veggie combo we ordered were terrific.  2 large pies fed 6 adults and 3 yound children.  The veggie pie was my fave - with roasted red & green peppers, broccoli and spincah - so tasty.

I recommend the pizza here.

The crepe cakse are a work of beauty and art - $55 - $65 each and so worth it.
Delicious crepes.

So excited by this place.

Raw at Boyd's is owned by Raw on 13 & Sansom.
The sushi is excellent - and this is a neat place to have a quiet, casual or business lunch.

The lunch bentos are tasty and plenty of food.
We enjoyed having lunch here numerous times in 2008 & 9.
Have not been back since I changed jobs.

We had great service (yes, really) from Ariel at Hildago - and the place was nearly empty (so maybe that helped).  My shrimp quesadilla (simple) was excellent and the Sopa Azteca was great, too.   Not cheap - and the $7.95 guacamole, while fresh, was not nearly as good as Dos Gringos nor my 12 year old kid's version.

Meanwhile, the food here is way, way better than at Diego's.

We are so glad to have them here in Media.

A little pricey for what it is...
Free iced coffee giveaway was perfect!

We have always enjoyed the food at the Polish Festival - but you can also get some of the basics (Pierogies, Cabbage Rolls/Gulabki, Coffee and Babka) year-round in the rec-room/cafeteria area under the shrine.

Not particularly inexpensive though - so bring a bit more cash than you might think.  Brings me back to those Polish-fest days!

Have not been here for quite a while due to working "up north" and shopping for dog food and supplments at DelChester Feed (Love that little old place!).

Now I work 2 minutes away so this PetSmart and the nearby other "big box" stores come in handy.

Stopped in at 12 noon on a random Tuesday for a tick collar and some supplments.  Get your dog on Glucosamine/MSM at a young age! It makes a real difference in their elder years.

Happy they are here.

What a difference 2 years makes.  Still need more dining and after 6 PM this place is DEAD - but during the work day we need LUNCH - and breakfast.  And another Starbucks (There is one in the hotel) - or better a La Colombe or Old City Coffee.

Keep it coming.  This area has such great potential.
More shopping would be good.
A spa?

I am updating my review to give a GREAT recommendation.  Go see Mai and ask for CND Shellac - the relatively new no-chip gel lacquer.  It claims to last 2 weeks (mine lasted 9 days cip-free, 11 days with some edgewear - by day 14 it was cashed).

I just had a spa pedi, eybrow wax and a Shellac Mani (in a rich red shade) all for $67 ($77 with a $10 tip).

I am re-thinking Chau's.  I will be back.

OK, I went to Ursula's spa "Pause" which is a single treatment room inside her make-up studio.  The facialist Elina was excellent.  the facial itself was also very good - and the home-made vegetable based (cucumbers and parsley) mask was the best part of the "Seasonal Phacial" that I got.

They are running a deal thru 5/2/09 where you can get one of 4 different PHacials (cute - huh?) for $60 - instead of the list price of $110 - which nobody pays.  I say that because she also has a discounted series price and cut me a deal to get a series of 3 more phacials - so I did.

If you are a client of UrbanFront Pilates - next door - she will definitely work with you.

For $60 I had a great facial and Elina did an extensive arm, neck and back massage, too.  The products are all cheap private label - sorry - but they are.  The just have Ursula's label on them.  The cleanser and toner were good - but very standard.  I am a product junkie and didn't buy any products.  Thankfully, neither Ursula nor Elina tried to push any on me - they were both sweet as sugar.

I can't wait to go back for my $50 back treatment nerxt week.

So for $60 it's a 5 star facial - but for $110 - no way - maybe 3 stars.

I will compromise and give them 4.  They are definitely worth checking out.  Also Ursula charges a very, very high price for lash application.  I'll be doing them myself.

Oh well.

Oh, and they offer REAL sugaring (not wax mixed with a little sugar, sugaring.).

Elina is really the star of the show, so I hope Ursula treats her well.  She is a good facialist and I know one when I feel one!

I am writing thuis review kinda sorta on behalf of my dad (who might even give them 5 stars - he loves it here.).  I have only been here twice and both times (with my parents, of course - who LOVE the fresh mozzarella salad and prime-rib (or is it filet) beef sandwiches.

The first time we went my daughter was a wee 6 or 7 months old and I was in a post-partum haze.  The experience was a drag from soup to nuts.  (Nevermind that we did not order any soup nor nuts).  Mom ordered and raved about her fresh (and milky white) mozzarella and tomato salad.  Dad was in red-meat heaven.

Strangely enough we never actually get any beer here.  (The 'rents don't drink it.)

Then little angel-pie decided to pee in her diaper.  So I had to change her diaper.  And things got ugly.  There was NO WHERE - and I mean no where to change her.  The ladies room was a one-person operation with NO changing tabel and no area.  The floow in there seems icky.

So I whipped out my portable changing pad (waterproof) and tried to subtley and quickly change her on a tabletop in the back hallway.

I was immediately yelled at by a (male) manager to stop.  I basically ignored him - as I was nearly done anyway) and finished wiping the babies butt, threw the dirty things in a plastic baggie, threw the baggie backinto my diaper bag and went back to the table.

I was so ticked off.  I mean, what was I supppsoed to do - there was NO WHERE to change this kid.  A 6 month old baby.

Whatever.

So anhow - thety have great food and a terrific selection of salads - but don't bring a non-potty trained kid here.  (In our case an infant.)

Rant over.

This farm-stand is on my regular route so I stop here in season for locally grown peaches, tomatoes, sweet summer corn and freshly cut flowers (mind the bugs!).

Driving by their sunflower field is just so uplifting.

Nice young (teen) gals running the front register.

Support our local farms!

Surprisingly wonderful.  This opld-school diner has friendly "career" waitresses and serves a terrific french onion soup. (Not too salty - and just the right amount of golden brown bubbling chees on top.)

Don't miss the home-made pierogies - a plate of 3 (large) one sauteed in ample amounts of butter and sweet onions.  BLISS (and calories) on a plate.

We really enjoyed stopping in here while house-hunting in the Media area and plan to return.

Every summer/fall I stock up on Billy's fantastic poultry-based (he makes pork based also) sausages which he sells at the Media Farmer's market.  I can't wait to get to his (new location) place in Wilmington.  The chicken/broccoli rabe and chicken/spinach/provolne sausages are delectable.

As aforementioned, parking is inadequate here - but if you go on a Sunday morning you can park at a metered spot in the street and walk across.

A bit pricey - especially for produce - but staples like milk and eggs are on par with Acme or Giant.  Lots of gourmet items and prepared foods.

A nice "chi-chi" market in yuppified D-town.

A great selection of molded chocolate confections and other candies and goodies.
Conveniently located in the RTM.

Bark, non-pareils, peanut butter cups, chocolate covered pretzels, rats, bats and Halloween and Christmas chocolates, too.

Fun!

For technician skills (love you, Mai!) this is the BEST I have found in Media so far.
Plus they treat my little one so well (cute pedicure chairs for kids with DVD players in them.)

I had a mani and spa pedi ($45 - but they are offering a discount through 11/17 for their 10th anniversary). Oh - and a mani is regualrly $12, Pedi $25 (mani plus pedi is $30 I think??  They give a small discount).

Spa pedi is usually $35 (Mani and spa pedi ran me $45 - actually $41 after the 10% disc. - not including the tip I left.)

Very nice people running the place.
I'll be back for sure!

Panchero's is akin to Qdoba/Chipotle and other fast-food Mex in that you move down "the line" and select your items.

Panchero's schtik is that they press your tortilla to order (The pull out a blob of dough from a proofing box and flatten it in a press).  Even though I usually get a low-carb option - I had to try the tortilla, I mean, come on, it's why you go to Panchero's.  Verdict?  Very fresh tasting and the quesadilla I got was tasty.  

Slightly cheaper than Chipotle - and I think I like it better.

Need a fast-casual Mex?  Stop in to Panchero's.
Plus it's right next door to the Media, Starbucks, so you can get a $5 coffee to go with it.

This is a review for the meeting space and public areas of this newly opened and sorely needed hotel in Media, PA - great location for business travelers who need access to the Delaware County Courthouse.

I attended a meeting in a meeting room (rented for a fee) on the first floor.  
Since this hotel is brand new, everything was super clean.

The very young man at reception was friendly and helpful and said that rack rates vary from $125 - $200 for a single room or a "King Suite" with a pull-out  couch.

There is a teeny tiny indoor pool and several kids were enjoying it.
They also include breakfast and the crowded breakfast area (at around 9:15 AM on a Saturday) seemed good.

We need this Hampton Inn very much so I pray they will keep it clean and well maintained.

Pleasantly surprisedby the quality of the food.  Small Plate option of a single Salmon Spring Roll ($5.50) was perfect.  Quinoa Salad was nice but thank goodness I got the cloyingly sweet dressing on the side.  Loaded with sugary fruit puree too.

It's close by - so we'll be back.

John, the owner is such a nice man.
He gave my daughter 2 pretzels and a pretzel dog (with or without cheese).

The pretzels were cooked evenly and not too gooey nor burnt, however there was alot of salt which she picked off.

Good pretzels and located near our house.
New owners have made things better but hours are still insufficient and sporadic.  Now that Kung Fu tea has opened up about a block away, Boba Tiki needs to up their game.

We came back to Hildago with another couple who are regulars and they directed me to order the pork tenderloin special, served in a delicious chiorizo sauce and stuffed with Jamon and cheese,   It was amazing. I likened it to a Mexican riff on Pork Saltimboca,

Amazing!

Ariel (The owner's daughter) is lovely as always and the fresh pico, guacamole ($8) an chips are a must.

We love you, Hildago!

Very impressed with the service and food for our group of 8 (supposed to be 12 but 4 people bailed) on a busy Saturday night.  French Onion Soup was perfect - not too salty and not too greasy.

Others enjoyed burgers, veggie quesadilla (loaded with 'shrooms) and guacamole (very good).
Fried calamari is not my thing but the table enjoyed it.

Prices seem to have risen a bit - but it was never "cheap" here.
A great selection of beers of all sorts.  Decent (but pricey) cocktails  ($9 - $13).

Massimo's pizza is located in Booth's Corner's Farmers Market and thus has limited hours.
I got 2 slices and 3 (rather large) garlic knots to go for my 14 year old.
She ate one of the slices (plain) and 2 of the $1 a piece knots right away and seems to really love it.

Later for a second meal she ate the other knot and the remaining slice of "upside-down" pizza - just like plain cheese pizza but cheese is under the sauce.

She liked them both but prefers the classic Neapolitan pie to the "upside down" pie.

All in all?  At $2.50 a slice this is a good way to get pizza by the slice - they have a ton of choices including "square" Sicilian, tomato pie, Hawaiian and many more.

And the garlic knots are, indeed, yummy.
I love coming here - and have been coming here since about the age of 10 - I kid you not.  Asian art and decorations for the home.  Quintessentially New Hopian.

Went to the "unofficial" yelp event last night at ten stone.
Even though I am old and farty and not much of a bar-chick, we had a great time.

It was a lovely evening and we were able to snag a nice table outside.  My husband and a friend of mine ordered beers and I had a vodka cranberry.  (Made with the house vodka - it was pretty bad - I should asked for Grey Goose - Oh, WELL.).

A bit later we got hungry so we ordered a spinach and apple/goat cheese/candied cashews salad (YUM!), a chipotle chicken wrap, a big mug of spicy chicken chili, and another big mug of edamame.  Reaqlly quite good for "bar food".

I will definitely be back!

I dream of El Limon's Al Pastor - it's so good.
The guacaomle/Salsa/chips combo for $5 is a great value.
My kid devoured her huge $9.95 shrimp burrito.  (Dry - but you can also have it with one of 3 terrific sauces).

Even DH enjoyed his salad with Asada.

Love this place - and a free margarita if you simply ask.

Brand spankin' new Chipotle in Media/Lima, PA near the old Granite Run Mall (that has been demolished for brand new stores like this).

We are so glad you are here.

Love those burrito bowls.
Please stop charging over $2 extra for guac.  At Qdoba guac is free (price is built in to base price though.)

Love the kids meals - enough for a grown up.

Surprisingly impressed by the "group dining" experience our school group (70 fifth graders are about 50 parents/teachers) has every year here. Carb-heavy el-cheapo menu of Bread & Butter, Chicken with Mashed potatoes (buttery) and Veggies (Squash/Zucchini) - super buttery.  For Dessert?  BREAD pudding.

Meanwhile that was a kid friendly and safe choice.  They greeted, seated and got us fed in under an hour.  WOW!

We had an amazingly great time - food and service (by the lovely Maria) with our party of 6.
It was the first day of the "new" OctoberFest menu and we surely enjoyed it.  Mustard Crusted Salmon, Caesar Salad, Chicken and Pork Schnitzel and of course, great beer and beverages.

The only thing preventing a 5 star rating?  Deafeningly loud - as it was quite crowded (Saturday at 1 PM_ and we sat right near the open kitchen.

Service was quick and attentive.

Lovely!

I dunno - we come here about once a week and never have had an issue - my kid is a vegan so her "bowl" is rice, beans, pico and guac.  Never a problem.  Young staff but they are always fine to us.

Not sure why others have so many problems?   But yes, they do need to clean more.

Run by teens.
Fast food.
Not expecting the "Ritz".

A great dining area with casual places like the crepe place, a juice bar, Buddy's Burgers, Noodle Bowls and an OPlive Oil/Balsamic Vinegar place.

Fun to browse around and eat lunch here.

Just ordered a sofa and loveseat from Ashley - will update this review when it arrives (3 - 8 weeks from now.).   Fingers crossed.  So far the sales team has been great - and we are on track to receive the furniture in mid March.

O.M.Goodness.
The hangover burger could easily be called the Heart Attack burger.

If you are ravenously hungry and have lipitor on hand, then try it.
I ate 1/2 (and a side salad instead of fries) and I need a nap.\

Perfectly cooked burger on a brioche bun with bacon, cheddar cheese and a fried egg.

My diet has been calorie bombed!

Took the other half home.
So good.  So bad.  So good.

I stopped in after seeing the takeout food a coworker got at my new job - 2 minutes away.  It seems like a typical strip-mall take out spot with about 5 green-jade plastic tables.

The whole family runs the place and my pint of Beef & Broccoli (6.75) was just fine - asked for light sauce but still was not so light. The grandson (son?) was there and he is so cute - about 4 years old.  Nice younger lady running the front counter.

You can also get a lunch special from $5 - $7 which includes pork fried rice or white rice.

I will be back - but I don't do Chinese too often.
Maybe in 2 weeks...

Strip mall is easy to get in but hard to drive out of (202 and another busy , divided highway).

Note:  They do not provide water nor ice so you HAVE to purchase a bottle of water (or a soda) or else go without if you are dining in.  I caved and bought a diet coke, but next time I am bringing my own water.

I gotta say, for $3.71 I got a perfectly crafted (yes, that hot, hot barrista CRAFTED it) iced latte served with a smile and it tasted Deeeee-licious.

Maybe it was because it was 5:15 PM?
Maybe it's because I asked for it with "whip"
Maybe it's because the barrista was so hot (I did mention that, right?)

But whatever it was that latte was MAGIC!

Nice place.

Decent Chinese/American food.  Square on Square is better 0 in my opinion, but the decor here is a titch nicer.  They serve all the standards like egg rolls, chicken & brocolli and pepper steak.

I have had lunch here a few times - never dinner- and I always got in and out quickly.

Convenient Walnut Street location.

Young & Bowman have been our family's plumber for years and years.
They are trustworthy and know their stuff - and they come relatively quickly when its an emergency (and when ISN'T it an emergency when your toilet seriously malfunctions?)

Nice folks.  A bit pricey, but great customer service - and they come in the dead of winter to fix those leaky pipes.

A new-year's day feast with my 12 year-old salmon-loving kid and great sushi.
We actually tried to come at 2:40 PM - they are CLOSED from 2:30 - 5 PM (no "linner").

Lunch is a MUCH better value than dinner, but we love the spicy tuna ball appetizer and salmon plate.  (Ask if they have toro and/or salmon belly - as both are terrific.)
The Tropicana roll ($7.95) is a tasty also.

Friendly service and not crowded.

My friend lives in Kennett Square and I just HAD to get an iced coffee - so off to the trusty Dunkin' we went.

Average prices, place was dead-empty at 4 PM (so speedy service) and all the "usual" DD suspects.

America may run on Dunkin - but Dunkin runs on me!

Long live the iced latte light!

This Dunkin has a drive thru - but in the morning coffee rush (7:30 ish) I usually park and go in -it's faster.

I come here on my way to work.
decent service and clean dining area.

I have gotten breakfast here once and lunch 3 times so far - and it's right in my building complex - where the old Marathon used to be.

The meatballs are the real deal - fresh and homehade.  I also have tried the CHicken Cutlet with spinach and provolone - and it was delicious - although not diet friendly. (The cutlet is fried - but they do offer a grilled version.)

They also have a nice salad bar with a few hot foods on it. I got it today.  I also had a large ($9.99) spaghetti and meatball platter.  The meatballs were tasty and authentic. (Only 2 though - wish there were more.)
Pricey for what it is - but so much better than Au Bon Blech across the courtyard.

The lines are long though and they need better crowd management.

Super-friendly service - and a good selection of papers and poster board.  I needed some in a pinch - and there it was.

Nice to have an art supply place around.

Keeps getting better - and much improved from 2010.
Christmas market (back every year), small ice rink in winter, music and food trucks in summer.

Nice!

Swanky indeed.  I loves me some good bubbly - so I was very excited to come here - and have been here thrice total.  The large & small plates are great for sharing.  Sushi is good - but not high-brow.  (Not Shiroi Hana Quality).  The Asian/Fusion fried rice and other dishes were good.

Pricey - but not mind-blowingly so.

Great service all 3 times - and not crowded - but all 3 times we went early.  Good date place.

I'll be back!

I work in Plymouth Meeting/E. Norriton now and we had Izzie's cater a lunch for 30 people.  The sandwich trays were very good - much better than many other places - as the sandwiches were served on mini challah rolls that were very fresh and delicious.  Chicken and Tuna Salad were great and not overly mayo-laden.  Meats looked good too - corned beef, turkey and roast beet.  1/2 sour and full dill pickles, coleslaw and pickled tomatoes were decent (I am not a coleslaw fan).

Very well done - and we will order again.

Just got back from IHOP in warrington (down 611) for an early (8:30 AM) breakfast on Labor Day.  Thus they are getting a nice, pleasant, non-mobbed 4 fat beautiful stars from me.

There were 5 in our party and (miracle of miracles) we were seated promptly and cheerfully greeted by a smilling late-teen server "Kelsey".

We ordered pancakes, crepes, eggs and omelettes all around and everything was hot, freshly made and served the way we specified.  I  much prefer IHOPs pancakes to Perkins - but my 3 year old has never met a pancake she did not like.  I also love the crepes - I omit the giant wad of butter-like spread they plop in the middle.  Who needs to eat THAT much fat?

2 for 2!

Now the best part - the check came quickly and was accurate, too boot.

In the past this IHOP has been a crazed 2-3 star mass of strollers and screaming children.  But today's miracle breakfast was just a J.O.Y.

Stay tuned for an update.  (Don't go here during peak times - it's a frikkin' zoo.)

We don't "do" fast food - but - we will on occaision take our little one (now 7 - went there more when she was 4,5 or 6) to play there and eat chicken and fruit cup.

It's fried.  It's not that great for you - but it's way better than McDonald's or BK.
Plus the kids just love that play area.

So we love Chik-Fil-A - on special occaisions.

Super-yum and a super value.
I also forget its here because I usually don't go that far down Arch Street, which is a shame because I love Aya's.

I have only been at lunch time - but the prices have been reasonable and the food is excellent.  Nice yellow/earth toned decor, too.

Delicious baba ghanoush and pita bread.  (Very thin, hot pita - so yummy.)
They also serve some Italian-Greek ish food - sort af a Medditerranean hybrid.  

I agree with Caroline about the Aya's taster - what a great way to start the meal.

The Chicken gyro is enormous and very nicely seasoned.  Not greasy, too, which is a plus.

LOVE Aya's! Can't wait to go here again.

Very good for grilled cheese, a few soups and salads to go with it (and a neat TV watching area - like a mini movie theatre - in the back).

I tried a sample of the roasted tomato soup (VERY good) but settled on a 1/2 & 1/2 - where you pick 2 different grilled sandwiches to try.  I got 1/2 shortribs and 1/2 Baja Chicken.  I really enjoyed the Ribs and Mashed potatoes (Not too much). Next time I will add tomato to it.  Avocado Ranch dipping sauce as tasty, too.

I wish they'd offer an alternative to potato chips (A green veggie?  Cucumber slices?).

I would definitely come here again - but not too often.
Plain grilled cheese I can get at home.

Oh - the parking lot in this "strip" is awful.  Outback Steakhouse is there and take up a big chunk of the lot.

Absolutely no issues - we came at 7:15 PM on a Wednesday night in the summer - so no line and thankfully, no dried-out old food.

My kid got a steak burrito to go and I did not have to cook.

Seriously.  No issues.

Decent enough service - and a selection of papers and poster board.  I also got some crayola (yes, really) art supplies here in a pinch for my (then) 4 year old.

Convenient location.

Nice to have an art supply place around.

Kinda pricey for potted plants, hanging baskets, garden supplies - but it has been there for years & years.

Always a good place to get my mom a hanging New Guinea Impatiens - in a pinch.

Also potting soil, pruning shears, the odd supply that I forgot to get at (dare I say) Kmart.  Oh - and Kmart is way, way cheaper.

BUT - and this is the big but - Buckmans will give you free gardening advice (try getting that from the zit-faced, disinterested 16 year old at Kmart!) and that my dear, is priceless.

A welcome addition to State Street and a good place to take the kids for a cup or cone of house-made ice cream.

Flavors change periodically but the always have chocolate, cookies and cream, vanilla and at least a few fruit flavors. (Sorbetto?)

Love the Media Theatre.  Love the location, the history behind it, the shows, the fact that Wanda Sykes is involved (part owner?).

Love the camp in the summer.

Support your local theatre!

Well, I may be biased because friends of the family run this place, but Suzi's is the "best little topless bar" in Line Lexington.  

No really - it's a good place for a bachelor party or just to chill.

Not MY scene, mind you - but yes, I have actually been here on a few occaisions.  

Say Hi to Joel at the bar - and Suzy is still alive and well - but she does not run the bar any longer - her kids do.  We love you, Suzy!

This is my 7 year olds FAVORITE store for cheap makeup (lipsticks), accessories, floral hair bows, ribbons, sunglasses and funky boots.

We love to browse here - and occaisionally buy, too.

Very kind staff.

Delicious fresh fish, but pricey.
Lunch (Just a special) was $15.95 - so $20 after tax and tip with no beverage.

5 pieces of nigiri and a delightful spicy tuna roll.
The sushi chef (there were 3 or 4 when I went at lunchtime) was de-scaling a huge and beautiful snapper.  Wow.

I still wanted more - LOL.
Friendly server and dark, but elegant digs.

A strange smell when we entered though - not awful or I would have left.

Meanwhile, I can't afford to have lunch here on a regular basis.  The full/dinner menu looks amazing - so maybe I will try a dinner here.

Severino supplies fresh and frozen pasta to restaurants and gourmet stores all over the area.
Good stuff!  And a great selection.

The basic linguine and fettucine are staples for us.
Stuff pastas like cheese ravioli and tortellini are also excellent.

I had already reserved a spot in this convenient garage (19 near Market/Chestnut) for an evening event in Philly and then I read the (scathing) reviews.

I feared the worst but was very, pleasantly surprised.
Drop off at about 4 PM on a Summer Thursday was easy-peasy and Antoine was friendly and let me rummage around my car for a bit to make sure I took everything I needed with me (You can't easily get back to your vehicle once they valet park it).

Pickup is where most garages in cities fail, long waits, damage to vehicle, horror stories.  Thank goodness - I had NONE of that.  I presented my pre-paid parking pass and my ticket and in about 15-20 minutes (yes that's long but not horrible) My vehicle arrived.

I would definitely park here again but not during the business day (too much money) and not on a Friday Night (Center City is insane on Friday nights).

It's FREE and it's just gorgeous in springtime to see the Azaleas here (and aklso at the Morris and Tyler arboreutms.)

Lots of parking - and less crowded, less well-known than Tyler or Morris, the Jenkins Arboretum is a great place to commune with nature and get your filll of big, old trees - and younger smaller ones.

Take a camera!  (Or bring a book and sit on a bench.)

Nice for kids - but a little more sedate (or in kid-speak boring) than Morris.  Our little one likes the pond though - she saw a turtle which made her day.

Yuki is now DD & my go-to place for a mid-priced Sushi lunch.  We even take some of DD's friends there and they all love it.  The $25 salmon plate is a bit pricey but at lunch time you can get a 5 piece sushi plate (with a Cali roll) for $12.95 - comes with (excellent) miso soup and (boring, but fresh) salad.

Service is quick and efficient.

Sushi chefs know el kiddo and treat her great!

Better!  A good cup of La Colombe coffee served by a lovely Polish gal, and my lemon/butter crepe was now only 3.99 - better!!!!

I'll be back.

A fantastic choice for a corporate lunch (or date night dinner) in the "LoMa" - Lower Market area of "downtown" Wilmington, DE.  I had a lunch salad ($16 - ouch but so good!) with pesto shrimp, pine nuts and fusili (just enough).

They also serve delicious La Colombe coffee beverages (I got a latte to go).

Too pricey to eat here every day for lunch but once every few weeks I will be returning for sure!  Fresh ingredients and lovely service.

So pleased.

Stopped in around 6 PM for a $2 promo small iced coffee and a 99 cent donut for el kiddo.

Young teen/college age kids running the show were bored (slow time at 6 PM in August) and disinterested.

Product was fine.

Parking lot truly sucks.

My (nearly) 9 year old LOVES Annie's - even more than Rita's.  Why?  You can get Jimmies (Sprinkles) on your water ice.  And they have the "pink one" (Is that Bubblegum or Cotton Candy) and the "blue" one (Blue Raspberry) and they have soft serve in cups or cones (just OK - I have had better frozen custards - but this is soft serve ice cream - not custard.).

Friendly young teens (mostly gals) working the counter and a line in the summertime.
Gravel parking lot and a big wooden porch to eat on.

If you are a kid?  This is part of a great summer experience.

Bring some small bills - do them a favor.
New ownership.  Still a great value for (bird) seed (and horse/dog food).

As a sushi lover, I was sooooo pleased to see this placeopen.  Owned by the same people from Shiroi Hana, I went here with high expectations.

My 5 year old and husband also loved our first meal here last night.  My little one spent a long time looking at the live (huge) scallops and giant orange clams still moving in their shells.

We ordered the shumai for the child (who loved them) and an asoortment of tasty and inventive rolls.  DH liked the triple spicy double tuna roll, and I liked the Hamachi Verde - which I ordered without Jalapeno (I'm a wimp).

We can't wait to come back and try more.

Consistently good.

A great meal last night - DD & I salmon-binged on a Salmon plate and a salmon sashimi appetizer.  The kind chef gifted us with some Salmon Toro, too!  #SlamminSalmon

For chain-BBQ, Mission is darned good. Certain items are better than others, IMO.
The ribs (both spare and baby backs) were fall-off-the-bone tender and super flavorful (even sans sauce).  That said, there are 6 or 7 sauces you can try including a vinegar-based Carolina one.  The ribs did not need sauce - the (dry) brisket, however, not even sauce could save.

The pulled chicken was also very good.

Brisket?  Too dry. 

Sides - mac & cheese, green beans (a little mushy) and cornbread all solid.

A great lunch choice.  And daily they sing the National Anthem at precisely 12 noon - so if you are in a rush get here by 11:45 AM.  The line forms quickly at 12:05 PM.
Breads, pastries and coffee.  Not cheap - but you get what you pay for.  It's GOOD stuff. Small place, gets crowded during the AM coffee rush.

This is, indeed, a Viet Namese/Asian Market and they have terrific (and inexpensive) produce.  They also sell a large selection of seafood and meats (including ready to eat ducks and chickens - the onion chicken looked great.

Additionally, there are about 100 types of noodles - Mi, Fun, rice, wheat, Japanese, Ramen, soba - you name it.  WOW!

Rows and rows of condiments and sauces, too.  Plus FRESH eggs by the gross if you need 'em.

Neat place!  Can't wait to go back while it is still new and clean.

My little brother (who is now over 30) worked here in High school and they were great to him and to our family.

A good local source for all things hardware - and much better customer service than at a chain store like Home Despot.

This is a fairly new Chipotle.

I'm a Chipotle fan from back in my Manhattan days - so I was glad to see one open in Warrington.  While I must admit to liking Qdoba a tad more - Chipotle is my go-to place for a Burrito Bol (Naked Burrito) with Chicken, Black Beans and Guacamole.

It's fast and cheap - but watch those calories - I never get cheese and rarely get sour cream so I can justify that guac!

This branch of Chipotle is in a stand-alone building (did it used to be the Pizza Hut - I forget).  It has a cool-gray ambience - a bit industrial looking.  We usally get take out, though so we don't really care.

On the Sunday afternoon when we last visited, the place was loaded with families with young children.

Delicious - and a heck-of-a-lot more athentic Thai food in the Riverfront Market (3 S. Orange Street).

The owner and chef are so sweet and everything is cooked FRESH.  The Tom Ka (I had mine with Chicken) was spicier than I am used to (next time I'll get it wimp-i-fied) but was loaded with veggies, chicken and goodies.  REAL galangal and fresh kaffir lime leaves.

The real McCoy!

NB:  No credit cards.

4 for our service (Hailey) and 3 for the food.
Cooperage is a soul-ish/southern American Whiskey Bar - with a decent selection of wines as well.

A good friend and I dined here on Friday night.  We made a reservation and sat inside, although the weather was perfect for outdoor as well.

The house Lynchberg Lemonade looked tempting, but my companion opted for a mojito - which he enjoyed.  I had a bunch of Arnold Palmers. (Being a HARD CORE drinker - not!!!)

We both had salads.  My friend's duck pastrami salad was good but a little light on the duck.  My Southern Chopped salad was excellent - and to my surprised I even liked the fried okra.  Once again proof that if you fry something, people will eat it.  I ordered shrimp on top of it- and for some reason I did not catch that they were to be"blackened" shrimp.  It was a shame, too - as they were GORGEOUS big shrimp (4 of them) but so spicy I could not eat them.

Hailey took them off our bill.

So anyhow - we had an enjoyable time at Cooperage.
Food was solid 3 stars. Not mind blowing - but really tasty for bar food.

We took our 4 year old to Expressive Hand on Sunday - turns out (thank goodness) they are waiving the studio fees for the month of Januray, 2009.  Normally is costs $10 for adults and $8.00 for kids plus the cost of the pottery you paint.

Our daughter selected a $20 coffee mug (Woulda been $46 if studio fees were applied - that's one damned expensive mug.).

Meanwhile - she had a blast.  The clean, well-run studio allows you to select pottery piece and apply your choice of underglazes and designs.  After your design dries (Allow at leat 90 minutes to be there you need a minimum of 3 coats of color), they with fire and glaze it.

Pick up is in one week.  We can't wait to see our childs creation. And she can't wait to do it again!

Of course, they have birthday parties and other events, too.
Plus they offer ASL (American Sign Language) classes and workshops.

A neat place - and more personality than "Color Me Mine".

Scott Goldoor the owner and Jeff Taylor our DJ did an excellent job at our 2008 at the Joseph Ambler Inn.  They were attentive to our and our guests needs and musical tastes.

We sent them a PLAY and (more importantly) DO NOT PLAY list and that was great.

Perfect for a wedding and reasonably (average - not low, not high) priced.
We had them for 4 hours.

I echo what many others have said - Wegman's is terrific - and a great choice for a take-home meal.  I got a salmon sushi platter that was so much better than any Acme or Giant (Blargh!) and a lovely selection from the fresh cold salad bar.

Next time I will try the hot foods.

It's such fun to shop here.

A brand-new, super-clean, SORELY needed, Starbucks with a busy drive through in "Brookheaven".  Brookhaven had nothing like this shopping center - until now.  A new Giant, a wine/spirits (State) store, Smashburger, Hand & Stone - and finally - a real Starbucks.

My advice?  Skip the drive through - especially if there are more than 4-5 cars ahead of you and just go in and get your stuff.

Hallelujah,
RIP, Suzy has passed away - but Joel and company are still running the bar and it's still a great place to party.

This place is Sooooooo tiny - seating for 10 at tables and 3 at the sushi bar.
My 7 year old loved her shrimp shumai, and DH 7 I enjoyed our maki.

The standout though?  One of the BEST chicken Udon bowls I have ever tasted.
Rich broth and perfectly tender udon (not mushy).  So perfect on a chilly December night.

A good, solid sushi spot.

This used to be Chong's Garden Chinese restaurant for years 7 years - so for nostalgia alone, I am glad to see a nice, new coffee spot (actually it's been here for a while).  I was a "Bucks County Coffee" and appears to be a Saxby's now.  

Anyhow - decent coffee drinks and a great central d-town location.
Great selection and value for fresh produce (and seafood) plus a vast array of international food products.  Good place.  $10 minimum to use credit/debit.

A teeny-tiny sushi-spot packed with goodness.
The platters are a good value and the fish is fresh and many varieties are offered.

My companion had a fresh lobster roll and the meat was sweet and plentiful.

I enjoyed my Hamachi nigiri and watching the big screen TV.
Sadly - that TV does overwhelm the tiny room and voids-out the "ambience".

In any case, the owners were there and the chef was friendly.
Plus, you can walk to the Franklin Fountain for dessert.
It's not Morimoto - but it's a heck of a lot better than Mizu down the street.

Now that I work nearby I stop in for a quick lunch at Wegman's from time to time - but I always spend way too much on sushi.  (13.99 for a 9 piece platter of nigiri.)
Delicious and fresh though.

I'm in heaven!  Finally some dresses with a full-circle skirt.  Cute shoes.  Wonderful!!!
Celeste Giuilano - where are you???  We need your pics on the walls here!

I had an excellent first experience at TJs today for lunch in the dining room (the bar was too loud and crowded for my liking).  Cobb Salad was fresh and tasty with lots of white meat turkey and bacon. Crisp romaine.

Nice ambiance and a LARGE list of beers, stouts, porters, ciders and ales.

Can't wait to come back.

A little pricey - but OK.

Lunch specials for $6.99 are a decent value - a 1/2 cheesesteak (huge - can't imagine eating a whole one) and iceberg salad.

Kiddo had a single slice of plain pizza.
Loads of Large screen TVs to watch "the game".

Efficient service.

Not sure what to say about "The Parkway" - but it is an integral piece of the Philly Landscape and Cityscape.

Many events, parades, races and benefits are held here - and when they are the traffic is re-routed and it's kind of a pain.

If you live in the city - chances are you have been on the parkway on your way to a museum or even to work.

OK - first of all I got take out - so that might account for the lower review.
Secondly, I had bun  (not Pho) - but here's why I thought Pho Ha was good but not great:

Sugarcane shrimp was soggy (possibly due to take out)
Shredded carrots on top of the Bun were overly pickled/vinegary.

I will be back to try the Pho and the service was GREAT - so friendly and welcoming, but honetsly?  I've have way better bun at Pho Cali and numerous joints in Oakland, CA.

Good prices.

Update:  I went back for Pho (I got the one with diced tenderloin) and awesome Summer rolls.  Excellent.

I have been back a few times and the customer service here is wonderful - Miracle our cashier was so sweet and friendly.

I usually get the spare ribs now - I like them even better than the baby backs.
The "Black Plate" special can vary but once it was BBQ shrimp and they were delicious - I hope they bring them back.  Would love to try salmon, too.

This LARGE dry cleaners (and tailoring) is located at the corner of 17 & Arch.  Great location for the Phoenix and nearby Comcast Center.

They have cleaned a few items for me at a good price and well done.  They also cleaned and preserved my wedding gown.  (Ouch - that price!!!!!)

I also had a zipper replaced on an expensive jacket.  It cpst $35 to have the new zipper put in, which seemed really high to me, but iot was better than replacing the jacket. (Which would have been a few hundred bucks.)

Ladies who run the place are nice and the computerized systems helps ensure your stuff is really YOUR stuff.

FINALLY a decent sushi spot near my new digs.
It's not Nobu, nor Doma, but the service and decor were great (on a slow Wednesday night0 and best of all the Green Lobster Roll ($14.95) was amazing. (Fresh basil and lobster salad - get the sauces on the side!

Can't wait to come back and try some sashimi - to see how fresh the raw fish is here.

I'll be back!
A cultural institution in Philly.  We have seen musicals and plays here mostly.  Expensive!
