I love Lee's - for decent cheese steaks and roast beef or turkey hoagies with all the fixin's. They renovated it after the fire and it looks great.  Nice guys (and a few gals) runnin' the show.

2 years later - and thank goodness, La Fia is still here and still has my favorite salads and sandwiches ($12 - $20) for lunch.  A good place to take a client or business colleague.  This part of Market Street needs more dining options so we are thankful La Fia is here!

I had a very different (and better) experience at Uncle Oogie's.  I thought it was GREAT!!!!  It's a Soufilly pizza joint with a small dining area.  We had terrific platters (each was around $12 and came with an enormous basket of delicious garlic bread.

We shoulda split a platter - because they were insanely huge platters of food.  Chicken Parm (delish) and Chicken Olivia - even better with spinach, roasted red pepper and a light balsamic sauce.   Served with spaghetti and tons of rich "gravy".

The meatballs are fried and the "real McCoy".  Delicious.

The "Old Italian" pizza is, indeed loaded with herbs so if you don't like basil - don't get that - but we loved it's thin square crust and lovely sauce.  They also offer a tomato pie and a Margarita in addition to the "plain cheese" pies.  Plus they offer white and specialty pies.

And the hoagies (especially the chicken ones) are huge, fresh and filling.

I love it here and can't wait to go back - or get take out. (But I bet it's better fresh outta the oven and eaten right there.)

OMG - a hair away from 5 star perfection.
We got a dozen small cannoli here for our holiday celebration - filled to order.

Chocolate Italian Cream
Vanilla Italian Cream
Traditional Ricotta with (not many) chocolate chips)

The shells were crisp and delicious.
Just wish there were a few more chocolate chips (my dad's did not have any and mine had 3 or 4).

We are also fans of  the "black tie" strawberry shortcake" - their regular shortcake topped with chocolate covered berries and edged in chocolate shavings. The berries sliced into the filling are fresh and not gloppy.  The whipped-cream based frosting is tasty as well.  A winner!

So happy to have found this place.

OK.  Now I will eat my words.  I went to Argan last night at 6:30 for the THIRD time and it was the charm.

The first night I wandered it at about 7:45 PM.  The doors were wide open and there were 2 little kids running around and 2 men eating at a table.

Turns out they close at 7 and it was just family.  Meanwhile I stood at the counter (alone) for a good 2-3 minutes watching them sweep up (it was dawning on me by then that they might just be CLOSED - duh!!!!).  So finally one of the men came over to the counter and said "Sorry, we close at 7".

OK.  No biggie.

So a week or so later I show up at 6:45.  I study the menu and WOWZA - the prices are high.  So I walked out.

But last night - FINALLY - I got a chance to eat here.  The place was empty - save for 2 men behind the counter.  I stood at the counter watching them chop vegetebles for 3-4 minutes.  They said nothing to me.  I waited, and waited, and finally one man said - "Are you ready to order"?  I was - and ordered a Zaaluk (eggplant salad) sammy with tomatoes, cukes and crunchy blanched green beans,

but the pita bread - wow - so fresh.  They do, in fact, bake it there.

I did not like the $7.48 price tag - for a veggie sandwich - that seems steep - but I will be back to try the lamb for sure!

This flower shop is underground - on the concourse near the subway.
They offer a full range of floral services including weddings.

The owner is very kind and generous and has supported my daughter's school(s) throughout the years with modestly priced floral offerings and also gift certificates to charitable events.

I wish I had known about them sooner.

OK - should I say what I really think?  I am a little trepidatious about my review of the STORE vs. my feelings of the owner, Jennifer, who came to my spa in NY way back when for Astara training.

I will review the store - which she really HAS done a nice job with.  ABL carries HTF and high end beauty products - like Astara, Comptoir Sud Pacifique (which by now she probably stopped carrying) Fragrances, Cosmetics and they also offer a limited menu of spa and beauty treatments and eyebrow waxing.

I wish her luck.  I wish she had been nicer to me.

This is a solid 3 start place but i am giving it 4 as the food I had happened to be excellent - but i ordered a special.  Lobster Salad on an English muffin with hollandaise (from a mix?? - I got it on the side and it came cold - so that part wasn't excellent).

Very good service for a relaxing lunch.  Not cheap - but not expensive either.
Medium price, medium food, and mediocre decor (needs a re-fresh from 1992).

Lots of older folks eat here - but they often know where the nice quiet places are.

I will definitely be back.

Very good service from our friendly female server.  (Can't remember her name.)
And a full bar!

Fantastic!  Real La Colombe espresso drinks and ice cream AND gelato.
My 11 year old went straight for the "creamsicle" gelato.  A small ($3.25) was plenty.

We had several varieties of Rustica Pizza at the Yelp Philly event on 7/31.  They were so yummy.  I tried the veggie pie with spinach, fresh sliced tomato and ricotta.  YUM!

I also tried a few bites of the Philly-cheese-steak style pie - sliced steak meat, cheese and onions.  (I picked out the onions - as I don't "do" onions).

Even though it's porbably AMAZING if you eat it fresh at their location - it was still AWESOME pizza for delivery.  I can't wait to go to the store and try a fresh pie.

One of the other yelpers has rustica on speed dial - and has it delivered to his home, office and even to certain bars.

Kewl.

We took the "hop on, hop off" double decker bus tour yesterday for $25 total - myself and my 4 yea old who they (not I) suggested was free and let ride for free.

Even at the reduced rate of $25.00 for the 2 of us this is one expensive tourist ride.  The 20-some stop loop encompasses most of the major Philly sites (save for South Philly) including the new Please Touch museum.

If you take it early enough in the day you can even get off and enjoy the Art Museum or Please touch.

We got on at 1:30 and took the entire 90 minute loop.  Then we got off took a break and got on the 4 PM bus (same great driver - Donna, and guide - Ernest - a funny guy) in order to get off at the Chinatown stop (right in front of the arch).

My 4 year old just loved sitting on the top deck (hold on to your hats and watch those tree limbs!).

If I were a tourist who had NEVER been to philly and wanted to quickly see the major stuff - I would take this.

Back again and had Mahi Mahi tacos (and a friend got Shrimp tacos) so we each had one of each.

DELISH.

Perfect Arnold Palmer too - and great service in the bar area.


I am lovin' this place more and more.
Not cheap though - $50 for lunch for 2 (I paid, lucky me) with 1 beer and no dessert.

It was my first time at Zama and I dined alone and sat at the sushi bar.
I had completely forgotten that it was restaurant week - and while the set menu looked fetching, I opted for a few a la carte items.

I started off with a trio of handrolls.  The fish was fresh and excellent - but the lovely server, Roxanne - who explained so very many things to me - forgot to tell me that they come wrapped in soy paper.  Had I known I would have requested nori.  (I like the crunch of nori with a hand roll - espescially with the salmon one.)  No matter - they were so perfect.

I also had a side order of ohitashi (spinach) - which I love.  The portion was very small - and it was a side - so I ordered something else.  

Something heavy.
Something decadent.
I so should not have order this - but I did and I loved it, too.

The braised short rib app over crispy larmen.

Oh.  Boy.

The bill including 1 non-alcoholic drink (a refreshing limeade) and tax 'n tip was $40.

Not bad.

Decor is gorgeous - a giant paper koi on the ceining and great light woods and textures throughout.

Zama - I am infatuated and will return soon.  Can you win me over from Doma? You are nearly 5 stars.

We shall see.

This place used to be the Wawa - and it has since improved in cleanliness and product quality, now thatOld Nelson took over.  A good place to get coffe, sandwiches and packed foods.  Plus it's right across the street from a Dunkin Donuts so you can get all your pre-work coffee/donut & smokes and head to the office.

What a fun place for breakfast or lunch.
A friends and I had lunch here (ironically nobody had any coffee).

The food was just fine - and the servers are friendly and cool (great hair and ink!).

A great neighborhood place.  Wish they'd stay open later (close at 2 PM) or do dinner a few nites per week.

Also - note:  cash only.

Still one of the best Sushi spots around.
The tamago is frozen (bad) but the Spicy Tuna Balls are great and the sashimi is solid.
The last time I went I tried a specialty roll (can remember the name) for $14.95 (ouch) and the hamachi sashimi app.  (YUM!).

Ask for sauces on the side if you prefer.
Sushi chef Sam is very nice, too.

I'm still a fan!

This has got to be the cleanest and most well run Rita's that I have ever seen.  The summer-teen/college aged staff is actually pleasant and well mannered.  We stopped by for frozen custards on July 4th weekend and it was a great experience. (As Rita's goes.)

The frozen custard is quite good.  I am not a water ice eater - but I love the custard at Rita's.  News flash! Their "Gelatti" is NOT Gelatto.  It is a bastardization combo of water ice and custard.  Whatever.  It tastes good.

Bring on the coffee flavored frozen custard, please.

I am so happy so say that Aya's is still terrific.  And - if you get the $6.99 daily lunch special (Wednesday it was a chicken pita sandwich), it's a great value, as well.

Love the hot, thin pita, baba ganoush and tahini here.

Super-yum!

Not bad for a chain - nice sunny, light wood decor, quick service (even on a weekday lunch), and tasty thin crust pizzas with lots of fresh toppings to choose from.

I also like the CPK Cobb salad - the half is PLENTY big - not need to get the larger size.

Tortilla and Minestrone soups are good, too.

Nice.

Hostess Gift Central!  Monther's Day, too.  Wonderful home decor items, chocolates, jewelry items and accessories.

LOVE IT!

I stopped at DiBruno's on a whim at 7:45 AM for a (pricey) breakfast sandwich.  COOKED TO ORDER.  I had scrambled eggs (2), cheddar, spinach and tomato on an english muffin.  Came to $4.49 with tax - yikes - but man was it good.

An indulgence for sure - and you gotta wait several minutes - especially if there is a line (at 7:45 there wasn't) as they painstakingly prepare everyone's sandwich, omlette or oatmeal ONE at a time.

Wow.  A yuppy puppy brekkie for sure!

I have been dying to try Bittersweet and now I can't wait to return.
Eli (at the front counter) and the other staffers are so friendly and helpful.
Note:  You order and pay first and then sit down and they bring the food to you.

Breakfast and lunch ONLY - except for Wednesday dinner (Dining Out in the Chaos aka Dining Under the Stars).

Creme Brulee Pancakes are a sweet-dessert like treat.
I opted for the savory special - Breakfast enchiladas and tasted a terrific side of Vegetarian Chili with Sweet potatoes and Black Beans (I loved that best!).  The cornbread accompanying the chili is house-made and perfect!

I want one of everything!
What a great place.

What a great find. Fabulous, family-run Thai with a cute stand at Booths Corners complete with Boba teas.

We'll be back.

Still great - but we had a 4 star experience.

Thankfully we dined early so we could order off both the Happy Hour menu (Nachos with skirt steak was good and surprisingly plentiful for a half portion.) and Dinner Menu (Planytains with Crema!)

Lovely food, delicious fresh cocktails.
Great Service.

LOVE IT!  (So close t 5 stars - please bring back the pomegranate salad).

$50 for 2 of us - one drink a piece and lots of bites.

Believe it or not - I like this staples - it's a large one (the one I go to the most is at 1500 Chestnut - which is smaller, less selection and a bit higher prices.)

This one is fine and unlike Nu S., I never had any problems here service-wise - granted it's run by high school and college "kids".

I get toner, post-its, copy paper, highligheter pens, batteries, memory cards/sticks and occaisionally even a case of spring water when it's a decent price.

Glad to have a Staples nearby.

Oh - and terachers - sign up for your 10% discount and they also give credit for school supplies to your school.

Nice big parking lot.  Easy-peasy.

On the LAST Wednesday of every month you can get a Medium 2 topping pizza for $3.99 (Normally it's $4.99).  Seriously?  You can't get a frozen pizza for $3.99

We love this deal and get one pie for every 2 kids and it's perfect for two (or one ravenous adult.).

Sashimi puts a sushi joint to the test - and the $13.95 sashimi app is a generous taste of 4 fish (tuna, salmon, seared (cold) albacore, Y.T. and 1 cooked shrimp).

If you love the inside of a spicy tuna roll without the rice try the spicy tuna ball app.  5 bite-sized balls of spicy tuna coated in crunchies.

I am a fan of this place!!!

Well, it's 6 years later and I am pleased that Jeenwong is still there - and my egg noodles with shrimp ($8.95) came with 6 BIG shrimp and lots of brocoli and carrots.  A little on the greasy side and not spicy at all (I am a wimp so that's fine by me - if you want spicy don;t get this one - or ask them to make it spicier which they will do.)

So pleased to have Thai within a short distance of my work.

This is a BIG target and it well designed.  I got in and out of here fast and hit all 4 departments I needed - Pharmacy, Cleaing Supplies, Baby Gear and Girl's Clothing.

I always drop at least $100 whenever I walk into  Target and here was NO exception.

We bought our chest freezer from HH Gregg 2 summers ago - and what a great $79.99 investment this has turned out to be.  It fit in our car (we got a smaller one) so we did not need to pay to ship it home and the sales dudes helped us "dollie" it out to the vehicle.

No issues here.
And no tax in DE!

We had an excellent lunch at Concerto - mostly sushi (which was fresh - not off tasting at all) maki and an excellent duck salad.

The staff wqas pleasant and the decor is very nice - sleek and modern as others have described.

I am sad to see some very negative reviews on here - and feel fortunate that we got fresh fish and a great tasting meal.

Ameriflex administers our firms DCA and FSA (Flexible Spending Accounts).  It has been a dream so far to have claims processed and paid so quickly.  These accounts are "use it or lose it".)

It sure beats the old way we did things.
A large Wawa with a gas station and decently clean restrooms.  Got in & out and back on 73 with no issues.

A great place for a basic (or not so basic) Turkey sammie.  I love the turkey here - simple, tasty and not dry.  (Thank the lord.)  They offer alot of sides, too - but I usually just get the sandwich and then, if I am still hungry I head to Little Thai Market or Sang Kee for a small bite of something else.

Not as clean anymore (somehow I KNEW that would happen) but still a great place for fresh dragonfruit, enoki mushrooms, many varieties of vermicelli, sauces and other Asian staples that you just don't see in the Ack-a-mee.

Fresh bean sprouts and frozen Har Gow (shrimp dumplings) were on today's list!

Seasons - you have redeemed yourselves.

I ordered our Superbowl pies (2 large - with an array of toppings) and 25 wings 2 days in advance and they were ready,correct and piping hot when I picked them up at precisely 6:30 PM. (Tip:  get the NY Style crust - not too thick, not thin.)

Fabulous!
Much better than the pies we had last year (from a different place).

We'll be back for Superbowl food from Season's next year - and I bet many times in between.

This venue is fine - but our service at the Diva Drag brunch was terrible.
The actual drag show was hilarious and fun and well put together, but our server was a space cadet (Another server from a different section actually took over for a while which was good) and forgot to get us drinks, get our food, etc.

They need more servers during the Sunday brunches 3 or 4 was not enough for over 100 people.

All is all, the venue was fine - and the ladies room was clean!
We'll be back.

Another great, simple, perfectly broiled salmon dinner with rice and cucmber salad at Lobster Claw.  The place was PACKED - every table filled - on a Saturday night.  Friendly service and simple, delicious seafood meals.  (Fried or Broiled).

LOVE IT here.
I love the vibe of this small shop and the merchandise is gorgeous.  Perfect cruise-wear, beach wear and summer/spring wear.  Pricey - but unique and fun.

Still amazing after all these years.
My now 11 year old kid and I had a whopping $85 lunch including a Pachinko Roll (delicious), the Tartare Trio ($15), Naked Salmon roll and JUMBO Ebi Shumai.
Also Nigiri and sashimi a la carte (Salmon belly, salmon, REAL home-made tamago and more).

We love this place SO much!
We miss you!

Stopped in for an actual sit-down lunch today with a colleague (usually I have been getting take out due to work) and we had a terrific time.

It, of course, helped that we got there at 11:40 AM and the sushi bar was empty (It wasn't when we left!) and we also both love sushi.

The "A" roll - a caloric concontion of shrimp tempura, mango inside, spicy (not too spicy) crunchy tuna outside (sauces on the side - eel sauce and spicy mayo) is tasty - but best shared as it is heavy and filling.

The Yellowtail sashimi was perfectly fresh and artfully presented (Sliced perfectly and no blood-line).

Tuna dumplings (so unique) never dissappoint.

LOVE it here still.

The Lawn.
The music.
The picnic basket.
The Summer.

The traffic jam getting outta there.
The bugspray (bring some)

The Mann.

So good for "Italian" hot sandwiches, cheese-steaks and roast pork with greens.
Garlicky spinach and sharp provolone (50 cents more).

I had a cheese steak hoagie - and it was one of the best (Tony Luke's and Jim's beat Pat's and Geno's any day!)

Fresh bread.

Good stuff!

Re-joined Tyler as a dual membership (2 Adults - do not have to be in the same household) for $75 for a year (Admission is normally $15 but they now have reciprocity with PHS - Hooray!!!!)

Brian at the front desk was terrific and the volunteers in the butterfly house (a few of whom were tweens/young teens) knew their stuff.

Nice new restroom facilities (and a meeting room area - and air conditioned - WOW) near the "edible garden".

A few of the (now over a decade old) treehouses have fallen into disrepair.  Please consider donating to help aid their restoration.  Tyler is a wonderful place and an important wildlife and plant refuge right in Delco.

Love it here.

A solid 4 this time for properly cooked Hunan Duck and (Special) Crystal Shrimp Dumplings.  They don;t always have these dishes but if they are on special (or ask - and they if have it they'll make it!) consider these.

Ian and staff are excellent and attentive.

No issues.
Our go-to for "Classic" Chinese-American in Media.

Love the service here from Katie who dotes on my parents (Mom gets the same meal EVERY time - A flounder sandwich, no bread, side of sliced tomatoes).

Wonderful seafood that is always fresh and tasty.
Cucumber salad is refreshing and sweet.  Love it.

My Shrimp salad sandwich was bursting with plump shrimp.  LOVE IT HERE.

Prices have gone up - $16.95 for the salmon dinner now.  Wow.
$19.95 for Ahi Tuna.

Still, love it.

Came here for my birthday dinner - just me and the husband (DH) - and poissoned myself on fresh sashimi (appetizer), Tuna Tartare (a bit oversuaced - heavy on the ponzu, but still tasty) and a delicious Salmon Belly, Cucumber hand roll.

Lovely food, decent enough service.
Best sushi around for the price (cheaper than Teikoku or Azie, closer than Sushi Nami).

Sadly, now that Vic is gone - the magic is, sadly, fading.
Want the old Vic's?  Try Jay's Favorite - Jay & Vic know each other and steal each others recipes.

Again, reminder:  sauce on the side if you don't want an over-glopped roll!

For $12.69 ($11.75 plus tax) I had the lunch platter which was a plentiful amount of protein (I had the brisket and it was very good), 2 sides (Try the carrot fries or the Brussels Sprouts - both are good) and the green goddess salad with a delicious sweet honey citrus dressing.

I liked everything I tried and I left with a bunch to take home - it was plenty of food.

Good healthier choices than at a typical fast-food joint - but they are also right next door to Mama's and I just love it there, too.

Decisions, decisions - we are blessed.

Kacey at the front counter was terrific - great customer service.

A solid 4 now - we have been back at least 3 times for dinners with our 7 year old who gobbles down edamame, shumai, meaty delicious spare ribs (or boneless ribs) and fried rice.  (Good - but a bit greasy.)

Reasonable prices, great service from Annie and Ian, and Panda Cookies (from Japan) for $1.50 to take home at the end.

Oh - and they raise and release butterflies.  You can view the chrysali at the register.

A good, solid, delicious, "classic" Chinese-American joint.

LOVE it - and cheaper than Maggie Kuo.  (But we like it there, too, for fancy-schmancies.)

While I am partial to Morris Arboreutum - I also love Tyler.
It is beautiful in the spring when the trees and gardens are blooming - late spring May - June is awesome here.

No, you can't bring your dog - but do bring a blanket or find a bench and read a book or paint or take pictures and just relax.

And if you are a member of PHS (Pennsylvania Horticulture Society) you can NOT go for a reduced rate. That irked me a bit.  Very nice front desk staff.

It's worth the trip!  (And visit Morris, too.)

I used to come here with my BFF from Jr. High and H.S. back in the day.  It was a nice, quiet (and back then) safe park to hang out in.  We would walk on the paths.

In more recent years (albeit that's still 5-7 years ago) I brought my little dog here.

A nice park - and we need those!

I stopped in to Vic's after not coming by in a long while.
The place was SO crowded that I ate in the window.
I had the Ocean Brother Roll (sauce on the side) and it ROCKED.

I still love it here - but it's just so tiny and cramped.

I sometimes go to Jay's now.

Consistently 4 star.  I thought quality was slipping there for a while - but I went here again tonight and had the (always great) tuna dumplings (thin sashimi slices of red tuna pounded flat and stuffed with an avocado/tobiko/sauce and pulled together to form a litle red pouch.  Glop (er. I mean sauce) on the side.  YUM!

I also had the (ouch) $13.95 "Crazy" roll which is similar to my "usual" the Ocean Brother roll.  Both are topped with a luscious REALL lump crab topping.  (I get my sauces on the side).  The Crazy has spicy tuna & 'cado inside, While the Ocean Brother has Shrimp Tempura inside.

I think I found me a NEW fave.  The Crazy Roll is less heavy (not fried) and I love that fresh crab topping.

I am STUFFED from eating all that myself - and (including the bottle of Fiji water - it still pisses me off that you have to BUY a water.  They won't serve you any.  Only green tea.) the tab came to $28.  

It's not cheap.  It's very small and cramped. It's still GREAT food.

This place is teeny tiny - so know that before you go.  Also when I went and asked for a glass of water I was told they have no water and I'd have to buy a bottle - which I did.  I went again today and again had to buy a $1.80 bottle of Fiji.

Vic offers a great roll cominbation special and also serves some creative and (fattening - too much rich sauce) non-traditional rolls.
Order the sauce on the side and problem is solved!

One item worth getting though is the "tuna dumplings".  This is really a sashimi type appetizer.  Thinnly sliced raw tuna is filled with a creamy avocado mixture (again - fat-city) and molded into a dumpling shape.  Worth a try if you are into avocado.

Also try the Sansom Roll. It is a meal in itself.

Recently I also tried (and now have dreams about) the Ocean brother roll - a huge roll stuffed with shrimp tempura and avocado,  and outside has a delicious mildly-spiced CRAB SALAD (real crab) and wasabi tobiko.  It is usually drowned in eel sauce, so again - I get mine with brown rice, sauce on the side.  (I know, I'm a picky pain in the ass.)

I prefer to go to Vic at Lunch time as it is not a dinner place.  Way too small - only 8 seats at the bar and NO TABLES.

Note:  As of July '08 prices have gone up and there are no more 2 roll lunch combos - you must now get 3 rolls for $11.95 - which is still a good deal. (But I usually only need 2 rolls. Oh well.)

This store seems somehow better now.  Maybe the flow is quicker during the morning rush?  Maybe its now that the lady cashier knows me by face I get better service?  I still cringe when I spend over $7.00 on coffee/espresso drinks and a breakfast sandwich - so I am not in here often.

Consisently high quality fish and friendly service for take out lunches.
The 3 roll combo is a filling meal and a good value.

Tuna Dumplings are delicious.

MUCH better than Jay's favorite.

I used to love WMMR before they changed formats years ago.  I still listen on occaision but now that I am officially older and fartier I listen to WMJK (which used to be the valium station and is now classic rock and DiBella).

This starbucks at the corner of 20th & Market serves the local lawyers and stock exchange folks and they really manage the morning line well.  Staff is decent enough - and the bathroom is usually OK - kept locked.

Not bad!

We ordered from Uncle Oogie's for a company event - and my chicken.avocado salad was delicious.  The pasta and 'parm platters looked great, too.

Love it here, still.

Oh how my family - especially my parents who eat there nearly every week when they are "in season" - loves the Lobster Claw.

Run by a mother and her son and his partner, this home-town seafood joint has a casual feel (GREAT for kids) and tasty fresh fish, seafood and sides.

They are just such nice people and have been around for years.

My mom gets the fried flounder sandwich and dad is partial to the grilled salmon plater.  The cucumber salad is light and sweet - not too vinegary and JUST delish.  I like the mac 'n cheese.

Last time we went I had tilapia - but the fresh blue-fish was on special and it looked fetching as well.

W love it here.  They also sell loads of take-out.
The fried food is never greasy - the onion rings are so tasty.

You gotta try this "little nothing place" becuase it's really all-that.  5 stars for food and about a 3 for decor. (No atmosphere..)

We joined as a family for $60 - so now we have to go at least 4 times to break even.
We went yesterday to roam the vegetable garden (and eat a few tomatoes) and sit in the many "sit a spell" chairs and benches designed by a multitude of artisans.

Well worth at least 2 visits here per year.  We'll see if we go 4 times and it so, we'll re-join next year.

Note:  NO RECIPROCITY with PHS (sucks!) but they do have a discount for AHS members (which I am not.).

Excellent front desk staff - we left our credit card there and she called me on both phones.  Also the volunteer/docent in the butterfly house (maybe he is a paid staffer??) was so kind to the kids and knowledgeable.

Surprisingly good and what a value - $5.00 gets you a whopping big portion of rice (mostly), salad (iceberg and 2 tomato slices), chicken or "lamb" or both and white and/or hot sauce.

AND you get a can of soda and a bottle of water.

Whata value - and it's pretty tasty, too.

Nice guys running the show.
$5!

FIVE!

Wow.

Azie has evolved into our "special occasion" restaurant as it is just too overpriced to dine there on the regular.  

Meanwhile, my daughter was turning 13 so for the 4th consecutive year we booked a party of 9 here and had great service by Dan, Tom and Ashley (who remembered us from last year).
The service was great and we were seated upstairs in a lovely semi-private area.

Why not five stars?  The sushi here is just "meh".  A few of the white fish varieties (Snapper?  Fluke?  Who knows) were not fresh tasting, although the 3 biggies (tuna, yellowtail and salmon) were all just fine.  Stick with the tartar - the sauce is tasty and 2 orders of salmon tartar disappeared quickly.

Cocktails are delicious here - my Pom-Pop was so easy to drink, and the F.I.G jam is amazing, too.

The strip steak, diver scallops and crab (or shrimp) fried rice are all terrific.Feeling simple?  Salmon or Chicken Teriyaki (Usually so boring) are delightful here.

$4 cappucino and $8 creme brulee for dessert capped off a wonderful experience.
Many thanks to the staff for making a special birthday even more extra-special.

Ever since Tom's Dim Sum opened, we have not been to Da Shin for a while.
Today my kid was home because schools were closed.  So I ordered lunch for 3 including Shu Mai (delicious), Steamed Pork Dumplings (Very good but a bit doughy) and Sesame Chicken.  (Not my fave but my kid loves that fried dark meat chicken.).

Excellent service.
They seem to have updated the menu a bit and changed owners (again??)?

A great place to get upscale (a bit pricey) gear for the garden and cute gift ideas - like home-made jams in elegant jars from Gregory Benjamin.  Love it!

Garden tools, too (spades, hoes, rakes, trugs and gloves) and potted plants.

This location at 19/20 & Market is my "old faithful" when I am on my way to the office or running errands in this area o Center City.  There is usually a longer line during peak hours but moves quickly (hello, mobile ordering!).  They have occasionally screwed up my order but always make it right if they do - thankfully they don't mess it up too often.

Between this 'Bux and the one at 18 & Market I am well-stocked with overpriced caffeine to get me through my stressful rat-race of a week.

Mad props to the barristas who are "workin' it".  Especially the nice young man who works 3 - 7 PM ish.

Gotta have my latte. #DiabetesInaCup

OK, here's my long awaited review of Nineteen (I'm not gonna call it XIX, just 19 is fine for me.).

Even though my "special" birthday was almost a whole month ago, a very kind & generous girlfriend gifted me dinner at 19 tonight.

Chuck, our server was fabulous - I want to make that clear- as I am about to say some critical things about the service.

Here's how things shook down...

I arrived for our 6 PM reservation early - at about 5:45.  Since it was a lovely evening, I decided to have a drink on the terrace, and selected a table out in the open air.  I put down my water bottle and asked the (very pregnant) hostess where the ladies room is.  She explained that I needed to go down 1 flight on the elevator.  Great.  Fine.  

When I get back there is some guy sitting at "my" table and my water bottle is gone.

So I move to another outdoor table - and the host (not the hostess) brings me a bottle of water (huge 27 oz. bottle of fancy-schmancy water from Norway - which - by the way - was damned tasty water.) to replace it.  I order a virgin Mexican Mojito - which was perfect, by the by, - a refreshing libation of club soda, fresh lime juice and basil-infused (you really could smell it) simple syrup.  Limeaid with a twist.  FAB-U!

So I drink my mocktail and quite happily sit and chill until way, way past 6 PM.  At 6:15 or so I call my g.f. - guess what???  She's seated in the dining room and has been there for half an hour.  Nobody came to get me.  Nobody told her I was there.  No nothin'.

So I ask to move to the table, and we chat and order.

Decor:  5 stars.  The dining room with it's pussy willow & pearl theme and MARVELOUS rotunda is so breathtaking. 

Service: 2 (Chuck gets a 4 or 5 - he was great), everyone else was snotty and/or pre-occupied).  VERY SNOTTY.

Food - varies - 3-4 - here's why:

We started with salads.  I splurged and ordered the lump crabmeat salad which was truly delicious and lightly dressed in an orange-champagne vinaigrette.   The tomatoes were red, ripe and actually tasted like tomatoes.  The small chunks of avocado were smooth and buttery.  The bibb lettuce was right on!  For $15 bucks (whoa-momma!( that was my kinda salad.  For $15 bucks you could put a little more crab - though I must say the crab that was there was sweet and PURE lumbo lump meat.  Nary a shell!

We both had the(only vegetarian) tagliatelle entree.  The pasta was hand-crimped, and light and luscious.  It was bathed in a lemony (very sharp, but I got used to it) buttery sauce and LOADED with various hoity-toity mushrooms including morels, hen-of-the-woods, oyster and others.  If you don't like shrooms - do NOT order this.  Quite frankly I was mushroomed-out by the end of it and left (no joke!) over 1/2 cup of these precious morsels - I ate all the morels - plate side).  I also chased down all of the succulent beans (small fava - large lima - something else??)  and fresh sp[ring peas.  Oh - and there were ramps and FIDDLEHEADS.  A nice spring dish.  High-end veg for sure. But quite alot of mushrooms.

For dessert had a kickin' strong cup of Illy cappucino.  Good - but somehow not as good as the cap at Davio's.  A bit bitter.  Wesplit ahome-made waffle with nutella & berry compote.  The waffle itself was great.  I would have preferred less "glop" on top of it,but my friend preferred the sauces to the waffle. She digs nutella.  Oh - and they put a little green candle in the scoop of (homemade??) vanilla ice cream on top of the waffle.

Thankfully nobody sang!
 
Since someone else paid, It was a 4 star time, but honestly?  Forthe money there are much. much better places to eat - and drink - not only in Philly - but in Philly high-end hotels.

That said - the private dining room is nice- and I would definitely do a business lunch or dinner here.

But for my own life?  I doubt if I'd run back here.

Still there - Still just $5 (for lunch WITH a drink - I get a bottle of water) - Still as good as you can expect for street-cart food.

I get the lamb over Salad with "white sauce" - and it is plenty of food for lunch.

And - it's five bucks!

5 star service from Kelsi last night.
We tried to go to Dining Under the Star (aka Chaos out in the Humidity) but there were no outside tables.

So we sat on the 2nd floor (roof deck was also full) and enjoyed Kobe (actually Waygu) on a hot rock, sushi rolls, Crab meat Pad Thai and a delicious chocolate fondue for dessert (same as Teikoku).

Our 9 year old had never been here before and she loved it - especially the fondue and hot-rock beef.  She also devoured a California roll.

Good times!

About $100 for the 3 of us with no alcohol ordered.

This is my go-to Giant when I am in Doylestown.  I much prefer it to Acme as I know the layout of the store (I start in Produce and work my way aisle by aisle).

The freezer sections are clean and adequately chilled.
The Milke, OJ and Dairy are right on my way to the check out.

(Line up, folks, it's COVID time)

The young-ish cashiers are friendly and do a fine job.

No issues.

A strong four stars - but not five.  The service is rather spotty and some of the hostesses and bar staff need to up their game.

Meanwhile I had ($6) 2 pieces of Salmon nigiri - fresh and good, a spicy-crunchy tuna roll (very good but not the best ever) and a beet salad (loaded with blue cheese - next time I will skip it) and served over crunchy iceberg that others may scoff at - but I enjoyed.

Pork Belly app ($13) had barely a smattering of pricey foie gras on top (best part) and delicious braised kale underneath.  

Honestly - this is my favorite place in Media so far.
Great food and when the service is good it's a great spot - but twice now I have been made to feel as if dining alone there is a no-no.

Acme - you have redeemed yourself!  I desperately needed a roast chicken the day before Xmas (Christmas eve day) and they were not only open (and a bit crowded but not awful) but had fresh birds ready.

Psyched!

Happy Hour from 5 - 7 PM (Monday thru Thursday) is a great option with $5 cocktails (try the Azie Blue) served up by Juan - the long-time, friendly bartender.

Lovely atmosphere, great (albeit pricey) food and a good date or special treat place.

Take out lunch for me and my 14 year old came to just under $25.
She still loves that (fried) Sesame Chicken.  Pork Fried Rice.  Egg Drop or Wonton Soup.

I had B&B  - Beef 'n Broc.

Solid.

Great service, too.
Seems like an extension of the other Christmas Market across the street.  Lots of fun to browse around but nothing I felt compelled to buy.

Open from 7 AM - 4 PM only (sometimes even closing a bit earlier) this  breakfast & lunch spot (No alcohol served) is lovely for "Breakfast for lunch".  My Eggs Benedict (California - with Avocado and a slice or tomato instead of Canadian Bacon) was delicious. Came with slightly bland and slightly underdone hash-browns.  Plenty of food for $9.95. Friendly service - and you pay at the front.

It was jam-packed at precisely 12 noon on a Wednesday - so come earlier if you can.
Parking is also a drag - but the end result is worth it.

Sit on the patio under an umbrella if the weather permits.

NICE!

Had a 3 star service (4 star food) experience here for my birthday party (11 guests).
We were seated in the front bar area at two 6-top tables.  Splitting the check at the end was a nightmare, plus the pre-added gartuities rangesd from 21 to 40%.  (40%??  What???)

Everything got corrected eventually.

Meanwhile the best bites of the night were the Salmon tartare (magical) and the Chilean sea bass.

Very expensive for what it is - but it's one of our go-to spots for special occasion meals.
I wish the service was better - they get so busy on a Saturday night that I tend to not go there on weekends.

Still a great place for sushi (don't miss the tuna dumplings) and sashimi.  Same friendly owners and wonderful service at a tiny bar that gets PACKED at lunchtime.

Great find!

Many thanks to Matt and the gang for hosting my class's High School reunion at Villa Capri.  We basically took the place over with about 65 people in attendance for light apps (Calamari, bruscetta, "Brooklyn" pies, salad and mini cannoli).

We all had a great time and the bar was well run.

Excellent.  Excellent cheesesteaks.
I had the Italian (Sharp Prov and Broc. Rabe) and added mushrooms - $.75.
My friend had "The Works"/

About $11 a pop - but huges and delicious and NOT dripping with grease.

Crowded and cramped to eat there - but so. worth. it.
Teeming with tourists - NATCH.

CASH ONLY  (ATM on site)

I visited Azie for the first time alone - and it sure won't be my last.
Expensive - yes - but I had impeccable service on the (now open) rooftop deck and tried the delicious (and huge) Chicken Noodle (rice noodles) soup. Simple - but great.

Good selection of cocktails, too.

Can't wait to come back and try more.

On par with Linvilla Orchards (but no petting zoo, less crowded and better for a purely Farmer's Market experience.

They don't grow the produce here (yet - they are buying up land across the stree) - but they carry a ton of plants, flowers, produce and cider.

My house cookies!!!  
Cider donuts
A smattering of gourment goodies.

We love it here.

Much improved over the years and in winter my teen enjoys the River Rink.

Lots to see and do in summer, too.
Famous for Fireworks (and crowds) on July 4th.

A new, fresh, clean and well-stocked Giant that already is crowded on weekends and during peak shopping periods.  Way better than the crapolla Acme in Granite Run.

I still visit the Giant in Aston because i know the store layout (or at least i knew it before they renovated a piece of the store) and can shop faster there.

I am a Giant shopper for sure - more than Acme, Shoprite, Trader Joe's Wegmans's (too far) or Whole Paycheck (love it, too far, can't afford).

For my every day groceries, look for me in line, at Giant.

A much needed addition to Brookhaven/Media/Aston area as the existing Giant was getting super crowded.

Large aisles and (CoVid excluded) usually well stocked.

Yay!

Celebrated my kids 11th birthday here (we celebrated her 10th here last year) with a party of 7. Service by Ashley was top-notch, 5 star all the way - but there are some serious food errors that occured.

My mother & I shared the Strip steak, and while the flavor was delicious the meat was gristley and not pleasant to eat.  We also asked if we could have veggies instead of truffle fries and we got ONE sprig of asparagus each.  (What??!)  Luckily a plate of light cooked vegetables (quite al dente) arrived but over half way through the meal.

Dessert was divine as always and service good - but that steak?  I can and have made better at home.

Oh - and skip the shrimp shumai.  They're frozen.

I lived in Center CIty for 6 years from 2005 - 2011.
I also lived in near West Philly (Univesirty Cityish) from 1991 - 1993 - probably would have given that about 2 stars.

So many classic things to see and do - the Museums, Reading Terminal Market, Italian Market, South Street, Old(e) City, the Historic District.

Philly is on the rise - the shopping, dining and entertainment have all improved even with the recent economic unrest.

Mayor Nutter is doing the best he can.

First Watch (alot like Turning Point) is a casual breakfast/brunch/lunch place.
On weekends it gets very crowded but we were able to snag an outdoor table after a 35 minute wait.  (Thanks, Vince!)

Avocado Toast, Eggs Benedicts, Salads, Veggie Sandwich, Fresh juices and delicious (sweet and caloric) iced coffee.

All the food was great.

Pricey for egg dishes but a fun brunchy spot.
Large portions.

A delicious selection of coffee and espresso drinks, smoothies, pastries and other treats.  A chill, laid-back atmosphere.

Love it.

When we lived in Philly we were stuck with the Class of 1923 rink, so now that we are suburbanites, we take our 8 year old to IceWorks (not for hockey - just for open family skating).

She loves it - especially watching the Zamboni.
Plus they have classes here - but we have not yet had her take any. We also enrolled her for 2 weeks of "Camp Chill" - the ice skating camp (they also have ice hockey sumemr camp).  I will update my review once camp has come and gone. And they offer birthday parties.

Wear a jacket - it's COLD in the rink.
At Christmas they have a few "Skate with Santa" sessions.  Fun.

They also have a snackbar on one side and a full "bar-bar" with hot food on the other.

Just a hair away from a 5 star experience last night.  Dining Under the Stars was poorly attended due to spotty rain - but that was great for us as we snagged a prime table on the roof deck and had a fine and wonderful meal.

Great service and food.
Bulkoki spring rolls, Kobe Hot Rock, Sushi and Salmon teriyaki were all terrific.
El kiddo devoured her food - including a shrimp tempura roll.

So what's the problem?
No more green vegetables served with entree - only mashed yams (excellent).
I was craving some green beans or broccoli or kale.  Anything.

There is an $8 side of mixed veg - but we didn't go for it.  The entree was $22 alone for salmon and yams.  they used to include a vegetable but no more.

Also $10 for a side (huge - but still) of plain fried rice with only egg is CRAZY!

PLEASE BRING BACK the GREENS!

A perfectly made Iced Latte and a Smoothie for my friend with a clean restroom (need a code to use it) and friendly service.

No  issues.

Fergie's latest creation has transformed Oh! Shea's into the Goat.   Either named for the Goat statue in Rittenhouse Square or perhaps aspirational as The Greatest Of All Time?  In any case the bathrooms are clean, everything has been painted and the menu is re-vamped.

A full bar with any and everything you need plus short rib poutine?

All we need now is Chris behind the bar.

Good work and best wishes!

Will be closed nearly all of January 2022 for much needed renovations.
Meanwhile, we will miss those (pricey but tasty) homemade soups.  The Italian Wedding, Tomato Bisque and Corn Chowder are all excellent.

A great place for produce.  

See you in 2022.

2 words.

Pulled Pork.

You must try their version - sweet and delicious.  My 10 year old LOVES it.

We usually visit the CFA in Lima, and this one has the same owner.
We finally got a chance to visit the drive-thru during the great Corona-scare of 2020.

That said the drive-thru moved very quickly except for an error when the cashier rang us up.  This was quickly corrected and we were on our way except - no ketchup.

They forgot ketchup packets.  Oops.  Thankfully we were going home and have ketchup there.

Also, did you know CFA serves FISH during Lent?  They are delicious - I got the filets (no bread) but you can also get them on a sandwich.  If you like fried fish - and happen to be here during lent - try the fish.  Surprisingly good.

Wawa is a necessary evil.  I have a love/hate relationship with it, but all in all we are lucky it's still here.  The cigs, sodas and water bottles are there when we need them.

A quart of milk.
Some sliced Mango (really) and in a pinch, a wrap.  (Blech.)

Glad to have you nearby, Wawa.  Wish you had more parking.  The spots are nearly always full.

Attended a big (350plus) event in the grand ballroom.
Excellent service and surprisingly good food.

Recommend..

I love DuRoss - the man and the store.  He is a doll.  And he is a damned fine saponifier. The soap "popsicles" are just soooooo cute.  And the Mojito body scrub (the sugar based one) is really heavenly in the shower.

They even have a men's line and carry a few Italian and HTF (that's hard to find) bath & body products made by people other than Steve Du Ross.

Great staff and cute, cute shop.

LOVE IT!!!!

Oh - and they also did a private event for our group and it was such fun.  If you can, grab a bunch of gals and have them do a soap & lip balm making workshop for you. It's a blast and you take home the goodies you make.

A good friend (who was a regular at their old location) and I had lunch at the new location of Taqueria Moroleon.

While the new "Italian Diner"-feeling location is spacious and clean (full bar with LED color-changing lights and tequila bottles shaped like skulls), it has lost some of it's charm from the "old days".

Thankfully, the food is wonderful (at least, we were very pleased).
My friend had a specialty burrito (can't remember which one) and I had the Lunch combo #2 with a chicken burrito (instead of beef) and a GREAT corn-tortilla wrapped cheese enchilada.  The tortilla tasted super fresh.

Service by Suri (Suril?) was great - what a doll!

Prices are a bit high - especially for dinner - but for lunch it's a decent value and the portions were huge (both of us took home about 1/2 of our meals).

Fresh (slightly greasy) chips and 2 kinds of salsa (not pico) were a refreshing change from the "Old El Paso"-style "ketchup" we are used to getting at El Tapatio.  (Sorry El Tapatio - we love you for different reasons).

Will update review after I pick up the car.
Drove mby and saw this in my corporate parking lot.

Expensive ($17 for exterior, $14 for interior only, $27 for both) compared to my drive through place.

We shall see.

Very courteous guys running the show.

This is for the NEW Capriccio that opened near Love Park.

So far so good - my 4 year old and I have been here 3 times and had ice cream and chocolate covered pretzels and milk for snacks.  She loves it here and usually when we come iot's pretty mpty.

It is brand spankin' new - and the bathroom (ask for a key) is still clean and fit for use.

It has pretty much the same menu as the Old Capriccio on 17th Street.

The manager, Liz, is really nice and has a son about my dd's age so that's cool.  I wish them much success.  Hope they can keep in clean and new looking.

So far so good - my 4 year old and I have been here 3 times and had ice cream and chocolate covered pretzels and milk for snacks.  She loves it here and usually when we come iot's pretty mpty.

It is brnad spankin' new - and the bathroom (ask for a key) is still clean and fit for use.

It has pretty much the same menu as the Old Capriccio on 17th Street.

The manager, Liz, is really nice and has a son about my dd's age so that's cool.  I wish them much success.  Hope they can keep in clean and new looking.

Mellissa - my 8 year olds FAVORITE stylist from Mastercuts and about 3 or 4 other ladies (mostly or all from Mastercuts) have left and opened their own salon on the 2nd Floor of the Granite Run Mall.

The space used to be a salon and you can tell they re-did it on a budget - but the dated digs are not why we come here.  We come her for Melissa whom we love and the great $12 kids and $15 adults cuts ($25 for a wash cut and blow dry).

Melissa is a talented stylist and has done updos, braids, cuts' bang trims, flat ironed styles and more on my 7 now 8, soon to be 9 year old who was PETRIFIED of the salon until we started coming here.

Check out Shear Bliss - if you are ever near Granite Run Mall - and ask for Melissa.
She's the best!  (And Margot is great for color, too.)

I am taking a gamble - made an appointment due to good service when I walked in.
The next day I took my (adorable) 8 year old in for photos.

The session itself went very smoothly even though our photographer was a trainee which had me worried. The other lady (an experienced photog) trained him and they both took pictures during the session.

We had about 50 shots to choose from and narrowed it down to two poses.

Sheets of photos are $18 each (or a package of 10 sheets plus a CD for $135).
We only got two 8 by 10s and would have loved to buy more fbut they wanted $105 (talked them down to $75) for just the CD filled with .jpgs.

No thanks.

Also they tried to sell us a $12 "club membership" where you get $10 off every visit and "free" sheet.  This would be a good option if we ever were to return - but I will not be rushing back here.

That said, there is no seating/session fee and I like that alot.

We'll be back if we ever need more shots of el kiddo.

I will be generous and give 4 stars - it may be more of a 3 star place for most people.

We were treated extremely well here todayfor our holiday luncheon - a party of 19 with a nice set of choices for a prix-fixe menu.  We all got the Tuscan Bean soup (good - not great) and choice of Caesar ir House Salad.  I had the house with Balsamic vinaigrette - and it was fresh and tasty.

I had the Chicken Parm as an entree - which was deep fried - but otherwise good.

Dessert was a chocolate mousse coated profiterole.  Tasty but unappetizingly presented.

Service was surprisingly attentive and timely.  And yes, just as Chrissy R. did, I heard the Broad Street line train rumble on by when I was downstairs in the ladies room.

3 steps up from an Olive Garden.

I went to Oggi today and saw Henry - who has been there for 17 years.  I had a great single process color and a simple, classy haircut.  I also bought a great Kerastase leave-in treatment - and I love this line of products.

It was a pricey day - dropped about $175 including tips - so I won't be back often, but I will be back.

One big turn of- black hair all over the floor at Henry's chair when I sat down.  And nobody came to sweep it up at all during the nearly 75 minutes I was there.  Eew!

Wow!  Finally a clean, safe, fabulously-stocked (and equally highly priced) convenience grocer.  The have milk, shrimp shumai, honey candies, go-go squeeze (applesauce) and boar's head deli.

All the neccesities.

Thank goodness they opened!

Even though my daughter did not enjoy her veal parm (she said it tasted "like soap") and my father did not enjoy his lamb chops (they were "just fair").  My husband, mother and I enjoyed our dishes.  (My mom and I shared the Veal Francaise - which was delicious and, thankfully, not drowning in butter-sauce as we asked for it "light" on the sauce).

Salads were super fresh and the best part for me was the screppelle soup.  Awesome.

Good service, too.

My 10 year old wanted to give this place 2 stars but I like it here and next time I am coming without her.  Meanwhile, she polished off her New York Cheesecake for dessert with no problems and I enjoyed a perfect cappuccino.

So there!

Brand new - huge and much needed in this part of town.
A big improvement over the dinky "State Store" they closed on Chestnut.

So happy to be able to get a few bottled of bubbly for the holidays or a bottle or liquer or vodka when I need them.  (And an easy walk from 20th Street Station).

Wawa, is, indeed, the Native-American word for munchies.
And smokes.

And this one is convenient - although smaller than some.

Gotta.  Have a.  Wawa.

3,5 stars - but I will give them 4 due to excellent service from Cathy (??) and the hostess.

It was our first visit but we will return.  I had the Grouper (special that night - but I have a feeling often) with fresh tomatoes and lumps of crabmeat.  The fish was perfectly cooked and not dry at all.  Delicious but a bit salty and over-sauced (lots of butter.)

DH had the Chicken sorretino with spaghetti in a blush sauce.  (Again, way oversauced - but delicious).

The food is good and portions are large (we both took some home) but there are definitely some areas for improvement (salt and oil/butter content are too high).

As I said before - very good service that night. (Saturday at 6 ish.)
I will be back!

If you can take the noise level (excruciating - even when it's not busy) and the crowds - and you have a kid from age 4-8, then take 'em over to Giggleberry for the overpriced birthday experience of a little lifetime.  They have a gorgeous carousel (best part of the joint, if you ask me.), overpriced food & pizza, and Giggleberry Mountain - a place where your kid can run off some energy.

Lot's of video games and "token" gobbling machines, too.

We plan to have our daughter's 4th birthday party here.  I'll let you know how it goes.  I had to BEG the management to let us have milk & juice instead of soda (can you imagine feeding soda to a group of 3-5 year olds?)  No outside food is allowed, so you are stuck with their overpriced, non-nutritive package.  I hope the "free" cake is edible.

God help us!

I went here for a drug test for a new job.  Arrived right at 8 AM but they did not open the doors until close to 8:15.

There was one guy ahead of me and they I got in and out right afetr that.

Friendly staff, clean waiting and treatment rooms.

No issues.

Surprisingly good food here.  Especially for a local bar.
We had salads with grilled chicken, pecans, dried cranberries and goat cheese crumbles.  All for $6.95.

It does reek of beer though.

And the service was excellent.  A cool lady bartender with "Trust Me" and 2 crossed handguns tattooed across her chest.  She was cool!

Considering that I now work right across the street, I will likely be a lunch time regular.

Not a good choice for food but a GREAT choice for your morning coffee/latte/Muddy Waters (Coffee with Espresso shot added).  Super friendly staff and clean comfy digs with FREE wifi!

Breakfast sandwiches are $5 and up.  Ouch.
a Medium Latte and egg-cheese-bacon on a bagel was $9.

Can't afford to come here daily but maybe once every 10 days or so?

Super friendly barrista and cashier in the AM.
Line can move SLOWly..

Famous Dave's has our family hooked on their version of inexpensive, decent BBQ.  It is great for our 6 year old (she can get BBQ chicken or mac 'n cheese and DH 7 I can get an elegant meal presented on a trash can lid.

Tyrone & Alicia are the BEST servers!  Give them a BIG raise!

The management treats us so well here - and Wilbur (the pig mascot) entertains out little one.

Try to come here at 3 or 4 PM when the lunch rush is over and dinner has not yet begun. And you can get the lunch-size (and price!) specials ANY TIME which is great.  3 ribs for $7.99 includes a side, a corn cobette and a mamoth sweet cornbread muffin.

Carbo-loaded BLISS.

Makes me happy, happy!  I will edit my review once I try the meat ravioli I just bought over the weekend.  I am so anxious to try it and to find a great new source for pasta and ravioli and sauces in the Italian Market area.

Brand-spankin' new Bruegger's Bagels (of the chain popular in Boston and other cities) has come to Center City.  The offer a vast selection of bagels - baked fresh on premises - including abulous Rosemary & Olive Oil, Sesame, and whole wheat renditions.

Lots of wraps, ciabatta and "Softwich" - sqaure soft bagel-like bread sandwiches.  The have 2 soups per day and offer salads.

Everything is under $8.00 and a few sandwiches are about 5-6.

I will be back.  I hope they can keep it first-day fresh and clean.

For chain it's a solid 3.5 stars (I'll be generous and give 'em 4).  The Chicken Marsala and pasta are good.  Ask for light on the sauces if you are watching your calories - they are loaded with fat.

Service was surprisingly good and effcient.  

I would NOT wait in a line though - so try to avois Friday & Saturday nights.  It is easier to eat here when it is less crowded & less noisy.

Again - for a chain it's way better than the dreaded Olive Garden - and I loathe Macaroni grill (friends and family love it but we had  awful food at one) with their bitter, cheap olive oil.

If you must do fauxtalian - this is a better bet.
It's ain't Le Castagne, and it sure ain't Lusardi's but it's tasty and easy/family fun.

Wegman's certainly has established its formula - with grocery, cafe, pub and many pre-prepared meal options.  I stopped in for lunch on a snowy day and it was still fairly busy.  Sushi was good but not great (Grocery Store Sushi but more varieties than most) and steam-table Chinese/Asian-American was OK and fresh.

Inexpensive and lots of choices for lunch.

This location has closed - but they have re-opened a brand spankin' new one in Love Park (17 & Cherry ish).

Can't wait to try it - as I miss my Vanilla Italian Sodas.

We had such a great experience at the Center City Staples today - now granted it was about 10:45 AM on a Thursday and the places was dead empty - so that alone was a novelty.

My little one and I peacefully shopped for scotch tape, markers, posterboard and other art supplies.  the cashier we had (the only one on today - wish I knew her name) was funny and friendly and awesome.

What a surprise and a treat!

Upgrade.  (During an off time.)

We had the "set meal" here (They are all prix fix menus) prepared by the AI students.  It was very nice.  I had a Kentucky Hot Brown - and I am a big fan of those when done well.  This one was.

It is a nice experience to eat in a culinary school where the students are being graded on their product.  You are ensured there will be no messing around.

I would recommend reading the menu on the website and if you happen to like what they are serving - then by all means GO!

We celebrated our 3rd wedding anniversary at JAI last night - and the weather and scenery were PERFECT.  We come back to the JAI (where we were married on 06/07/08) every year on our anniversary for dinner.  the past 2 years we brought our DD and both sets of parents.

This year it was just us and our DD who is now 6.
She had a delicious lobster mac 'n cheese with smoked Gouda.
She also ate one of my 4 lamb rib chops which were divine.
She also had 3 bites of my husbands salmon which was perfectly cooked.  (All that stuff was 5 star).

Here's the bad part - HIGH salt content for sides and sauces.  My sauteed mushrooms were so salty I had to say something and send them back.  Inedible.  They promptly cooked another (only slightly less salty) batch which I took home - and may toss.

DH's salmon was on a bed of soba noodles drowning in a sweet/salty sauce that, too, was over-salted.

What a shame.

Meanwhile the apps wre AWESOME - some of the best sweet potato fries we've ever tried (and we try them at lots of places) .  Served with a warm marshmallow "fluff-like" dip.  HEAVENLY.

The smoked duck tostada was great, too.  (If a bit on the smokey side.  Yes, it is very smokey indeed.)

Dessert coffees at $8.50 are a delcious indulgence - topped with a cloud of REAL whipped cream.  Chocolate covered strawberries (call ahead to speacil order these) are LARGE, plump, red, sweet and juicy coated in luscious chocolate.

We love it here - and got to watch the end of a Saturday wedding and the rehearsal for a Sunday wedding.  Lots of weddings, showers and events are held here - and we know why - it's a GREAT venue for events.  (And now they can accomodate a larger wedding in the expanded ballroom.)

We love ya, Tegue & Neil!  Best regards to Wendy, too.  See you in June 2012.

My 4 year old dd & I love to browse around the Shanghai Bazaar and gawk at all the kitch-y souvenirs, silk clothing, parasols and other China-town goodies.  She loves the red & gold chinese writing and the twinkly lights.

They also have a great book and musical instrument section on the 2nd floor.

A fun place to take your kids.

Came here in the dead of winter and tried the "Blueberry Pancakes" ice-cream (a special, seasonal offering).  very good - and they claim to make the ice cream onsite.

The decor is cute but very dusty - place could use a good cleaning - especially the display case in the front with the ice cream cakes.

Interesting nostalgia swag on the walls - but again - DUSTY.  Please clean!

I agree with Spa Girl.  WHile not a plus size woman - I do gfo to City Sports for sneakers and have found 2 great pairs over the past 3 years there.

Sales people were sooooo helpful and when they have a sale the prices are OK.  (Not cheap - but you get what you pay fir.)

I also like the Life is Good brand for Tees and tops.
I was also able to snag some comfy socks that "wick away moisture" for a reasonable price.

Yay City Sports.

Needed a low-beam headlamp for my car and had no problems this time.  Came in, asked the "parts" guy, got the bulb, paid.  Got 10% off with my PepBoys card, got out.

No issues.  Much better.

This is a review for the BBW in the shops at Liverty Place (1st Fl.).
The manager here is an older lady who has been here about 1.5 years and I love her!  So helpful and friendly.

I try to shop here often to keep up on what's new.  BBW has a 90% market saturation for women from 18-65 in the US - that means nearly EVRYONE has shopped at a BBW at some point.  The products are NOT top quality - but for the price they have some very good items.

I like to buy the anti-bacterial soaps here in bulk when they are on sale and I have a coupon.

Shop wisely and use coupons and sales together and you can score big at BBW.

Very fun for little kids especially.  My little one went here at age 3 and again at age 4 to try on fireman's gear and learn about the history of firefighting in the US and Philadelphia.

And it's free!

Just had a "Taste of Philly" catered lunch at our office - cheese steaks, chicken cheese steaks, caesar salad (with chicken breast chunks on the side to add in), fresh fruit platter, individually wrapped pretzels, TASTYCAKES and more.

Very well done - and a nice change from pizza, pizza,pizza.
That said - at an April 2012 lunch we had the tomato pie (square pie covered in chunky sauce with circles of fresh mozz.) - sooooo good!

Surprisingly OK.  Very nice front desk person (one guy - works=ed at least a double shift) and housekeepers.  Breakfast is included and is semi-decent including a 1 minute pancake (not waffle) machine.

Rooms are small but clean and comfortable. Strange lighting - bathroom area is super bright.
No complaints.

Yes, is may be a bit over-hyped and it is certainly pricey and pretentious - but you get what you pay for.  The fish is swimmingly fresh and the dishes are NOT traditional.  The sizzling bowls (one with Yellowtail another with Kobe Beef) and desserts are outstanding.  It budget and appetite permits, say "omikase" to the chef and you will be well taken care of.  This is a special occaision (or expense account) place.  FOr every day sushi eating, I go to Shiroi Hana.

Don't miss the succelent toro tartar.  What a treat!  The upstairs bar is a nice place for dessert and drinks afterward.
Avgolemono soup and dolmades for the win!  Can't wait to come back and have a REAL gyro - or even a shrimp gyro.  Fresh veggies.  SO happy to have found this place.

Ok - they re-did my car and it looks GREAT now.
I shall return.

Very, very good customer service.

Note - Credit Card tips are NO LONGER ACCEPTED so bring cash to tip your stylist, please!

Still a great salon and I still LOVE MElissa, Nicole, Aly and the gals!

The Charcoal Pit is a local landmark and institution.  A friend of mine worked here as a teenager serving up burgers and soft drinks. (Lots of shakes.)

It's fun for a family to come here, too.

Not healthy - but nostalgic and fun.

A great location for conferences and conventions.  It is CONNECTED to the Convention Center and right next to Reading Termincal Market.

Rooms and Restaurants are average Marriott Corporate fodder.

While my go-to is Victory cleaners in Aston (awesome!) I  have found Apex to be on my way some times and they are WAY better than the cleaners near the Elwyn Train station and also better than the one near the Giant in Aston, so these are my "second place" winners for Dry Cleaning in Media/Aston.

The lady (owner?) is friendly enough and has my clothes ready when I need them.

Wish they were open on Sundays.

An Italian Market staple - and a great resource - if pricey - to the city.
I also like Claudio's - just a block or 2 away - for Ricotta and fresh made mozzarella.

Dicbruno's has a great and vast selection of meats and cheese and they do catering, too.  Also a nice Olive bar (also try Talutto's Olive bar - smaller but nice and fresh.)

They get very crowded around the holidays and on weekends - so try to come on a random Tuesday to avaoid the crowds.

Whoa - expensivoso!  But very friendly nice Korean lady at the counter and GORGEOUS looking stock - a copious amount of produce and groceries stocked floor to ceiling.  Reminds me very much of some of the NYC mini-markets I used to frequent.

A nice addition to the nabe.

We got a nice container of chunked mango for $4.00 and they threw in a free banana.

Got 2 big hoagie trays (with numerous little bags of Herr's chips) hamt, turkey, roastbeef.
Very good - pickles and peppers on the side.

Delicious and budget conscious and a change from Pizza for a crowd.

A beautiful and renovated Wawa with gas, food and everything you might need.
Getting out of the parking lot during the morning rush hour is not easy so be careful and take your time.

Love me a Wawa iced coffee in summer.
My teen likes the new-ish "create your own" salad bowls.

Beats the heck ouuta Mazella's.

The HUGE portions of perfectly al dente pasta (try the pappardelle bolognese) and chicken parm run about $12 - $14 for lunch.  We took over half of it back to the office.

Delicious - and great service from Barbara the hostess.  She is a doll!

We'll be back for sure.

Good value - 2 kiddie cones (with sprinkles/jimmies) for about $6.00.

Black Cherry was excellent with big pieces of cherries in it.
Brownie Batter was dark, rich and super chocolaty.

Yum!

These are like little apartments with a small kitchen and bath.
Andrea at the front desk is terrific.
I would stay here again but would request an upper floor as everyone walking by could see inside the room, so I had to keep the shades drawn all the time.

During the summer there is an outdoor pool.

Breakfast (meh) is served daily and Monday - Wednesday they serve light supper/snack items.

5 stars for Melissa, 4 stars overall for Shear Bliss - Nicole, Margot (only in a few days per week), Ali and the gang are terrific.

I had a color, highlights and a cute cut from Melissa.

Don't be turned off by the strip-mall location - Melissa is well worth seeing.
And she is the only one who will cut my 9 year old's hair.

No issues with this Chipotle location near the Walmart and PetSmart in Springfield.
Parking lot on this side is fine - on the Walmart side it gets crazy.

Line moved quickly - but we came at an off hour (5 PM on a Sunday).

Standard Chipotle grub.
A more scenic and often quicker alternative to the hell of 76.

OMG - this place s great for $3.99 Bubble tea and a variety of espresso drinks (my latte was terrific).  NO DECAF available.  Cute theme with movies and TV shows.  Froyo, Korean-style shave ice, RAMEN (did not try) and Liquid Nitrogen ice cream.

The lady (and her artsy husband) who run this place are terrific.

Service can be a bit slow as every order is made by hand.
We loved it here.

Oh - and we bought 6 macaron to go.  FAB!

Chocolate peanut butter bar was great - a friends kid was selling Gertrude Hawk for a fundraiser (I did not know they did that?).
Sometimes stop into the Springfield Mall store for a treat for my own kid.

I am a big Fellini's fan - and have been to multiple locations (none of which are owned by the same people).  The Berwyn Fellini's can get very crowded, but luckily the night we went it wasn't.

My usual go-to is the Penne Sophia Loren (or the classic Linguine Scampi or Vongole) but on a sweltering August night, we opted to share the (enormous) Mediterranean salad.  A simple bed of crispy-fresh romaine topped with 4 shrimp, a big blob of lump crab meat (so good) and seared tuna slices, plus hunks of tomato and (we omitted) red onion.

The lemon vinaigrette served along side was delectable.

Service from Victoria (she is a hoot!) and 2 expediters was terrific as well.

WINNER!

We'll be back.

This is a hidden (head North up Broad) FREE treasure that all should know about.  It has weird Science stuff - some of it creepy (Things embalmed in jars) and much of it old and historic in nature.

The Wagner is just $20 a year to join (they are free - but the donation really helps them stay around.).  They educate TONS of school kids every year - many from bad nabes in N. Philly.

They also had my daughter's preschool class up for a feild trip and they loved it.

The PHS (Pennsylvania Horticulture Society - aka the folks who produce the Flower Show) also offers several EXCELLENT lectures in conjunction with the Wagner each year.  If you are a PHS member - the lectures are FREE.  (And awesome!)

Kailon catered a sushi bar fopr my husband's corporate party held at the DuPont country club.  He is such a great guy and makes terrific sushi including rainbow rolls, unagi maki, shrimp tempura & california rolls.  

Good party sushi - can't wait to dine in the restaurant and get some nigiri!

Thanks, Kailon - we love Okura!

Had fingerprints taken for a security clearance here (gateway Shopping Center Location) .
No issues.

I love Seasons 52.  Yes - they are a little pricey , but the food and ambiance are terriic.
Big comfy booths, a gorgeous bar area with orange and strawberry infused vodkas displayed in large glass urns.

Terrific iced tea and REAL lemonade.
Tast flatbreads, sandwiches (at lunch) and fish dishes.

Never disappointed here.
Great on a date or for lunch with the girls.

I am not a Fry-eater - but when my company so generously comissioned the Philly Fry Truck for a 2 hour corporate event - I could not resist - I asked for a 1/2 order and it was plenty.  We were given 2 choices (both with "regular" fries) - one was a "loaded" baked potato with cheese whiz sauce, sour cream, chives and bacon (or not - if you wish).

The other - which I tried was "Philly Steak" - with melted american (so good, so bad), steak meat and bacon.

Decadent.

So bad for you.
So tasty.

Perhaps my employer wants us all dead?  
Serve with a side of Lipitor.

We had an amazing meal and enjoyable evening at Teca along with stellar service from Jen and "Baba" the manager.

Initially we were told there would be a 20 minute wait for a table so we sidled up to the long bar and started to read the drink menu.  All of a sudden our table was ready!  (So great - because we were hungry by then - and the wait was only about 8 minutes!)  In future I would recommend reservations for Friday or Saturday nights here - the summer Gay Street scene is pretty hoppin'.

The tables are pretty close together (we sat outside on a lovely night) so we got to know a couple from Atlanta next to us.  Everything they ordered and everything we ordered looked amazing. We enjoyed our drinks - I had an $8 Kir Royale and DH had a Belgium Raspberry lambic that smelled and tasted so sweet and fruity (you better like fruit!) that even I could have easily drank it.

Our proscuitto and melon app - at $13 - was 5 star perfection.  The large ball of creamy fresh Mozzarella (di Buffala!!!) was divine.  It was served with 2 slices of panini-pressed bread that was good for dipping into the lemon-noted olive oil on the plate.

DH & I both ordered pasta as our main dish - mine was a special of pappardelle (house made - and a little on the thick side but perfectly cut and cooked to a toothsome al dente) with shrimp (5 medium sized ones) and lumps of crab meat (sweet, shell-less and delectable).  DH had the penne a la vodka and I did not taste it but it looked great, too.

We shared a delicious creme brulee (the top was stll warm from being blow-torched) for $8.

Cappuccino (at $5 - ouch!) was a let down.  Extremely bitter tasting and I fear the beans were burnt.  I could only drink a few 

They are sooooo close to 5 stars on food - but there are a few areas for improvement that are holding me out on the 5th star. (Fix your ladies room stall doors and the lights on the stars, please!)  Food snobs from NYC or Philly may shun the 'burbs - but Teca was a big winner for me last night.

We'll be back - hopefully soon - to see if they can keep it up.

Oh - and I wanna buy a bottle of that olive oil that is supposedly pressed at the owner's place in Italy. Good stuff!

This is the rating for the eye Doctors downstairs - not for the glasses/upstairs part of the store.  My 6 year old had a thorough exam with Kimberly Toscani and it went very smoothly.  No issues.

So far - no glasses are needed, but we'd certainly consider getting kids frames here - they are pretty reasonable, too.

My kid recently attended a classmates party here and it was run beautifully.  She enjoyed the ball pit, trampolines and especially the Zip Line.

The 2 hour party with about 20 5 & 6 year olds had 3 staffers running the show - and they ran it smoothly and well.

They also offer gymnastics classes and "drop-in" play sessions.

FUN!  (Similar to the Little Gym in Narberth - but not as nice decor.)

Sterling Leather (and now the other shops) has been around a loooooooong time.  A good friend of mine used to work there as a summer job in the late '80's.  Sterling offers mid to high end leather clothing and goods.  Lots of gift-y ideas too - and now they have more than one shop.  (They really have expanded.)

Surprisingly excellent non-pizza items.  I had an extremely fresh garden salad - chock full of tomatoes and cucumbers, served with balsamic vinaigrette.  DD enjoyed 3 garlic knots (lighter and "fluffier" than what we are used to) - so fresh and yummy and a small plate of ziti.

Friendly service from "the guys" at the counter.
Reminded us of our favorite spots back in Brooklyn - but Bravo's is much larger and cleaner.

We'll be back!

Fabulous service by Mylissa for our impromptu party of 18 on a sunny Friday Lunch.
We ate outdoors and enjoyed a mountain of wings (with various sauces - try the Kickin' Korean, Mexican Garlic or BBQ), excellent cheese steak nachos (so bad for you, but tasty stuff), burgers and salads.

My $12.99 "special" salad with 7 tiny shrimp was just OK, but the $5 Strawberry Mojito made up for it.

It's really 3 star food but we had such a good experience I am giving 4 stars.

Del Val has nearly always had a farmstand - but when they tore down the old one on Rt. 202 years back, they built a MAMMOTH Market.  It was pricey and closed.

Well, it re-opened and I gotta say it's better than ever.
We took our little one to the October Fun Weekend (Weekends in the fall from late September thru Halloween you can go on weekends from 11 AM - 4 PM).

It was a glorious 90 minute afternoon filed with organic produce, pony rides ($4 a pop) a corn maze, a FREE rope maze for little kids, Bouncy Castles ($2.00 a go) and free pumpkin painting (but you gotta buy the pumpkins - $.79 per lb.

Lots of mums, gourds and of course, Creamery Ice Cream

What a great place.

I hope they make it this time.

I love TD Bank - and go to this one primarily to use one of the 2 ATMs.

One big complaint though - when the changed their ATMs so that only a few are "full service" (Only a few ATMs take deposits, sell stamps, etc. - the rest only dispense cash)

I feel that all the machines should take deposits.
My 8 year old loves getting her picture taken here and has done since she was about 4.  And she's never seen any of the Rocky Movies (to my knowledge).  It's fun to watch her pose like Rocky.

I am updating my review - we just got take out from Jack's tonite and it was really great (can't give that 5th star though as the decor is in SERIOUS need of rehab and take out is better than eating in because of this.)

Our meal consisted of very good (mild - if you want it hotter ask) hot and sour soup, non-greasy spare ribs that were moist & meatty, delicious 10 ingredient rice rice. Shrimp & Lobster sauce (normally a dish I loathe!) was full of big, perfectly cooked shrimp.

Not so good?  Beef lo main was too oily.  Steamed Pork Dumplings while tasty had a heavy dough.  Good but not great.  

Jack himself was there when we picked up our order, and his manager gave my 5 year old a lollipop - which made a big impression.

This is pretty much the best & one of the only Chinese take out joints left in D-town.

I have been coming to Grandpa Hicks since the late '80's when i worked at Accents & Images (before the expansion) across the road.  The lady who owns it is so nice and they have a great selection of cheese, coffees and CHAMPAGNE mustard - which is just the best.  In days gone by you could get old fashioned lemonade (in the summer only) served with a lemon stick (a candy stick) that you would use as a straw.

They cater, too - and make lovely gift and holiday baskets of goodies.

Gotta love Grandpa Hicks.

I am giving 4 stars because of the great, great special treatment we got... because...

Believe it or not -we had our wedding rehearsal dinner here.
Yes, really.

It was either that or the Olive Garden (Don't ask - but my future and now current father in law had 2 out of 3 of his son's rehearsal dinners at Olive Garden - and wanted ours there too.)

There was no FREAKIN' way I was gonna have my rehearsal dinner at an Olive Garden.

Bensi's is about 1-2 steps above an Olive Garden.

It is a Jersey-based chainette with Red-Sauce favorites.
The General Manager, Joe and his staff did a SUPERB JOB with our crowd of 18.  We got the whole back room to ourselves.

We designed a custom menu with 4 entree choices (plated) and family-style salads and apps.  The Bensi Salad (we substitued fresh tomatoes for sun-dried) was GREAT.  The bruchetts - less so.  The mozzarella sticks (and I don't usually indulge in fried foods) were surprisingly tasty.  The Tilapia Francese (special ordered) and Chicken Marsala were very nice, too.
