Dad enjoyed his sausage and peppers - but was not floored by it.

I had a dessert brought in specially - and it was very nice that they let us do that.  (Incidentally - Fruit Flowers/Incredily Edible Delights makes for in impressive dessert option)

The bill for all of us was very, very resonable (which made my father inlaw happy).

Incidentally, our neighbors had a party catered from Bensis - Chicken Marsala & Penne Pomodoro - and it was very good.  They also catered my "surprise" bridal shower.

In real life - this is a 2-3 star place - but for what they did for us - 4 stars!!!!

Probably one of the most happenin' places at the slowly dying Plymouth Meeting Mall - especially weekdays for lunch.  Try to come before 11:50 AM when the line forms out the door and down the hallway.

Standard Chick-Fil-A fare which my 12 year old loves.  Chicken Strips (or nuggets) a decent side salad (if you can wait 5 minutes they'll make you one without cheese.)

Wish they'd bring back the long discontinued Cheesecake - my kids loved it.  The "Ice Dream" will have to do.

Well I have been to BOTH Vietnam and Vietnam Palace and the srvice and decor at Vietnam PALACE were better than that "place across the street".  Food at both is excellent and comparable in price.

I really enjoyed the Tofu Spring rolls (under vegetarian selections - last page of the HUGE menu) and at $4.50 an order - they were a good value, too.

My BIG bowl of Banh with grilled shrimp was excellent - and for $1.00 extra he added 2 beef-stuffed grapeleaves - which I really wanted to try and never had.  Glad I did!

Good stuff all around anf the have a HUGE private room upstairs for banquets - even a wedding.
I am seriously considering have a private event here.
Thanks to Victor and my lovely (male) server - don;t know his name.

Oh - and they have a full bar.

Took my 6 year old to VP for the first time and we were lucky enough to meet Tracy - who is coordinating a large party we plan to have here in April.  The party room upstairs can seat 90 and is roomy and lovely.  You could easily have a baby shower, brunch, dinner or even a small wedding here. Our group will probably only be about 25 - but still - can't wait to have it!

My little one ordered Tamarind Shrimp Skewers which she loved and Shrimp Bun - so we had a shrimp fest.  It was delicious.

The Vietnamese iced coffee was sweet and a jolt of much-needed caffeine.  (We had just come from the flower show so we were TIRED.)

This is a great place with reasonbly priced, tasty food.

We can't wait to see how our party goes in April.

Dr. Carla Patton and Madeline Brown are both bright, articulate, caring and compassionate doctors.  I had been seeing Dr. Patton in my late teens/early 20's until I moved away from Doylestown.  When I returned I desparately needed care, and then met Dr. Brown who has been a true life-saver.

The office can be crowded and there is often a wait time, but they do their best.  Call ahead as soon as you know you'll need an appointment.  They are worth seeing - and a great practice for women.

JC Penny is trying hard to resurrect its failing business.
Prices are, indeed, somewhat lowernow - no coupons or a sale every other week.

Decent variety of ladies and kids clothes.

We are thrilled and delighted to have a greek place in Media.
The chicken souvlaki is thigh meat (delicious - and I prefer dark - but keep that in mind if you only eat white meat chicken).  My 12-year-old scarfed down a traditional lamb/beef gyro, and I had the pork souvlaki (tender and juicy - so good.)

Avgolemono soup is one of my favorites ($4.95 for a nice large bowl of it) but this one was only fair.

Everything comes with fries - costs more to have a greek salad instead.  (The salad is on romaine and is very fresh and tasty.

Decor is brand-spankin' new and clean looking.
They really gutted this place and it shows.  WELL DONE.

We wish you the very best - and I will be headed back in soon for some Dolmades and Baklava (have not tried them yet.).
I agree with Valerie S.  I frequent this Wawa when i need gas on my way back from Brinton Lake or other shopping spots.  Never a problem - get in, get gas, get out.

Makes me happy, happy!  I will edit my review once I try the meat ravioli I just bought over the weekend.  I am so anxious to try it and to find a great new source for pasta and ravioli and sauces in the Italian Market area.

Once I taste them I am hoping to make this review a 5 star!

5 stars for our actual balloon ride - safe procedures, take off and landing by Barry who is clearly a pro with over 23 years of experience as a pilot.

The 1 star off is for customer service - I was proactive and called alot but they are slow to return calls and use texts (one of which I never got).  Once I clarified that I need to be CALLED not texted they complied.

Our flight was rescheduled twice due to weather- but the 3rd time was truly the charm.
Much fun!

Perfect Flight.
Better (selection-wise) than Spice Corner in the Italian Market but still not as good as Penzey's.  The prices are not that great - but they do have a good selection.

I had a gift certificate for a Wash, Cut & Blowdry with Toni and she is a terrific lady.  The salon itself is not fancy - and they don't push you to purchase products - in fact I was not asked anything about product at all which was kinda refreshing.

A great blowout.  And a cut is just $17 ($25 with the blowout.)
Single process color is $55 (with or without a cut).

Kids cuts are $12 (under 10 years old).

I'll be back to see Toni again for sure!

Update - 2017:  Toni is gone - but Renee is there now.

A little better post-rennovation (2015), bathrooms are still marginal at best.  ONE cashier at the Amtrak ticket counter.  ONE.  They need 2 for sure.

Few amenities - but thank goodness the a/c was working on that hot July afternoon I traveled from Wilmington to NYC.  Trains were packed and oversold.

I had dinner here at about 7:30 PM on a Friday night and the place was DEAD empty - I was the only person there.  The 2 people working (Owner's Mom who does alot of the cooking) and man at the sushi bar, speak NO english.   Very, very nice people and I want them to succeed but they can barely communicate.

Aside from that, the place is new and clean and the fish was fresh.
I had the Tuna Tartar ($12) app and the Sashimi app ($12).  Fresh miso soup with LARGE chunks of tofu was great (complimentary?) and a small iceberg salad was fresh with what appeared to be ranch dressing?  (a creamy white dressing, not the typical orange colored ginger dressing).

They offer Sushi - as you'd expect but next time I will try the Chinese food menu as the owners are CHINESE!  Porkchop and Chicken Legs over rice looked great.  And home-made shrimp wonton soup.

I will be back.

Local dance school used Gertrude Hawk as a fundraiser around Easter time and the Chocolate bunnies (Big - but hollow) are delicious and worth the extra money.  The chocolate covered pretzels - packages in an elegant gift tin are terrific too.  Pricey - but that extra cash goes to the fundraising organization.

Pretty good, I say!

A little pricey - if it was $25 I would come every week - but for $35 ($42 with tip) it's better for important things.

I had a nice blow-out with Hope but I did not like it at first - not straight enough and it was a humid day - so I asked her to use the flat iron, which she did an then I loved it.

My hair is fine and slippery so the style only held for about 7 hours - but that was good enough.

Cute salon - like sitting inside a pink cupcake with sprinkles.
Fun.

I will be back and I enjoyed Hope's witty banter.

One note:  Receptionist has a "cold" vibe - but it was 47:45 Am so maybe she hadn't had coffee yet?

Also - I LOVE that you are open at 7 AM so I can get a 'do for a business meeting.
AWESOME!!!

3 Cheers and 4 stars to Fran (our fabulous server) and the Silver Diner.

Yes, it's faux.  Yes it's a bit kitschy - but when we went (for a lovely lunch on a weekday at 2 PM) it was clean, nearly empty (great service) and the food was GREAT.

My dining companion had a decadent platter of 4 Challah-French toast slices drizzled in (not too much - just right) caramel sauce.  Served with 2 eggs and CRISPY long bacon strips.  It was the picture of perfection and - according to my friend - tasted great as well.

My unique dish was the crab-cakes benedict.  (luckily I asked for the sauce on the side - as I did not need the extra glop/calories).

The 2 crab cakes (one atop each english muffin half) were VERY good.  Lots of crab and not too much filler.  I was even able to get broccoli in lieu of home fries.

We each ordered soft drinks which were served in large "vats" (free refills) and Fran got us to-go cups, which was a nice extra touch.

We'll return for sure!  A great alternative to the mall restaurants.

really good, solid, pies - delivered fresh and hot - and ACCURATELY (Whoo-hoo).  Decent chicken-cheese steaks too.

Reasonably priced, ample dining space (albeit not glamorous - and packed at peak lunch hours).

Note:  If you work for a big firm - like we do - they wil do BREAKFAST pizzas 0 wth bacon and eggs and ham on them - they are slammin' good - but by special order only.  (Normally there's nobody there during the breakfast hours.)

Get here early or you may be disappointed.
We arrived at 6:45 pm on a busy Saturday and they were sold out of burnt ends, chicken and ribs. Luckily we enjoyed pulled pork, chopped brisket and wings.

Sides of cucumber salad, Mac 'n cheese and garlic mashed potatoes were satisfying.

Reasonably priced and super casual.

Cute, needed and pricey coffee spot on Bridge Street in "downtown" Lambertville.

Bought 2 brownies ($2.75 each - YOWZA) and they really weren't that great.

Nice counter staff, though and the place was hoppin' on a Sunday afternoon.

Great and conveniently located kitchenware shop.  They have cook and bakeware, bar ware and even coffee beans they grind (or not) to order.  A vast selection of peppermills.  GREAT for the novice or pro-Am cook.

Helpful staff and "decent" (not cheap but not overpriced) prices.  Many of the items here are high end and thus are pricey by nature.

While I am not a 5 guys fan, I gotta give props to the attentive and friendly staff at this relatively new Media outpost.  I ordered a burger - which is 2 patties in a lettuce wrap.  $2.09 for a Dasani (shudder).

If your kid has a peanut allergy don;t go here - they serve peanuts-in-the-shell while you wait.

Typical 5 guys - not healthy, limited menu, but what they do, they do well.

And wow that cashier was great.  (Anitra??)  Big shout out to her.

Kudos to Justin and the team for a lovely lunch of Bun with Sugarcane Shrimp and a Spring roll.  A $4 Hot Espresso with Condensed milk served both as a beverage and a dessert!

I love Vietnamese food and Pho Street is a good place that is sorely needed in the 'burbs.  Prices are moderate and service today was wonderful.

Can't wait to come back!

Ate lunch here again and this time had the Pho and it was very good.  Even better? The summer roll appetizer with peanut sauce.  Sooo good.

Can't wait to come again.
Great for a winter warm-up.

No issues with this location of Giant - and fortunately I shopped at a non-peak time - a weekday at 5 PM.  Place was dead empty - just the way I like it.

Prices match my go-to Aston Giant location and selection here is a tad more limited and also a few more ethnic (Hispanic and Asian) and high-end items.  (Welcome to Newtown $quare).

Ah, Giant.  You put Acme to shame!

Met a fellow yelper here for dinner and we both sprang for the $26 lobster rolls.  Big, meaty and the real deal!  Excellent - and the toasted, buttered top-split NE-Style bun was just right.

I subbed tender green beans ($2 up-charge, dang it!) for the fries.

My Arnold Palmer was quite tasty, too, with 1/2 iced tea and 1/2 "rosemary" lemonade.  Herbaceous yet refreshing.

I would come back - but for the price (a bit too high) I won't be running back.

Happy hour is what you want here, not dinner. Service by Vinnie at the (crowded) bar and $1 buck a shuck oysters and shrimp on Wednesday nights are a good deal. And half of Philly was there to take part.

The $7 lemon drop martinis are well made, easy to drink and also a good bang for the buck. 

One of the best happy hours in Center City. 

Skip the dining room, hang by the bar!

After YEARS of walking by and not stopping in (even after reading great - and not so great reviews on yel) I popped in for a quick take out Iced Ethiopian Yrgecheffe coffee.

Soooooo delicious and a roasty-toasty (but not burnt tasting) flavor.

Friends truly don;t let friends drink Charbucks.

Well worth the $2.40 including tax.

Can't wait to come back for a proper Ethiopian meal.

Wow!  We got a Wegman's - right on my way to Whole Paycheck and just past the Fresh Market.

Love Weggie's - but very crowded and you can easily over buy/over spend here.  Don't shop hungry!.  The cheese department is terrific.  Also a "Pub" and dine-in prepared foods (and mediocre sushi).

Cute little coffee bar in the front of the store, too.

This is our go-to spot for take out Chinese in Doylestown (and seeing that I worked at the now de-funct Chong's Garden for 5 years - I know what I'm talking about.).  Jack is a great guy - he used to have a place in New Hope, too - but now it's only D-town.

The steamed dumplings are a little doughy - but my 4 year old loves them.  The 10 ingredient fried rice is cooked to order and is DELICIOUS every time.  Full of chicken, shrimp, scrambled egg, peas and other goodies.

We also enjoy Chicken & snow peas and peppersteak.  The peppersteak is loaded with onions - so know this - you can ask for it without or with less onion.  The chicken is all white meat and delicious.

They will make you just about any and every old school Cantonese or Mandarin sih you could want.

Oh - and get it for take out - the dining room needs a re-hab.

This place is kind-of a tourist trap and part business-yuppie lunch spot.
They do have decent food, cutesy decor (with swinging chairs at some tables) and over-priced cutesy-named drinks.

They also recently starting hawking 2-bite teeny-weeny desserts served tapas-style.

Whatever.

The "Green Submarine" is a veggie sandwich that I'll get in a pinch at lunch time when I am forced to eat here by co-workers who have no originiality and are too scared to try Matyson.
This was sorely needed and now, thankfully, is well used and seems to be well maintained.  Lovely.

I had wanted to try Fat Salmon for quite some time and yesterday I got a chance to have lunch there.  For $13.50 they were offering a special holiday lunch.  You got a choice of soup or salad (I had the iceberg salad with tasty ginger dressing), and either 2 maki, 1 maki and 1 cooked item or 2 cooked items.

I chose 2 of the specialty maki which normally are $7.50 - 9.50 on their own - so this lunch was a good value.  Ask for sauces on the side - alot of the special rolls are loaded up with semi-spicy mayo and tempura crunch.

The regular lunch menu is also a great price point. Dinner prices are a little high but not crazy.

Cool, icy-blue decor made it feel like Christmas.

Service was quick and efficient.

I can't wait to go back. I will try the sashimi and then render a TRUE verdict.
For now though, I still stand that DOMA is the best sushi spot goin' in Philly these days.  (Save for Morimoto which is cost prohibitive.)

The people who work here are so kind and the food is very good - the shrimp salad now has larger shrimp (YAY) but the lamb chops were over cooked.  (Mine at home are better).

Spanakopita is always a great choice.
They even gave us free rice pudding for dessert.

Salads are super fresh and tasty.
I am sticking with salads from now on.

They have a gorgeous Olive Bar and delicious fresh-made ravioli.  I need to compare yet to see if they are beter, worse or on par with Superior.  Service was attentive and pleassant.

Veal ravioli were 7.79 per pound.

OK, Ok!  I have been won over by LOMA - the barristas, the terrific lattes (I dream about the next one I can get - and for $3.60 I can get a medium) and now that I tried a (pricey but egg-cellent) breakfast sandwich - I am hooked.

Just about a 5 star place - but prices for food are, indeed, high.

This is the Wawa in Ambler.  I stop here for gas and often coffee or other beverages as it is on my route that I drive (over an hour) regularly.  Friendly Staff (even during COVID19 era) and great coffee.

I agree with Gourmet G.  The building is an historic place - and while the quality of the productions can vary greatly from "What was THAT?" to "Broadway Quality", I have seen many a show here under many incarnations of this great play house.

I am so pleased at how GOOD Diane's Deli really is.
Classic sandwiches - breakfast and lunch items.  Huge deli-style sandwiches, chicken and tuna melts.

The decor is dated - but comfortable and clean - and the service is great.  

We love it here for office-related lunches.
The closest thing to a REAL deli you will find near here - and the sign simply says "DELI".

Great for pedestrians - not so great for traffic flow and parked cars blocking Mount Alverno Road.  We needed this trail so I can't complain too much - but the parked cars along the road were not anticipated.

Meanwhile, on a nice sunny day - this is a great place to walk, jog, run, bike or walk your dog (Please keep your pooch leashed and pick up after them!).

Our company catered a "social" reception complete with a beer/wine (iced tea and lemonade) bar with an excellent and attentive server.  She was just great.

Out crowd of 50-60 people devoured the delectable cold sandwiches and salmon mousse and LAYERED CRAB DIP - man that crab dip was tasty stuff!

I highly recommend le Petit Chef if you need a catered event in the Radnor/Wayne/King of Prussia area.

This is the Panera closest to my work (at the moment - LOL) and as long as you go before 12 noon (like 11:50 or so) or after 1:15 PM, you're fine.

Otherwise there is a line and it's hard to find dine-in seating.
Salads are good here - I especially like the "seasonal" Cobb Salad with chicken and the bistro onion soup. (I get it without croutons to save a few carbs.)

They are somewhat famous for the pick 2 combination - soup or 1/2 sandwich or smaller salad.

It's fast food - but way better for you than Burger King or McDonald's.

There is also a honeygrow (better tasting but more money) and a Qdoba in this same strip mall/shopping area.

Took DD & DH to Pho Street in Springfield. She had a Summer Roll (Shrimp) and Shrimp Tempura (NOT anything like the Japanese one) and a Mamoth Mango Smoothie (drank about 1/3 of it).

 I had luscious Iced Vietnamese Espresso with Condensed Milk and Bun. I loves me some Bun. Just like Mama made (not!). 

So glad to see el kiddo enjoying foods from around the globe. DH had Broken Rice with Lemongrass Beef.  Fabulous food & service.

This place is so cutesy - and faux-euro-feeling.
I popped in for a quick take-out salade nicoise ($11) and will stop in for coffee one day soon.

I had good service - there was no line at the café at 1 PM on a Thursday.  The seating areas, however were full of people camped out there all day or for hours at a clip, so I could not have sat down even if I wanted to.

Very urban-chic bookstore.
Love the book machine.

3.5 really - our kid did not like her chicken salad sandwich on croissant nor the Boylan's Diet Soda (She wanted a true Diet Coke) but we (6 adults) all enjoyed our food very much.

Outstanding French Onion Soup and lovely salads and entrees.
Crabcake (either on a "snowflake" roll or addedto a salad) isvery good.
BlackPepper linguine is drowning in a too-rich sauce with 3 shrimp (small poriton).
Clams in Lemongrass broth were good but broth way very salty.

Too full for dessert - but we'll be back!

Brand-new Petco in the "Promenade at Granite Run".
Very clean (new) and stocked well.

No issues.

Prices on Eukenuba are a tad higher - so I will stick with my seed-feed store.  Comparable to PetSmart but cleaner and seems better run - we'll check again in 6 months.

Keep it groomed, people!

Stick to the Chinese/Cooked dishes and you will have a better experience (in my opinion).  Mandy, the server, is just lovely and treats my elderly parents - who are dine-in regulars - like royalty.  She even knows what they usually order.  (Creatures of habit).

The "special" house wonton soup is truly delicious and the meaty spare-ribs are so much better than "that other place" in Doylestown.

I like to get the Chicken with string beans, light on the sauce (to cut the grease factor). My parents love (but I am not a big fan) the Honey Walnut shrimp. It is fried so too rich for me.  If you like fried shrimp and sweet sauces you might like this.

The dining room at lunch on weekends is always nearly empty.
Take-out does a decent business.

Give Jade Island a try - it's really quite good.
For Chinese.

5 stars for food but 3 for the overworked bartender - DeeAnne - who tried her best.  There were 2 huge parties on a busy Saturday lunch so we sat in a booth in the bar area instead of the sunny garden room (perfect for parties).

My dad's ribs and my pork schnitzel were just terrific.

DeeAnne is a lovely lady, too but she had to make drink orders, tend bar AND serve about 5 tables.  Just too much.

Meanwhile, if you come during a quieter time, the Plumsteadville inn is just so nice.  We love it here.  Don't miss the crab cakes.  Out of this world!

We visit the Doylestown Saladworks about every 2-3 months when my DD wants "her usual" (She's 6) - a salade nicoise with shrimp instead of tuna, extra pasta, russian dressing mixed-in.

This may not be the healthiest choice - but if i can get my kid to eat vegetables, I'll take it.

This Saladworks is nice and clean and the lettuce and veggies are MUCH fresher than the scary saladworks in Phila.

We like it here.

Yum Yum is a real donut shop.  Good coffee, cheap prices, greasy fresh donuts.  Been there for YEARS.

Love it!

The Plumsteadville Inn is open and even has rooms available once again.
A good choice for lunch or dinner - with good salads (Caesar topped with steak i

I am gonna be generous and give them 4 stars as they cater 9and in a timely manner, I might add) many of our office functions.  The pizza is 3 star but the salads are chock full of goodies (eggs, olives, tomatoes, cucumbers, etc.)

They also served a unique hot sandwich platter at one of our meetings.

Very nice change from pizza.

As salad works go (they are a local chain of custom-tossed salad and panini shops) this Doylestown location of Saladworks (near the K-Mart) really isn't bad.  My little one & I order the same salad every time - and she loves it.   It's about $9.00 after tax but is way big enough for an adult anbd a child to share.

As with all the saladworks, they also have sandwiches (panini) but I don't care for them.  At least at the D-town store the lettuce is usually fresh and crisp (and NOT brown) and the ingredients are in good, cold, condition.  The high school gals (and a few guys) who work here are well mannered and friendly.

NOT like the crappy ones in Center City.

I am happy that Saladworks exist as I do not eat traditional fast food like burgers or subs.  Home of the $8.00 salad (or $9.00 for the one we get).  Do you want white or wheat (roll) with that?

This is the Dry Cleaners in the gateway Shopping Center (on the far end - around the corner from Staples).  I needed 2 items cleaned and they were done well before i needed them.  Prices are exactly the same as 2 or 3 other cleaners in the area.

Cheerful service.

No issues.

Will use the again when I need to.

This is our go-to Saladworks - and is far better (fresher veggies and lettuce, cleaner dining and restrooms than Philly locations or mall locations.

The staff is friendly and the prices ar $7.99 - $8.49 for salads (plus more if you add extras.)

My 7 year old loves saladworks - and if it gets her to eat more veggies - I am all for it.  (granted she loves her salad to have pasta in it - but she does eat veggies, also.)

Fantastic food and good service from Kate I the Chandelier room on a busy Saturday lunch.  Our party of 3 feasted on decadent chicken pot pie, fall-off-the-bone BBQ ribs and a classic Wedge salad. Best of all? Added a crabcake to the Wedge salad and it, quite honestly, was one of the best all-crab, no-filler crab cakes that I have ever eaten. Seriously.  That good.   I can't wait to have another! $9 a pop but so worth it. My dad pronounced it the "best crabcake outside of Maryland".

Lovely food. Such a treat.

This is a brand-new Royal Farms right on 452 in Aston (South Aston?).
My kid loves the fried chicken - though we are both not keen on their fries - which are BIG slabs of skin-on spuds.  Just not our thing.

But for gas, Chicken and Krispy Kreme? (Must get them in the AM or they get stale super fast.)
Here's your spot.

Back again for a wonderful $11.50 Honey Fried Chicken Tossed Salad lunch with that exquisite buttermilk dressing.  LOVE it!

Service is always great - and the Fish of the Day was Trout served with a delicious roasted asparagus and quinoa salad.

Kudos to Wendy, Jackie and the wonderful team at Day by Day.
We love it!
Nice green space - a welcome respite within the City of Brotherly Love.  Especially nice during the late spring.

The male manager who has been there for the past 2 years or so is very helpful.
I recently tried and love the smooth infusion conditioner.  I also (still) am hooked on the Green Science skin care line - even though it is IMO obscenely expensive.

Decent products - some are great others suck - be choosy and you just might find a few keepers at Aveda.

No issues here - except the restroom which was in need of service.
Theatre itself was clean and comfortable and no lines.

The one in Glen Mills is still nicer but this beats the crappy AMC Granite Run.  (But that one is soooo cheap with $3.99 matinees.)

AMC has taken over the county.

Food is was over priced and sucky.  We skip it.

As many in the yelp community know, I am not a big fan of Charbucks (aka fourbucks) BUT- and this location deserved the big but... considering that this shopping area (near the Target on City Ave.) is the only walkable place near my new office, I come here for an occaisional Ice Green Tea Lemonade.

This Starbucks is clean and (aside from morning rush) not crowded.

A pleasant surprise.  My goodness - I may start (gasp) liking Starbucks again.

With all the great international cuisine in Philly, I almost never consider Chinese (my first love from Childhood) anymore, but when I am sick I NEED soup.  Wonton, Subgum Wponton or Hot & Sour.

Well, Square on Square came through for us last night.  Delivery took about 40 minutes on a BUSY, Rainy Friday night - which isn't horrible considering those conditions.

My husband enjoyed his sweet-yet-spicy General Tso's (The call it something else) Chicken.  I ordered a Quart of THE BEST HOT 'n SOUR (For real.  I love their version.  Chicken and tofu and just enough black pepper, red pepper and vinegar).  I also got a quart of the "special" wonton soup which had a tasty broth and was loaded with chicken, pork, bok coy and mushrooms.  My only complaint?  Only 4 of the DELICIOUS, petit wontons in one quart.  Next time I'll ask for extra wontons - and gladly pay for them, too.  

I ate a small bit of each soup and had plenty left for the next day.

You saved me, Square on Square.  Those soups are the BEST.

My father in law pretty much LIVES at grocery stores.  He's use $1.50 worth of gas to go to a store to save 50 cents on a dozen eggs.  You get the idea...

But we all can agree on Wegman's.  It is a pleasure to shop here and the selection is great.  If you are a comparisson shopper (and in our family - you are!), you can also nab some good bargains here.

We got some terrific imported cheeses and yummy prepared foods here and made a gourmet picnic for a fraction of the cost of having it catered.

Wegman's also does a fairly good job of appetizing/catering of their own - but we prefer to just buy the componenets and assemble them ourselves on trays.

Wegman's is great.  Wish there was one in Center City Philly!

I respectfully disagree with Ellen R.  Penzey's herbs are fresher and in many cases more reasonable than the Spice terminal at Reading Terminal Market - and both have a loved place in my heart.

As a dedicated Penzey's catalog shopper - I have to say that I just LOVE Penzey's.  With the exception of the California Basil and crystallized ginger - that I can find better elsewhere.

The BEST Chinese around - and its not even in Chinatown.
We got delivery today - a day-after-the-snowstorm order takeout kinda day.

A QUART of the fabulous hot & sour soup always cures what ails me.
Delicious chicken & snow peas.
Pan fried dumplings are average - not mind blowing.

Service was friendly on the phone and lightening fast (They showed up in 17 minutes!)

Yes, it is pricey here - as in $13 - $15 for tricked-out burgers and sandwiches.
The best deal going - if you happen to like the day's picks - are the pick 3 which is a boring salad, a soup and a 1/2 a sandwich or wrap.

Today's picks happened to be great - a turkey club wrap with Turkey bacon and the soups (both sounded awesome) were tomato veggie or butternut squash.

I had the butternut squash soup and the salad and took the wrap HOME.
Two lunches in one for $12!  Plenty!

Good service and we sat outside as the weather was just perfect.
Got here at 11:50 AM just before the rush. Do not come here at 12:10 or 12:15 PM.  Come early or late for better service.

While I agree this is THE practice to take your kids (what choices do we have) our doctor, Cynthia Hill, has always been wonderful - once we actually get to see her.

The office is not well run.  Lots of waiting - not only for appointments, but also to get paperwork (forms cost $10 ) filled out and also waiting to PAY your copay.

Meanwhile, our 4 year old has gotten excellent care and I have received good ad vice from Dr. Hill and Advocare/Society Hill Pediatrics.

I had passed by La Pina (on Route 202 - on a divided part of the highway where the Firebird's is) but never got a chance to try it (It opened in February 2018) until today with a group of 5 ladies (all from work).

Our server Luckee was accommodating and wonderful.  She split our check and even split the cost of the $11 table-side guac - which Luckee herself whipped up for us in a huge stone molcajete.

I was overall very impressed with the menu, decor and service.  The tuna ceviche was excellent and the house salad (I know, what could possibly be so great?) was Amazing - with jicama, heirloom tomatoes and avocado.  A small sprinkle of cotija cheese, too.

Very, very fresh tasting food.

Can't wait to return for the $5 Happy Hour (Monday - Friday 5 - 7 PM.)

Our company ordered bulk take out for about a dozen people and everything was accurate and fairly good food.  About $15 per person.  The caprese salad was just fair as the (Roma) tomatoes were squishy. The fresh Mozzarella really was fresh and delicious as were the added (4.99) grilled shrimp.  Greens were gritty.  Not fun.  Wings here are surprisingly wonderful. 

Can't wait to try dine-in.  I shall return. 

Thank you for providing my company with a good alternative for lunch.  If I eat one more Panera-catered lunch... blah!

We had a great experience here - so much so that I made my 9 year old a VIP (unlimited session fees for $50 for a year).

No, it's not cheap, but you can easily spend 90 - 120 minutes at a clip here and it's a great rainy-day activity for artistically inclined kids.

Might even be fun for a Girls Night Out party with the grown folks!

We even came back the next day (Sunday - when one adult pays the $10 session fee - up to 2 kids under 12 pain free!).

We're in!

One night a week they serve - of all things - tacos - and they are pretty darned good.  I had shrimp tacos and gelato for dessert.

This is still not my favorite place - I want to love it but I just don't.

The guitarist in the background (again only on Mondays or Tuesdays - I forget which night) is terrific.  talented guy!

Great service, nice decor - but the food is just OK. If you plan ahead you can also have a larger party here - maybe 15 - 20 tops.  Above that and they really can't accommodate you.
Try to go for tacos - not Italian (how weird!!!!).

Very good sushi (better than Temaki in my opinion) and decent chinese (kinda pricey for what it is.).  I actually liked the Granite Run Mall location better for chinese (did not have sushi there.).

Specialty Rolls are expensive - $16 for the Eagle Roll - topped with chunky lobster salad.  Rainbow Roll ($12) was good, but stuffed with fake kani stick.

Good deal for lunch - higher for dinner.
Full bar.

Nice!  Will be back soon.

Fantastic decor and attentive device from Chris made up for a few minor problems with the food. 

Pizza are fresh tasting and there are so many varieties. The 7 inch mini is quite small, so get a salad to go with it.

Seafood salad was very good, however the beef on the land 'n sea salad was way too over cooked.

Pricey, but you are paying the rent on the swanky digs.

I enjoyed it here but next time I will modify my order.

I don't even like hoagies and I so love Primo.
We stopped by the "quant" Claymont location today for lunch where my co-worker frequents and is known by name.

The 2 ladies who man the counter at lunchtime are very nice and funny.

I got a (basic) Turkey wrap and he got a Sharp Italian wrap.
I love that they offer wraps now, because the bread is very heavy and chewy - yummy - but filling.

Also - if they happent o be hot and fresh (which they were today) grab a cookie - I got white chocolate macadamia - and oh, wow!

This is a cute little comedy club and they get some funny, funny people in here to perform.  The 2 drink minimum (you can get food in lieu of drinks) kinda sucks as it forces you to spend MORE money - but hey, that's kinda how it is.

Nicely run - we had fun and will return.

It's great to laugh!

We are giving Bertucci's a strong 4 star review after last nights early dinner (We arrived at 4:50 PM and by 6:30 when we left the place it was mobbed with a long line of hungry families and a brisk take-out biz.

DD who is now 6, loved her penne & cheese off the kids menu.
I enjoyed the chicken marsala.

The meal was very nice (especially for a chain) and the brought out a slice of tiramisu with a candle in it for FIL's birthday.

Jonas, our server, was effifient and pleasant.

DD spent a LONG time watching the pizza guys (and gals) roll out the dough.  She loves it here - which is mostly why we come here.

VERY family friendly.

Yes - they really do deserve 4 stars.  Great catering - fresh salad, good pizza (and stellar tomato pie) and COOKIES!!!!!

A great value for a crowd.

A beautiful building with 2 restaurants (And plenty of room to host a private event) inside and engaging architecture.

Service is friendly and warm.
A nice seleciton of fine teas.

Casual yet elegant - and a decent "date place".

Oooh - I am first to review this place - now I guess I better be careful lest I let out my secret and they become so crowded that you can't get in...

But wait a second - you already CAN'T GET IN on a busy weekend morning.

The Bread Crumb is what I would classify as an "elegant greasy spoon".  It's a Breakfast & Lunch place (no dinners) it's really, really cheap and has sassy yet sweet waitresses who make you feel like family.

And the breakfast basics (Pancakes, eggs, omelettes) and all really cheap, large portions, and well prepared.

It's a treat to come here.

My parents like it, too.  (And they are next door to the Larder so you can shop after you eat.)

CASH ONLY!!!

Feast Your Eyes has catered our corporate event for the last 2 years (maybe longer).  The food is always great - and there are even tasty vegetarian options.  Hot food is kept hot and cold foods and chilled.

Friendly efficient staff - our set up was a buffet so no "servers" really - but they kept it stocked.  Delicious roast chicken - i know it sounds so simple - but theres was lemony and garlicky and terrific (even with the bones in.)

The owner, Lynn, is a doll.  Love working with Feast your eyes!

Took my little one (now 6) here for an emergency sore-throat-that -might-be-strep (it was).  And had a great experience with Dr. Cynthia Hill.  We just love her.  Points off for the long wait though.

Fortunately the on-call nurse service is EXCELLENT.  They will call you back right away if your kid ever has a medical problem.  So wonderful.

I stopped by unexpectedly while walking by "The Porch" at 30th Street station at about 9:30 AM on my way to work.

I ordered a "Cali"  (BLT with avocado and a deicious lemon/lime mayo that really added a pleasant brightness).  Menu said $4.50 but she only asked me for $3.50.

Sweet gal on the truck!

So very pleased.
I can't wait to try their burgers.

I really like Ong's.  (Just stay out of the bathroom and don't look around the kitchen area too hard.  I have had some Pho and other noodle dishes here.  Prices are reasonable and it's a GREAT place to bring my little daughter who has been here about 3 times from ages 1.5 - 4.

I also happened to stop in during the Chinese New year and the dragon parade and fire-cracker festivities stopped in.  What fun!

We enjoy it here. (And it's very affordable.)

Carversville Inn has gone through numerous chefs and menu re-vamps over the years.  It is a great, historic structure and feels so homey and comfortable (yet elegant - in a countrified way).  

Please note that I have not actually dined here since the mid nineties and I am quite sure the menu, chef and prices were all drastically different back then.  But it was terrific - I had an unforgettable duck breast that was PERFECTLY cooked.  No idea if the current menu offers duck.

Meanwhile IF YOU CAN FIND IT - you gotta check out the C-ville Inn.  A great "date place".

I haven't been back to Giwa in over 2 years - and boy am I glad I stopped in for a Galbi lunch special today.  Delicious and quick.  Sub multi-grain rice for white for $1.25 extra.  

Good stuff!

Next time I shall try the Korean Tacos.

Wow - I can't believe I've waited this long to yelp Square on Square.  I have eaten here many times -mainly for lunch as they do a filling, mid-priced lunch special.  The Hot & Sour soup here is some of the best EVER .

Really.  5 stars for the H&S Soup.

We also had a large group party here in February 2008.  They offered a set meal with soup, appetizer choice of 6 entrees and dessert.  It was very well organized and our group of over 30 people left well-fed and happy.

The manager, Steven, is very nice and easy to work with.

The only detractors here (preventing the 5 star rating) is the extremely long lines at lunch time.  (Don't come at 12:30 on a Tursday of Friday) Also the decor is in need of refreshment.  Kinda grungy.

Don't miss the Mango Chicken and Filet Mignon - really tender and nice here.
We go here often.  Children's room.  Computers.  Books.  you got it!

I am still working out a few issues we had with our move (2 items were slightly damaged), but in general our experience with 2 Men and a Truck went well.  Ben and David in dispatch were great.

Our moving team (3 men and a truck) were just OK.  Brandon was the best of the bunch.  The other 2 guys seemed to really not care much one way or the other.  It's a crappy job and they did fine in the beginning (loading the truck) but toward the end things fell apart.

Items wrapped in plastic were not unwrapped on arrival - leaving us to unwrap and dispose of yards and yards of plastic wrap.  (Not earth shattering, not a tragedy - but not fun either.)

They came in 15 minutes under estimate.
Boxes are available but very expensive.  We bought 4 boxes (2 big wardrobe boxes and 2 mediums).  

PACK YOUR OWN STUFF and use your own boxes!

Reservations with Miah and Michele were great, the actual flight with Cody for our group of 4 was perfect, however a few things were not perfect.

Ordering video clips did not work well - we somehow missed one clip and we are still waiting for it.  Hopefully we'll get it soon.

Also we waited about 25 minutes late for out 2 PM flight (we arrived at 1 PM) - took off at 2:25 PM.

Meanwhile all the kids LOVED it and can't wait to do it again.

Initially I did not have high hopes for La Belle Epoque - having read the menu and passed by many times - it just never appealed

French food?  Not my fave. 

Meanwhile, we went here last night and had very good service and EXCELLENT food.
And the best part?  One of the tastiest French 75 cocktails ($10) made to perfection.

The only food downer?  The French Onion Soup which had way. way toomuch rosemary - as in sticks 'n twigs of it.  (Not salty though - and served in a Big bowl for $8).
The best part?  Both entrees- mine and DH's.  He had the Duck confit crepe - which I tasted and we both loved.  I had the duck with raspberry sauce - cooked to perfection (I like my duck with plenty of quack still left in it).  The haricot vert and fluffy (buttery-chivey) mashed potatoes were also divine.

I shall return. And I will bring our 9 year old - she loves duck,
Very pleased!!!

Nice place for a date night,too.  Much smaller inside than I had imagined.
Big fans and supporters of this much-needed animal rescue facility.

Stopped in to Mulberry today for a snacking emergency - and they graciously made my little one a PLAIN turkey (no mayo, no mustard, no veggies, no nuthin') on white (untoasted).

Not MY choice, but what-evs.  She dug it and devoured it and I willingly forked over $4.79 for it.  OUCH.

Great service by the counter staff.

Oh - and I got me an INKO Iced White tea.   - I luvs that stuff!

Mulberry Market is all THAT and a bag of gourmet chips!

Brunch here is the real showstopper.  (Not really a 4 star for other meals).  The food is American-ish with a twist.  I enjoyed the bread basket offerings - they were really fresh and tasty.  Nice alcoholic drinks, too.  Pricey - but very genteel and worth it.  Gorgeous decor and professional service.  CROWDED for brunch - but worth it.

Make a reservation.

We shop at AC Moore alot - usually at the one on Comubus Blvd - but also at this location - which is nicer and cleaner.  They all have the same layout - so we head straight to the scrapbooking and paining supplies.

If you have a coupon - you can get some good deals.

They are now cash only (except for large catering orders).
Still a great "safe" choice for lunch or brunch.

The crispy honey fried chicken salad is my favorite, and any "fish of the day" is great (Salmon, mahi mahi).  For dessert don;t miss the delicious chocolate cake with buttercream frosting.  So good!

Nice salad and hot specials.
Friendly service from Wendy and the crew.  (The cashier lady is lovely - I can never remember her name, though.)

And the support my child's school!

We love Day by Day!

I stopped in after receiving a flyer in the mail.  This is a brand new location - and I have heard many mixed reviews (and some bad ones) for Massage Envy - disinterested practitioners, high turnover, etc.

So - with trepidation I booked a $59 Intro Murad Facial with Billie Jo.  She is terrific and thus, I "drank the Kool Aid" and became a Massage Envy Member ($60 per month and you get 1 massage).

I will have my first massage in a few weeks and will update my review at the time.

Front desk staff is very good!

A very nice, spacious and apparently well-run Staples.
Found what we needed on a Sunday AM and got in and out super quickly.

Friendly staff.
No issues.

Get a facial with Billie Joe. RUN - do not walk for a Murad (they have to use Murad - it's a corporate thing) facial and ask specifically for Billie Joe.  She is the best part of this ME location.

The massage therapists come and go and come and go and frankly, I have not yet had one (since Hudson - who left and I knew he would) that I can say is excellent.  They are fine.  Not bad and not awesome but fine.  Alot of the therapists are fresh out of school or looking to establish or re-establish a following and then they leave.  I have only had one truly BAD massage here and the therapist was let go shortly thereafter (She was a true "space case").  I have also had some GREAT massages here and then the therapists have left (Hudson [who was reverse commuting in from Philly] and Sam - who had personality problems).  Mindy and Mary seem to be good.  Mindy has treated my kid and my kid LOVES her so I am praying she will stay. Please STAY for a while, Mindy!!!!

Meanwhile, the front desk staff (also a bit of a revolving door - I hope they keep Celeste as she is terrific!!) is quite good and the owner seems to really know her stuff. Go, Celeste!

As a former spa owner, I am truly picky about who(m) I let touch my face - and Billie Joe is a gifted esthetician (formerly was at Toppers, I believe).

So like I said - try out Billie Joe for a facial (I like the Vitamin C one) .

Oh - and if you get a good massage therapist - I hope you will encourage them to STAY.
I really miss Hudson.  He was great.  I am hopeful who(m)ever I get next will be a "keeper".
Billie Joe and Celeste are keepers. Please do right by them!

Oh - and the facility itself is gorgeous and clean and well-maintained.  Love it!
Fun to browse here - but I rarely ever buy anything any more.  It was better when I was a teenager and could actually use this stuff. It is VERY touristy nowadays - or maybe it always was.

So far so good.  We took our newly adopted rescue dog (from Delco SPCA) here for a check up the minute we brought her home.  The vet tech we saw was very kind and the vet himself was also good.

Seems like a decent practice.

Zio's can get very chaotic and crowded but the "Grandmom" pizza is terrific.  Sicilian is a bit thicker and cheesier - my 9 year old gets that.  Traditional cheese-steaks and a few goodies like rice balls and zeppoli keep us coming back.

No problems here - just good, reasonably priced pizza and sandwiches.

I was gun-shy at coming back here after my awful dinner experience - but I have eaten many lunches here in years past.  I got the $10 lunch special (includes soup and rice) and had the terrific hot 'n sour soup.

Large portion of food for lunch - took some home.

Avoid for dinner - but fine for lunch.
You have redeemed yourselves, Square on Suqare.
See you again for lunch.

543 is Urban Outfitter's answer to the (pricey) corporate cafeteria - and there are a bunch of good choices including soups, a salad bar, sushi (too expensive for what it is - Salmon Avocado roll is $8.) and sandwiches.  Hot entree's rotate.
Lovely salads - around $9.

If you work here - it's one of the only options, so I hope even more places will open up down here.  Lo spiedo is wonderful but too expensive for a "regular" lunch.

Ran in and out for yet more Caudlalie Eau de Raisin (this time it was $18 plus tax for the 6.7 ounce spray).

Got a few samples of NARS and Bobbi Brown, too.

This is a review for the Drycleaner/Wash 'n fold services.  They also own the adjoining Laundromat next door.

Parking can be tight so be careful!

Meanwhile, I stopped here when our dryer broke for the $1 per lb wash 'n fold service.  BUT - they are not open on Sundays (The laundromat is, but the dry-cleaner is closed Sundays) so I waited and just dropped off some "regular" dry cleaning.  Whoa!  Dry cleaning here is more expensive that Victory - but Sharon (owner? manager?) was a sweetheart and gave me 20% off because I was a first time client.

Whew.

A few days later my dryer was still out of commission so I dropped of 12 lbs ($12.00) of necessities and they were washed, dried and folded neatly ready by 12 noon the next day.

I will definitely come here for wash 'n fold, but if I only need dry cleaning, I will go to Victory (unless you come here on a Wed or Sat - 20% off when you drop off on those days).

Sharon - you are terrific!

Tampopo has gotten better - at least now that I know what to order (and what not to order).  Today I got a side order ($2) of egg cake (tamago) and a veggie and tofu (fried but still so tasty) bibimbop.

Called it in, picked it up, no lines, no worries.

Sweet.

I pretty much agree with EVERYBODY (and I mean everybody) else on N. 3rd.  Great food, great & busy artsy eye-catching decor and perfect for brunch.  (SCORE!  A near-perfect bloody mary with a great kick to it.)

We enjoy it here - but it can be a crowded cluster-f&%k at peak times.

Normally I'd give Bertucci's about 3 stars - but this location is BRAND new (aboput 5 weeks old) and we had excellent service.

Come early - they get CROWDED and the places is loaded with kids & babies.  This is a very, very family friendly place - and mom & dad can get a drink.

I recommend the Tialpia served over Spianch if you are watching your carbs, as the Bertucci's menu is a carbo-loader for sure!

My 4 year olds loved her kid-sized pizza and even moreso loved watching the pizza ladies (and men) make pizzas).

A safe suburban bet for those with kids.

A big Lowe's with everything you need.
Got in & out (self check out) for light bulbs the other day.
No issues.

I love the food here - but the prices are high.
The quinoa salad ($7) is amazing but it's not enough on its own to satisfy me for lunch.

Luckily a lady split it with me so I could also get a salmon platter ($11).

So instead of $18 I spent $15.

Still a high price for lunch - and I really wanted to get a veggie juice, but that would have been another $5.

So it's one thing at a time for me.

Oh:  Even my 8 year old loves it here - she ATE the quinoa salad and enjoyed it and also LOVED her mango, strawberry, pineapple smoothie.  (But who wouldn't love that?)

Pure Fare was better today.  $11.88 for a green detox juice (I just LOVE this one) and a wheatberry salad.  Salad was scrumptious and quite filling. Sweet potatoes, beets and all things I like in it.

Service was a bit sullen - fortunately I came at 11:45 AM before the lunchtime rush kicked in.
Pretty good for a hotel restaurant.  Nice view of the river and the terrace is a great place to have drinks when the weather is nice.

Haven't been back to Tampopo in such a long time, so today I had the fresh salmon BBB (salmon was not as fresh as it should have been - but the veggies and asian pear were great, brown rice at no extra charge.

But what brought my 3 star lunch (take out) up to 4 stars was the amazingly fresh (still warm) tamago.  

For $2.00 - you bet I'll be back for more "egg cake".

P.S.  Bring back the Galbi Box!!!!

Had a wonderful lunch for 4 adults plus my 9 year old.
Excellent lunch specials (Chinese) and sushi, especially the "Flamingo Roll"  ($15 - ouch) with Mango, Avocado & Salmon over a shrimp tempura roll.

Wild salmon Nigiri ($3.50 for one piece) was heavenly.
Hamachi nigiri ($3.00) was very good also.

Great lunchtime service and bill was around $80.00 (no alcohol, no dessert ordered).

The four of us (my 9 year old, her 8 year old BFF and the friend's mom) stopped in and found all sorts of giftable goodies - so we got a balloon animal kit and a paper doll book of "Boo" the world's cutest dog.

What a fun place!
Great for giftables.

The fish is indeed, always, always fresh and delicious.  The prices are very high - and the preparation is old-school (no creamy crunchy over-suaced Americano rolls here!).  If you want quality fresh fish - this is a good place to get it.  

Genji has been around for-ever - I went to the old University City location back in 1991-1993 before the owner (killed himself?) died.

The present location on Sansom is the "new place" - and it, too has been here for-eh-ver.

Meanwhile - service.  If you are a regular (which I am, sadly, not) you will be treated well.  If, like me, you fly solo and sit at the bar - you may well be ignored.  

I favor Shiroi Hana these days which has both old-school hand-rolls and nigiri as well as a few "new-fangled" gourmet-rolls.

But Genji is a great placed for the sushi loving purist who seeks a wide variety of fish.  They had the most delicious Madai (Japanese Pink Snapper) and Kanpachi (baby yellowtail).

A good safe (fresh=safe) bet.

I came here yesterday early in the AM expecting to meet a friend at Pumpkin Cafe - but they don;t open until 10 or 11, so I got a FABULOUS fresh-juiced, juice of ABC (Apple, Beet, Celery) plus parsley and a bit of ginger.  $4.75 (ouch) but worth it.

The banana was .50 cents.

They also have delectable Almond Croissants from Metropolitan Bakery, Fresh Duck eggs for a buck each, frozen locally sourced meats and lots of great goodies.

The lady at the front counter/barrista is a doll!

NICE!

3.5 stars really.

Day by Day has been a reliable lunch spot and catering go-to place for me and many people at my firm.

The fried chicke toss salad is delicious and they serve a "safe" selection of sandwiches.  In the summer-  the gazpacho is a refreshing and tasty choice.

The specials of the sday - often fish and omelettes are also really, really great.  They often sell out of the fish special - so come early for your lunch.  They don't do dinners - although last summer they briefly toyed with a "dessert cafe" concept which I wish had fared better.

Anyhow - it's a great place to grab a safe, reliable lunch.

Ooh!  I can't believe I forgot to Yelp Rose Tattoo.  It's an easy walk from my apartment so we've been there numerous times in the past 3 years.  Took my parents there, too and they enjoyed the meat dishes and tasty salads.

There are several dining rooms, but I love the bar which is canopied by green plants and flowers.  (There are 2 bar areas - maybe 3.)

From the outside RTC looks kinda like a biker bar - and it always looks closed.  It's not.

Inside - wherever you sit - you'll get great food and lots of drink options.
We really love the desserts.  White Chocolate 7 Strawberry bread pudding was a delicious special one night.  Really.  Try the desserts.
Sometimes I just get an appetizer and a dessert and I am FINE with that.

Can't wait to go back.

Wow - am I ever glad I finally got a chance to eat here.  It is MUCh better than Miran.  (Sorry, Miran.)

I got a Galbi for dinner and upgraded (for $1.00) to the multigrain rice - which I am so glad I did.  The rice and grains were so healthy-tasty.  The Galbi was "textbook perfect" with a delicious BBQ flavor and just the right amount of fat. (Not greasy - but tasty and beefy.)

The side dishes of Kimchi and Sweet Yellow Soy beans were also "textbook perfect".  The Gabli and rice came with a mixed green salad dressed lightly in a soy dressing - fresh and good.  Also steamed carrots - naturally sweet and a few YUMMY edamame.

What a great meal.

Can't wait to come back again.  (Wanna get a Dolsot Bibimbop next time.)

Oh, and the man behind the counter (who I am guessing is the manager and possibly the owner) was very nice.  It's counter service, but he was so friendly to me. (It was not busy when I came.)

Also the clean bathrooms have really cool tiles.  BONUS!

Pure Fare, in theory, is my kinda place.  Fresh, natural, often organic ingredients.  Blue Bottle Coffee.  Fresh Juices (I got the Green - and it was awesome!).

Prices run high, but the food is very fresh and good.

I did not like that the sandwiches were premade (I wanted to get one with no onion.).

Lunch was $15.12 for a salad and a juice.  Man!!!!
We donate gently used baby and toddler clothing and toys to NOVA and the work they do is so valuable.  Great for donors and customers alike.

Stopped in today for "Linner" (We wanted to try Temaki but they close from 2-5.  DRAT!) with my 8 year old.  Service was cold as ice at first (maybe they were leery of the kid, but they warmed up.

They tried to seat us in the back (so dark back there) but we asked to be closer to the windows and they obliged.

Linner for 2 cost $50 with tax and tip - small plates.  1 cup of hot & sour (very good) for me, edamame (Huge portion for $4) for sharing, Shrimp Shumai (just Meh - 5 tiny pre-frozen ones) for the 8 year old (She likes Doma''s better - she's a shumai connoisseur), "meh" sushi appetizer (came with Cali roll and I never would gotten it had I known that - I was expecting all nigiri).

We also got VERY delicious seafood and spinach dumplings - these are a MUST try if you like fish (and an avoid if you don't).  The hand-made pasta/dumpling skin was light and pan fried on one side.  PERFECT.

Agedashi tofu was a bit soggy - but the dashi was delightful. That said, I WOULD get it again as I love fried tofu.

We'll be back - but I sure wish folks would give me and my kiddo the benefit of the doubt.  She's a well behaved kid and not at all bratty. And she knows her food!

Meanwhile - skip the sushi here - but I can't wait to try the Moo Shu Chicken here.  Their Chinese dishes are great,

I am going to be generous and give Tony A.s 4 stars (they may only deserve 3) as related to the DELIVERY ORDER we had for a large catered party (25 people) tonight.

Our group of professionals met at a nearby office complex so we needed a place that could deliver and provide a low cost alternative to Pizza.

We ordered a large hoagie tray (2 large platters) with Italian hoagies and Turkey & Provolone (no onions) with oil & mayo on the side.  Also we had 1 tray of wraps, vegetarian (GREAT - full of spinach, eggplant, peppers etc.) and Chicken Caesar wraps.

Additionally there was a large bowl of romaine salad with tomato, cucumber, sliced bolied eggs and sides of 2 dressings.

The pasta salad was not great - overly dressed in a vinegary dressing.  Yuck.

The dessert tray of brownies and cookies (Sugar, Chocolate Chip and White Chunk macadamia) were very yummy.

All in all a great experience.  Everything arrived on time and as we specified.  I can not speak for the ambience of the dining room as I ahve never set foot in the place.

I used the Edible Arrangements location in Commack NY.  I can't find a listing for it.

I will write a complete review when i know where to put it.

Note:  You can also order from FruitFlowers.com - a DIFFERENT company called Incredibly Edible Delights.

Both companies are great.

Stopped in here for a quick cafe au lait ($1.75) just before the yelpy awards.
Staff was a bit "snotty" - but not horribly so.  Coffee was perfect - so delicious - I love La Colombe and they even did our wedding favors for us back in 2008.

This branch is in a great location - right near city hall - and offers some respite from the high traffic area. Clean, wood seating, wood floors.  Very chic looking.

Oh - and no splenda (tons of other sweetners thought).
And - as per usual - no menus so just order what you want (Latte, double macchiato, whatev...)  That's a bit uppity to me - but that's La Colombe.

Uppity coffee to get you UP!

I always go to the Aveda store in Liberty Place to redeem my aveda coupons - for free samples or products on my birthday.  Service is very (sometimes overly) attentive - and I usually feel guilty if I don;t spend money that day.

I like the new GreenScience skin care line very much.  Not as fond of the hair care.

When they're hot - they are just heavenly - especially the White Chunk Macadamia - but DAMN they are expensive.  (And way too caloric for me to indulge in regularly.)

If you time it right you can get a free sample - which is just a bite or two and can be just enough to prevent you from buying and eating a whole one.

The buy 3 get the 4th free is a standard "special" - so that's really not so special after all.

Hooray!  The Thai Chef folks that I loved so well on Chestnut Street have an outpost in a stripmall in Glen Mills.

The Tom Kha is terrific - with a bowl of light jasmine rice, it's a meal in itself.

So glad to have found themand can't wait to return.

Support the independent pharmacies before they all disappear!
Pickwick has a great selection of cosmetics, too - like OPI and Essie nail polishes.

Glad they are still here.

We had a private event for about 20-22 diners in the back room at Effie's and it was handled beautifully.

We had many vegetarian restrictions so the following dishes were served, family style:

Spanikopita (delicious!)
Tyropita
A large mixed plate with hummus, baba, feta, olives, peppers and dolmades (awesome domlades by the way)
Chopped Cucumbers & Tomatoes in oil & vinegar
Penne with Onions, Kalamata Olives and Onion in tomato sauce.

The food was wonderful and the 2 ladies serving worked their butts off.  Wer had an amazingly good time. (And the good weather helped.)

The outdoor courtyward is a fun place to eat as well.

I can't wait to come back and have some lamb chops!

Great job, Effie's!

I come here when I just GOTTA get my galbi fix - the meat is so delicious and the pan jan - while small - is always tasty.  I had diced pickled turnips, bean sprouts and kimchee that day.

I love the multigrain rice, too - $1.25 extra but worth it for me.

Starting to use this CVS more & more due to it being next to Chick-Fil-A and having a kid.  No issues and stays open a bit later than the Aston one.

The parking lot is a bit tricky so be careful leaving.  (Getting in is no big deal.)

Ok, here's the deal.  If you're going on somebody else's dime - do it!  It is really high-priced for faux-pub - but I gotta say they do a few things there really, really well.

For instance, one of my dining companions is from England and ordered a Bomdardier which he said was well poured and not "too fizzy".  It was however, served much cooler than you'd get back home.

My entree of Hake was delicious served in a buttery lemon caper sauce over a small bed-ette (to small to call it a bed) of kale.  Not dry - in fact it leaned toward the underdone side - and thus was tender and large-flaky.
I also enjoyed the cold poached shrimp (5 for $14 - large ones) with lemon mayo & cocktail sauce.  Simple - but so tasty!

Desserts are not a strong suit save for the hot chocolate pot. (worth the 15 minute wait - order this with dinner if you are in a rush). Skip the Eton Mess unless you like TART fruit.

My decaf cappucino (not listed on the menu - but ask and ye shall receive) was EXCELLENT.  Try a Pimms Deluxe (or a classic Pimms cup) for a refreshing treat. Oh - and they have (for $5.50 each - OUCH) fancy-schmancy organic bottled sodas from the UK - I had a Luscombe's Sicilian Lemonade that was great and worth the 134 calories of sugar-water.  (THat's ORGANIC sugar water to you!).  And they carry Ribena (a blast from the past!).

I may be back - but for the price point, I'll be waiting a while.
Oh - and I won't be missing Mantra!

A lovely - and brand-spankin'-new cafe at Sister Cities Park.
Not cheap - but on par for Center City - and greatly needed.

Please put in another register and speed up your lunch-time service.

You're really on to something here.
Delicious coffee drinks.  Quiche.  Sandwiches.
(Great ice pops, too!)

The service here is excellent.
The parking is still pretty awful - and now there is a "Super" Wawa next door.
Nonetheless, I still come in every month or so for a $5 latte.
I love it, it's expensive, I feel guilty when I do it - but I gotta have a starbucks fix every once in a while.

Buddy's is getting better and better.
They have great looking salads now - and the sauteed shrooms & spinach (FREE) are blissful on top of a burger or grilled Chicken.

Service (you place and order and pick it up - but they usually will bring it out to you) is great and friendly.

We are having our future class dinner here next time!
3rd graders love it. (Especially that snazzy Coke freestyle machine.)

We went to Rose Tattoo AGAIN last night and man, was it ever good.
But the BEST part was dessert.  (They are now $8.50 a pop - but easily split by 2 people.)

Try the Paris Brest (yes, that's what the call it "BREST").  It's a puff pastry (very buttery - almost tastes fried but is baked.) split in half and filled with not-too-sweet whipped cream, home-made chocolate mousse and sliced straberries (no red gelatinous glop - thank god!).)

The whole thing is topped with a chocolate covered strawberry and served with a scoop of strawberry sorbet and garnished with chocolate and strawberry sauces on the plate.

SKIP DINNER - EAT DESSERT.  (Or order apps or sides - the side of Gnocchi is generous for $7.00)

LOVE THIS PLACE even more now.

We ate here last night and normally, I am not a fan of chains - and the RT in Liberty Place is awful - but - and here's the BIG but...

We had an excellent meal and great service.

I had the (fresh, and many choices) salad bar and a side of lobster mac 'n cheese.  The menu seems to have been upgraded.

FIL had a gorgeous and huge burger - so big he took half home.
MIL had a steak & lobster dinner (2 tiny tails - but buttery and cooked nicely).
DH enjoyed the pasta carbonara but I tasted it and did not like the overly salty-smoky flavor.

Meanwhile - we had a great time and believe it or not, I would go back again.  Soon.

We adopted a 2 year old mixed breed female.
Jury is still out but so far so good.
A nice neighborhood market with cigs, bottled water and some good gourmet items.  Staff seems pleasant and prices are high but not crazy.  We need more markets like this in Philly.

PureBread is a great lunch option.  They used to offer a full coffee/espresso bar but they don;t anymore.  So, mostly I go for soups (the mushroom bisque and lobster bisque are delicious but caloric) and salads (I like the Cobb).

All the menu items are named after dog breeds and there is dog related decor and monitors with local dogs.  I love dogs so this is great for me.

A great choice in Glen Mills near tons of shopping.

Came here on the strong recommendation of a friend that their Sicilian Pie (or Tomato Pie) when baked fresh is some of the best. ever.  I agree - gives Corropolese a run for their money.  Meanwhile, today I tried a panini (on an enormous Ciabatta loaf) with pork, sharp provolone and broccoli rabe.  Asked for a bit of sauce on it - PERFECT.  This is amazing.

My friend had a small (still plenty) sausage and pepper sandwich/sub/hoagie and it was old-school and very tasty according to her.

Jeanne-Marie (sp?) our server was friendly and wonderful but way overworked - she was serving 2 full dining rooms at the lunch rush by herself.  Ouch.

Nice place for a casual red-sauce Italian meal.  Can't wait to come back and try a pasta dish.
Molto bene!

Lunch with a party of 5 (co-workers) and while a bit pricey it was perfect for a business-casual lunch. Service was fine - our male server (Mike??) was on point with drink refills and bringing the check (it was quite busy on a rainy Thursday from 12:15 - 1:30 ish). Restroom was clean and comfortable.  Decor is very nice.

My only complaint?  The chicken tostada was fried - as in battered and fried and dripping in grease.  Next time (if I get that item) I will ask if they can do it with grilled chicken.

Steamed spinach (by request) was perfect and I am glad I asked because one colleague's meal came with sauteed spinach which he said was loaded with salt and oil.

Please folks, ease up on the fatty foods and we will return much more quickly.

Thanks!

Had another massage with Mindy and she is terrific.
I love her - and hope she'll stick around for a while.

Billie Jo - the WONDERFUL esthetician and Celeste (Front Office) are great, too.
I am having a facial with Billie Jo in a few weeks.  

I am very pleased with my Massage envy membership - but I do wish and hope that they can keep the "good" therapists longer.  They work very hard.

Really good - buttery - hand made Amish-Style pretzels.  Reminds me of when Auntie Anne's wasn't a chain - and really did have good pretzels.

These are so much better.  Get 'em while they're hot and eat them on the spot.

Carb-y goodness.  Little white head covering not included.

Yum Yum is a small, local chainette of donut shops.  I am glad they are still around because, as a kid their donuts and fried delights - like apple fritters and bowties were kick-a$$.  Waaaaaay better than Dunkin'.  (Although Dunkin's cofee is better than yum yums.

A cop and fire fighter-haven, yum yum used to be open round the clock - or at least until midnight - and then they'd open at 5 AM to start the morning baking (or frying, as the case may be.)

I loved it there as a kid.  Can't afford the caloric intake nowadays.

A bright, sunny shop with a nice selection of white, green, black, roiboos and herbal infusions. Excellent service and at least 3 or 4 free samples available each day.

Also a small selection of Cadbury confections, honeys and tea ware.

Lots of fun for the tea lover.

Need a bike or supplies/parts for one?  They've got it.  Nice Center City location, too.

We shopped here for a tandem stroller attachment (trailer) for our bike.  Ended up not buying one though - way too cost prohibitive.

Super yay!  Love the turkey burgers here.  They are NOT dry and so tasty.  I pass on the big bucket o' fries in favor of their YUM-CITY mac 'n cheese.  I order mine sans the tomato "jam" garnish.

They also have kickin' sides like greenbeans (crisp and studded with tomotoes) and sweet potatoes.  (Grilled with butter and cinnamon suger - like dessertm baby!).

It can get crowded and crazy - which is why it is not 5 stars -but the price is right and this spot ROCKS."
When they're hot - they're HOT - and sooooooo delectable when fresh out of the oven.  these pricey, large, thick, butter-laden cookies scream with flavor and taste sublime.  Oh, my hips!!!!

So glad that Animo is still around and still delicious and a good source for a healthy meal.  The green Lemonade is still my fave - and I tried a Brisket and eggs breakfast bowl - made with love by Darnell (Yay Darnell!) that rocked my day!

Love it here and I keep coming back.

Even my vegan teen can find good choices here.  (They are not a vegan restaurant and serve cheese, eggs and meats).

Love it!  Wish it were bigger and more days - but I will take what I can get.

Support Philly's Farmer's Markets.
Support Fair Food.
Support Farm to City.

Join a CSA and patronize local farmers!

This is now my go-to 'Bux as I work at 18 & Market (I used to frequent the one at 20 & Market).  During the morning rush it gets absolutely mobbed - use the mobile ordering if you can and you can swoop in and out to get your over-priced #DiabetesInaCup.

Meanwhile, I treat myself to a latte about twice a week.  Trying to cut down but I love them.

I know people claim to not like Starbucks but the long lines here (quick moving) seem to indicate otherwise.

Gotta have my FiveBucks aka Charbucks!

This 4 star rating is based solely on the ONE item I ordered (to go).
I got a Little Buddy (single patty) burger to go, on a busy "Dining under the Stars" Wednesday.

UPDATE:   We went back to Buddy's a few weeks later at my 9 year old's request.
Chicken sandwich was good (fried) but Sweet potatoe Fries were soggy and studded with big crystals of salt.  The sweet fries at Front Street Fountain are way better.  (And the burgers here are better than Front Street).

The burger was cooked fresh and there were loads of free toppings to choose from.
I got Lettuce, Tomato and sauteed 'shrooms.  (Garlicky - but not overly so and delicious).
VERY good burger for the price.

Super fresh - served on a squishy seeded (Lots of sesame - so be aware) roll.

My 9 year old - who doesn't even drink or like soda - seemed obsessed with the Coca Cola freestlye console. She got an Orange/Vanilla Hi-C - talk about a sugar high!

Friendly young gals running the counter. Very good service. Especially Amanda - she is so kind to us and even gave my kid a plush toy when my kid did not win one from "Tha Claw" machine.

We'll be back - way better burger than Zac's!
Next time I will skip the sweet potato fries (but maybe I'll try a milkshake).

I had wanted to try La Padella for months and finally got a chance to dine here.  It was worth the wait and I can't wait to return and sample more of their fabulous Italian menu.  The meatballs are large and very tasty. If you enjoy Brussels sprouts, don't miss the Brussels sprouts app - with lump crab meat and a rich remoulade. Super fattening and heavy, so share with friends.  

Service from the amazing Laurie is top notch.  We love her.

Great food and even better service.

In general I really lurve Weggie's.  The bulk foods, the prepared foods, and the superb cheese section are stand outs for sure.  I wish there was/were one in Center City Philly and I would surely shop there.

we spend a little more when we come - not so much due to pricing (the prices are competitive for most items) but because we splurge on all sorts of specialty foods and unique items we just can't get at Is-It-Fresh (Superfresh) or Ack-A-Mee.

Go to Wegman's - but don't go if you're hungry and bring your shopping list so you don't impulse buy!

I love Whole Paycheck -and this location is no exception.
The Taco Truck on the roof, the hot and cold food bars for a quick lunch option, and the ability to shop here at an off-peak time (parking is bad during the weekday lunch rush).

Plentiful seating options (2 floors) and enjoyable.
Expensive - sure - but worth it to me.

This place is toooooo cute!  We came here twice - both times with our (then 2 no 3 year old) daughter.  The second time we came was for a kids music concert and it was way, way crowded - but such fun.

The food and coffee drinks are great and it's a cute place to hear live music.

Had a superb Chicken Cacciatore ($10) with orzo for lunch.
As usual, friendly service and great food.

We love Day by Day!

Need a Mother-of-the (Bride, groom, Bat Mitzvah girl) dress?  Prom Dress?  Elegant suit to wear to a wedding?  Cocktail attire?

Penina and her daughter have what you need!

Great cusomer service and lots of sizes (from petite to "big gals").

We love Penina.

Ran in, got my Caudalie Eau de Raisin ($22 plus tax) and ran out.
Had to BEG for samples - but eventually got a few.

Expensive, higher-end brands.

Glad they exist.

NARS concealer is $32 now.  Ouch.

Go see Tina - she is so nice - and does fabulous HAND DRAWN nail art on my little girls nails.

I also had a spa pedicure (35 vs. 25 - and they throw in a wimpy massage - next time a regular pedi for me) and regular mani (13).

Tina is great!!!!  (She did not do my pedi - she does my kids nails)

La Maison has been a central-D-Town staple for generations.  It has also gone thru 2 possibly 3 ownership changes over the past 35 years.
Meanwhile, they offer a nice variety of standard and rare domestic and imported cheeses, as well as pates, spreads, bread and cracker products and all the making for a good catering company.

You'll pay Doylestown prices - but they are nice ladies and run a good show.  Years back they'd bake their own croissants - especially on weekends. Not sure if that is still done - but the treats that came out of that oven were rich, buttery and blissful.

I wish them generations more of success!

A strong 3 - maybe even a 4 - for the expertise of Laura who help me to plan a small happy hour event for my office.

We enjoyed the Raspberry Wheat beer (3.50 is a decent price for it) and other drinks.  We also tried the salmon spring rolls (excellent) cheese-steak eggrolls (good not great) and southwestern springrolls (my husband liked these).

In addition the Hawaiian Pizza was very tasty - and the crust was freshly baked.  I also tried the Ale & Onion soup which tasted good, but was very, very oily - almost greasy from the oils in the cheese.  Eew.  It was OK as "french"-style onion soup goes but I have had better (and I have had worse.).

The place is MASSIVE - a great idea for private parties -especially on a night when you can enjoy the deck.

The best part of the night?  Meeting fellow yelpers Jessica E. and Chris from Delaware!  Thanks for coming out!

I have lived in the Pacakrd Building for 3 years now - and while the rents continue to rise & rise, the building is still terrific for us.  Great location and basically well run and well managed.

We wish they'd replace the 22 year old washer dryer in my apartment though.  It takes FOREVER to dry clothes and is a waste of electricity.

The entire building is 100% electric - so there's no gas bill - but the electric bills for heat and a/c - especially with out 15 foot ceilings (a plus and also a minus) - the bills are SKY HIGH.  (Pun intended.)

Some of the front desk staff are lazy - but most are very nice and willing to help you with dry-cleaning and packages.

It's a gorgeous apartment for a luxury price.  Smack dab in the middle - of NOTHING.  (Broad Street bet. Vine & Callowhill).

There is "The Sunday Breakfast Club" aka homeless shelter 1/2 a block away so there are quite a few unsavory goings-on in the alley next to the building.  AND little police patrol.  Once we get home after work - we stay there!!!

We went there last night - 4 of us, after tasting the fantastic timballe de scripelle (like an Abruzzi-style lasagna made of home-made parmesan crepes, with mini meatballs) at the SlowFood Philly event in HeadHouse square.

We ordered 3 apps & 4 entrees between us.  The breaded Olives - which we loved, the Riceballs - were Good but not WOW and a truly terrific tomato, fresh fior-de-latte mozzarella and grill artichoke salad.

It was so great.

Then the entrees came.  I had the Timballe, my husband had the home-made pasta (herbed pappardellle-like sheets) with duck & beef ragu.  So delectable.

Our friends both had terrific grilled entrees.  Lamb chops and skewers of  Chicken and home-cured sausage.  Both entrees came with roasted potatoes.

We had no alcohol - just soft drinks.  Oh yeah, my husband did have a beer - a good one - and orange-blossom scented pale ale.  Nice.

For dessert the chef - who was kind enough to chat with us, comped us a platter of 3 desserts.  A traditional cassata-like cake (good - not great), a silky panna cotta (YUM) and the best - LIMONCELLO-soaked tiramisu.

That would be worth the usual $7 for-a-dessert charge.

I really, really like this place and would welcome the chance to go back.
The patio in summer is nice, although we sat inside.

It was a lovely time.

They re-did this Sunoco a while back and the mini-mart has really improved with better restrooms, a Subway (inside) and hot foods.  The gas is "market priced" and it's easy to get in and out here - right in "downtown" Media (LOL - I have to laugh at the phrase "downtown Media").

No issues - and I come here quite often when I need gas in Media.

No issues with the Media "martini glass" bouquet delivered locally for a party and it arrived fresh and on time.

My 9 year old & I stopped by the store - because we had never been inside and the nice lady GAVE us each a free chocolate-covered strawberry.  Made our day!

EA is a nice alternative to a cake at a party (you can add chocolate covered berried or banana chunks) or instead of sending flowers to someone.

Ah, the Troc.  So many shows - but so many that I saw soooooooo long ago.  Loved it back then - can't really comment on it nowadays.

And they get some really great acts in here!

Better.  A big Target with everything we needed.  Except for the picked-over shoe department.  I have come to the conclusion that unless its for a young child or flip flops that Target is NOT a place to buy shoes.

Luckily DSW is right nearby!

In any case we got a bunch of household products we needed.
