Another delicious lunch of orzo salad, Salade Nicoise (with freshly seared tuna) and of course the honey fried chicken tossed salad.

Wendy is still there and the gang is always friendly and happy to see us.

Love lunches at Day by Day!

Cathy, our sassy server, was a delight.  She is a pro and has been here for about 6 years.  We sat in their outdoor "Covid Tent" on a busy Sunday morning at 11.  We got a table for 4 right away and juice/coffee/tea.

The eggs Florentine are terrific but they come with cheese.  Next time I will skip it and also get the copious amount of hollandaise sauce on the side.  A calorie/fat bomb for sure.  Too about 1/3 of it home.

Now I need a nap...

5 stars for my amazing practitioner, Dr. Nonack - he is truly a kind, caring and competent physician.

The administration of the practice needs work though and this is systemic throughout the PENN healthcare system.  Please bring back late Monday night appointments.

Please consider Saturday appointments - even once per month would help.

Kielie at the Media office (I probably spelled that wrong) is terrific and runs the desk well.

The in-house lab for blood draws (alas - Michael has left circa 2021) is so convenient, too.

Staff do not seem well compensated.

So pleased to see a healthier alternative for lunch - the petitio burrito (small) is plenty big.  Prices are high and ordering system is too slow (no big menu - you have to read the small menu) - plus my juice was wrong.  (They re-made it with no issues.)

Love the food choices, not liking the slow ordering procedure (line is huge at lunch hour) and innacuracies.

Also the up charges for Guac and Meats is too high.  (The small burritos are 6-7 as it is - I don;t wanna pay $10 for a SMALL - when I could get a regular sized (large) burrito for $8 anyway.

A few kinks to work out - but I will generously give them 4 stars - for now - I sense trouble ahead, so please get it together and re-structure the burrito menu a bit. (Add ons.)

Keep the steamed kale - it's great!
Also, I am getting green lemonade (ask for it with less apple, more green) every morning for about a week now and I LOVE it.

P.S.  The breakfast "beans & Green" petitio is terrific and at $4.5 is a decent value. The eggs & greens is also a good and filling breakfast for $4.75

When it's fresh - that vanilla pound cake is simple, heavy and rich and DE-FRIKKIN-LICIOUS.  For $11 a pop - get 2 and freeze one.

So good.  A neighborhood staple and a "real" Philly treat.

I support Planned Parenthood.  This location is smaller and has limited hours (funding cuts have been a problem for all Planned Parenthood sites).

They have my support.

This Wawa was literally my savior as I was trapped in a huge area-wide traffic fisaco when 95 was literally shut down (in both directions) as was 476 due to 2 major overturned truck accidents.

Traffic was crawling on 291 and all arterial roads.  A 35 minute drive took nealy 2 hours and I. Had. To. Pee.

Thank heavens for this Wawa - and the friendly female cashier who directly me safely out of the parking lot back on to 291.

A cutesy & kid-friendly (family mecca) bakery in Chestnut Hill right on "The" Avenue.  Cakes, cookies and other sweet treats at medium (not cheap, but not ridiculous) prices.

They also have ice cream.  My little one is sold - and I am not too far behind.  (Although I prefer cakes from the Night Kitchen bakery a bit farther down the hill. - see my other reviews.)

2 pretzel dogs and 3 free pretzels for $4.59.
Everything was hot and fresh (I arrived at 7:30 AM).

No issues.

Carb-y goodness.

OMG, Weber's!  I haven't been here since I was a kid.
Meanwhile, yesterday (a Sunday) about 6:30 PM we were driving back to Philly - and attempted to go to the Cherry Hill Mall - which was closed.
So we wound up on a whim, stopping at Weber's.

The Elvis impersonator in the driveway was an interesting touch.  Nice guy - actually (and he's available for parties).

DH & I both got cheeseburgers, DD got a hot dog with ketchup AND a cheeseburger.  We shared a chocolate milkshake - which the lovely female server offered to split into 2 cups for us.  So great!  DD & I each had a few sips of the thick chocolate goodness and then called it quits.  I can't imagine drinking a whole one.

The burgers tasted great and were so juicy. A little small - but they were heavy so that was fine.

DD liked her hot dog and ate a good bit of the burger, too - and of course then felt sick and stopped eating.

A little too much of a good thing.
A rare indulgence, for sure.
CASH ONLY.

So nostalgic on a cool summer night to be served by a "carhop".

Yuppie diner where clientele and staff are all straight out of a J Crew Catalog.  Excellent and good looking (mostly female) wait staff and FABULOUS albeit higher priced diner classics with a twist.

Turkey chili was terrific as was house-made oatmeal and Eggs Benedict (pricey) with a variety of add ons including spinach and crabmeat.

So good.

LOVE!

Can't wait to return.

Super yay!  Love the turkey burgers here.  They are NOT dry and so tasty.  I pass on the big bucket o' fries in favor of their YUM-CITY mac 'n cheese.  I order mine sans the tomato "jam" garnish.

They also have kickin' sides like greenbeans (crisp and studded with tomotoes) and sweet potatoes.  (Grilled with butter and cinnamon suger - like dessertm baby!).

It can get crowded and crazy - which is why it is not 5 stars -but the price is right and this spot ROCKS.
4 stars for the food.  I try to ignore the surroundings.  Great Duck.  And hands-down best steamed dumplings.  LOVE 'em.  Wonton Duck Soup can be a little greasy - but man, it's a tasty indulgence.

We went here AGAIN for New Years eve and the food was amazingly good. And they treated my 4 year old so nicely. She loved the mango sorbet and vanilla ice cream, of course. 

They had a "special" somewhat limited and pricey NYEve menu. I had the mushroom ravioli which was absolutely delicious. My friend had the Chilean Sea Bass and LOVED it. We are **this close** to giving it 5 stars, but my husbands fillet mignon (came with lobster) was overcooked. 

The appetizer of HUGE bacon-wrapped, vegetable stuffed jumbo shrimp was divine - served over 2 sauces: rich horseradish cream and raspberry coulis - swirled together on the plate. At first I thought $15 for 2 shrimp seems INSANE - but they were, indeed, HUGE. 

The desserts were, of course, the BEST part - and on New Year's eve they were each garnished with gold-leafed chocolates that said "Happy New Year" on them. (My 4 year old gobbled down the chocolates with glee.) The Black & White creme brulee was perfectly prepare with a hot crispy top and cool creamy sweetness beneath (My husband & I shared it). My friend got the espresso chocolate torte - which really was overkill. Just a bit too-too if you know what I mean - but if you are a chocolate/espresso lover you could catch a wicked buzz off of that! (Served with 3 chocolate covered espresso beans - which alone would make me buzz.) 

Our server was friendly and attentive - although i think she secretly was not thrilled about us bringing our young child in. 

Oh - and I had 3 Arnold Palmers - you know what a big drinker I am. 
They were terrifically refreshing. 

The chefs are great guys who can really "throw down". I just love the rose tattoo. They are really, really, close to 5 stars for me.

MInella's redeemed itself - specifically George, our wonderful server.  A friend and I came during Covid and the place was nearly empty so we could sit and eat.

We each got burgers - big (8 oz) juicy burgers.  Topped with whatever you can think of.  If you wish side of fries and (2) onion rings.  Massive pile of fries.

Very good experience, thank goodness.  I had all but given up on Minella's.

I have since been back to Talula's 3 more times - including last night.  Each time was a true 5 star experience.

But not last night.

Service was still great.
Food was not 5 star.  (The cheese plate was still 5 star - best bites of the night including Délice de Bourgogne and a fantastic onion-y Abbott's Gold Cheddar.  (Had that last time and swapped it into the "World Travel" cheese plate.)

The cavatelli app was superb.  But tiny.
TINY!
Yes, I know it's an app - but they presented it in a huge, deep "pasta" bowl and it made it look even smaller.  Maybe serving it in a more propotionate vessel?

My friend ordered the spring foraged salad which sounded heavenly on paper and in real life was just OK. The ramps were over powering and the foraged lettuces were a bit bitter and odd tasting.

The beets and ricotta side still rocks my world.

It was a strong 4 for food, 5 for service but...
...here's the BIG but...

The cocktails have somehow gone awry.
Even my Arnold Palmer was just "meh. (Did they change their iced tea??)
My friend ordered a "The Painter" - a champagne cocktail and it looked like a watered down mimosa with lemon juice instead of orange juice ($12 - FEH!)
And the enormous wine glass that the rose came in (Reidel crystal??) made the skimpy less-than-6-oz. pour look positively puny.  ($10 - FEH again!)

I am deeply saddened to have to downgrade Talulas as it was one of my absolute faves.

So sad.
So sad.

Meanwhile - come have a cheese plate here - but be wary of the new barkeep.

We came on a Sunday for a late lunch and had great service from Luna.
Cheerful (loud - they turned it down) music and Horchata (ask for it).

Delicious Al Pastor (I got it in my tacos) and fresh guac.

My partner's burrito (veggie) was chock full of goodies.

Very fair prices and portions.
Good tasting food.

Haven't been to Devil's Alley in years (try 5 or 6 of them) but stopped in for lunch on a not-so-busy Friday (It was 11:50 AM - so the rush had not yet hit) and had a great, basic cobb salad (I subbed Salmon for pulled Chicken) and it was terrific. 

The Honey Mustard and Blue Cheese dressings (I sampled both!) are very good and the lettuce was fresh and crunchy.

Service from the hostess (Alyssa/Alicia??) was outstanding, too.  She is young but been in restaurants for 7 years.  So kind.

We'll be back - and in less than 6 years, too.

Devil's Alley is still a good choice - even after all this time.
Keep it up!

A fantastic find on an unseasonably warm November day.  Lentil Soup, Horiatiki Salad -topped with salmon - so perfect - and "greek" waffle fries.

Great service from Ian.

We loved that house-made pita, too.

Everything was so tasty and moderately priced.  Lovely!

Delicious linguine with clam sauce (whole clams, in-shell) and just enough garlic in the not-too-oily sauce.  The long-stem (fried) artichoke appetizer is truly marvelous but so heavy for an app.  I had it as a lunch entree and was stuffed.  (The panko-coated artichoke halves are smothered in a rich rosa sauce - delicious but so caloric.)

A diet bomb but a special treat.
Attentive and efficient service.

For whatever reason everything seemed way better at Diego's during Margarita weekend.  The $4 frozen margs didn't hurt!  The special - Shrimp Tempura Tacos with Mango Salsa were great ($15 for 3) and the queso fundito is basic but tasty.

Chips & Salsa and service with a smile were constant and we had a great night - even if the place was "ear-splittingly" loud.

We are big supporters of the Mummers - and my little girl just loves the parade - especially the comics.

I am partial to the Fancy Brigades, myself.

Anyhow, this SMALL museum (kind of a glorified practice hall) is a once-must-see Philadelphia experience.  Neat.

Ah, target - that's tar jhay - the french department store.
Not really - but as target's go - this one is clean, suburban and has everything we need.

We come here when we are on the way back to Philly from Doylestown - it's right on the way.

Loves me some target!

Still a solid choice for lunch, dinner or drinks and munchies.
Very good quality food - but also high priced.

Heirloom tomato salad ($10) was small but very delicious.
Cheese Plate is always a fine choice as is the pint of Prawns or house-cured salmon.

Lovely food - simple, fresh ingredients.
Complicated drinks and high priced soft drinks ($5 for luscombe's!)

Ok service but a few little mis-steps. For example - we were not served any bread & butter until we asked for it - late in the meal.

A good pick for a Center City lunch.

On our way to LBI - Red top (and Green top next door) are our go-to "touristy" farmer's market stop.  yes the prices are a bit much and we ask which produce is local (some is not).

Picnic tables yes. Restrooms - no.

3-4 stars - I will give them 4 as our service was excellent (we came on the Sunday night of July 4th weekend) and the food was surprisingly excellent.

Our party of 3 sat in the back dining room which was a/c-chilled to a crisp.  Bet that comes in handy on crowded nites - but it was DEAD at 6 PM on that particular Sunday.

We started with a DELICIOUS order of chicken nachos and they were served with blue corn tortilla chips, salsa, guacamole and a good amount of melted cheese.  YUM!

My friend ordered the grilled chicken (her usual - she's been 3-4 times and unlike other reviewers - she likes the grilled chicken here), my husband got the pork burger and I got and LOVED the (fried) fish tacos.  At 3 tacos per order for $9.50 - that was very fair.

The only culinary "oops" were the twice-fried french fries.  They were hard as rocks and cold.  Kinda greasy and blah tasting.  I bet they sat around due to the low-turnover night.  I bet they taste better fresh outta the fryer.  Too bad.

Oodles of beers on tap and by the bottle - even a choice "by the cask".  Hubby got a Blueberry wheat pale ale - which tasted great.

The chocolate beignets and other choices tempted us from the dessert menu, but alas, we did NOT order dessert as we were too stuffed to manage it.

Less pretentious (and less cutesy) than Pub & Kitchen - this is not a gastro-pub - it's simple bar food with a fresh tasting twist.

I live walking distance so I'll be back for sure!

We went to Indonesia last night as part of the foodie group (Shout out to Foodie M!) of 31 people.  For $35 (including tax & tip - BYOB) per person we had an absolute banquet of food. 2 Diet Cokes we ordered in addition were less than $3.00.  Dang - I should brought some bubbly!

Our hosts (the owner and 2 attentive, hard working servers) treated us so well.  We had the entire private banquet room upstairs, and it was lovely, with fresh flowers on the long table, and ice water ready for us.

Our appetizers were balls of sticky rice stuffed with aromatic chicken, wrapped in a banana leaf.  (The banana leaf is used prevelantly in Javanese cookery).  I liked it, but it coulda used some dipping sauce.

Next we had a choice of soup - Chicken with coconut - different than Thai - and a little thinner - or an EXCELLENT Lamb soup.  The soup did have bones (lamb ribs) in it - so that turned a few people off - but I loved it - as the flavor was so tasty.  Lime leaves and lemon grass - and not at all "too hot" nor "too spicy".  I really, really enjoyed that soup.

After the appetizer and soup I already felt full, but I tried to pace myself (and failed) for the formidable feast.  Each couple was served a lazy susan with about 6-7 different dishes on it.  Large bowls of yellow aromatic rice (so delish) were placed on each table so we could all have as much rice as we liked.  (The rice had a faint jasmine tea aroma to it and was so sweet and wonderful. - Carbo loading at its best.)

The dishes on our lazy susan included a succulent and tender beef curry.  Now, I am not a curry person - but this was terrific.  A lovely "barbequed" chicken in a sweet red pepper sauce was fragrant and tasty.

All the meats were flake-tender.

I was not a big fan of the mackerel - again steamed with spices and wrapped in the ever-present banana leaf.  It tasted too fishy and cat-foodish for me.

The Udup-Udup - mixed vegetables with FRESH crispy bean sprouts and crunchy green cabbage was a good palate cleanser.

Fettucine-like strands of egg omelette were simply delicious as well.
Nasi goreng and Sate (yummy chicken sate) were on the platter, too.

Another stand out was the crisp, slightly sweet and calorie-laden corn & egg fritter.  Two of them were perched atop the center of the lazy susan and DH and I ate those right away while they were hot and perfect.

By now I was so full I could barely try the tempeh with shrimp and green beans (sounded better than it was) and Potato-meat croquettes (not my thing, but other people loved them).

Not one but 2 dessert courses followed.
Fried bananas - one of my favorites - were served with a small pitcher of syrup.  "They're not just for breakfast anymore"!  The batter evokes a french toast (sans cinnamon) taste.  They were a little thickly breaded (I am accostomed to Japanese Tempura bananas) for my liking - but I was so stuffed that I really didn't mind.

The final dessert was really. Well.

Weird.  It was a warm "soup" of sweet (slightly chalky) coconut milk, with pieces of (yummy) jackfruit), tapioca pearls, mung beans, shredded green jello (eeeew) and pieces of white bread.

Maybe it was because I was now too full to enjoy anything - but this type of dessert (take every tpical Javanese dessert item and put it in a bowl) would not ever be my cup of tea.  (Or soup - as the case may be.)

The best part of the evening was the terrific conversation and friendships made.  Foodie M.'s mom and sister sat near us - and that was terrific.
We also met another couple who were smart and funny and had been to Indonesia before (Though Balinese cuisine and easter Javanese are quite different.)

I would highly recommend trying Indonesia and supporting this wonderful local business.

A great time was had!

This outpost of Smashburger is infinitely better-run than the one near my home.
The red-shirted managers were serving the lunch crowd (Quite busy on a Friday) and very attentive.

I actually ordered the Kid's meal and the portion was just fine for me.
Glad to see this option.

Still, I wish they'd allow upgrades to sweet-potato and/or "smash" fries from "regular" fries.  The sweet potato fries (to me) are much tastier.

A calorie-bomb for sure - but if you stick to salads and get grilled (not fried) chicken or the (fairly decent) turkey burger you can get away with it once in a while.

Wow - I honestly can NOT believe that nobody reviewed this venerable (old, ancient, classic, etc.) Media institution.

"The" Townhouse has held countless High School reunions (even weddings), corporate luncheons and functions in their numerous party rooms (and the large "ball room" downstairs).

I attended a small (25 people) dinner last night - but before it began we sat at the (again) classic bar downstairs where Barbara kept those refreshing Arnold Palmers coming!  She is a doll.  (And the $2.00 off each drink at happy hour (4-6 PM) and free munchies were a plus.

They also offer $3.00 bar snacks - but we saved room for our meal upstairs.

Once upstairs I had a ball looking at all those classic photographs from events long past (The 25th class reunion of the Class of '42, and even a picture of Mr. Biddle - when he was about 20 - from Drinker Biddle & Reath).  Nicki - our server has worked at D'Ignazios for 40 years!

We started our "set" meal with a very fresh green salad.  I had the tasty lobster ravioli and others had chicken or a veggie option.

Dessert was an uber-rich flourless chocolate cake.  It was drizzled in a raspberry sauce and tasted like eating fudge.  It was OK, but a bit much for me.  Other folks RAVED about it.

So, yes, I would definitely come here on my own for dinner - or book an event here.  They are "old" pros.  

One possible con?  It is an OLD place - so some of the decor is really authentic - so if you want a more polished look (like for a wedding?  I would, personally never do a wedding here) you may be turned off.  For a High School reunion or Corporate event?  PERFECT!!!!!

Cute little place with a limited menu and a selection of Viso's partries.  We come here for cannoli when we are too lazy to drive to Viso's in Aston.  Friendly service and nice & clean inside.

Pleasant.

We held our group's holiday party for 10 people here with an open bar and a small buffet and everything went so well.

Great service and good filling food like roast beef, ham and great mac and cheese.
They also served individual garden salads in small torilla bowls - cute and tasty!

Fun and great times always at Oh! Shea's.

We have enjoyed coming to OOka for years now.  Whenever in Doylestown and we want sushi -it's where we go.  They offer alot of Americanized (fattening) non-traditional rolls, and the sashimi parfait (with strawberries).  Also some seared nigiri - one with foie gra which is a decadent treat.  I was not as impressed with the kitchen entrees - having tried the veggie yaki-udon which was bland.

My fiancee likes the chicken dishes, butusually we stick to sushi creaions here.

It can get crazy-crowded on weekends.

Very good.  Nearly 5 star for a yogurt place.  Vast variety of flavors - including a no-sugar added french vanilla that (to me) tasted better than the Tahitian Vanilla.  Double Cookies & Cream was great and the kiddo loves the NY cheesecake variety.

Oodles of candy and fruit toppings - and whipped cream if you ask.

Very friendly young female staff.

Clean and inviting.

Crazy parking lot - always is (Outback takes up half the spots).

Nice location in an affluent shopping center that is always crowded on weekends.
Clean and comfortable,  Medium sized with seating and a retail area.  (Not a teeny one and not huge).

Better - much better - but still very heavy-handed with the Olive oil on nearly every dish.
The burrata of the day ($16 was truly outstanding - served with paper thin slices of speck and roasted peppers and beets (purple and gold).  Gorgeous and delicious.

The table-side filleted whole branzino (enough for 2 to share at $36) was perfectly cooked and served with roasted veggies (terrific) and potatoes.

A side of broccoli-rabe was textbook - but again - drowning in garlic and olive oil.  

Service was perfection.  Decor is beautiful.
Love this place.

Even on a PACKED Saturday night my 9 year old & I had a terrific time at Ruby's.  We opted to sit at the counter rather than wait for a table and watch the plethora of fries & burgers being whisked away.

El kiddo had an "Orange 50/50" milk shake and a fried seafood platter (so healthy, i know!).  She even likes the coleslaw here.

Not gourmet, not fancy - but good family fun.

Surprisingly good service on such a busy, busy night.

Love these guys!  The name-sake ravioli is delicious and affordable - usually frozen and many varietys.  Great tortellini, too - meat or cheese (I love the meat).  Great hoagies and sandwiches.  SHARP Provolone.

The real deal - straight from sou-philly.  Oh - and they support the Mummers - so go to P&S!
Spacious, clean and well stocked Staples with office supplies and computer equipment too.  Convenient to my office.
believe it or not we had a sandwich tray CATERED from Barrels (to a swanky law firm no less) and the food was Di-VINE!!!!!  The chicken cutlet with rabe was perfection on a roll.

OK, I gotta update my review of OOKA, as we just had an incredibly GOOD night here.  Our first time coming with our 4 (nearly 5) year old and sitting at the teppanyaki grill. (No, it's not Hibachi.  It's teppanyaki, thank you very much.)

We made a same day reservation for 6:45 PM on a Saturday (tonight, actually) and were accomodated and got in just before it started to get packed & crazy - as Saturday nights at Ooka D-town are known to be.

Service was truly excellent.  The waiter and teppanyaki chef were both extra accomodating to the little princess - the chef even made an extra Onion Volcano during the teppanyaki grilling portion.  She was mesmerized.

The place had an unusually high number of kids and families - I guess I never noticed this before because every ogther time we have come sans bebe (thank god!) and usually we sit in the sushi dining room or at the sushi bar.

Once again I ordered the Seared striped bass with foie gras suishi and once again it was melt-in-your-mouth delicious.  Next time 2 orders!  It's that good. 

Toro was a bit of a disappointment (but at only $7.00 I had to try one).  I also ordered 2 pieces of Maguro ($5.50 for 2 pieces vs. $7 for ONE toro - they said "O" but I bet it was "Chu".)  Anyhow the toro was a little gristley and the Maguro was perfect.  Next time I'll be skipping the toro and loading up on Hamachi (perfect and ocean-fresh) and the aforementioned seared bass with foie.

DD & DH had teppanyaki meals -which are never a HG for me.  DD loved her shrimp, noodles and rice.  She wouldn't touch the veggies.
Hubby ate his chicken meal but said (as predicted) it was too heavy on the soy and the margarine (yes they slather that grill in grease).

Bringing kids?  The teppanyaki will keep them very entertained.  Want a better meal?  Order sushi based dishes.  (Just my opinion.)

Go Ooka.  What a change from the Domino's pizza and ultra-conservative Christian Bookshop that used to inhabit the space.

OMG Amazing!  The adobo pork, smoked chicken salad, OMY Fingers (kinda like tiny fried lumpia stuffed with pork) are all wonderful.
Elaine (LaLaine?) and her staff (family) are terrific.

Can't wait to come back and try the brisket and rubs.

A true gem!
Go there NOW!

Nearly 5 stars - the food is 5 star for sure!
I had a huge platter (ate about hald) of Chilaquiles with 2 delicious fried eggs over top.  ($8.00 for lunch)

Wonderful service and delicious, authentic selections - like Chiles en Nogado (the real McCoy with Pomegranate seeds - in season!)

My friends had the Burrito Maya and it looked great (I had one small bite - and it was!).

What a find!

Let me preface this by saying (again) that I am really not a steak 'n hoagie kinda gal. But Lee's makes a darned good one (both steaks and hoagies are good here - and believe me, they are 2 entirely different species in the sandwich kingdom).

I have had a very good chicken cheese steak with shrooms here within the last 5 years.  Prior to that - probably 12-15 years ago (yes really) I used to have roast beef hoagies with lettuce, tomato, no oil, no onion.  (But this is probably too far back to comment on.

Decor is sparse - and functional.  Fairly clean - BIG PLUS and I would feel just fine taking friends or my 3 year old to grab a meal here.  Take out is even better.  (wink, wink)

I honestly don't remember if they sell Beer. I highly doubt it given PA's restrictive liquor laws.

While i can't speak for the other baked goods (and I have had many at the RTM location), the traditional cheese and chocolate chip filled-to-order cannoli at the Comcast outpost of termini Bros. are TERRIFIC.

Very crisp cannoli shells and a thick, but not gelatinous, creamy ricotta based filling.  Soooooo good.

2 words:

Tomato Pie!

Corropolese tomato pie is truly wonderful (and a huge one will feed an army of guests - which is exactly what we did at my sister-in-law's house for a family party) - rich and tomato-ey with a dusting of parmesan cheese on top (no mozzarella).  

Eat it hot - or room temp - or even cold the next day is still pretty good.

They also make enormous hoagie trays - replete with Italian meats and cheeses - onions, lettuce shreds and tomatoes sliced paper thin.

A great catering option - Superbowl, birthday or otherwise.

I am giving a high review to Aerosoles because both myself and my 5 year old (yes, 5) enjoy trying on shoes here.  I was even able to find some decent, low priced (39.99 - 59.99) comfortable "classic" shoes that are great for work.

There is a very nice man at the Walnut Street Aerosoles (Jax?? Jack? - white gay guy - very nice) who has sold me now 2 pair of "moc croc" loafers.

Plus they humored my little one by letting her march around the store in faux leopard, high-helled ankle booties.  She was in heaven.  Had they not been $99 I might have bought them just for her dress up! 

Meanwhile - I like the shoes here.   Not a holy grail - but good, cheap workaday shoes that (sometimes) don;t look too old-lady.

We did not stay here - but we did stop here for a dire emergency bathroom break for our 6 year old.

Lobby was nice and clean and the front desk staff cheerfully directed us to the restroom.

Asked about room rates on the way out and rack rates are $159 - $209.

Tom at "I Hate" Steven SInger treated us great and even hooked us up with "swag" when we visited recently with "the real" Steve SInger.

A good selection of full and 1/2 eternity bands in a variety of metals and settings.
Very "eye clear" stones that appear to be well cut.

So happy.

So glad this place is here!
They carry all the "health food" standards and a few unique packaged goods and products.

A small fresh produce section - but all organic and good.
Clean, well stocked aisles.

So happy to support them.

Food still sucks - but we had such great service for our group of 6 (CinemaSuites seating is great!) by Dell and others.  Dell is so friendly and wonderful.  Give her a raise!

Do NOT order any of the sushi - blargh!
Also the food pricing is ridiculous for the crap quality that you get.  

I had a frozen Mango Margarita and it was fine.
The movie itself was great - and we all had an enjoyable evening.
This place is no=w called Delicatessan with new management, staff and menu items.  Please see my complete review under"DELICATESSEN"

Went here on the recommendation on a friend and was NOT disappointed.  Came in early (5:30) on a Saturday night and it was still slow.  By the time we left at 6:40 it was filling up.

Even though most people probably go to the Outback Steakhouse next door - I would say to come here instead.  Great service and solid Thai dishes.

We only oredered one item off of the Japanese section of the menu - a Tuna/Avocado Salad - served in the avocado shell.  YUM! ($12).

My fave - classic Tom Kha - was heavy on the lime juice but still delish.
Steamed Thai dumplings were light and luscious.  (Will definitely get these again.)
Drunken Noodles were a tongue-tingling treat.  Perfectly cooked noodles - tender not mushy.

LOVE IT.

Good service.

Why not a 5?  They neeed to CLEAN the fabric ceiling drapes - they are loaded with dust.  Eew. Also the Thai iced coffee was not great - and I usually love this.  There's was clyingly sweet and the coffee was so bitter. ($3) Won;t get it again.

Meal for two (no alcohol, I think it's BYO).

Note:  I have now been back 2 or 3 more times and the dishes are all good - sushi is fresh and Thai food is great.

I finally got a chance to try Estia - I walk by it all the time.
We were part of a LARGE private event held in the huge downstairs ballroom.  You could easily have a wedding here (150 people or less is probably best - we had 187 in our gfroup and the room holds 180 max. We were crammed in like sardines).

The tables were pre-set with salad (romaine with dill dressing - quite tasty), bread, pita and hummus (yum!).

Entrees and dessert platters were served family style.  Food was delicious and excellent - especially the Branzino over "greek-style" roasted veggies - potato, zucchini, eggplant, peppers) - all were terrific.

Pasta alla Greca is an inexpensive way to feed a crowd.  Tasty - but too light on the spinach, IMHO.

Deseert of a very nutty baklava (good but not the best I've tried) and a moist bordering on wet-with-syrup walnut cake.  People either loved it or hated it - I enjoyed it, but it is WET and very, very, cloyingly sweet.

Note:  They have a private wine room for dining up tpo 14 people.
I sense a party in my future at ESTIA!

Great for pre/post theatre, too.  They know how to get you in and out.

Chambers offers a terrific brunch, and great lunches and dinners.  Our family has gone there for years.

At brunch time (which can get really crowded so go early) they have an omlette station and a very nice (and cute) young man pouring waffle batter.  It's a bit of a wait but so worth it for a fresh hot waffle that you may top with fruit or whipped topping (alas it was NOT real whipped cream).

Yum-my!

For dinner, my mom favors the petite filet which is cooked to order, and the strawberry salad.  I adore the pear salad with goat cheese and a sweet poppyseed vinaigrette.  Add a heavenly grilled, sliced duck breast from just $4.00 more.  (I add it every time!)  I have dreams about the "duck salad".  That duck breast was crispy-skinned and yet medium rare inside and soooooo tasty.

Chambers is a marvelous place to go and it's right in the heart of Doylestown.

And, Matt - the Chef - is a doll!

We had a delightful lunch for 5 that far surpassed my expectations for in-mall Chinese.  Edamame and Gyoza apps were tasty.  Lunch entrees were reasonably priced and perfectly sized.  Some of the best (basic) Chicken and brocolli - tender white meat and not gloppy.  Outstanding shrimp lo mein with thinner than usual noodles - not overloaded with onion.  NOT GREASY.  A pleasure.

Rainbow shrimp was great, too- and not skimpy on the shrimpy.
Friendly, efficient service and lovely decor.

Full bar and sushi (did not try it yet.).

We can't wait to return

This supermarket is very nice and BIG - it's basically a re-do of the old Superfresh - and now it is a GIANT.  The produce department had many GOOD selection (even in snowy January) and my little girl loves to use the label printers - where you can weigh and pre-scan your produce so that check-out moves way more smoothly.

Tom, our "bagger" and Felicia our cashier were lovely.

NICE market!

Ok yelpers and oenophiles - hold on to your hats!!!!

Moro in Wilmington - tucked away in a semi-residential area - is a real find.  The chef-owner has an ENORMOUS wine collection and the selection of wines - bottles and by the glass is astounding.

The 2-level restaurant - open for about 7 years - is scheduled for a re-model soon - but we hope they won't change the FABULOUS 5 star menu choices.

DH & I sat in a lovely round booth on the 1st floor.  The upstairs was FULL with a private wine dinner party - maybe 60 people - and LOADS of stemware.

We started with drinks - a $12 red wine for him, a Moro (Sicilian Blood Orange) Bellini (made with house Prosecco) for me - $10.

We read over the extensive menu including a mind boggling array or antipasti (for 2 or more).  Eventually we decided.  DH started with a delectable Duck Confit salad with FRESH greens, shaved parm (the good stuff) on top and a mouthful of buttery-shreds of confit in EVERY bite.  I had the tuna tartare - which was served over "smashed" avocados - so it was kinda like a tuna tartare guacamole.  It was lightly sprinkled with Hawaiian pink salt (I told them to go light and they did!!!) for a terrific crunch.  YUM-CITY!

Our 5 star entrees did not disappoint - with the daily special of proscuitto-wrapped venison over polenta for him, and a decadent papardelle with crispy pork jowl pieces and fresh green peas.

Here's the only negative (which is why I am giving them 4 stars instead of 5,) - the a/c on the first floor was simply NOT sufficient.  We were seated near the wood-burning (gorgeous) oven and we were FRYING.  I mean sweating-hot frying.

SO hot, in fact - we moved upstairs (about 10 degrees cooler) to have dessert on couches in the bar area.

Dessert was great, too - a berry creme brulle (a little too soupy) topped with a generous assortment of vanilla-sugared berries - black, blue, straw, rasp) and FLASH-FRIED mint.  You could taste the olive oil on the mint leaves.

I could have just eaten the topping.  (The creme itself was not the greatest ever - but still very tasty, indeed.)

Our server Michael is a pro - and a great guy.
The upstairs bartender whop handled us from dessert on (Grappa or Limocello, anyone?) was also very personable.

I can't WAIT to return - but you GOTTA solve the a/c problem.

Soooooooo close to a 5 star night!

No issues, quiet, clean, has a kitchen.
Easy check in and out.
Breakfast included.

Right near Mall and walking distance to Joe's Crab Shack (next door) and Capital Grille.

Our 8 year old just LOVES ruby's.  Everything from the train that runs around the track on the ceiling to the red & white decor and uniforms and the "old fashioned" feel.

It's really 3 star food - salads, burgers and fried chicken and fish - but it's a fun place to take the kiddo. Kiddo always gets a (small) milkshake. I usually splurge on a vanilla diet coke ($2.89 - but free refills).

She also loves the huge gumball machine in the front.

Service is OK - can be great if you get a good server.  (Lots of teens and college-aged folks working here).

Not bad!

3 words:

Butter Bean Honey.

'Nuff said.
Go there now!

If you can get a seat at the nearly-always-packed- counter, Profi's is a welcome respite from the bustle of RTM.  I enjoy the fruit filled crepes and get mine with banana & strawberries - no "glop".  I do not like saucey crepes and Prfi always makes mine to order.  (They do a great job - and I really enjoy the crepes themselves which are lightly sweet.

I have never tried their savory crepes - but I'm always tempted to.
I am glad they are in the Market.

Hit or miss - but tonight, thankfully I hit big on girls clothing.
And no line (But I went at 5 PM on a Tuesday).

This place can really bomb so the 4 stars is a generous offering.
But when I hit here, I hit big!

I was super hungry and Delilah's (at 30th Street Station) actually looked good to me tonight so I got a chicken leg/thigh (fried) for $3.50 and a small mac 'n cheese ($5.00) and I gotta say - they were both great.

The mac, I still think is over-rated - but the fried chicken was not over-salted this time and was greasy but not disgustingly so.  

For whatever reason - it worked better for me tonight.

Lia's is a great choice for a group luncheon.
They have catered 2 events for our group (over 200 in attendance) now and both were excellent from both a food and service perspective.

One event was at the Boothwyn location, the other at the Austin Room (Nicer - in my opinion).  They have 3 locations.

Buffet style food and an open bar (or cash bar as you prefer).
You teens/young adults passed a few (frozen) hors d'ouvres.

Excellent carving station with roast beef.
We brought in our own cakes.

Well executed - so happy.

We ate a lovely lunch here today.  Service was slow, but pleasant.  Our server, Lisa did a terrific job with our party of 8 and everything was served as ordered.

I had the Chadwick's chopped salad (minus the bacon, dresssing on the side) which was terrific.  And for $10.95 it is gargantuan.  Topped with a warm, sliced, grilled chicken breast.  The interesting addition?  Shaved white chocolate.  YUMMY.

CInnamon sweet potato fries were cold, but still addictive.

A nice place - very upscale "country club" decor.

The only complaint?  Very slow service.  Slow for a hostess to greet us, and slow to order and get our food.  Don't come here if you are in a rush.  Thankfully we weren't or I'd have to give it 2-3 stars.

Food is GREAT!

I actually like this branch of Staples - the manager Mark is very nice.  He may not be there any more.  

I get items printed here for work and also have purchased school and office supplies for my 12 year old middle schooler.

No issues.

A fine selection of meat and poultry products and friendly, attentive service, but boy do you pay for that.

I wound up getting 2 lbs of fresh chicken breast for 3.99 per lb. I also tried their steak tips.

They offer good looking prepared foods, salads, sandwiches and there us a cheerful place to eat there if you wish.

We need more butcher's so I will support them, but I pay less for my duck breasts direct from D'artagnan. So glad you carry D'artagnan, though.

I'll be back!

Chambers offers a terrific brunch, and great lunches and dinners.  Our family has gone there for years.

At brunch time (which can get really crowded so go early) they have an omlette station and a very nice (and cute) young man pouring waffle batter.  It's a bit of a wait but so worth it for a fresh hot waffle that you may top with fruit or whipped topping (alas it was NOT real whipped cream).

Yum-my!

For dinner, my mom favors the petite filet which is cooked to order, and the strawberry salad.  I adore the pear salad with goat cheese and a sweet poppyseed vinaigrette.  Add a heavenly grilled, sliced duck breast from just $4.00 more.  (I add it every time!)  I have dreams about the "duck salad".  That duck breast was crispy-skinned and yet medium rare inside and soooooo tasty.

Chambers is a marvelous place to go and it's right in the heart of Doylestown.

I can't believe D-towners have not yet tried this place.
This one's not bad.  I get a small for $3.00 and it;s full of fruit - grapes, mango, melons, oranges - and they give you a banana with your order.

This is a true treasure for Philadelphia providing much needed green space.  It needs to be better maintained and I am fearful that this year's budget cuts will adversely affect the park system in Philly.

There are wonderful mansions to explore, ball fields, picnic areas and bike trails.

Love this park.

We go to both the Aston Library and the Middletown Library.
Aston is newer (building is in a Municipal facility with nice bathrooms, etc.)

Easy to get on a computer (you can be on for 30 minutes) here.
Also the children's area is well organized.

They don't seem to have as many kids activities here as at Middletown, though.
If you have a young child (under 5 especially) check out both libraries for great FREE children's programming.

Oh - and READ.  read to your kid and have your kid read to you.

This is the "big-momma" state store on Chestnut - that is packed to the gills with both product and patrons - especially on a Thursday or Friday evening in spring/summer.

Wow.  The lines were so long you'd think they were giving it away!
I got my chilled Prosecco and out the door to Kanella I ske-daddled.

Thank goodness they were here.

Wow!!! Such good values on certain things -like Globe artichokes, Haas Avocados and mini pumpkins.  (I won't ever buy pumpkins at Linvilla again!)

I am so glad I found this place - and starting at $20 they make fruit baskets - great for holiday gifts.

Oh - and it's mobbed.  I went on a Thursday at 4:30 and the parking lot was nearly full - I can only imagine what weekends must be like.

A definite improvement!

I had a wonderful facial (although it was pricey - at $120) with Kim who is an experienced and knowledgeable aesthetician.  5 stars for Kim for sure!  Her technique is excellent and my skin looked and felt wonderful afterward.

I also had a much anticipated "Raw Earth" pedicure with Cati - a 41 year veteran who has won Best of Philly several times.  This was a 3 star disappointment.  Cati herself is a sweetheart and does excellent work - but the pedi was rushed.  She worked on me for 35 minutes max, and then the next client was there - waiting.  Cati is in such high demand that she is just waaaaaay over booked (a compliment, yes, but to the detriment of client service).  I don't care to spend such high prices for an in & out.  That said, I will come back again - but next time for the regular pedi.  $15 - $20 more for a quick application of CND Raw Earth Scrub & Mask - not worth it.

The spa itself is gorgeous and well managed.

Aside from high prices, I would now recommend Phoenix - especially for tourists.

UPDATE: Crap!  its a day - and two days later and I broke out from the facial.  Nothing major but a bunch of small raised itchy bumps (pink - not red) along the jaw line and all over the face.   I think that nifty gommage she used was too much beta-hydroxy for me.  Too bad.

Tuesdays, Wednesdays & Thursdays the townhouse is offering a HUGE 3 course meal for $21.95 (ad $5 if you want the "slab" of tender prime rib.

Plus we had a $25 gift card from a friend so - what a great night with plenty of food and stellar service from Chris (Kris?) Christie who has been a server at TowneHouse for over 16 years.

The hostess greeted us like regulars even though we're not.
I love to sit at the bar and chat and nibble of the free munchies(get there early for that).

My only complaint?  Clams casino - the topping was good but the clams themselves were not quite as fresh as they could be.  (A little fishiness detected.)

Veal parm was classicly prepared and so good.
Oh - and they now have curbside caterin (Minimun 12 people) for $14 for App or salad and entree.  I will definitely be using this for my late summer bash!

A comforting, nostalgic, huge meal.
Safe to take the parents or grandparents here, too!

Hadn't been here in a while and I was long over due.
Delicious made to order crepes.

Prices have been raised since 2009 - but that's to be expected.
Very good customer service from the gal up front and the man making the crepes.  (Choice of white or wheat flour - NICE!)

Love me a good quick crepe.

Jes had my first Jes-made glazed donught.  So fresh and perfect.
Nice!

Expensive - but you get what you pay for - decadent treats at Miel.  Not a place for an "everyday coffee" - although some will beg to differ - but I love the mini-sized cakes and tarte tatin that is old-school elegant in the true (vraiment) French tradition.

Bonne chance!

A wonderful place to stock up on Asian sauces, seasonings and ingredients (ramen, noodles, frozen treats).  Also fresh veggies & meats (a little pricey).

Love!

I was a huge C21 lover when I lived in Manhattan, so I was thrilled to see an outpost in Philly.
Snagged a Calvin Klein Dress for $70 (Marked down from $134).

We'll be back!

This seed/feed store is where I get Eukaneuba dry food and California Natural for my small breed dog.  The guy who owns/runs the place is very kind to me every time I come in.  They have better prices than Concord Pets in Aston, but not as good as the prices of the "big guys" like Petco and Pet Smart.

The store itself looks "grungy" - seed and stuff on the floor and the aisles are small and cramped - but they have EVERYTHING you could ever want for birds, cats, dogs, small mammals and horses.

I stop here on my way to Gentile's next door.
I will continue to come here as I like to chat with the owner and he now carries the MSM/Glucosamine supplements that my dog actually likes.  (And again - slightly cheaper than Concord Pets and way cheaper than Drs. Foster & Smith.)

One's experience at MAC can ary greatly depending on the make-up artist/sales person you get.  As a true product junkie, I have alot of MAC products - but in fairness I also have alot of other brands some more expensive and some less.  MAC does charge for Bridal and special occaision looks and they also offer lash application - which is great if you want it done right.

I like to get the bronzer and foundations from MAC. Once you know what color you are (I am NC15) you can not go wrong.

Better.

I have been back a few times - and they HAD the items I needed (and my very commonly prescribed medications in stock).

Friendly service.
CLEAN store that never seems crowded (at least when I go.).

Plenty of parking.

We took my 3 (now 4) year old to see the STAR WARS and Real Pirates exhibits and both were terrific. We also saw the Chronicles of Narnia - which was just ok.  This is a must-see for kids - and there is enough to keep the grown-ups interested, too.

Try to NOT go on a weekend when it is packed.  Also there were alot of broken exhibits and/or construction going on when we last visited.

Membership is a cost-effective option if you plan to visit multiple times.

BRING YOUR OWN FOOD/SNACKS - dining options are poor.

Smile Cafe has better food that Erawan which is why I am giving it 4 stars to Erawan's 3.  But I happen to like the new Thai Chef & Noodle Fusion place that just opened on Chesnut even better.  The service here is quick and friendly and the place is as big as a minute.  

Seriously - it is very tiny in here and somewhat cramped.  It's like you are eating in someones apartment,  Lunch prices are reasonable.

I ate here in the early nineties and have not yet re-visited - so this review is based on a distant - but positive memory.

A great date place!  We had seafood and lobsters.  Large portions and stiff drinks.

I will review in more detail once I visit it again in the 2000's.

A close gal-pal of mine and I both tried Tangerine for dinner for the very first time last night.  We arrived for our (early) 5:30 PM reservation just as they were opening and thus, were the only people there.

The interior is very dark/dim/romantic and GORGEOUS.  The right hand wall is completely votive-lit in small arch-shaped alcoves.

The low leather chairs were very comfy - but we are both short, petiit women - not sure if a big guy would feeel the same.

We started with non-alcoholic drinks at the bar area (iced tea and Limonata).  The custom drink menu looked great - but we were driving.

Then off to our table for dinner.
We split the YUMMY arugula salad with tasty candied almonds.

Then she (vegetarian) custom ordered a $22 veggie/side dish plate and I had the Kobe beef appetizer in lieu of a full entree ($16).  My friends fava beans and kale "casserole" were delicious. She did not like the farro much.  My app was great - but not light.  It came with a rich parmesan crema - so good you could lick the plate.

We shared 2 desserts.  As mentioned by others - DON'T MISS THE CREME BRULEE.  Ours was banana  and was accompanied by 3 house-made 'Nilla-style wafers.
 
We also got the Chocolate Chocolate Chocolate trio which was not realy that great. The mouse cake was cold and very dense, the Napoleon had delectable house-made ice cream (choloate of course) and there was a torte-of-sorts with a delicous fresh whipped cream blob on top.

Meanwhile with tax and tip our bill (no alcohol - remember) was $95.  OUCH.

Thus 4 stars.  It is great - but simply not a 5 star value.

This is a good place for a guy to take a girl to impress her. She may still not like you after the meal, but she'll have had a good time.

Oh - and it's $17 to valet park your car.  (My friend drove - I walked.)

Service was excellent.  (But it was early and we were the only guests until about 6 when a few LARGE party groups came in.)

Also -if I ever go back - I will go for cocktails "mezze" and dessert only.  The desserts are really worth it. That creme brulee is one of the best I've tried - complete with black specs of vanilla bean at the bottom, cold cream and a hot crackling sugar crust encasing the paper thin banana slices.

Kudos to the pastry chef!!!!

3 cheers for Dali (co-owner of all 3 Gianfranco's Pizza Rustica locations) and groupon user.  

Last night I took my 5 year old for Pizza here using a $16 groupon (that I paid $8 for) and I must say it was so worth it.  She had plain pizza - very, very good.  I had an excellent chicken sandwich on fresh-made bread (kinda pizza-doughy but a bit denser) with sharp provolone and delcious chopped broccoli rabe and spinach with garlic.

It was so good.

Ambience? Don't look for that here - it's a local pizza joint.
Great service and good, solid pies.

Can't wait to come back.

I also bought a gift card - they give you 10% more that you put on it and the don't expire.  So if you buy a $10 gift card you get $11 on it, $20 gets you $22 etc.

We'll be coming again for sure.

Let me preface this by saying that I am a "verge-atarian" (On the verge of vegetarianism) and even I can appreciate the carnivorours, juicy joy that is Five Guys.  The "little" burger is big enuf por moi and I load that bun with all the complimentary veggies.  (All the toppings are free - other than cheese and bacon - which are not even neccessary - given the amount of artery clogging fat already present in aforementioned juicy burgers.)

I have also never gotten the fries - as after eating the burger my grease quotient has been met for the day.

But I do occaisionally indulge in a single little burger from five guys.  It is worth the 8-10 minute cooked to order wait.

Yes.

It's worth it.

We saw "Menopause: The Musical" here a few years ago - but the sound was so loud it was deafening!!!

Otherwise - a great small theatre with decent productions at moderate prices.

Good inexpensive lunches and of course, my all-time favorite soup Tom Khai Gai.  After all these years, Thai Singha House is STILL in business (though the decor looks about 20 years old) and a great place to grab lunch when in West Philly.

I also enjoy the Pad Thai here.

NYAJ had surprisingly decent bar-food.
Our bartender, Abraham was attentive and friendly.  The $5 Fresh Fruit sangria tasted like fruit punch and was so cloyingly sweet that i did not finish it.
$5 guacamole and chips (chips were huge and freshly made) had bland guacamole.  Tasty - but not at all spicy.  More like Avocado dip.

The best was the entree - a Pappardelle loaded with asparagus and kale in a garlicky pesto sauce.  Very tasty and the grilled chicken on top (you can get this dish sans chix) was juicy and perfectly grilled.

I'd come back here - but with Harvest across the street (which I much prefer - but it's more expensive) I won't be rushing back.

All in all this place is a BIG improvement from the Outback Steakhouse that was in this spot years ago.

Upgrading to 4 stars based on FANTASTIC Customer service by both the pharmacist/pharmacy tech (lady in the back) and the nice young lad out front.

DD & I came here with a 25% EVERYTHING in the store (excluding sale items - which excluded alot) and literally took a cart (a CART - sho does tha?) and loaded up with Advil, Vitamins, Hair dye, Cosmetics, Cleaning products, all sorts of stuff.

We snagged a great deal.
And the 2 aforementioned CVS staffers helped us find it all.

And the nice young lad up front even processed a return of one item a few hours later when I realized I bought something we didn't need.

Wow.
My mid is changed on this location.
For the better!

Little Italy delivered oodles of pies (Plain cheese, mushroom and veggie) for a large block party I attended.  Very good pizza.  "Class" neapolitan pies - not too thin (not pizza-on-a-cracker) not too thick.

Very good.

An old-fashined five 'n dime style "everything" store - stationary, household goods, kid stuff, party goods, wrapping paper, tools, socks.  A vast variety that is as close as Media, PA gets to the "Vermont COuntry Store".  A note of nostalgia and fun shopping here and a sweet lady at the cashier in the evening time on weekdays.

Louis B. gets it right!
There is also a Deal Stationary store - 1/2 a block down the street.  (Same Owners)

FUN!

Bucks County Ladies?  This is the place.  Like a one-stop shop for Bridal and wedding needs.  Of course, the main attractin is the bridalboutique with dresses for the bride, Maid of Honor, Bridesmaids and MOMs too.  Even flower girl dresses.

But this ain't no David's bridal.  (And also, it ain't Kleinfelds)  Be prepared to pay for such wonderful personalized service.

I did NOT purchase my gown here - but I did get my shoes and alot of great accessories here.

Also a good place to go for proms and evening dresses.

Oh, and its been around for-eh-ver.

This family-owned and run outpost of Lee's is a good, quick option for hoagies, cheese-steaks (try as a wrap) and sandwiches of all sorts.  They also make wings, fries and a few appetizer/snack items.  Chips and soda, of course.

Healthy?  No.
Well run?  yes!  The owner/owner's wife is a doll and has been running the place for 17 years.

Walls are covered with sports memorabilia.

Love me some Lee's from time to time.

I am very pleased to report that things are improving at "the Pit".
Better tasting hummus (supposedly now sourced by Sabra Salads) and fresher toppings.

I tried the Greek God (no onions, no feta) and it was very good.

My faith is restored in the Pita Pit! Keep it clean, keep it fresh  - and I'll be back for sure.

Hooray!

We love you, Chris!  (And Chris's son.  I forgot your name.)
The staff at Oh! Shea's treat our group like family - which is why we'll be having our annual holiday party here for the 5th year in a row.

Reasonably priced, tasty food and good strong drinks (and beer).
Classic Rock - with lots of Rolling Stones for Maryellen and Tom on the jukebox.

It all adds up to a fun, fun, fun event!

Peter Mac does it again - with great assistance from Joey - they have opened a catering/take out place with terrific Italian (and American) sandwiches, platters and catering.

We sorely need this.

Do not miss the smoked wings and ribs - fan-flipping-tastic.

We attended the Grand Opening event on 10/1 and all the food was terrific - especially the sides of roasted red peppers and brocolli rabe.

I am thrilled and delighted that La Porta and now La Porta Via (next door) are here!

My friends have come here and are regulars - and have been for years.
Chris and the other bartenders know them and what they like to drink - and that having the Rolling Stones on the sound systems is a must.

The french dip sandwiches hit the spot after a long night out when you are hungry and the drinks are moderately priced and strong enough.

Love coming here and relaxing in a non-chi-chi atmosphere.

We have worked with Linda and Maureen at State Farm for our auto, renters - and now home owners insurance policies.  So far - everything have been very smooth and Maureen, especially, has answered all of my questions.

The lunch buffet offers many choices - including several hot entrees both vegetarian and with chicken.
The Naan is fresh and the breads baked to order (Roti, Poori - not on menu just ask) and delicious.

We had a large group of 10 here for lunch.
Very nice - and new.  Clean.

Can't wait to come back.

I finally got around to trying Polaris (thatnks for the recommendation, Spa Girl!) yesterday.  I got a "regular" manicure ($16) a "callus remover" pedicure ($47) and 20 minutes of chair massage while my nails dried.

There are 6 pedi-thrones and 8 manicure tables at this colorful (green & orange) cheerful and CLEAN spa.  The pedicure I got was very good - not a holy grail by any means but it was throrough with a nice scrub and massage.  for $15 extra (too high if you ask me) I got the "callus removing treatment" which basically was a bit of high % glycolic in plastic wrap for 10 minutes.  Big whoop.

They also have an even MORE expensive ($62) SPA pedicure and the highest priced, POLARIS SPA pedicure (which - for another $10 - making the total a whopping $72 - you get a paraffin dip.)  Double whoop-de-doo.

Now don't get me wrong - I am a pedi-afficionado and these are nice treatments - but the price points when you add them all up seem a bit above the norm.  They also have a weird pricing structure where you get a $1-$2 discount if you pay cash.

I didn't have enough cash to cover all my treatments so I paid some with cash and some on my debit card (Including a $10 tip - I spent $98.00).
NOTE:  You can not put the tip on your credit card - so bring SOME Cash with you.)

The lady who did my pedicure, Wanty, also did my manicure (very good, by the way) and and the chair massage (not great.)

I would definitely go back here for nail services but no way I would book a body massage nor a facial here as I doubt these girls are estheticians.  What they are - is nail technicians.

And decent ones, at that.

Good find!

Had not been to Firebirds in quite a while, maybe years?  Lunch with a corporate party of 4 was very good with stellar service (it was not crowded at 12:15 on a summer Friday) and solid food.

Deviled eggs with a candied bacon garnish were indulgent and spicy. (The fresh jalapeno was strong and kicking.)

My entree was a simple grilled salmon, served with broccoli and mixed veggies (zucchini, carrots, onions, sweet red peppers and yes, more broccoli).  The fish was done just to my liking. 

Colleagues dishes all looked great.

I would definitely come here again and it us great for a corporate event or even a date night.  

Great Lunch! Kudos to Jessica and Phil who served us.

Beautiful restaurant with ambiance and a young, good-looking, friendly staff. Bar is gorgeous and colorful.
Our group of 3 enjoyed the $23 Three-course feast and $80 kids meal- 1/2 a rack of ribs.

I can see how this is likely "formula" cooking and college kids are running the joint - but they are running it well.  We enjoyed the crab cake app and grilled salmon.  Many items are way too salty (smoke flavoring??) though.

Good stuff and strong drinks, especially the ($10) double black diamond martini (akin to the Flyin' Hawaiian) which is basically pineapple juice infused vodka.

I love coming here for an old-school memory.  I first came here with my parents as a child and had shirley temples and Chicken Cordon Bleu in the '80's.  I have been to luncheons here and weddings - but to simply come and dine off the regular menu is the best.

Great service and conutry-style decor. (Could use a bit of a re-fresh)

I will bring my daughter now!  Shirley Temples all around!

Oh - and it is beautiful for a Christmas or Winter dinner - lots of twinkly lights all around,

Better than the Merriam - but it ain't the Kimmel Center.
Still, it's a grand old-time theater and we have seen numerous productions here, including Jersey Boys.

Well staffed.  Crowded ladies rooms.

Our party of 9 (6 kids, 3 adults) received great service from Nicole - and ordered a wide variety of pizza, sandwiches, pasta and salads.  Food was very good - my 12 year old enjoyed an enormous plate of penne a la vodka.

Linguine with *white) clam sauce is a classic preparation with plenty of garlic and red pepper flakes.  Whole baby clams were plentiful and tasty.  Caprese salad was solid. Pizza was average in my opinion - but nothing bad about it - just a plain cheese pie for some of the kids.

All in all - a good experience.

This is a review for the event space and the Downton Abbey exhibit.
We were at Winterthur for a private event during the evening so we did not get to tour the grounds - but the museum was opened late especially for our group/.  Awesome!

I knocked off 1 star for the "tented" seating area - not enough seating and also very drafty - so spots were over heated and others very cold.

For that reason alone I would not have a winter event here. (And not a wedding.)
I bet in summer/late spring this is a better idea.

Boy, those DuPonts had bank!

OK, now that I have tried Crepe Maker in 30th Street station I am even more impressed with Profis.  The crepe batter here is far suprior - much more flavorful.  I am lovin' the crepes at Profi's.

It's hard to get a seat - but once I snag I stool you best believe I am ordering!!!

Practitioners are good but it can take for.eh.ver to get an appointment and they have no evening nor weekend hours.

I now see Teresa (Dani left) for my routine skin-checks.
I also have visited the "Cosmetic" side once.  You can get things like Cool-Sculpt and Botox there as well as super-pricey facials.

I will continue to use this practice but know that the administration is tricky.

Honeygrow is now on my heavy rotation for work lunches and I try to stick to salads and limit the dressing and carbs.  Service is good and ingredients are fresh and tasty.  Lots of choices.

Improved performance on new app.  YAY!!!!

Shout out to Steve who works the lunch rush - a very pleasant man.

I am upping this location to 4 stars (even though it is more of an urban 3 star location).  I got in and out of there on BLACK FRIDAY WEEKEND - and the super-friendly checkout dude "K", even scanned coupons for me - when I had forgotten mine.

We got $1.00 sale ink pads for 33 cents after the discounts.
We also got lots of great worsted wool yarn and knitting needles (Needing Knittles) for my 7 year old budding fiber artist.

I hadn't been to Smile Cafe in a long time - and got the Pad Thai lunch special as take out (it's a small place).  Very good value - a small (iceberg) salad, two little dumplings and a nice serving of Pad Thai with 2  (yes only 2) Shrimp in it.

Hey - for $8.50 including tax - who cares?

Tasty and cheap.

Kudos to Tony (executive Director) and Andrea (Director of Educational Programs) for a wonderful private event and tour they hosted for our group.

We even got to bake in the (10 year old replica of a) colonial bake oven.

It is so interesting to learn the history of the mill (founded in 1704) and watch as the water wheel turns the corn into corn meal (available for purchase).

The pond is stocked with trout ($5 to fish - including kids).
The grounds are gorgeous and we even saw a nice fat bullfrog.

October 1 is the fall festival - DON'T MISS IT.

I did not find the staff here abrasive at all - quite the opposite.
They even have a summer camp.

Definitely check out the Newlin Grist Mill.

Excellent choices but yes it gets pricey - especially the honey bar which is over $6 to $9 depending on all the fruit you add.

The stirfries are tasty but sodium and sugars (carbs) are high unless you opt for lettuce cups (no noodles, no grains).

I will be back.  And bringing more money.

Very clean store and friendly staff.  I spent over $11 - no beverage for a beef-based stirfry.  (At Qdoba next door it's about $8.50)
Trying to watch carbs so avoid the "sweet soy" - loaded with sugar.
Tried the (spring only) pesto.  Very good.  I wonder how many carbs that one has?

TJ Maxx can be a pick-through situation where you can hit it big or miss.
Often look for shoes, women's clothing, hosiery (small stock here), cookware (some are good deals on open stock - name brands) and even pet supplies (check the dates on anything edible for your pet or for you).

Excellent for hostess gifts (fancy wrapped soaps, candles, etc for $5 or less).  Check the clearance areas carefully.

Do not come here if you are in a hurry - especially over the lunch hour and/or during the holiday frenzey, as you will not make it back to your office in time.  The line for cashier and/or parking lot madness can eat up time.

Come when you can wander the aisles and pick through clothing racks item by item.  When you miss, you miss, but when you hit you can hit BIG at TJ Maxx (Calvin Klein dress for under $40!!!  Coach loafers for $50, etc.) 

Oh, and natch - Delaware is tax free so if you are from NJ or PA this is a great reason to choose this particular TJ Maxx - right over the state line.

I am not a pretzel lover - but man, these are good.  I eve like the pretzel dogs here.  The dough is just perfect.  The salt ratio is right on!  Chewy but not tough, wheaty flavor and FRESH out of the oven.

Tip:  only come to this brnach - Philly Soft Pretzel Factory has alot of chain branches - this one (as grubby as it seems) is best.

I have never been to the "skin care" (spa) side, but I see a Dermatologic NP ( not a Dr. but she is excellent) for routine skin (mole) analysis.  She also got me some Rx retinoids which I needed and Hydroquinone for brown spots.

I see Dani (Danielle) and love her - but getting an initial appointment took MONTHS - so if you had a true skin emergency i am not sure how they'd handle it.

I also took my 10 year old here to check out a "suspicious" mole - she saw a different female NP (mostly female practitioners and staff here.)

Lovely office with a LARGE waiting room with coffee & water available.  (NICE!)
Easy check in and check out - but getting that FIRST appointment takes patience.  Oy Vey!

Meanwhile if you need a derm - check them out.

Karla's has been a New Hope institution for eh ver (well maybe not quite as long as Jon & Peters) and it draws out the tourists a-plenty.  The food is good and it has typical New Hope prices.

The drinks are also mixed well and they offer specials - summertime grets a little crazy - but a winter weekday is the best time to go.

Great mixed drinks.

Believe it or not - Christmas Village manages to mix cool and kitsch and still come out Kool.

My little girl and I have been here for 2 consecutive years - and this year visited 3 times.  It's a convenient stop after school for us.

We have bought custom-made (pricey) stockings, doy toys and several treats.  She loves the German run candy shop stand with the chocolate covered fruit.  They even had 1/2 chocolate covered apples available one day - which was great because the whole apple is ginormous and far to much for her.

We also tried a crepe from teeh crepe and waffle making lady. Nice lady - mediocre crepe.  Oh well.  Perhaps next time a waffle?

There are also musical acts playing - mostly in the evening.
Such a fun place. - Oh and don't miss the Nutcracker tent (it's heated!!!) filled with ornaments and (pricey) nutcracker themed items.

5 star service from Sally and Ronnie (a 24 year veteran server - she is amazing) and 4 or 5 star food - but the noise level was deafening - and we dined at 5:30 PM (by 6:15 the place was packed).

Elegant (albeit pricey) cocktails at the bar (I had a Strawberry Basil martini that was delicious) followed by an elegant dinner, complete with an enormous ($130) chilled seafood display that was a meal in itself.  Crab Cocktail here is a treat!

Dinners included filet mignon, ribeye (overly sauced, for my taste - but the guys liked it), lobster roll (very good but not better than Cape Cod) and crab/lobster stuffed "sachetti" pasta.

Enjoyable desserts like fried donuts, creme brulee (yum) and buttermilk ice cream (very good).

Kudos to the chef and servers.

Not a ton of variety and no sushi for lunch time but for $7, you just can't beat it.  The lunch special is a bowl with your choice of protein.  Also you can get good coffee/espresso drinks here and even  breakfast 

There are more choices for dinner time, so I will need to come back then.

Lunch was a good value.

Stopped at this Wawa at 10 or 11 PM on our way home from Hershey with a sleeping kid in the car.  Ran in and out.  No issues.

Snacks, drinks, smoke and coffee.
Well - no smokes in front of the kiddo.  Ever.

Wawa.  There when u need them.
Grateful.

Your basic, big and well-stocked Pet Smart with everything our cat (and dog) need,  We get food, toys, treats and supplements here.

No issues.

Clean, large and great for walking, biking, dog walking and especially with the kids at CHRISTMAS when they have a ton of lights and lit trees.

Fun.

Delectable donuts holes - laden with sugar and oil.  Caloric BOMBS of goodness (or badness).
So melt-in-your-mouth crack-dictive.

Food is great - margaritas (at least the $2.99 house special Lime Marg on Wednesdays ) are awful.

Great nopalitas salad (Marinated cactus leaves) - fresh veggies and a light dressing.
Shrimp Ceviche was HUGE and tasty.

Serive at the beginning was great - but the server messed something up with my dining pal's credit card and we waited, and waited, and waited to pay our bill.

Nevertheless, we'll be back.

Muy delicioso!
My 9 year old has come here about once a year since the age of 3 and takes a cute picture next to the Rocky Statue.  A fun yet touristy stop.

Still going strong and now it is bigger and bigger and blends in with the other Christmas Market across the street.  Lots to see and browsing around was fun (and cold) but there was nothing I felt compelled to purchase.  A big plus - the heated tent where you can thaw out with a glass of wine or cup of (mediocre) coffee.  Very loud and crowded in there on a Thursday before Xmas.

This is a BIG, clean, super Wawa - with a gas station and tons of convenience food items, smokes, cold drinks, magazines, a deli counter with touch-screen sandwich ordering and lots of things now common to most Wawas.

It's convenient for the guys at the office, so we come here often.
I usually get a Jr. or Shorti Hoagie.

Whoop-dee-doo!

It's fun to poke around a REAL bookstore (not Barnes & Noble or Boring's ahem - I mean, Border's).

The people here are very nice - family owned and run - and they can recommend a great book or 3.

It's tight and cramped - but if you are here without your kids and NOT in the tourist-packed summer or Xmas season, It's a great place to just meander around and read.

And they have a cat!

A great source for nuts, candies, spices, teas and roasted coffees.  A fantastic find in Ardmore.  Walnuts, pecans, macadamia, almonds, all types of flavored/shelled pistachios. 

So great.

Um, but not if you have a nut allergy. 

Love.

Hit or miss - but when you hit, you can hit BIG.  As in designer boots for $18 big.  Or Like-new catalog clothing for $7 big.

Come prepared to slowly route through racks and racks of "no"to find the good stuff.
And - drop off your lightly-worn goodies for CASH here too!

Gorgeous park - and a horse farm with pony rides in the middle.
Riding trails, hiking, biking, nature.  Paved pathways, a few benches.

Great for the entire family.

Lotus is cost prohibitive for my family - but it is also another example of "you get what you pay for" in that the quality of ingredients and execution of preparation is spot-on!  (Especially in Summer and fall when the harvest locally is in abundance).

If someone else is paying?  I am all-in.  But with entrees from $16 (burger) to $30, after you add a $5 - $20 small plate or snack - it is pricey.

Also it is BYOB but they have an amazing selection of teas and infusions.
My $3 Genmaicha (Japanese Barley tea) was perfection,

Yes, I love it here but no, I can't come often.

While the food (I get the breakfast scrambler - no tots) is just OK, Austin behind the counter is a gem.  He has personality to spare and is so charming.  A big shout out to Austin.

Also - if they offered soup (tomato soup here is good) in the AM (yes, really) I would get it.

Another fabulous outpost of El Limon (I have also been to the Conshy and Fraser locations) and it is just great.  BIG-a$$ burritos (wet or dry or in a bowl), delicious Al Pastor, free margaritas if you dine in, friendly service, fresh guac.

LOVE me some El Limon.

Do not miss their Al Pastor - just enough pineapple and succulent pork.
So good.
Green Top - right next to red top - is a "touristy" landscaping/floral/plant place.  Fun to browse around but also tourist prices.

I was in this area for an 8 AM appointment and desperately needed coffee.
Target (Starbucks) does not open until 8, but Ruby's is open at 7 AM and does a VERY nice breakfast.

I had coffee and a very nice "veggie" eggs Benedict with spinach, tomato and avocado.  The hollandaise likely came from a mix - but i asked for it on the side and it was pretty good anyway.

So after tax and tip - I blew $15 on breakfast but it was delicious and a welcome respite.

Excellent service - the place was nearly empty - just me and one other table at 7:05 AM!

My 17 year old and I were both here for different things over the last few months - Xrays, CT scans, MRIs - they offer it all.

Basic Xrays are walk-in.

Very nice technicians.  The front desk ladies were very nice to me - but you must be polite to them - they are super busy and over worked.
They all need a big raise.

I am so grateful to MMI for providing much needed diagnostics for me and my kid.

This is a large, clean, well-run starbuck on the corner of Marsh & Silverside roads in Wilmington.  We usually stop by in the morning - and even at the height of the AM rush, the lines move quickly.

Fourbucks, Charbucks, whatever yoiu call it - it's nice tohave one around when you need it.

Especially in the Culinary wasteland of North Wilmington.

This is THE Starbucks - smack dab in the middle of New Hope's tourist district.  Right over the bridge from Lambertville.

And while, I tuly believe that "friends don let friends drink Charbucks" (or "Fourbucks") this one is not bad.  Nice customer service and the line (if there is one) moves quickly.

As Fourbucks goes - this is one of the better locations.

An older Library with a helpful staff including "Ginger" at the front counter.
Restrooms are NASTY.  Truly awful, but the meeting room is spacious and the different areas of the library (Teens, Little kids Adults, Music, Computers) are just fine.

Support our libraries!!!!  They are sorely needed.

While I did not wind up purchasing my frames here (too $$$), I was very impressed with the high level of customer service.  (Drat - I can't remember the name of the nice lady who helpeed me.)  It's a great place - too bad I can't afford it at the moment.

Not just gyros!  In fact, when we walked in late (8:45 ish) on a Wednesday night we did not even order Gyros.  The Avgolemono soup (one of my favorite soups of all time) was good and the Horiatiki Salad was fresh and fabulous.  It reminded me of the Horiatiki at Kanella (Cypriot) in Center City and that is a GOOD THING.

Service with a smile was stellar and the pastitsio and stuffed eggplant (with bechamel, baby!) were very filling but also very, very well made.  Classics.
Decor could use a refresh (thus no 5th star). Also front entrance is NOT compliant for elderly/physically challenged.

Just like Ya ya would have wanted it.

Can't wait to return.

4 stars for the food and 5 for the entertainment.  Maria herself - who had a cooking show on PBS for years - was in the kitchen when we came here for Mew year's Eve 2006.  (I was wondering why it took me so long to yelp her.)

We had a very enjoyable evening.  The best part were the home-made meatballs and the (keep it on the d.l.) tray of limoncello and cordials passed after the meal.

My only regret is that we have not yet returned.
We will!

Please note:  I came back here a second time on June 16 and had a mani & pedi for just $25.00.  Anthony himself did it and it was very good.  4 solid stars!

I had a good experience yesterday at 5 PM at Nails by Anthony.  A man (who I presume is Anthony) greeting me nicely when I arrived (walk-in) and a lovely lady, "Mimi" agreed to do my manicure.

I told her I wanted a "regular" manicure and 10 minutes of chair massage while my nails dried.  She said "Massage 10 minutes? OK?"

OK.

So the manicure progresses nicely - she does a good job and then she does a fabulous hand and arm massage.  For a really long time.
Evidently she thought I wanted the "spa manicure" which includes everything from the $12 "regular" manicure and adds 10 minutes of hand & arm massage.

So at the end while my polish is drying - she reluctantly gave me a bout 3-4 minutes of a lackluster b.s. back rub.

OK.  No big deal.  I kind of expect b.s. massages at nail joints.
Next time - honestly, skip any kind of extra massage - not worth the $8-$10.

I will however, be back for manicures - at $12 it was worth it.  The place is new and clean with 6 mani tables and 5 huge NEW pedi thrones.

I wonder, however, as is so often the case, if this place will be just as nice 6-12 months from now.

I kinda doubt it.

Expect to see a 1-2 star downgrade in a year.
They are new and trying to get your business - so take advantage while you can.

Also - they have ONE GOOD package deal (Most of their "packages" offfer no discount) - for $55.00 you get a regular mani, regular pedi, eye brow wax, lip wax and 10 minutes of b.s. massage.

Please note - I did not try the waxing here - I only trust my eyebrows to Jennae or Cara at bodyrest - but if you feel like taking a chance on a cheapie brow wax - this may just be the place.

This is a good alternative to Rittenhouse nails or the dreaded Gomo.
Again - try it NOW while they are still new (open for 3 months so far.).
You can get them now at the Media farmers market!  Whoo-hoo.  REAL Canele!
