OK, so it's still MEHxican - and the salsa and chips taste like tostios and old el paso, but the servers now know us - and we now know EXACTLY what to order.  The servers and cooks here work HARD and are very gracious to us.

I always get the #75 burrito with chicken instead of beef (I don't like the shredded beef here for whatever reason), guac on the side.

Fresh brewed iced tea.

I'm set for my "usual" business lunch - and most days we can get in, out and back to work in an hour.

We'll be back - because we have few other choices.

Sing it Black Crowes Style...

If I had a RE-ME-DY...

...anyhow - enough singing.  But remedy is a reason to sing.  I am so glad I can get a nice hot cup of greem gunpowder or an iced Jasmine in Summertime.  I love fine teas - and Remedy is a cute place to get some.

I am contually surprised and delighted by QVC (and I do not fit the profile of your typical at-home shopper).  I do not shop with them often but the jewelry, clothing and cookware items I have purchased over the years have all been high quality items and for good (to great) prices.

The Studio Park office complex is interesting to tour, and it's right in my own back yard!

Still very pricey - but great new digs and dining options.
We'll be back!

The Pizza Wagon comes to my office in Chestrbrook, PA about once a month or so.  (Kinda wish it was more as it is a culinary wasteland around these parts).  For $10 you can pick from 5-6 pies and for one person they are huge.  I think the $10 also includes a drink - can of soda or bottle of water).

I like the Spinach pie (it is supposed to be white but i asked for sauce and they did it!).

Wow - a beaders paradise right in our own (new) Media back yard.
Classes for kids and adults and a VAST selection of beads and beading supplies (books, wire, fishing line, clasps)/

Can't wait to take my artsy 7 year old here.
Very good jewish-style deli food - and they even have half-sour pickles.  YAY!  Not cheap - but nt horribly expensive either.  So glad they are here.

Thank you! Thank you! Thank you ! Yelp for introducing me to DnA.
They are a great find - and if I lived in NoLibs I certainly would be a regular client of Rich.

He did a great color for me - single process and a decent cut.
I have to say that my jury is still out of the cut - as I need to let it be for a few days.  I think it may make my face look fat.

UPDATE:  OK - I am officially not happy with the cut.  But I love the color.
I am scared to call them and tell them?  I don't want to downgrade them to 3 stars - as they really are a 4-5 star establishment.  I just don't like this cut at ALL.  (Still lovin' the color though.)

The spa is clean and gorgeous - and although it is nearly 2 years old - it looks BRAND spankin' new.  Excellent choices in color scheme (blue & white) and good design elements.

My only reason for not giving it 5 stars was the weird (somewhat icy) vibe I got from the assistant (It feels demeaning to say shampoo girl - as I am certain she does MUCH more than that.).  

The receptionist was cute and friendly and had GREAT HAIR.
I got some serious hair envy from pretty much everyone who works there.

I will return.  (So I hope the assistant won't totally hate me if she reads this review.)

I would DEFINITELY go here for color.  Rich knows his stuff!  (And his mom - who just happened to be in that day for highlights) is a sweetie.

I attended and spoke at a conference here but did not stay overnight in the hotel part.  The conference facilities were very nice, well-equipped and comfortable.  The breakfast and breaks had an abundance of well-stocked beverages and treats.

I would definitely consider having a conference here.

This is our go-to Wawa all summer long whenever we are at the Ridley Park Swim Club - you can walk there!  My kid and assorted friends load up on snacks, candy and cold beverages.

A g-d-send,

I love whole paycheck, er, i mean Whole Foods.
I stopped in when the store was very empty (YAY!) and the breakfast buffet was still up - so no hot foods for me.

I got a thing of Whole Foods Guacamole ($4.99 for a small) - so delicious, a $7 tub of mixed berries (yikes) and a $12.95 genji sushi salmon plate.  

Funny how just a few tasty snacks add up here.

All were terrific.

After we get our pet supplies at Tobin's (Feed Store), it's so tempting to stop for a breakfast sandwich or lunchtime feast.

Classic food served by friendly(mostly female) staff.
Cute place and good, simple, "safe" food.

In the heart of the Gayborhood is Cafe Twelve.
Plenty of comfy chairs, cafe tables - big windows that open in warmer weather and most importanly - top quality coffee drinks.

I had a cafe au lait (made with brewed coffee - not espresso) and it was smooth and delicious.

Super nice guys running the place, too. - And 2 fairly clean restrooms.

I'll be back!

This used to be "The Barn" and it had screens named Silo, Paddock and Hayloft - and other barn-like names.

Now it has greatly expanded to service the ever increasing amount of movie-goers.

It's a nice theatre with fairly clean environs.  I have great nostalgic memories of this theatre from when my friends used to work here in Jr. High & High School.

We took our 5 y.o. here on an un-crowded HOT summer Sunday at 2 PM and the a/c felt great.  Plus she sat still for the entire show.

This updated and upgraded review is based on the HAIR SALON (not the spa services.)

I received a coupon for a free haircut - and figured - for Free?  You bet I'll try it.

I was able to get a receptionist on the phone and she politely booked me for a 10 AM cut with Rudy - who is a doll.  Linda who shampooed my hair was really sweet, too.

I am happy with my cut (would have cost $55) and left a nice tip.

I may very well return!!!  Rudy is a sweet guy.

I love Beans (it's a chain) and the newish D-town location is a great addition to an already cutesy and affluent town.  You can snag dermalogica, OPI, Essie, Fekkai and many other well-known (and a few lesser known) beauty brands here.

A teeny salon-ette is in the back but it needs some tweaking to get it up and running.

Can't wait to come here for a quick wax.

Friendly staff so far.
Lovin' it!

Stopped in here to do a small shop (about $50 worth) because it was on the way home and I really loathe the local Acme.  This Giant is pretty nice - I vacillate between 3 and 4 stars.

Giant - for me - is my go-to for non organic food and select household goods.  I usually like Whole Paycheck (aka Whole Foods) and Trader Joes - but for low cost staples - I gotta trust Giant.

We'll be back.

I dither back and forth between 3 & 4 stars based on each experience.  This time a gal-pal and I dined in and shared Chips & Pico (Not enough pico for that big pile of chips) for $7 and 2 orders of 2 tacos.  2 shrimp and 2 pork.

The tacos were fresh tasting and the pork ones were LOADED with pork and avocado spread. 
The shrimp tacos were very skimpy with 2 small shrimp in each taco.  Delicious crema and radishes.

Next time?  I am getting extra pcio and skipping the shrimp tacos.

I am contually surprised and delighted by QVC (and I do not fit the profile of your typical at-home shopper).  I do not chop with them often but the jewelry, clothing and cookware items I have purchased over the years have all been high quality items and for good (to great) prices.

The Studio Park office complex is interesting to tour, and it's right in my own back yard!
Ettore is closed.  Larissa is now at Tommi on 7 & Chestnut.

This is now my go-to Strarbucks and is nearest on my way to my new job.  It's a 4 star place but I am knocking a star off gfor the horrendous parking situation.  It is located next to the Paoli train station which is jam-packed night and day and clearly there is just not enough parking for ommuters and locals alike.

I parked in a seafood restaurant next door and walked over.

Meanwhile, my Grande Nonfat Caramel macchiato (at $4.82) was pricey but delicious.

Nice gals running the show.
I wonder where they park???

Excellent Service, Crappy Parking

Having been to the original shake shack and a satellite NYC location before, I knew what I was getting when I walked in (and out) of the Philly Shake Shack a few weeks back.  12:30 is NOT the time to go.

So today I was wiser and went at 11:40 AM.
Perfect.  No line.  2 minute wait for a single burger with lettuce and tomato (no Shack-mayo for me) and a Half 'n Half made with STRAWBERRY lemonade.  I also got a taste of the Red Velvet Custard.  It was uber-rich and loaded with cake pieces and cream cheese icing.  The taste was enough - I did not need to get a cup of that caloric-disaster.

Meanwhile, my burger was great (I also enjoy the burgers at 500 degrees and when I've got cash to burn, Village Whiskey).

And they don't call me the "Empress of the Arnold Palmer" for nothin'.  That half 'n half was just what I needed.

Counter lady (I can't remember her name) was lovely and the guy cleaning the tables on the floor was a doll.  Execllent service (prior to the thundering herd that arrives at noon).

Do not come here during peak times.
It's night and day.

Oh - and they were selling a $9 (NINE Dollar!!!) artisinal Brooklyn chocolate bar at the front counter.  Come ON!  It can't be THAT good????

I have been a big fan of Sushi Nami's Paoli location for lunches (and the occasional dinner) for a while so I was eager to try the Wayne Location on Route 30 not far from my office.

Yumi was there (she is usually in Paoli) and  the place is new - but has the exact same menu.  Lunch specials are still there and still great at $14.00 for the salmon lunch.  The pork dumpling soup is a great winter treat - hot and fresh with 3 pork gyoza and a bunch of veggies.

Love it here.
Will be back!

Moved to 2040 Market and is now called Fine Wines & Good Spirits.
Much nicer - huge brand-new store.

Clean and gorgeous.

Lots of wines - less in the spirit realm (but Total Wine & Liquor in Delaware has spoled me forever).

Convenient to my work.  (Yay.)

Delicious food - great crocks of French Onion and BIG salads (even the side salad) chock full of goodies.  Service from Nicole was wonderful and my half coffee-half cocoa topped with a mountainous plume of whip was marvelous.

A decent selection of brews on tap from dark, chocolatey stouts to pale lagers and everything in between.

Moderate prices.
Historic architecture and a beautiful bar.

Lovely lunch. Can't wait to come back.

We love and support Greensgrow.  My 5 year old's class took a wonderful field trip here - and kids need to know about farming and Urban farming.

It is very important that we support locavore ventures and sustainable agriculture.

Go, Grennsgrow!

A good place to see live music.  Yes, the restrooms are pretty bad - but not the worst I've seen, by far.  And yes, there are copius amounts of drunk people - which increases based on the bands that are playing.

A nice big bar.

This is a fun artisan gallery.  Great for gift ideas and just poking around and gawking.  Colorful glass, bright pieces, jewelry, wearable art, I love it here.  Bring money.  And avoid the high tourist season when it's packed.

And please, don't bring a very small child who might break something.

Unlike, my good friend "Fish", who evidently had a bad experience here - I never did.  Back in the '90's we'd go here after work (I worked at Accents & Images when the original owner, Joe, was still alive.  Or we'd get coffee at Granpa Hicks - which was also great.

Meanwhile, when the throngs of NY tourists get you down, take a break with a slightly overpriced, but very tasty coffee drink here at house of coffee.  They have snacks, too - and good iced tea choices during the summer.

A welcome respite from the rest of Peddler's Village.

Next time we'll make an appointment.

A friend & I showed up on an extremely busy Thursday before the July 4th holiday weekend.
They were PACKED.  At least a 40 minute wait for the 2 of us to be seen.  (She for a mani, i for a gel mani.)

Gals were friendly enough - but they were multitasking for sure!

We'll stop back another time.  (We decided to try Gateway nails and wound up leaving there also - what a mistake.  Gateway Nails manager was soooooo rude).

At least the ladies are friendly here.

4 stars for the food.  I try to ignore the surroundings.  Great Duck.  And hands-down best steamed dumplings.  LOVE 'em.  Wonton Duck Soup can be a little greasy - but man, it's a tasty indulgence.

Oh - and watching my 4 year old scarf down 3 different types of dumplings was precious.  She sat at the counter like a pro.  She tried the shrimpdumplings, wonton (sans soup they are very tasty) and the steamed chicken dumplings.

Can't wait to take her back here.

While waiting for Jewelers Row to open this morning, I strolled by DELICATESSEN - at the site of the former Kibitz in the City at 7th & Chestnut.

Now under new (and friendly) management, Delicatessen offers Jewish-Deli style food with a twist.  I ordered the Side Kick Sampler ($12) to get a taste of 4 popular items.  All were excellent but the real standout was the home-made cheese blintz.

Jill was a great server and I can't wait to go back and try "Bubby's Kitchen Sink Pho".

Check this place out - it sure ain't Kibbitz any more.  It's way better.

3 star food - maybe 4 star if you order selectively.
I had a very nice salad (sans calorie bomb of fried tortilla bowl) with Avocado and shrimp.  Lovely.  Elote served on or off the cob with Chipotle mayo and Cotija cheese.

Friendly service, colorful decor and kid friendly.

Next time I am getting a margarita for sure! (And there WILL be a next time.)

My little girl and I are big fans of the Nicoise (we get it with shrimp instead of canned tuna) at Saladworks.

It's one of the best ways i get overtly get her to eat veggies.

Now, grant it, many Saladworks are kinda, well, rusty & gross.
If the lettuce looks bad - don't bother.  But at the Montgomeryville location (technically North Wales, I guess) the Salad's good!  The eatin's good, too.

SCORE!

Plus there is a Baja Fresh nearbu for hubby.

Not sure I can impart anything better or different than the other reviewers.
I liked but did not LOVE the soup I picked (should have tried a few more samples first).
I chose Crab & Corn (mostly corn) Chowder,  and it was OK.

The salad (1/2 is plenty big for me) a Cobb was fresh and good.

Weird ordering lines.

Saladworks with a yuppie vibe.
About $11 - with NO DRINK.

The hubby and I stopped in on a Saturday around 1PM and there was nobody ahead of us, so we got a basic oil change for $39.95 (plus tax was 40-some-odd).  Friendly quick service and we were in and out.

No issues.

I agree with manyof the valid points that DJ makes.  Valley Square is by far the newest, hippest, coolest Shopping Center around.

Good shopping, restaurants and plenty of free parking.

Might very well be a five star place - but I have not seen enough of it yet.
We visited today (and did NOT have enough time to explore it all).

The grounds are just wonderful - and post Hurricane Irene with the normally meandering Brandywine River now a raging mass of muddy water - WOW!.

We saw a great blue Heron and a couple of Cormorants, too.

Can't wait to go back and actually take the tour.

The Body shop is good - but not what it was in the old days when Anita Roddick was more involved.  I do like many of the products and the prices are moderate.

The body butters (gee whiz, there are now about 16 types of body butter to choose from) are good - I like the Mango and Shea - both for VERY dry skin.  The new Lemon one is lighter and nice.

I also love the Satsuma fragrance in things like body wash and lotion.

Fun to shop and the Body Shop.

We had a splendid late-summer/early fall meal "just the gals" at T's next door (The European Side - not the Italian side).  My duck salad which contained delicious macerated cherries and a slab (yes a huge slice/slab) of honey chevre (the "gateway drug" to all soft cheeses) was perfect.

An $8 side of Brussels sprouts was large enough for 3 to share and contained more bacon than should be legal.

Mussels (Moules Frite) come with fries (Frites) and 7 different sauces to choose from.  A classic Provencale was ordered.

The booze selections are many and varied.  Pick your fave.

We attended a party here yesterday for the daughters of a local celebrity.  

Really.

And let me just say that Pump it Up is like a chaotic wonderland for kids.
It's filled with giant bouncy inflatables, an obstacle curse, a giant slide, a slippery-slope tower, air hockey and more.

For kids aged 5 - 10 it's great!  The also have 2 private party rooms for the cake and pizza eating.

They reserve parking spots for the birthday child and also place all the presents into a cart and help you wheel it to your car (nice touch).

If we lived closer, we would definitely drop in for the "Pop-in play"  sessions.

Fun times!

Wow - nobody's yelped Poor Richards yet?  There is also one on Easton road - but this one is the priginal and has expanded much in it's 35-40 plus years as a Doylestown staple.

Poor Richards is a unique shop.  Is it a gift shop?  An antique shop?  A craft lovers place?  It's abit of all of these things.

A great place for tourists and locals alike to poke around and make discoveries.

Had a nice evening here - but had to beg for veggies instead of chips (trying to watch carbs) for the $7 pico 'n chips.  They eventually oblidges with delicious cucumber, celery and carrot sticks.  PERFECT!

I wish you'd offer veggies on the menu as a sub for chips - I'd be willing to pay $2 - $3 extra for it.

But man, that pico (avocado chunks in pico de gallo) is terrific.

Great service.

This review is for event services and catering - not for staying at the hotel.
I attended a catered dinner meeting held in a lovely mid-sized room at the radnor Hotel.

Our event included a cash bar with complimentary soft drinks and a choice of chicken, fish or vegetarian meal.

Rolls and butter were fine, salad was pre-plated but fresh and crisp with a delicious sweet dressing. 

I had the veggie entree which looked to be the best choice by far - a bed of cous-cous with pesto and a stack of grilled veggies on top.

Service was attentive (3 servers - one who also tended bar) for our group of 35 women) including coffee and dessert,

This was a nice event and a fine space.

Incidentally room rates seema bit high ($249 per night on a Saturday).  Not sure if I ever would need to stay here - and not sure if it is big enough for a large wedding - but a small wedding or anniversary party would be nice here, I think.
It CLOSED!!!!!

What's not to love?
Come hungry and enjoy all the lovely Greek specialties just like Yiayia made - maybe even better.  Moussaka, Pastitsio, Lamb Shanks (expensive), Gyros, Spanakopita and skads of greek pastries.

Aside from the food there are a few rides and carnival games for the kiddies ($3 -$4 per ride) and a flea market/shopping for the grown ups.

Tours of the church - and on Friday/Saturday night DANCING and music.

A terrific event.  We love it!

I go here for lunch - have never been for dinner.
Just wanted to get that out of the way.

Meanwhile, for lunch they have a reasonbly priced "bento-like" special.  I have tried the Kalbi (YUM) and Bulgoki boxes.  That Kalbi is truly tasty - Korean Short-ribs in a tasty BBQ sauce.  Served with 2 shumai (or sometimes another type of dumpling) some green salad and rice.

I have also have some clay pot dishes with tofu - but I am a wimp and found them spicy.

Miran is a needed addition to the neighborhood.  It is well worth a try.

A lovely meal at Teresa's (not Next-Door - but we shall try that next - LOL).
All the pastas can be made with spaghetti squash - so I had Spag. Squash in a beet sauce with a blob of goat cheese/mascarpone.  So decadent.

Basic - but just about the BEST Caesar salad I have ever tasted  5 stars for the romaine, baby!

Too full for dessert but the coffee and iced teas were great - and wow, what a list of WHISKEYS!

El Vez gets 4 stars for the GUAC - not for the rest of the menu - which would get 3.

The guacamole hear really is tasty - although if you've tried the guac at Xochitl - which is made tableside with cotilja cheese fresh-ground to taste - WOWZA - but that's another review (check out Xochitl and Tequila's in Philly - regional Mex fare.)

Anyhow, back to El Vez which is filled-to-the-brim with Starr-kitsch.  Kitschy or not, this is a good place to get an over-priced fruity drink and schmooze with the yupsters.

I better go again before I turn 40 and get permanently banned from the joint!

This is my go-to Taxi service, and the dispatchers are lovely. (A woman on the weekend mornings, another woman during the week and a guy "Joel"? some evenings).

I did have an issue over 2 years ago with unreliability, but recently they've been great.

Just call 215-744-7777 and press 1 to reserve a cab.

Prompt, courteous service in the "Yellow & White" taxis.

Huge portions of old-skool Jewish-style (not Kosher - they have shrimp salad and meat and dairy) deli food.

I had the Matzoh Ball Soup with Kreplach ($6.75 plus $ extra) and a Dr. Browns Cream Soda (diet) and was in retro heaven.

The clean, BRIGHTLY lit dining area was pleasant enough (when I went it was not crowded - dinner time)  and Claudine, my server was a doll.

Can't wait to go back.

A nice green space - which is sorely needed - in Center Ciyt.  It may not be as well known as Rittenhouse Square - but it is a fine park and lots of cool stores and restaurants are in the surrounding area.

Cheap gas.  Full Serve.  Center of Town.

WINNER!

This Acme (a larger one) is on my way to work so today I literally ran in and out at 7:20 AM for a quart of milk and box of instant oatmeal packets.

The place was nearly empty at that hour so it was no biggie.
Friendly cashier, too.

No issues and I know I'll be back.

This is a nicely maintained dog park good for small, medium or large dogs.  If only my 13 year old pug could handle the walk - but he just can't make it that far.

We'll have to drive him over one day.

Kitchen gadget central.  Love it here - and great for wedding and shower gifts.  Kinda expensive - but many of these things just ARE expensive (like espresso machines and a sno-cone makers).

Fun place to shop and knowledgeable staff.

It's worth a visit here for the decor and architecture alone.
Ring the bell and a nice gal will let you in.

Super-trendy fashions for men & women - and all made in the USA.
I picked up a $135 top (Ouch) but 3 dots for $70 (Less painful but still high).
Very cute stuff here.

Went for lunch with my 11 year old and we actually enjoyed it - but still there are flaws.
Rice is not the right texture. Too hard and crumbly. Hwever, the salmon sushi (nigiri) we ordered was fresh and tast.

The "rich man" roll ($13) is basically a souped-up spicy salmon roll topped with MORE salmon.  I got the 2 sauces (A sweet mango syrup/sauce and eel sauce) on the side which was a good move.

Kiddo got a rainbow roll sans "fake crab" kani stick.  She hates fake crab.  Smart kid.  $11.

"Regular" rolls are $5.25 - and for that I'd just as soon get 2 Alaskan rolls for less that the cost of the "rich man".  Dessert ($4.50) was an overly greasy tempura banana.  El kiddo devoured it.

A decent place but there are better places closer to Media and even better in Philly.

Went for lunch here with a friend today and the place was EMPTY save for the 2 of us.  We were treated extra-well due to this, I think.

We both had lunch specials - a very good value - and my sushi platter was super fresh and delicious.

The ramen here is good, too!  And we split vanilla mochi ice cream for dessert.  YUM!

I will definitely be back to try the specialty rolls.  (My sushi lunch was a yellowtail scallion roll - 8 bite size pieces and 5 nigiri.)

Great diner food at a reasonable price served by lifer staff in a neighborhood institution.  Can get SLAMMIN' crowded on weekends at brunch time.  I like to go for dinner and have breakfast for dinner at Zoto's.

Fun stuff!

Great buy 3 get free sale - scored 6 $6.00 items for less than $17.00 (I have a 10% off card also.)

If you buy smart and buy on sale - you can get some nice bath & body gifts here.

Another successful (yet a bit pricey) meeting at the Hub - this time in a smaller room.

Sandwiches and salad for lunch (thanks steven starr) were great and a nice selection of beverages throughout the day.

Comfortable, professional, business-y digs.

Clean restrooms.

If you have to suffer through another boring meeting or training class - try to do it here.

I discovered AOS back in like 2003 on Madison Avenue in NYC.
Meanwhile, they have one in Philly so, back in 2008 when my then fiance (now husband) and I were in pre-wedding mode, I got him a gift certificate.

He wound up getting a "Royal" shave and said it was great, but both he and I know he NEVER in a million years would spend that kinda money on himself.

So last year I got him another gift card.
And I'll probably give him one next year, too.

We like it here.

4 -5 stars for the view alone.  They could serve old shoe leather (which some steaks kinda resemble) and it would still be a great ambience.  Meanwhile, as hard to believe as it is, Chart house is a CHAIN.  It is a such a nice place, though - and a great "special occaision" restaurant.

Just don't have a steak.  The salmon was excellent when I had it years ago.
Come to think of it the steaks I also had quite a long while ago - perhaps they have a better beef supplier now.

But anyhow, yes I do recommend the Chart House - especially for Mother's Day (Father's Day) and birthdays.  It is just a joy in Spring and Summer.

I heart Sephora - I liked it even better when they first started in the '90's and had even more brands (probably too many) and harder to find items.

Love it.

I just went here on a RAINY horrid day for lunch and wound up getting it to go.  I had the Chicken Parm over linguine special.  (8.95)  It is delicious and HUGE, plus it came with a fresh hot garlic breadstick.

I can't wait to go back and try the pizza.

I have attened numerous events here - mostly associated with Square 1682 - the restaurant, but also some in the hotel lobby (They have wine for the guests!).

Rooms are small - and not cheap - but it's a great location and a nice place to stay. Slick decor.

Note:  Check in is at 4 and your room may not be ready any earlier.

I am a GINORMOUS fan of Sugarfoot and eat here for lunch whenever I visit my firm's WIlmington office.  The tuna melts, chicken salad sandwich, salads (with goat cheese) and soup (Chicken & dumplings) are all top notch.

Eat in or take out.  It's all SOOOOOOO good.

Too bad they only do AM and lunch.  (No dinners.) Wilmington rolls up the sidewalks at 4:55 PM.

Great for in-office catering, too.

Such deliciousness!  We even contemplated having our wedding here.  (THey have a gorgeous private room for multi-course traditional (or modern) Chinese banquets.

A good selection of fresh sushi, too.

Tasty dumplings and soups.

WE LOVE IT HERE!  Gorgeous decor and attentive service.
We'll return!

3.5 stars. - A decent breakfast place for the Diner Classics - and Eggs benedict with "hollandaise from a mix".  Big portions and OK prices.
Surprisingly decent hot coffee - maybe I lucked out with a fresh pot?

Overly made-up servers (can you say black eye liner at 10 AM)? wearing support hosiery.

Nostalgic - and a darn sight better than Country Squire (Blech.)

I am optimistic about Gavin's - an Argentine-owned Euro-style cafe, right near Taney Park and sorely needed.

The original Irish Bar (from years ago now serves as the coffee bar.

We had some cold drinks here yesterday and I got a home-made beef empanada that was so delicious.  The salad menu sounds great, too.

This is sorely needed in this area and I hope they will be successful.

Go, Gavin's!

This is now my go-to Saladworks near my job.
The ladies who run the lunch rush are so kind and friendly.

The salad is consistently good (fresh lettuce is a must for me) and I sometimes add on a cup of lobster bisque or Turkey Sausage/Kale soup on a cold day.

I come in about twice a month.

Yes, it's both - a dine and a dive bar (in the back) complete with Sassy waitresses (I love "Sugar") and a great manager, Vi.

The place is grungy - and up until recently you could smoke there and nobody would hassle you.  Dem Daze R gone, Alas.

I really like coming here - breakfast is great, lunch specials and even for dinner.  The Chicken Cacciatore - if they have it as a special - is a must.

I love my Midtown.

So. darned. expensive.

But I fall for it more and more now that my 5 foot 7 and still growing amazonian 13 year old figure skater has grown out of ivivva and wanta "higher performance" fabrice than VS's PINK.

Luxe.
Pretty.
Fun.
A bit elistist.

And did I mentioned to bring some money?
Even on sale it's pricey for workout togs.

But we love them anyway.
I came here for alterations - so I can't really comment on their cleaning services - but the lady who did my dress fitting was so friendly and nice.  Great workmanship. I will return.

This review is for the Print & Marketing center and Cory, in particular at the Glen Mills location.  I needed - of all things - a document to be laminated (people still do that??) and thank goodness for Cory and his help and advice.

We have also shopped at this Staples location for "back to school" supplies.

Glad it's here!

This is a review for the banquet room and facilities. We attended an event in a large room and there was an open bar area in the "lobby" which was also nice.  Area was clean and service was excellent from porters, servers, bar staff and more.

The catering manager was on hand and additional trash cans were brought right away when they were needed.

The renovations look very nice and continue - so there is still scaffolding in front of the hotel.  When it is done it will be better.

Very good service for a large (200 people) event.

Pretty much the only fast food place I will let my kid eat at.
The kids meal with 4 nuggets, fresh fruit and lowfat milk is a pretty safe option.

You can get a grilled chicken sandwich (they charge extra for a whole wheat roll).

You can get a side salad but it's loaded with shredded cheese which I try to pick off.  I sometimes get a diet lemonade.

Not too bad.  But it's still fast food.

Kovacs doesn't look impressive from the outside, but the man who runs it is terrific and was very, very kind to my friend who used to walk here almost daily from his Media Station apartment.

A great place to grab snacks or a sandwich before catching a SEPTA train into Philly.

They also have grocery items, lottery tickets and COFFEE!

Kovacs' is a neighborhood institution.

Raw - the sushi & sake lunge from 12 & Sansom - opened a 2nd branch inside Boyd's Department store on the mezzanine level.

I just had lunch there today and for $13 it very well may be the only thing I can afford at Boyds!

Less of the snotty attitude, too.  Much quiter and more refined.
I had a yellowtail bento box and the sushi and all of the elements (miso, salad, gyoza, and spicy tuna tartare) were all top-notch.

I'll be back soon!

Wowie Wow!!!  5 star food for sure and 4 for the service, value and decor.  Especially for lunch - the $7.50 - $850 pita sandwiches are so tasty and the gyro is made with reall meat - not "mystery meat from a spit".

The avgolemono souyp is delectable, piping hot and comforting.

The filet mignon souvlaki (small lunch portion) is the real deal with tasty chunks of filet.  Just wish there were a FEW more.

They also have outdoor seating on a covered deck for when the weather is nice.

GREAT FIND - thanks to my parents who have been coming here for years - but somehow I never had!  I sure will be back.

Chick-Fil-A Lima is very well run and has worked with my kid's elementary school many years now to organise fundraisers and family events.  There is a play area for the little ones, and even though I can not STAND the political views of the company's CEO, I was not able to boycott them, because they are the only fast food I will allow my child to consume.

The chicken sandwich (whole wheat bun available) is pretty good for a fast food option - and you can get fresh fruit instead of fries.

El kiddo also loves the mini cones (not so mini!) of "Ice Dream".

I don't listen often - but the weather and traffic are repeated often and in a predictable fashion.
Yes, I agree with below that the ads are LOUD and annoying.
Methinks I shall never shop at the DUMP just on principle.  (They also advertise on WMKJ - 102.9 - which is my favorite station.  (Especially in HD.)

Anyhow - Philly needs you, KYW - so keep on keepin' on.

Oh - and in winter - please repeat the school closing numbers more often.

So glad we finally got to try La Porta - and especially the 5 star Caprese - one of the best I have had in a long, long while.  Home-made Mozz - so creamy; A drizzle of "the good stuff" - aged balsamic; red, ripe, roma tomatoes; basil chiffonade.  SUPERB.

The lasagna was so rich I almost could not eat it.  (Although others I know would swoon over this.)  An excellent meaty bolognese - but the creamy sauce on top was just too much.  Delicate house-made pasta sheets.  Topped with a fried egg that was, alas, oddly cooked (Thus precluding me from awarding LaPorta the fifth star).  The egg was, indeed, fried = the bottom was actually crispy and brown - the top?  Raw.  Not runny (which I like) but raw albumin over the yolk.  Slimy.  Not good.

Meanwhile the 2 pizzas our  table tried (Malfatta - neat! and a classic Margarita) were excellent.

Lots of love and care goes into this food and it shows.

LOVE IT and will return soon.  But I'll try other things (like the salads which sound great) that are not quite so rich and heavy.

Gorgeous bar area and a rustic older dining room, too.
Lizzy - our server - and a brand-spankin'-new bus boy were pleasant and friendly.

Good job, Peter!!!!!
Welcome to suburbia.

Fabulous service at the bar during Happy Hour from Paul and later Hailey.  $5 White Cosmos were terrific.  $7 mini tuna tartare was a tasty treat.   Skip the deviled eggs, the ones at Paramour are better.

A nice change of pace from my usual. I will be back!

I stopped at this Starbucks in a state of latte-emergency.
I desperately needed a caffeine pick me up and this location at 5:30 PM on a Friday was nearly empty so I got in and out quickly.

Staff was friendly and restrooms were clean (enough).

No issues.
Thankful they are here.

We had a marvelous first-time experience for lunch on a Wednesday at the Metro Diner on Concord Pike - just South of the PA state line.
Our server Eddie was terrific and later the manager, Isaac, came over to see how things were.  (Everything was great - believe it or not.)

One of us is vegetarian (not vegan so eggs are OK, this is not a vegan place - lots of eggs and dairy) and she had a veggie wrap (huge - took 1/2 home) with Avocado and the "usual" suspects but also with FRIED JALAPENOS - inside the wrap.  Wow.

I had a "trying to cut carbs" eggs Benedict so - no English muffin and plain steamed spinach instead of potatoes.  $13.29 (no tax, baby, we're in DE).

I am sorry others did not have a good experience, but honestly, we had a great lunch and I can't wait to return.  (That divided highway, though...)

I received good service at Watch Co. when having my husband's watch band and battery replaced.  Mattie (sp?) the lady at the front was very kind and I got in and out of there quickly and the watch works great.

A nice selection of Citizens Eco-Drive, too.

I have always supported food coops, CSA's farmers markets, Natural food stores and the like, so I was delighted to find Weaver's way.

In amongst the crowded, cramped, narrow aisles - along with farm-fresh local produce (much in season - less in the winter) are other treats.  Honey.  Peanut Butter.  Fresh Eggs (with round deep yellow yolks), and a nice selection of snacks and prepared foods.

If I lived in the neighbordhood I'd be joining for sure!

Without Whole Foods and Trader Joe's I'd be sunk.
So, Whole Foods - I am be-whole-den to you.

High prices and all - what choice do I have?  My child must have chemical-free, persticide-free, herbicide-free non Genetically Modified organisms on which to feed.

That meat case is impressive!  As are the baked desserts.  The juice bar is a saviour - and sushi never hurts!

O, Whole Foods - how I love thee - though parking really sucks.
A least they'll validate the lot and save me a few bux.
Very good ice cream - not withstanding the long lines that are par for the course at the RTM - my 4 y.o. dd loves Bassett's and as an occaisional special treat we get her a small cone.

A-may-zing.
So good.  For $3.75 I got an excellent iced decaf latte.

Perfect.
Gorgeous setting, great service and smooth, rich-tasting coffee drinks.

YUM!

Returned to La Porta for 5 star food and service but oh  - so many flies!!!!
You need to do something about the black fly population inside and out on the patio (which is lovely, otherwise).

Tracey our server is terrific and the Caprese Salad (with August-ripened Heirloom tomatoes) was perfection and the house-made spinach gnocchi were terrific.

Can't wait to come back - but please get a bug zapper!

This has been my go-to Whole Foods for a while now - sometime I will trek to Glen Mills or Plymouth Meeting.  I know the layout of this WF better than others so I can get in, get what I want, and leave relatively quickly. 

Also if you go after 7:30 PM or before 8 AM it is much less crowded.
Avoid lunch hour and the after-work rush.  (Although - lots of these yoga-pants ladies look like they don't work.  Must be nice.)

Chi-Chi Devon location with prices and attitudes to match.  (Attitudes from the patrons - not the hipster staffers.)

A beautiful new store next to the Whole Foods in Wayne - with a good amount of sparkling wines and vodkas (That's what I needed on the day I shopped).

Decent prices (But face it, this is PA - if you want good prices on Liquor you go to NJ or DE and sneak it back in your trunk.

Happy to have a nice place to buy booze.

I was treated to lunch here today by a coworker and had the salmon lovers ($13) special.  6 pieces of sashimi (I asked for all sashimi as I am trying to cut carbs and they complied.) and a [mild] spicy salmon roll.

Also came with choice of miso soup or iceberg salad.  I got the salad with the ginger/sweet (carb) dressing on the side.

Service from Rebecca was excellent and the place was not crowded on a random Tuesday at 12:15 PM.

I will return when my sushi/Asian craving hits next.
They are CLOSED!!!!

If you need to plan a business event or function - the hub is a good place to know about - they can accomodate the business and social components with A/V and wireless computer capability plus catering by Starr.

Between the giant screens, the configurable tables and chairs and the enormous cookie and brownie trays i would say all in all that the hub is a pretty sweet place for meetings. (Even boring CLE classes.)

Pretty Sweet!

Dee M.  said it best - and I agree.
Cheap gas just over the DE border, plus all the Wawa usuals.

This section of the city is a great mix of old, historic Americana and new, hip trendy boutiques, galleries and restaurants.  It's lots of fun on First Friday - and good for families in the spring & summer, too.

A nice place to visit and live.

OK - I am upgrading corner bakery cafe for their excellent work with catering.
No, the food isn't all that wonderful - but it's better than lots of others we've had.  The cavatappi pasta salad (side) is great and the breads for the sandwiches are fresh and not sogged-out.

Nice presentation and better yet - they arrive on time and don't cost alot.  (Hot pasta meal for 8-10 is $90.)

For whatever reason the food seemed better this time as we watched our child's figure skating competition.
We had lunch AND dinner here - including a decent cheesesteak quesadilla.

Wings were overcooked and dried out.
French Onion Soup is not tasty - had a weird acidic component.

But - the Fish Sandwich ($8) with fries was good.

Counter service and a full bar.
Friendly staff.

My high review is because of Larisa, the lovely russian nail tech who did my spa pedi and mani at Ettore.  I succumbed to th temptation of "spa week" and got the spa pedi and regular mani - usually 52 + 17 - for $50.  That's a good deal!

The salon has 2 pedi thrones in tiny roomettes, plus 3 mani tables.

The place was bustling-crowded as it was a Saturday AM and the hotel had alot of weddings.

The salon itself seems OK - the front desk needs to be more attentive and friendly - when I arrived a man was at one counter (on the phone) and a lady was at the "payment" counter with another person.  Neither acknowledged me for several minutes - until I waved at the guy on the phone.  He gave me the "just a 'sec" look.

Oh well.

Other than that it's clean, hotel prices (tourist spot) and I will be back to see Larisa for sure.  Great pedi!

It's been YEARS since my kid - now a teen - has begged for fro-yo but we found an ancient Sweet Frog gift card and it still is valid so - YAY.
Cookies and Cream for me and my vegan teen (They had 3 vegan options) had the dole-whip Pineapple (no dairy).

A plethora of candy toppings and fruits.

$6 for both of us (small cups).

Oh the Bon ton!  (In my mind it still is Hess's)  An all-purpose old-style department store right in the D-town shopping center.

You can get women's, men's and kids clothes and shoes here.  Accessories, hats, household goods and of course - cosmetics.  There is a Clinique counter, Estee Lauder - the works.

And if you read the Daily Mistake (I mean, the Daily Intelligencer, you can get coupons and come during one of their fabulous sales.)

Recently I bought a party dress for my 3 year old daughter here - a top designer in children's clithing - marked down from $110 to $59 - but I came with a sale coupon and walk out with it for $36.00

Gotta LOVE the Bon Ton.

Delicious 5 star hoagies - so good (and I don;t even like hoagies).
Chicken Suprimo, Bada-Bing, Nonna's Veggie and the new Meatball Sub are all winners.

Alas, one star off for the super-high price.  My wrap  was 8.99 plus $1 extra for subbing eggplant for red peppers.

2 subs and a small mac salad was almost $20.  Ee-gads!

Meanwhile, our kid likes it here, too.

A lovely - albeit pricey - lunch at La Porta.  Anything they make with their house-made mozzarella (or scamorzza or burratta) is amazing.  If you are a fan of fresh mozz - you must try it here.

We had the special salad of the day - a summery mix of lettuce, fresh burratta (decadent) red and golden beets and sliced peaches.  LOVELY.  The blackberry balsamic was perfect for it.  I added shrimp to mine (which made the $13 salad go to $20).

I really do enjoy the food here.

The best diner in my area.
A bit pricey - my salmon salad was $15.95 - ouch.

Breakfasts come in around $10 for omelettes or pancakes with toppings/fillings/sides.

My kid had a gyro platter with onion rings subbed in (upcharge!) for fries.

Soda was $2.45.

Bill for 4 people for lunch was $70.  Yikes.

5 star food and 3 or 4 star service for this update on Peter Mac's delightful La Porta on route 352 in Media.

Ate here for the first time in over a year and the late spring/summer menu is wonderful with crisp salads, pizzas, pasta and rich, flavorful entrees.

My pork cutlet stack with fresh mozz, spinach and peppers was so delicious and a generous portion.  I took about 1/3 home and enjoyed it the next day.

The bar was hoppin' on a Monday night and my Cranberry Moscow Mule was served icy-cold in the requisite copper mug.  Deeeee-licious.

Can't wait to come back.
Gone but not forgotten.

Wow!  Swanky renovations in 2017 include a REAl in-store Starbucks (Yes, you can use your Starbucks app or card) and re-done ladies room (THANK YOU).

Nice new floors in the deli and prepared food areas.

Still a great spot to get some cheap sushi for lunch.
I come in a few times each week on my way to work.

Super-fast, cheap take out lunches - you can't really eat here comfortably.  There are a few stools and a counter, but the place gets crowded (line out the door) at lunch.

Love tha Tom Kha Gai (Chicken Coconut Soup).
Red Curry is fairly spicy (to my taste).  Tofu is fried - but delish!
$6 combo plates to go are good but the fresh-cooked entrees are even better.  You get your choice of pad thai or fried rice with 1 to 2 entrees on top (from the steam table).  I tried a unique deep-fried egg half with tamarind sauce.  Neat.

Tip:  For better quality food than the $6 steamtable, call in your order - today I got $2.50 Tom Kha with soft tofu and a fresh order of pineapple fried rice $6.95.  Cost more than the $6 special but fresh, hot and cooked to order.  MUCH better.

Returned to Teresa's on a balmy, busy, summer Thursday night for a delightful plate of eggplant, spinach and cheese.  So good.

I always like the food here - both sides are good but different.
Lots of alcoholic choices, too!

I had a fine experience my first time at this Saladworks.  There were 3 women working the counter during the lunch rush on a random Thursday.  There was a short-to-medium line and it moved quickly.   They offered about 8 soups (my old Saladworks offers only 3 or 4) and I got a Cobb Salad with Turkey instead of chicken and Brussels Sprouts instead of Bleu Cheese.  

No issues.

Dining room was medium-crowded (we got a table and were not packed in).  

Did not use rest room.
Plenty of parking.

I will be back.

Beautiful furniture - and a huge variety of desks (need a corporate or lawyer-type desk?  Or a conference table/dining table - come here!).

Decent prices - and a few leather sofas and sectional.

BIG bedroom sets (ornate - and not our style - but beautiful wood.)

Need WOOD furniture that looks terrific and is well finished?  Head over here.

Neat place.
We were pleasantly greeted and allowed to browse on our own - which was perfect! (Not too pushy.)

I can't believe I have NEVER been to a Bonefish Grill before, but I have not.
And I will be back.

A little pricey for what it is (Chain - owned by Outback), but very tasty.
Nice atmosphere.
Great for my daughter's friend's 12th birthday dinner.

For happy hour (4 - 6 PM) the $5 drinks are a great value.
The blueberry lemon drop martini is like candy in a glass.  Lovely.

Also enjoyed the Cobb salad with shrimp.

Good service from Jess.

We'll be back!

I was turned off after my last lunch here so I did not return for a while but now, I am glad I did.  The Thai Basil stir fry (I chose chicken but you can get beef, shrimp or veggie or tofu) is delicious and inexpensive as a lunch special (back page of menu).

I also had some sashimi but stuck to salmon and tuna which were fine.  The escolar, snapper and hamachi here taste slightly "fishy" to me - and hamachi especially can taste "off" if it is not uber-fresh.

Lots of pre-frozen product in that sushi case, but hey, it's Wilmington, DE - not NYC or LA or Tokyo.

This is a good option for pan-Asian near my office.

My first experience at Yummy sushi was actually quite, well, yummy.

It was a busy lunch rush, so I sat at the sushi bar and ordered the $13 sashimi lunch special with a choice of salad or miso soup.

Sashimi, to me, is the litmus test for any sushi bar.  Yummy passed!  My plate had 3 slices of 4 fish and all were fresh and good, no fishy odor. Tuna, salmon, and 2 white fish I am guessing were sea bass or fluke. It was not yellowtail. It was not escolar (fake white tuna).

Salad was the standard iceberg with ginger dressing that many places serves. Also fresh, crispy and good.  

I will be back as this place is steps away from my office and relatively cheap.

Yay!

It seems much like the Vic's in Philly - but different owners.  Similar menu - and best of all TUNA DUMPLINGS - you gotta try these - so delicious.

I also got a sashimi sampler (app) with 2 pieces of tuna, salmon and yellowtail.

All were fresh and delicious.

$12 minimum for credit cards.

Huge!  Massive! And relatively clean.

We were fortunate to visit on a realtively non-crowded day and time (2 PM on a Sunday).

The A/C felt wonderful and our 5 y.o. enjoyed the movie and sat still for the entire show.  Yay!

It will be hard to write a captivating review without re-stating many of the sentiments already expressed below, but I shall try...

Last night we went to Buddakan Philadelphia (there are now 3 locations) which is celebrating 11 years in operation.  Surprisingly, even after living in Philly for nearly 4 years and trying tons of restaurants, this was our first visit.  Years back we visited and peeked inside to see the amazing Golden Buddha and the waterfall wall fountain. I had read the menu many times on the website - so I felt like I knew what to expect.  (N.B. they will be CHANGING the drink menu and dinner menu in a few weeks - finally.)

Decor and Service were easily 5 star, but there are too many small details overlooked for me to give Buddakan that elusive fifth star.  (As Starr restaurants go, this is pretty typical in that there is some over-hyping going on - but for a restaurant like this to survive and thrive for 11 years - an eternity for a restaurant - they are doing alot of things right!)

We started with $11 - $13 drinks at the nearly empty  bar (from 5:30 - 6:10 on a recession summer Thursday - it got crowded around 8).  The enlightenment was too strong with tequila for me to drink, so I sent it back and tried the tickled pink which was cloyingly sweet and the Malibu rum was not a great idea.  Oh well.  Meanwhile the ASIAN MOJITO was well-balanced, with freshly muddled mint, a hint of ginger and delicious.  (NOTE:  THey are changing the drink menu in a few weeks - many of these cocktails have been on the menu for years and it's all gonna change.)

Next the 3 of us sat at a great table on the main level (there is also a cute bar upstairs and more tables.).  One of us is a vegan and there are very few vegetarian options (and NO vegan apps! The edamame ravioli uses chicken stock)  He had vegetable fried rice (or could have had noodle dishes or the house salad.)  If you are a vegan - this is not a great place for you - unless you just want some drinks.

Everything is served family style with sharing plate s- which for us is great as we all like to share (execpt my vegan friend who, natch, would not eat the fish or duck).  Chicken Dumplings were a step up from the frozen gyoza we get at our favorite sushi joints.  Tasty for sure - but not worth $9.  A scallion pancake topped with shredded shortrib meat was enjoyed by DH but way too salty for my tastes.  A miss at $12.

Entrees were much better.  The miso black cod, that was so famous, lived up to most of the hype.  Perfectly cooked.  I subbed a DELICIOUS eggplant in lieu of the wasabi mashed potatoes.  That eggplant was GREAT - reminiscent of Kung Pao - it was studded with Pine Nuts.  YUM!

DH ordered the thinly sliced duck breast - a bit too well done for me - but I like my duck with a bit more QUACK left in it.  The accompanying Corn Spoon Bread was AWESOME.

Desserts were by far worth the extra calories.  3 people shared the chocolate Bento box ($14 with chocolatey-good 6 selections - easily feeds 3 by itself).  We also got the hot, fried, five-spice & sugar donuts.  Now this is how I wished the churros at Xochitl could be!  WOW!  Five slightly greasy, hot donuts with 3 delectable dipping sauces (well - the cream cheese was too thick to really be called a sauce) including a rich ganache.

A cup of green tea and a Millenum Cocktail (rimmed with Tang - what is with Starr and his obsession with Tang in cocktails???) capped off a lovely early summer dinner.

Great for special occaisions - and the tab was $180 or so including tip which really isn't bad.  Expensive but not obscene (we spent more on dinner for 2 at Morimoto!!).

I will be back - but maybe just for drinks and dessert!  (HA, HA!)
\
Oh - and I must mention our bartender Adele (She's there Thursdays thru Sundays) and our 5 year veteran server Meg who was charming and spot-on with our orders.

Oh - and if you want to (we didn't) they will valet park your car for $18.00).

So close to 5 stars - but not quite.

Very good service from a friendly Covid-19 compliant staff and tasty burgers - 2 thinly-smashed patties.

I had a lettuce wrapped cheese burger with fried mushrooms, lettuce and tomato and wee bit of M2O sauce (Ketchup plus mayo).

The owners were from Kosovo - interesting.

I would definitely come here again.
Better than Smashburger comparable to 5 guys with more choices (salads, smoothies and shakes).

Loving M2O so far.

A new fro-yo place (akin to those in Philly - pay per ounce).
Lots of toppings.

My 8 year old loved the pink and green decor.

Christian-owned FROG - Firmly Rely on G-d.

Whatever.

Where would we be without Uber and Lyft?
I check both and see which will get to me quicker out in the 'burbs.

Sometimes it's not about $$ for me but time.
Time is money.  LOL.

Anyhow - so far only good experiences.

We have a great experience at Elmwood Park zoo and became members.
It is best for families with young kids - and you can still feed the giraffes (They now have 3 males) and American Bison (we saw 2).

Due to Covid the little "choo choo train" and a few other exhibits are closed.
Bring a mask.

They have sanitizer at many of the playground and attractions.

A cute little zoo - you only need 2.5 - 3 hours to see it all and bring your own food/beverages.

Way less crowded than the Philly zoo but, of course, not as many types of animals.

A great place for local school trips.

Still lovin' it.  Brought a crowd of 5 here for bao, har gow, noodles and more.
Try the stir-fried green beans. - So good.

Inexpensive and fun.

OK.  I am now officially hooked on Zushi - I tried the "signature" zushi which is fish on top on "butter toasted rice" - not healthy but so tasty.  Smeared with avocado mash and sprinkled with tobiko and shredded scallions.  YUM.  $10 for just a Zushi or $15 for a combo meal (better deal - you get the Zushi, a California roll and a small seaweed salad.)

Super-easy touch screen ordering.

I am liking this place more and more.

A fantastic breakfast - real banana pancakes with both bananas on top and IN THE BATTER which is what i like.  Alas, fake syrup - I would gladly pay an upcharge for REAL maple syrup.  Yes, we know how much it costs!

Very nice service from our old-school server and the male host was efficient.

The "Springfield Benedict" (get the faux-hollandaise on the side) is delicious with spinach and bacon instead of canadian bacon.  HUGE and filling.

This large Wawa is nearly always hoppin' - especially the morning, lunch and after-work rushes (avoid).

The coffee lines in the AM are almost comical - you'd think they were giving it away.
Service is quick, efficient and depending on the gal or guy you get - can be friendly and funny (The young man I saw last night when I stopped in for a quart of milk - $1.59 - was so funny.).

Wawa is a very convenient thing!!!

New owners are taking over and good things are happening at Play It Again.  Thank goodness that Ellen (the manager) is staying.  Love her.

I have sold or consigned 3 pairs of high-end figure skates here.
My kid is a competitive figure skater and when she was younger would grow out of thr $200, $300 and $500 boots so quickly.

Now, her stuff costs even more but she now needs new skates from wear, not growth,

Have a young skater (figure or hockey)?  Soccer kid?  Tennis?

You gotta check out PIAS to sell your old gear.
Hey, $20, $30 or $50 in my pocket is more than ZERO dollars in my closet.

Wow. Very impressed. Generous slices of sashimi. Tuna, salmon and yellowtail were all fresh.  Enormous $5 tempura veggie app.  Next time I am getting the sashimi app - you get 2 pieces each of Tuna, Salon and Yellowtail for $12 instead of $18 if ordered a la carte.

So happy.  Got my protein fix.
Definitely better than Yummy Sushi around the corner and much quicker.  You can eat there but it is really a take out kinda place.
Super easy touch-screen ordering.

I will be back.  Hopefully soon.

Love the food here - burritos, quesadillas (traditional or Tex-Mex) and the Camarones Platter ($14.95) with Mojo de Ajo is a garlicky dream.

Service is down to earth and you may need to be a bit patient with the staff to get what you want.

Don't miss the house-made salsa verde - with fresh tomatillos.

Can't wait to try their Al Pastor next.

OMG - what is this?
A diner?  On Chestnut Street? - below is an excerpt from 2/6/2020 in the Inquirer:

"Center City's flagging diner scene got a boost this week with the opening of the Chestnut Diner, a snazzy, two-story affair across from Liberty Place at 1614 Chestnut St. It occupies the former 4 Seasons Food Court, which closed last year.

The Chestnut, open 24 hours on weekends for now, joins the 24-hour Midtown III, that wood-paneled vestige of the 1970s two blocks away on 18th Street, and the more modern City Diner at Broad and South Streets, which also runs 24 hours on weekends."

Our party of 4 had lunch there and server, Jen, a bubbly blond was terrific.
The food had some hits and misses.  (Breakfast is served all day)  The Cobb Salad was fresh and HUGE for $10.95 - came with a cup of soup. Burgers are served with fries and a cup of soup.  (A great value at $7.99 or 8.99).  Soft Drinks are $2.00 and come with refills.

The hot roast beef sandwich was a hot, gloppy mess.  PASS.

Also you pay "up front" which during a busy Friday lunch rush took quite a bit of time.

Come hungry!  All the classic Diner Faves are here.
No more 4 season's salad bar.  Much nicer than Little Pete's (remember that??).

I wish them much success.

We had amazingly good service from Alexa (and a shout out to Jeff the manager) at my ladies night Happy Hour (6 of us) at the bar area.

While Happy Hour prices (which are a great value - $5 drinks and $6 apps) only last from 4 - 6 PM we stayed until after 8:30 and a few of us enjoyed (Shrimp) Cobb salads (always terrific), Bang Bang Shrimp, Shrimp Tacos and Lobster bisque from the "regular" menu.

There is also a lovely server named Sara who treats me so well any time I come in with family or friends.

Yes, Bonefish is a chain, but I really like this location of it.
Don't miss the brunch menu - very good also.

Very friendly and helpful young guys running the place.
tasty selection of pre-cooked (softshell crabs, crab cakes) fried items that you can reheat.

Good for takeout (they have 2-3 small tables if you want to eat there.).

Lots of frozen seafood soups (Chowders and Bisques).

I'll be back to try the Salmon Teriyaki Rice Bowl. ($8.99).

This Maggiano's (Cherry Hill Mall) is much better than the one in Philly.
Cleaner, better service and for whatever reason the food tasted better to me. (Even though it's the SAME menu.)

Pasta dishes are a great value at lunch - but I ask them to go lightly on the sauce(s) - the garlic load is pretty intense.

A good place for a "family meal" - no, it's not earth-shattering - and it can feel a bit "cafeteria-like" as it gets loud and the acoustics are pretty awful, but we take the 5 year old here and she loves it.

Chima is the kind of dining where you much have a clearly mapped-out strategy before dropping $60 plus on lunch (or $80 ish for dinner).

Two words...
Meat. Sweats.

Two more words...
Food. Coma.

Some rookie mistakes to avoid:
1.  Skip the little cheese/bread - yes, they are delicious but they will fll you up.
2.  Go very, very easy on the salad bar - BE SELECTIVE.  
3.  Ask, ask, ask your server to bring you the cuts you most want.  Once they do get 2 slices of those you love the most (for me the Lamb (chops not leg) and Angus Beef (Classic) were the best picks.
4.  Allow adequate time - at least 2 hours.  This is not a place to go if you are in a time crunch.

Yes, I would go back here - especially for a celebratory meal, but I will also ask for a side of LIPITOR.

P.S.  NOT vegan friendly (Um, duh!).

What a great place!  This historic tower has a nature preserve and wildflower tours for kids and parents.  A great place for bird watching, too. Climb to the top of the Tower for a fabulous view of the surrounding countryside.  Don't miss a visit to Bowman's Tower and Wild Flower preserve.  (And if you have kids - bring 'em.)

Believe it or not, I had NEVER been to a MP before last night (Mother's Day) but I had read the menu, reviews and my brother and his wife love it there - so I kinda knew what to expect.

I completely agree that this is the kind of meal you can only have a few times per year.  Great for kids (they love to dip) and if you are younger and not as jaded makes a good "date night" or special occasion place.  They try to make it dimly lit and faux-mantic in there!  (LOL.)

It was PERFECT for Mother's Day - and our server, Amanda (who has been at this location for 11 years) was terrific.

For $40 per person ($20 for el kiddo) we got the "whole shebang" and even upgraded our dessert dippers ($4.95) to include a slice of (mediocre) cheesecake and frozen cream puffs.  not sure we'd do that again.

Also the salad (Caesar) was unimpressive.

The cheese and chocolate fondues were the best parts of the meal (would ike to see better veggies for dipping - we only got celery, carrot and cauliflower - would love to see broccoli, sugar snap peas, bell peppers.)

Court Boullion was very salty - but tasted OK - definitely imparted flavor to the potatoes and mushrooms.  Meats varied from delicious (Shrimp & Filet Mignon) to boring (Chicken) to not very good ("Ahi" Tuna - who BOILS tuna?)..

We'll return - but not right away.

I would go back just for dessert - or they now have (but not all the time) a $20 deal for Cheese, salad (yawn) and dessert.
Or maybe just dessert?

Oh - and the "Parmesan crusted pine nuts" in the Caesar salad were NOT parm crusted - they were downright candied.  Tasty - but not what i was expecting.

We had an excellent time at a corporate luncheon held at the Doubletree on 202 just North of Wilmington.  Over 150 people, cash bar, plated lunch.

Everyone could see the presentation and hear the audio.  (Microphones worked well).

Waitstaff was attentive and efficient.
No issues.
Parking lot is usually very crowded so use caution, otherwise - this is my go-to branch of TD bank.  Here or Aston, occasionally Newtown Square.  No issues.

Still love TJ's - the prepared Medditerranean Pasta salad makes a great lunch (and for $3.49 - whoo-hoo!). Also for $1.99 the frozen bowties with spinach and 4 cheeses is great (rich though and 390 cals.).  To say nothing of the divinely fattening shells with asparagus and brie ($3.49).

I come in very frequently now that I am working 1 block away.

I got takeout (delivered, actually) when I needed a quick lunch one day at my firm's Cherry Hill office.  It was really very good.  Cindy's is located in a nearby strip mall,  They have "the usual" Chinese food and a few Japanese selections as well.

I would definitely order again.  I never got a chance to dine-in so I can't speak to the decor or service.

Wow - that Riverfront Market just gets better & better.

Today I stopped in with business colleagues for a quick lunch meeting and while they were off getting cheesesteaks, Thai & Sushi - I got myself a FAB-U-LOUS Salade Nicoise from Harry's.

This huge and fresh salade can be make with freshly grilled Ahi Tuna or Shrimp.  I opted for Shrimp and got 5 big ones atop a mound of fresh crisp greens, grape tomatoes, nicoise olives, cooked potatoes, blached naricot vert (yum!) and a luscious side of vinaigrette.

I also sprung for a fresh-blended Arnold Palmer.

This place rocks!  Yes, I spent about $12 on lunch - but there was more than enough to take back to the office to eat tomorrow!

Hooray for Harry's as a fresh, quick seafood-lunch (they also do great burgers & fries with unique dipping sauces).

I've had some great meals at Pag's (the main restaurant has the best food of the 3 - wine bar, pizza cafe and restaurant.).  We shared a delightful Mozzarella di Buffula (the REAL McCOy - and priced to match) with red ripe summer tomatoes.

The garden area outside is a great summer night's treat.

In winter - try the (a bit heavy) house made pastas.  Tagliatelle was perfectly al dente hear and served in asugo di burro (Butter sauce - I think I spelled that wrong - sorry.).  Fresh shaved parmesan over the top.

Yes, the prices are steep - and a bit "too -too" for people like my parents - we prefere Luberto's which is more "homey" and alot cheaper - but for a romantic date or a birthday celebration?  In D-town I love Pag's.

Oh - and I came here with my daughter when she was just under 2 years old and they treated her really well - spaghetti and everything.

Well - I guess I am writing this review a little too late. Lily Orlando's frozen Italian Foods is CLOSING in 2 weeks (Nov. 2012).
Currently, Lily Orlando's is a line of home-made frozen take-out meals that you buy in the BP station.

Yup.  That's right.
Gas station.
With food.
In freezers.

Prices are $8.00 (cheese ravioli) to $16 (REAL veal parm) and each container feeds one big hungry guy or 2 normal people.

LOVE the food - and so surprise to find it.
And so sad to hear they are closing. (They may reopen elsewhere in Media once the dust settles - the BP is turning into a Wawa soon.)

Tried the Chicken Parm, Shrimp Scampi, Veal Parm and Cheese Ravioli.
It's just like the rest of them -HUGE and well stocked with all the things you need for bath, bedroom and kitchen.

Back again and lovin' it!
Got a case of Blackberry Hint Water (10% of a case of anything), some $18 maple syrup, a pair of duck legs and tons of boutique yuppified frozen meals. Plus crispy-fresh bean sprouts, mini bell peppers and a $2.17 single humongous mandarin orange called a Sumo.  Lady at check out was a doll - Kenishon??  I know I got that wrong.

I'm stocked up!

La Prima catered a conference I attended held at the PECO Building in Center City Philadelphia.
The theme of the conference was "Green Technology" so the caterer had to also be "green" - and La Prima is.

They use compostable plates, cutlery, paper goods etc and use foods from local CSAs and farms.

Meanwhile - how was the food?
It was Good to Great!  Pasta was served hot (not lukewarm) and chicken was delcious and not dried out.  (Food was a buffet in chafing dishes which can be hit or miss).

Servers were friendly and helpful.

Very well run catering with tasty food that is locally (when possible) produced and prepared well.

Yay!

This is a nice outpost for Teuscher - there is another (tiny) shop at 16 & Walnut.

Teuscher has a good assortment of filled dark & milk chocolates. The truffles at Leonidas are somehow better - in my opinion. And for packaging and presentation - I'm all about Neuhaus. 

But for top-quality chocolates, Teuscher is a safe bet for corporate or special occasion gift giving.  The flower boxes are beautiful - but very pricey.

I will be writing another - more detailed - update once I get my facial and my (groupon) massage - but for now I must give credit to Nikki for her excellent customer service (at least to me - she's always been great) and also to Christy (Christine??) who did my ($75) spa pedicure.

The pedicure itself was excellent.  CND and OPI products, included an exfolliating scrub, a massage and a wrap with a chocolate/peppermint clay masque.  Pollish application was very good as well - so far no chipping (it's only been 2 days though.).

What made it less-than-five star was the (gorgeous but) uncomfortable banquette that you sit on.  There are 6 pedi stations and they are just BEAUTIFUL to look at - but after a while my lower back pain started kicking in.  They do provide bolsters - but they were too wide for me.  It's a shame because you can tell alot of time and money went into the design of this spa and the nail area.  It is elegant, spotless and lovely.  But not very comfy.

Meanwile - I can't wait to return and  get another pedi from Christine (Christy??).

And I have a wondeful facial to look forward to in a few weeks.

This place is improving every time I go.

Had lunch here with Pat D. (what a sweetie she is!  and a great yelper, too.) and it was terrific.  Note:  If you are from Thailand or a true hot & spicy Thai lover you'll likely have to ask them to "kick it up a notch" but for people like me who like "wimpy" Thai - this place is great.

Decor is freshly painted with brand new everything (red wodd chairs) and a big blue sea-scape mural painted on the walls.

Service was quick and quiet - just great.

My 3 course lunch special (if you eat in it's 7.95 - 11.95) included a soup (I got the "ravioli" aka  wonton soup - clear broth and light, yummy wontons -2), appetizer (I got the Tom Sum - Thai salad made with cabbage instead of the usual - and more pricey green papaya), and entree (I had Masaman Curry with Tofu which was coconutty and mild - which I love - and I ate every bit.)

I will DEFINITELY be back.

YAY for close-by Thai!!!

Well, at long last, I can scratch Le Bec Fin off my to-do list.  Finally, I was able to justify the expense...  My husband & I celebrated his birthday by attending Chef Georges Perrier's Chef's table last night.

The main dining room is amazingly gorgeous.  What a place for a wedding or party!  We were seated in a slightly less glam area at the front of the house at a long table for 20.  (17 in all)

Perrier is running a special all summer Mon. - Thurs.  (20 seats per night) a "pay what you wish" 5 course set menu.  If you can, ACT FAST and get in on it before August is over.

The first course was the chilled pea soup from the regular menu.  Very good - but no way I would have ordered this in real life.  It was pluched with a dollop of almond ice cream which was heavenly.  (Made up for the fact that it's pea soup.)

2nd course was a single seared scallop.  DH & I are not scallop lovers - in fact, DH won't touch 'em so he had a salade ennui (boring salad) in its place.  I forced myself to eat the scalop and it was, indeed, perfectly cooked and surprisingly good (for a scallop fan I bet they'd LOVE it.).

3rd course was a slightly overcooked white fish called Limon (like a fluke or flounder).  I was looking so forward to this course and it was sauced with a lemon foam and plated over a few fava beans (yummy), chanterelles (a bit salty to my taste) and a tasteless hazlenut puree - the consistency and color of putty.

4th course was the best (save for dessert which was REALLY the best.) - a rare hanger steak.  3 -4 morsels in a decadent bordelaise (or was it a red wine/demi glace reduction?).  The sauce was lick-the-plate worthy.

And for dessert one of the BEST classic creme brulee.  Lightly laced with Gran Marnier and a crispy top.

Service was very attentive UNTIL the end when we needed our check.  At about 9:45 PM nearly everyone (there were several waitstaff) disappeared.

The Chef came out to our table prior to and during service and was collegial and utterly charming.  (Really.)  It helped that I speak un peu de francais and was seating next to a lovely, fluent, Belgian woman.  (Merci, Madame!)

Will I return?  Oh yes - but not in a hurry.  I would simply like to sit in the bar downstairs and have desserts off that AMAZING dessert cart (not part of our meal, alas).  That opera cake has my name on it!

Bien Fait!

Oh - and don't laugh but I actually drank (again don't laugh) a Mojito with my meal (I know, I know - in a French restaurant) and it was GREAT.  And it was $10.  My husbands manhattan was $12.  They do not serve Veuve Cliquot - which was what I was jonesin' for.

The best sushi I have found in this area - and so far I have only been there once for lunch - but man, it was good.  I tried the sushi "pizza" (sauces on the side - wasabi mayo & spicy mayo) based on a fresh-cooked scallion pancake.  Soooo tasty!

Plus this is a JAPANESE restaurant (Japanese/American) not Asian-Fusion - which I appreciate.  Heck, they even had Kampachi as a special.  Yee-Haw! And they DELIVER!  Wow.

Can't wait to return.

Ulta is kinda like Sephora meets Duane Reade.
Beauty supplies galore (at full retail), includingnails, hair and skincare.

Took my 10 year old here at her request for dinner.  (We ended up getting take out as it was nearly 9 PM)  Wonderful, friendly service - and now they greet me by name.

El kiddo loves the Doner platter and I got Koobideh this time.
Plenty of leftovers for lunch the next day.

Super-fresh pita.
I am now hooked!

Oh, my!!!
A cigar bar in Media?  Yes!  And a brand-new and nicely appointed one at that - complete with $70 lighters and $50 cutters and (of course) a great selection of fine (and moderate) cigars.

Best of all?  The bartenders are terrific - especially Melissa - who mixes a great cocktail with high-end tequilas (or vodka - they have a blood orange one).  

Food selections are limited but the cheese plate sounds great.
I will be back - and next time I am eating!!!

What an addition to the State Street scene!

The Manhattan Bagel in the Chesterbrook Shopping Center is my go-to these days for coffee on my way to my new job.  Service is quick and friendly and they all know my boss there - she is there every morning.

There are usually 5 pre-brewed selections - Decaf, House Blend, Hazelnut and 2 others (today is was Dark Roast and Pumpkin Spice).

Bagels are good too - but I need to lay off of those for a while.
This is a much cleaner location than the one in Center City.

Ya for Siren - it saved our asses in Jr. High and High school for sure.  It was a hang out and a place of employment for some of my friends.  Great selection of music and they can order you anything you'd ever want.

Back in the day Rice's was the shizzle!  We went almost every Tuesday in the Summer at the CRACK of dawn to score cheap socks, tee-shirts, back to school gear and fresh produce - simultaneously.

The place is HUMUNGOUS - but many of the vendors are lifers who are there week after week, year after year.

It's great fun for a bargain (but buyer beware, of course) antique (junk) shopping or just browsing around.  Great place to bring kids, too.

I had not been back here in years once I discovered Vic's and other places.
A good friend really wanted to come here for lunch and we both split an order of 8 steamed frozen) gyoza (They offer chicken, pork, veggie, shrimp or beef - wow!) and we each got the $8.95 lunch special.

It includes miso soup (good - but tastes like a kikkoman restaurant-mix) and your choice of 4 half-makis (4 pieces).  I got spicy yellowtail (OK), yellowtail scallion (very good), albacore cucumber (real Albacore - not Escolar - yay extra star for that), and Tempura Salmon.

Very inexpensive for lunch and quite filling due to all the rice.

The owner/manager from years ago seemed to remember me, too - which was nice but also made me feel bad that I had not been coming for a long time.

So my faith has been restored in Mizu - and although Vic is still better quality sushi, it is much more pleasant to dine here - at a table and not elbow to elbow with the other 7 seats at Vic.

I'll be back - and sooner than I had planned.

So Steven Starr kinda-sorta redid the bar at the back of the old Midtown 2 Diner and now it's the "Ranstead Room" - a pricey , dimly-lit speakeasy with fresh ingredients and $12 drinks.

Think Candied Ginger and Granny Smith Apples.

Fun.

Still got the old tufted red booths - just polished up a bit with the cracks repaired.

Grab dinner at El Rey and then walk ALL THE WAY AROUND (Darn it, just open the door!) to Ranstead.

Oh - and they don't even open until 7 PM - so NO happy hour here.

I grew up going to PVP alot - I even was "baptized" into my brownie troop - or brownie-ized or whatever that little ceremony they have is called, back when I was in 2nd grade.

We rode bikes here, and fished for sunnies, and have oodles of picnics and BBQs here in the summertime.

Lots of fond memories of Peace Valley Park and Lake Galena.

What a fun boutique with cute clothes, sparkly accessories and even BLISS spa products.  The owner and his daughter who works there are helpful and not pushy.

I'll be back for sure!

OK - again I vacillate between 4 & 5 stars.

Decor and Service were top-notch.
Cocktails are delicious - albeit pricey - with freshly "crafted" ingredents like smoked cinnamon and house-made bitters.

For "healthy" food - many of the dishes were oily or had fried components or incorporated bread.  The cauliflower was fried and oily.  Potatoes and root veggies?  Fried.

The best bite of the night?  Parsnip spread - on white toast (odd that so many things are served on bread??

Come here in the summer for fresher better choices.  Winter veggie fans, rejoice - you can get parsnips, turnips, potatoes, radishes and a plethora of beet varieties.

I wish I could remember our french female servers name - she was patient and kind.
The "bus folks" were workin' it, too!

Love it here.

This is for the Halal Cart with Green & Yellow Signage parked on the corner of 20 & Market (South East - not the Falafel Man on the NE Corner).

$5 got me a huge rice platter with 1/2 chicken cubes and 1/2 gyro (salty but not horribly so) meat cubes, iceberg "salad" with 2 slivers of tomato and a pile of rice.  "White" or "Hot" sauce (or both).

INCLUDED a soda or water - not bad for $5!

I have had good luck with Nikes at this location (near the Walmart & PetSmart in Springfield).
No issues so far - prices are on par with Famous Footwear and higher prices than crappy payless (I hate that store!).

I tend to come to chain stores for my kids shoes (my kid wears ladies sizes).
This DSW location is just fine for now.

Pate's and porc-loving products which i discovered at the Rittenhouse Square Farmers market on Saturday AMs - but their main place is in RTM.

Pricey - but delicious.
If you don;t eat pork - try the lamb pate.  DIVINE!

Oh - and they sell pre-cooked/pre-seasoned carnitas.  Neat-o!

Much less chaotic than the one on Chestnut Street - I guess it depends on when you go (lunch time and the holidays are mobbed just about anywhere.)

Yesterday I popped in around 6:45 (they close at 7) toget my "free cotton panty".

When I got to the registers there was a HUGE line - about 8 people and 1 cashier.

Straight away - 2 more ladies jumped onto the registeres and saved the day.  I swear, you'd think they were giving it away!  (Oh wait, they are...)

Anyhow VS must HATE me because I am a coupon minimalist - I only buy the item covered by the coupon and nothing else.  I took my 1 free panty and left.

I had to chuckle at the 2 ladies in front of me who were busily sorting through their stack of cards and coupons.

We're all they same - just looking for some free panties and cheap bras.

We had a delightful lunch for 5 that far surpassed my expectations for in-mall Chinese.  Edamame and Gyoza apps were tasty.  Lunch entrees were reasonably priced and perfectly sized.  Some of the best (basic) Chicken and brocolli - tender white meat and not gloppy.  Outstanding shrimp lo mein with thinner than usual noodles - not overloaded with onion.  NOT GREASY.  A pleasure.

Rainbow shrimp was great, too- and not skimpy on the shrimpy.
Friendly, efficient service and lovely decor.

Full bar and sushi (did not try it yet.).

We can't wait to return.
